JOHN LEO his first book of the description of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein why this part of the world be name Africa Africa be call in the arabian tongue (@) of the word Faraca which signify in the say language to divide but why it shall be so call there be two opinion the first be this namely because this part of the world be divide from Europa by the Mediterran sea and from Asia * * * * * * * * * * * other divide it from Asia by the red sea by the river of Nilus other be of opinion that this name Africa be derive from one Ifricus the king of Arabia foelix who be say to have be the first that ever inhabit these part this Ifricus wage war against the king of Aslyria and be at length by he drive out of his kingdom pass with his whole army over Nilus and so conduct his troop westward make no delay till he be come unto the region lie about Carthage hence it be that the arabian do imagine the country about Carthage only and the region lie westward thereof to comprehend all Africa the border of Africa Africa if we may give credit unto the writer of that nation be man of learning and most skilful cosmographer begin southward at certain river issue forth of a lake in the desert of Gaoga eastward it border upon the river Nilus it extend northward to that part of Egypt where Nilus at seven mouth discharge his stream into the Mediterran sea from whence it stretch westward as far as the streite of Gibraltar and be bound on that part with the utmost sea-town of all Libya call * * * non. nun. likewise the south part thereof abut upon the ocean sea which compass Africa almost as far as the desert of Gaoga the (@) of Africa our author affirm that Africa be (@) into four part that be to say Barbaria Numidia Libya and the land of Negro Barbaria take beginning from the hill call meies which be the extreme part of all the mountain of Atlas be distant from Alexandria almost three hundred mile it be bound on the north side with the Mediterran sea stretch thence to mount-meies aforesaid and from mount-meies extend itself to the streite of Gibraltar westward it be limit with the say streite from whence wind itself out of the Mediterran sea into the main ocean it be enclose with the most westerly point of Atlas namely at that western cape which be next unto the town call messa and southward it be bound with that side of Atlas which lie towards the Mediterran sea this be the most noble and worthy region of all Africa the inhabitant whereof be of a brown or tawny colour be a civil people and prescribe wholesome law and constitution unto themselves the second part of Africa be call of the latin Numidia but of the arabian Biledulgerid this region bring forth date in great abundance it begin eastward at the city of which be a hundred mile distant from Egypt and extend west as far as the town of * * * (@) nun stand upon the ocean sea northward it be enclose with the south side of Atlas and the south part thereof border upon the sandy desert of Libya all the arabian do usual call it the land of date because this only region of Africa bear date the three part call of the latin Libya and of the arabian sarra which word signify a desert begin eastward at that part of Nilus which be next unto the city of and from thence run westward as far as the ocean sea northward it be bound with Numidia southward it abut upon the land of negro eastward it take beginning at the kingdom of Gaoga and stretch westward even to the land of Gualata which border upon the ocean sea the four part of Africa which be call the land of negro begin eastward at the kingdom of Gaoga from whence it extend west as far as Gualata the north part thereof be enclose with the desert of Libya and the south part which be unknown unto we with the ocean sea howbeit the merchant which daily come from thence to the kingdom of Tombuto have sufficient describe the situation of that country unto we this land of Negro have a mighty river which take his the (@) of Niger name of the region be call Niger this river take his original from the east out of a certain desert call by the foresay negro seu. other will have this river to spring out of a certain lake and so to run westward till it exonerate itself into the ocean sea our cosmographer affirm that the say river of Niger be derive out of Nilus which they imagine for some certain space to be swallow up of the earth and yet at last to burst forth into such a lake as be before mention some other be of opinion that this river begin westward to spring out of a certain mountain and so run east to make at length a huge lake which very be not like to be true for they usual sail westward from Tombuto to the kingdom of Ginea yea and to the land of also both which in respect of Tombuto be situate to the west neither have the say land of negro any kingdom comparable for beautiful and pleasant soil unto those which adjoin unto the bank of Niger and here it be to be note that according to the opinion of our cosmographer * * * Aethiopia that land of negro by which Nilus be say to run namely that part of the world which stretch eastward even to the indian sea some northerly parcel whereof abut upon the red sea to wit the country which lie without the gulf of Arabia be not to be call any member or portion of Africa and that for many reason which be to be find in the process of this history set down more at large the say country be call by the latin Aethiopia from thence come certain religious friar sear or brand on the face with a hot iron who be to be see almost over all Europe and special at Rome these people have a emperor which they call Prete Gianni the great part of that land be inhabit with christian howbeit there be also a certain mahometan among they which be say to possess a great dominion a division of the four forename part of Africa BArbarie be distinguish into four kingdom the first whereof be the kingdom of Maroco which be likewise divide into seven region or province namely Hea Sus Guzula the territory of Maroco Duccala and tedle the second kingdom of Barbary call Fez comprehendeth in like sort seven region within the bound thereof to wit Temesne the territory of Fez Azgara * * * Errif garet and * * * Elcauz the three kingdom be call * * * tremizen Telensin and have three region under it namely the mountain tenez and Algezer the four kingdom of Barbary be name Tunis under which be comprise four region that be to say Bugia Constantina Tripoli in Barbary and Ezzaba which be a good part of Numidia Bugia have always be turmoil with continual war because sometime it be subject unto the king of Tunis and sometime again unto the king of tremizen certain it be that even until these our day this Bugia be a kingdom of itself and so continue till the principal city of that region be at the commandment of Ferdinando the king of Castille take by one Peter of Navarre the division of Numidia this be the base part of all Africa neither will our cosmographer vouchsafe it the name of a kingdom by reason that the inhabitant thereof be so far distant asunder which you may easy conjecture by that which follow a city of Numidia contain about four hundred family and be in regard of the libyan desert sever from all place of habitation almost three hundred mile wherefore this second part be think by diverse not to be worthy the name of a kingdom howbeit we will make some relation of the habitable part of Numidia some whereof may not unfit be compare with other region of Africa as for example that of Segelmess which territory of Numidia lie over against Barbary likewise zeb which be situate against Bugia and the signiory of Biledulgerid which extend unto the kingdom of Tunis reserve therefore many particular for the second part of this history we will make our entry and beginning at those place which lie upon the west of Numidia the name whereof be these Guaden Ifren Hacca dare Tebelbelt Todga Fercale Segelmess Benigumi Fighig Tegua Tegorarin Mesab Tegort and Guarghela the region of zeb contain five town to wit Pescara Elborgh nesta Taolac and deusin so many city likewise have the territory of Biledulgerid namely Teozar Caphesa Nefreoa elchamid and Chalbis and from hence eastward be find the isle of gerbe Garion Mesellata Mestrata Teoirraga Gademis Fizza Augela Birdeoa and eloacat these be the name of the most famous place of all Numidia be bound as be say before westward upon the ocean sea and eastward with the river of Nilus a description of the libyan desert which lie between Numidia and the (@) of Negro these desert have not as yet any certain name among we (@) they be divide into five part and receive all their denomination from the inhabitant which dwell upon they that be to say from the numidian who be in like sort themselves divide into five part also to wit the people or tribe call Zanega Ganziga Leuta and Berdeoa there be likewise certain place which take some proper and particular name from the goodness and badness of the soil as namely the desert of Azaohad so call for the drought and unfruitfulness of that place likewise hair albeit a desert yet so call for the goodness and temperature of the air a division of the land of negro into several kingdom moreover the land of Negro be divide into many kingdom whereof albeit a great part be unknown unto we and remove far out of our trade we will notwithstanding make relation of those place where we ourselves have abode and which by long experience be grow very familiar unto we as likewise of some other place from whence merchant use to travel unto the same city wherein myself be then resident from who I learn right (@) the state of their country I * * * * * * * * * * * * John (@) over (@) (@) of the (@) of Negro myself see fifteen kingdom of the negro howbeit there be many more which although I see not with my own eye yet be they by the negro sufficient know and frequent their name therefore beginning from the west and so proceed eastward and southward be these follow Gualata Ghinea Tombuto Gago Guber Agadez canon Casena Zegzeg Zanfara Guangara Burno Gaoga these fifteen kingdom be for the most part situate upon the river Niger through the which merchant usual travel from Gualata to the city of * * * cairo alcair in Egypt the journey indeed be very long but yet secure and void of danger all the say kingdom adjoin one upon another ten whereof be separate either by the river Niger or by some sandy desert and in time past each one of the fifteen have a several king but now * * * * * * about the year 1526. at this present they be all in a manner subject unto three king only namely to the king of Tombuto who be lord of the great part to the king of Borno who govern the least part and the residue be in subjection unto the king of Gaoga howbeit he that possess the kingdom of Ducala have a very small train attend upon he likewise these kingdom have many other kingdom border upon the south frontier of they to wit Bito Dauma Medra and Gorhan the governor and inhabitant whereof be most rich and industrious people great lover of justice and equity albeit some lead a brutish kind of life of the habitation of Africa and of the signification of this word Barbar our cosmographer and historiographer affirm that in time past Africa be altogether disinhabit except that part which be now call the land of negro and most certain it be that Barbary and Numidia be for many age destitute of inhabitant the tawny people of the say region be call by the name of barber be derive of the verb Barbara which in their tongue signify to murmur because the african tongue sound in the ear of the arabian no otherwise than the voice of beast which utter their sound without any accent other will have barber to be one word twice repeat forsomuch as bar in the arabian tongue signify a desert for say they when king Iphricus be by the assyrian or aethiopian drive out of his own kingdom travel towards Egypt and see himself so oppress with his enemy that he know not what shall become of he and his follower he ask his people how or which way it be possible to escape who answer he barber that be to the desert to the desert give he to understand by this speech that he can have no safe refuge then to cross over Nilus and to flee unto the desert of Africa and this reason seem to agree with they which affirm the african to be descend from the people of Arabia the original of the people of Africa about the original of the african our historiographer do much disagree for some will have they to be derive from the inhabitant of palaestina because as they say be expel out of their own country by the assyrian they come at length into Africa and see the fruitfulness of the soil choose it to be their place of habitation other be of opinion that they take their original from the sabean a people of Arabia and that before such time as they be put to flight by the assyrian or aethiopian as have be aforesaid some other report that the african descend from certain people of * * * * * Asia who be chase thence by reason of war which be wage against they flee into Greece which at the same time have no inhabitant at all howbeit the enemy still pursue they they be force to cross the sea of Morea and be arrive in Africa to settle themselves there but their enemy abode still in Greece all which opinion and report be to be understand only of the original of the tawny people that be to say of the numidian and barbarian for all the negro or black moor take their descent from Chus the son of cham who be the son of Noe but whatsoever difference there be between the negro and the tawny moor certain it be that they have all one beginning for the negro be descend of the Philistine and the Philistine of Mesraim the * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * Genesis the 10. v the 6. Mezraim be account the (@) of Chus son of Chus but the tawny moor fetch their pedigree from the sabean and it be evident that Saba be beget of * * * * * gen. 10. 7. which be the elder son of Chus diverse other opinion there be as touch this matter which because they seem not so necessary we have purposely omit a division of the tawny moor into sundry tribe or nation the tawny moor be divide into five several people or tribe to wit the tribe call zanhagi Musmudi Zeneti Hacari and Gumeri the tribe of Musmudi inhabit the western part of mount Atlas from the province of Hea to the river of * * * guadalhabit seruan likewise they dwell upon the south part of the say mountain and upon all the inward plain of that region these have four province under they namely Hea Sus Guzula and the territory of Morocco the tribe of Gumeri possess certain mountain of Barbary dwell on the side of those mountain which lie over against the Mediterran sea as likewise they be lord of all the river call in their language rif. this river tremizen call by the ancient cosmographer Caesaria or Mauritania caesariensis have his fountain near unto the streite of Gibraltar and thence run eastward to the kingdom of tremizen call by the latin Caesaria these two tribe or people have several habitation by themselves the other three be disperse confusive over all Africa howbeit they be like stranger discern one from another by certain property or token maintain continual war among themselves especial they of Numidia these I say be those very people as some report who have no other place than tent and wide field to repose themselves in and it be report that in time past they have great conflict together and that the vanquish be send to inhabit town and city but the conqueror hold the champion and field unto themselves and there settle their abode neither be it altogether unlikely because the inhabitant of city have all one and the same language with the country people for the zeneti whether they dwell in the city or in the country speak all one kind of language which be likewise to be understand of the rest the tribe of Zeneti Haoari and Sanhagi inhabit the country of Temesne sometime they live peaceable and sometime again call to mind their ancient quarrel they break forth into cruel war and manslaughter some of these people bear rule over all Africa as namely the zeneti who in time past vanquish the family call idris from which some affirm the true and natural duke of Fez and the founder of the same city to derive their pedigree their progeny likewise be call Mecnasa there come afterward out of Numidia another family of the zeneti call Magraoa this Magraoa chase the family of Mecnasa with all their duke and chieftain out of their dominion not long after the say tribe of Magraoa be expel in like sort by certain other of the race of the call by the name of Luntuna which come also out of the desert of Numidia by this family be the country of Temesna in process of time utter spoil and waste and all the inhabitant thereof slay except those which be of their own tribe and kindred of Luntuna unto who be allot the region of Ducala to inhabit and by they be build the city common call Maroco it fall out afterward by the who be the founder of Maroco inconstancy of fortune that one Elmahdi the principal (@) preacher among they conspire with the these be of the family of Musmuda expel the whole race of the and usurp that kingdom unto himself after this man decease succeed in his place one of his disciple call habdul Mumen a Banigueriaghel of the kindred of the the kingdom remain unto this family about a 120. year whereunto all Africa in a manner be subject at length be depose by the Banimarini a generation of the zeneti the say family be put to flight which Banimarini be say to have reign afterward for the space of 170. year the Banimarini which descend of the and of Magroa wage continual war against banizeijan the king of Telensin likewise the progeny of Hafasa and of Musmuda be at variance and dissension with the king of Tunis so that you see what stir and tumult have at all time be occasion in those region by the foresay five family certain it be that neither the nor the Haoari have at this present any jurisdiction at all albeit heretofore as we read in their chronicle they have some certain dominion before such time as they be infect with the mahometan law out of all which it be evident that in time past all the foresay people have their habitation and tent in the plain field every one of which favour their own faction and exercise all labour necessary for man life as common among they the governor of the country attend their drove and flock and the citizen apply themselves unto some manual art or to husbandry the say people be divide into five hundred several family as appear by the genealogy of the african author whereof be one Rachu who I have oftentimes read and peruse some writer be of opinion that the king of Tombuto the king of and the king of Agadez fetch their original from the people of Zanaga to wit from they which inhabit the desert the agreement or variety of the african language the foresay five family or people (@) divide into hundred of progeny and have innumerable habitation do notwithstanding use all one kind of language call by they Aquel Amarig that be the noble tongue the arabian Aquel Amarig which inhabit Africa call it a barbarous tongue and this be the true and natural language of the african howbeit it be altogether different from other language although it have diverse word common with the arabian tongue whereupon some will infer that the african as be above say come by lineal descent from the sabean a people of Arabia other say that these word be even then invent when the arabian come first into Africa and begin to take possession thereof but these author be so rude and grossewitted that they leave no write behind they which may be allege either for or against moreover they have among they another diversity not only of (@) but of significant word also as namely they which dwell near unto the arabian and exercise much traffic with they do for the great part use their language yea all the in a manner and most of the Haoari speak Arabian though corrupt which I suppose come first hereupon to pass for that the say people have have long acquaintance and conversation with the arabian the negro have diverse language among themselves among which they call one Sungai and the same be current in many region as namely in Gualata Tombuto Ghinea and Gago another language there be among the negro which they call Guber and this be rife among the people of Guber of canon of Casena of Perzegreg and of Guangra likewise the kingdom of Borno have a peculiar kind of speech altogether like unto that which be use in Gaoga and the kingdom of have a language of great affinity with the chaldean arabian and egyptian tongue but all the sea-town of Africa from the Mediterran sea to the mountain of Atlas speak break arabian except the kingdom and town of Maroco and the inland numidian border upon Maroco Fez and tremizen all which use the barbarian tongue howbeit they which dwell over against Tunis and Tripoli speak indeed the arabian language albeit most corrupt of the arabian inhabit the city of Africa of that army which be send by Califa * * * (@) otman the three in the four hundred year of the Hegeira there come into Africa fourscore thousand gentleman and other who have subdue sundry province at length arrive in Africa and there the general of the whole army call * * * (@) Hucha (@) nafich remain this man build that great city which be call of we * * * Cairaoan alcair for he stand in fear of the people of Tunis lest they shall betray he misdoubt also that they will procure aid out of Sicily and so give he the encounter wherefore with all his treasure which he have get he travel to the desert and firm ground distant from * * * Tunis Carthage about one hundred and twenty mile and there be he say to have build the city of * * * (@) alcair the remnant of his soldier he command to keep those place which be most secure and fit for their defence and will they to build where no rock nor fortification be which be do the arabian begin to inhabit Africa and to disperse themselves among the african who because they have be for certain year subject unto the roman or italian use to speak their language and hence it be that the natural and mothertoong of the arabian which have great affinity with the african tongue grow by little and little to be corrupt and so they report that these two nation at length conjoin themselves in one howbeit the arabian usual do blaze their pedigree in daily and trivial song which custom as yet be common both to * * * * * * the moor of Granada we and to the people of Barbary also for no man there be be he never so base which will not to his own name add the name of his nation as for example arabian barbarian or such like of the arabian which dwell in tent the mahometan priest always forbid the arabian to pass over Nilus with their army and tent how be it in the four hundred year of the Hegeira we read that they be permit so to do by a certain factious and schismatical * * * * * a (@) patriarch Califa because one of his noble have rebel against he usurp the city of cairaoan and the great part of Barbary after the death of which rebel that kingdom remain for some year unto his posterity and family who jurisdiction as the african chronicle report grow so large and strong in the time of Elcain the mahometan Califa and patriarch of Arabia that he send unto they one gehoar who of a slave he have make his counsellor gehoar a slave by condition conquer all Barbary Numidia Egypt and Syria with a huge army this gehoar conduct his army westward recover all Numidia and Barbary insomuch that he pierce unto the region of Sus and there claim most ample tribute all which be do he return back unto his Calipha and most faithful surrender unto he whatsoever he have gain from the enemy the Calipha see his prosperous success begin to aspire unto great exploit and gehoar most firm promise that as he have recover that western dominion unto his lord so will he likewise by force of war most certain restore unto he the country of the east to wit Egypt Syria and all Arabia and protest moreover that with the great hazard of his life he will be avenge of all the injury offer by the family of unto his lord predecessor and will revest he in the royal seat of his most famous grandfather great-grandfather and progenitor the Calipha like well his audacious promise cause a army of fower-score thousand soldier with a infinite sum of money and other thing necessary for the war to be deliver unto he and so this valiant and stout chieftain be provide for warfare conduct his troop through the desert of Egypt and Barbary and have first (@) to flight the vice-califa of Egypt who flee unto Eluir the Califa of Bagdet in short time he subdue very easy all the province of Egypt and Syria howbeit he can not as yet hold himself secure fear lest the Califa of Bagdet will assail he with a army out of Asia and lest the garrison which he have leave to keep Barbary shall be constrain to forsake those conquer province wherefore he build (@) and cause it to be wall round about in which city he leave one of his most trusty captain with a great part of the army and this gehoar the first (@) of cairo city he call by the name of alchair which afterward by other be name cairo this alchair be say daily so to have increase that no city of the world for building and inhabitant be any way comparable thereunto now when Gehoar perceive that the Calipha of Bagdet make no preparation for war he forthwith write unto his lord that all the conquer city yield due honour unto he and that all thing be in quiet and tranquillity and therefore that himself if he think good shall come over into Egypt and thereby with his only presence shall prevail more to recover the remnant of his dominion then with never so huge a army for he be in good hope that the Calipha of Bagdet hear of his expedition will leave his kingdom and prelacy and will betake himself to flight this notable and joyful message no soon come to the ear of Califa Elcain but he be by his good fortune much more encourage then before and not forethink himself what mischief may ensue levy a great army appoint for viceroy of all Barbary one of the family of Sanagia aforesaid find he afterward not to be his trusty friend moreover Califa Elcain arrive at alchair and be most honourable entertain by his servant gehoar begin to think upon great affair and have gather a huge army resolve to wage battle against the Califa of Bagdet in the mean season he that be appoint viceroy of Barbary compact with the Calipha of Bagdet yield himself and all Barbary into his hand which the Califa most kind accept and ordain he king over all Africa but Califa Elcain hear this news at alchair be wonderful afflict in mind partly because he see himself repel from his own kingdom and partly for that he have spend all his money which he bring with he insomuch that he know not what in the world to do determine some severe punishment for gehoar by who counsel he leave his kingdom of Arabia howbeit there be one of his secret counsellor a very learned and witty man who see his lord so sad and pensive and be desirous by some good advice to prevent the danger imminent comfort he in this wise your highness know most invincible Califa that fortune be most variable and that the courage of your soldier be no whit daunt by reason of these mishap for i own part as I have heretofore show myself to be your trusty servant so will I at this time give you such profitable counsel whereby you may within short space recover all those dominion which have be so treacherous take from you and may without all peradventure most easy attain unto your own heart desire and this you may do without maintain any army at all yea I assure you if you please to take my advice that I will forthwith procure you such a army as shall give you great store of money and yet notwithstanding shall do you good service also the Califa be somewhat (@) these speech ask his counsellor how this may possible be bring to effect my lord say his counsellor certain it be that the arabian be now grow so populous and to so great a number that all Arabia can contain they scarce will the yearly increase of the ground suffice to feed their drove and you see with what great famine they be afflict and how they be destitute not only of habitation but even of victual and sustenance wherefore if you have heretofore give they leave they will long ere this have invade Africa and if you will now license they so to do doubt you not but that you shall receive of they a huge mass of gold this counsel can not altogether satisfy the Califa his mind for he know right well that the arabian will so waste all Africa as it shall neither be profitable for himself nor for his enemy notwithstanding see that his kingdom be altogether endanger he think it better to accept those sum of money which his counsellor promise and so to be revenge of his enemy then to lose both his kingdom and gold all at once wherefore he permit all arabian which will pay he ducat apiece free to enter Africa conditional that they will show themselves most deadly enemy unto the treacherous king of Barbary which liberty ten tribe of arabian (@) Africa be grant unto they it be report that ten tribe or family of arabian be half the people of Arabia come immediate into Africa unto who certain inhabitant of Arabia join themselves insomuch that there be find among they about fifty thousand person able to bear arm their woman child and cattle be (@) Rachu a (@) (@) almost innumerable the story whereof Ibnu Rachu the most diligent chronicler of african affair who we have before mention set down at large these arabian have traverse the desert between Egypt and Barbary first lay siege unto Tripoli a city of Barbary which be overcome they slay a great part of the citizen the residue escape by flight next of all they encounter the town of cape which be by they take and vanquish at length they besiege cairaoan also howbeit the citizen be sufficient provide of victual be say to have endure the siege for eight month which be expire they be constrain to yield at what time there be nothing in cairaoan but woeful slaughter hideous outcry and present death this land the arabian divide among themselves and begin to people and inhabit the same require in the mean space large tribute of the town and province subject unto they and so they possess all Africa until such time as one joseph the son of jeffin attain to the kingdom of Morocco this joseph be the first king of Morocco who endeavour by all mean to advance the friend and kindred of the late decease king of Africa unto the kingdom neither do he cease until he have expel all the arabian out of Cairaoan howbeit the arabian possess the region thereabouts give themselves whole to spoil and robbery and the friend of the say decease king can bear rule but in certain place only afterwards succeed in the kingdom of Morocco one Mansor who be the four king and prelate of that mahometan sect which be call muachedim this man albeit his grandfather and great grandfather have always favour the posterity and friend of the foresay decease african king and have restore they to their ancient dignity devise altogether how to oppose himself against they and to usurp all their authority wherefore make a feign league with they we read that he provoke the arabian against they and so very easy overcome they afterwards Mansor bring the great part of the arabian into the western dominion of Africa unto the better sort of who he give the habitation of Duccala and Azgara and unto the base remnant he bequeath the possession of Numidia but in process of time he command the numidian slave to be set at liberty and so in despite of the arabian he cause they to inhabit that part of Numidia which he have allot unto they but as for the arabian of Azgara and of certain other place in Barbary he bring they all under his subjection for the arabian out of desert be like fish without water they have indeed often attempt to get into the desert but the mountain of Atlas which be then possess by the barbarian hinder their passage neither have they liberty to pass over the plain for the residue of the barbarian be there plant wherefore their pride be abate they apply themselves unto husbandry have no where to repose themselves but only in village cottage and tent and their misery be so much the great in that they be constrain yearly to disburse unto the king of Morocco most ample tribute those which inhabit Duccala because they be a huge multitude easy free themselves from all tribute and imposition a great part of the arabian remain still at Tunis for that Mansor have refuse to carry they along with he who after the death of the say Mansor grow to be lord of Tunis and so continue till they resign their government unto the people call abu-haf upon condition that they shall pay they half the revenue thereof and this condition have remain firm even until our day howbeit because the arabian be increase to such innumerable swarm that the whole revenue be not sufficient for they the king of Tunis most just allow some of 1526. they their duty to the end they may make secure passage for merchant which indeed they perform without molestation or hurt of any but the residue which be deprive of their pay betake themselves whole to robbery theft slaughter and such other monstrous outrage for these lurk always in the wood no soon see any merchant approach but sudden they break forth deprive he of his good and life also insomuch that now merchant dare not pass that way but with a garrison of safe-conduct and so they pass sometime to their great inconvenience for they be notwithstanding constrain to give unto the foresay arabian which be in pay with the king of Tunis great sum of money and be likewise oftentimes so in danger of robber that they lose both their good and life adivision of the arabian which inhabit Africa and be call by the name of barbarian into diverse progeny or kindred the arabian which inhabit Africa be divide into three part one part whereof be call Cachin the second hilell and the three Machill the Cachin be divide into three nation or tribe to wit the tribe of Etheg Sumait and sahid moreover Etheg be divide into three family that be to say the family of Delleg Elmuntefig and Subair and these be disperse into many region Hilel be derive into four generation to wit the people of Benihemir of Rieh of Sufien and of chusain the family of Benihemir be divide into the lineage of Huroam Hucben and the tribe of Rieh be distribute into the kindred call Deuvad suay asgeg Elcherith Enedri and Garfam which kindred possess many dominion Machil have three tribe under they to wit Mastar hutman and hassan Mastar be divide into Ruchen and Selim hutman into Elhasi and Chinan and hassan into Devihessen Devimansor and Devihubaidulla Devihessen be distinguish into the kindred call Dulein Berbun Vodein racman and Hamram Devimansor into Hemrun Menebbe Husein and Albuhusein and last devihubaidulla into Garag Hedeg Teleb and Geoan all these do in a manner possess innumerable region insomuch that to reckon they up at large be a matter not only difficult but almost impossible of the habitation and number of the foresay arabian the most noble and famous arabian be they of the family of Etheg unto who Almansor give the region of Duccala and of tedle to inhabit these arabian even till our time have be put to great distress and hazard partly by the Portugal king and partly by the king of Fez. they have at all opportunity if need shall require a hundred thousand soldier fit to bear arm a great part whereof be horseman the arabian call sumait enjoy that part of the libyan desert which lie over against the desert of Tripoli these make often invasion into Barbary for they have no place allot they therein but they and their camel do perpetual remain in the desert they be able to levy fourscore thousand soldier the great part be footman likewise the tribe of Sahid do inhabit the desert of Libya and these have have always great league and familiarity with the king of Guargala they have such abundance of cattle that they do plentiful supply all the city of that region with flesh and that especial in summer time for all the winter they stir not out of the desert their number be increase to about a hundred and fifty thousand have not many horseman among they the tribe of Delleg possess diverse habitation howbeit * * * (@) Caesaria contain the great part of they some also inhabit upon the frontier of the kingdom of Bugia who be say to receive a yearly stipend from their next neighbour but the least part of they dwell upon the field-countrey of acde upon the border of Mauritania and upon some part of mount Atlas be subject unto the king of Fez. the people of Elmuntefig be seat in the province of azgar and be call by the late writer Elcaluth these also pay certain yearly tribute unto the king of Fez be able to furnish about eight thousand horseman to the war the kindred of Sobair do inhabit not far from the kingdom of gezeir be many of they under the pay of the king of tremizen and be say to enjoy a great part of Numidia they have more or less three thousand most warlike horseman they possess likewise great abundance of camel for which cause they abide all winter in the desert the remnant of they occupy the plain which lie between Sala and Mecnes these have huge drove of cattle and exercise themselves in husbandry be constrain to pay some yearly tribute unto the king of Fez. they have horseman who as a man may say be natural frame to the war about four thousand in number of the people of hillel and of their habitation HIllel which be also call Benihamir dwell upon the frontier of the kingdom of tremizen and oran these range up and down the desert of Tegorarin be in pay under the king of tremizen and of great riches and power insomuch that they have at all time in a readiness for the (@) six thousand horseman the tribe of Hurua possess only the border of these be savage people give themselves whole to spoil and robbery and alienate their mind from the war they never come forth of the desert for the people of Barbary will neither allow they any place of habitation nor yet any stipend at all horseman they have to the number of two thousand the kindred of Hucban be next neighbour unto the region of Melian who receive certain pay from the king of Tunis they be rude and wild people and in very deed estrange from all humanity they have as it be report about fifteen hundred horseman the tribe of Habru inhabit the region lie between oran and these exercise husbandry pay yearly tribute unto the king of tremizen and be scarce able to make one hundred horseman the people call Mussim possess those desert of Masila which extend unto the kingdom of Bugia these likewise be give only to theft and robbery they take tribute both of their own people and of other region adjoin unto they the tribe of Rieeh inhabit those desert of Libya which border upon Constantina these have most ample dominion in Numidia be now divide into six part this right famous and warlike nation receive stipend from the king of Tunis have five thousand horseman at command the people of suay enjoy that desert which be extend unto the signiory of tenez these have very large possession receive stipend from the king of tremizen be man of notable dexterity as well in the war as in all other conversation of life the kindred of Azgeg dwell not all together in one place for part of they inhabit the region of garet among the people call Hemram and the residue poslesse that part of Duccala which lie near unto Azaphi the tribe of Elcherit dwell upon that portion of Helin which be situate in the plain of Sahidim have the people of Heah tributary unto they and be a very uncivil and barbarous people the people call Enedri be seat in the plain of Heah but the whole region of Heah maintain almost four thousand horseman which notwithstanding be unfit for the war the people of Garfa have sundry mansion neither have they any king or governor they be disperse among other generation and especial among the kindred of manebbi and Hemram these convey date from Segelmessa to the kingdom of Fez and carry back again from thence such thing as be necessary for Segelmess of the tribe of Machil the people call ruche who be think to be descend from Mastar do possess that desert which lie next unto deed and Farcala they have very small dominion for which cause they be account no whit rich howbeit they be most valiant soldier and exceed swift of foot insomuch that they esteem it a great disgrace if one of their footman be vanquish by two horseman and you shall find scarce any one man among they which will not outgo a very swift horse be the journey never so long they have about five hundred horseman but most warlike footman to the number of eight thousand Selim inhabit upon the river of dara from whence they range up and down the desert they be endow with great riches carry every year merchandise unto the kingdom of Tombuto and be think to be in high favour with the king himself traffic to Tombuto a large jurisdiction they have in Darha and great plenty of camel and for all opportunity of war they have ever in a readiness three thousand horseman the tribe of Elhasis dwell upon the sea-coast near unto messa they do arm about five hundred horseman and be a nation altogether rude and unacquainted in the war some part of they inhabit Azgara those which dwell about messa be free from the yoke of superiority but the other which remain in Azgar be subject to the king of Fez. the kindred of Chinan be disperse among they which before be call Elcaluth and these also be subject unto the king of Fez. very warlike people they be and be able to set forth two thousand horseman the people of Devihessen be divide into the kindred of Duleim Burbun Vode Devimansor and Devihubaidulla Duleim be conversant in the desert of Libya with the african people call Zanhaga they have neither dominion nor yet any stipend wherefore they be very poor and give to robbery they travel unto dara and exchange cattle for date with the inhabitant there all bravery and comeliness of apparel they utter neglect and their number of fight ten thousand four thousand be horseman and the residue footman the people call Burbun possess that part of the libyan desert which adjoin unto sus. they be a huge multitude neither have they any riches beside camel unto they be subject the city of tesset which scarce suffice they for the maintenance of their horse be but a few the people of Vode enjoy that desert which be situate between guaden and Gualata they bear rule over the guadenite and of the duke of Gualata they receive yearly tribute and their number be grow almost infinite for by report they be of ability to bring into the field almost threescore thousand most skilful soldier notwithstanding they have great want of horse the tribe of racman occupy that desert which be next unto Hacha they have very large possession and do in the spring-time usual travel unto tesset for then always they have somewhat to do with the inhabitant there their people fit for arm be to the number of twelve thousand albeit they have very few horseman the nation of hamrum inhabit the desert of tagavost exact some tribute of the inhabitant there and with daily incursion likewise molest the people of nun. their number of soldier be almost eight thousand the people descend of Devimansor the generation of dehemrum which be say to derive their pedigree from Devimansor inhabit the desert over against Segellmess who continual wander by the libyan desert as far as ighid they have tributary unto they the people of segelmesse of Todgatan of tebelbelt and of dara their soil yield such abundance of date that the yearly increase thereof be sufficient to maintain they although they have nothing else to live on they be of great fame in other nation be able to furnish for the war about three thousand horseman there dwell likewise among these certain other arabian of more base condition call in their language Garfa esgeh which notwithstanding have great abundance of horse and of all other cattle a certain part also of the people Hemrun obtain many and large possession among the (@) from whence they have a notable yearly revenue bring they in this part of Hemrun make often excursion towards the desert of Fighig in summer they disperse themselves all over the province of garet possess the east part of Mauritania they be noble and honest person and endue with all kind of humanity and civility insomuch that all the king of Fez in a manner do usual choose they wife out of the same tribe needs therefore must there be great friendship and familiarity among they the people of menebbe do almost inhabit the very same desert have two province of Numidia under they to wit Matgara and retebbe these also be a most valiant nation be in pay under the province of Segelmess and be able to make about two thousand horseman the kindred of Husein which be think to be descend of Devimansor be seat upon the mountain of Atlas they have in the say mountain a large jurisdiction namely diverse castle every where and many most rich and flourish city all which they think be give they in old time by the viceroys of the marini for so soon as they have win that kingdom the kindred of Husein afford they great aid and service their dominion be now subject unto the king of Fez and of Segelmess they have a captain which for the most part reside at the city common call Garseluin likewise they be always in a manner traverse of that desert which in their language be call Eddara they be take to be a most rich and honest people be of ability to furnish for the war about six thousand horseman among these you shall oftentimes find many arabian of another sort who they use only to be their servant the tribe of Abulhusein do inhabit part of the foresay desert of Eddara howbeit a very small part the great number of who be bring unto such extreme misery that they have not in those their wild tent sufficient sustenance to live upon true it be that they have build they certain habitation upon the libyan desert but yet they be cruel pinch with famine and with extreme penury of all thing and that there may be no end of their misery they be constrain to pay yearly tribute unto their kindred and parent the offspring of Devihubaidulla one generation of the people of Devihubaidulla be those which be name Gharrag these enjoy the desert of Benigomi and Fighig have very large possession in Numidia they be stipendary unto the king of tremizen who diligent endeavour to bring they to peace and tranquillity of life for they be whole give to theft and robbery in summer time they usual repair unto tremizen where they be think for that season of the year to settle their abode their horseman be to the number of four thousand all which be most noble warrior the kindred of Hedeg possess a certain desert near unto tremizen call in their own language Hangad these have no stipend from any prince nor yet any jurisdiction at all rapine and stealth be only delightful unto they they provide only for their family and themselves and be able to set forth about five hundred horseman the tribe of Theleb inhabit the plain of * * * alger Algezer these have often vagary over the desert unto the province of tedgear unto they be subject in time past the most famous city of Algezer and tedelle howbeit in these our day they be recover again from they by Barbarossa the Turk which loss can not but great grieve and molest their king it be report moreover that at the same time the principal of the say people of Theleb be cut off for strength and cunning in chivalry they be inferior to no other nation their norseman be about three thousand the tribe of Gehoan inhabit not all in one place for part of they you may find among the people of Guarag and the residue among the people of Hedeg and they be unto they no otherwise then their servant which condition they notwithstanding most patient and willing submit themselves unto and here one thing be to be note by the way to wit that the two forename people call * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * the arabian call (@) and (@) descend from Ishmael the base son of Abraham Schachin and Hilel be original arabian of Arabia and think themselves to be descend from Ishmael the son of Abraham and those which we call Machil come first forth of Arabia and derive their pedigree from Saba before who the mahometan prefer the former which of Ishmael be call ismaelite and because the arabian call (@) descend of Saba there have always be great controverfie among they which part shall be of great nobility they have write on both side many dialogue and epigram whereby each man be wont to blaze the renown the virtuous manner and laudable custom of his own nation the ancient arabian which be before the time of the ismaelite be call by the african historiographer arabi-araba as if a man shall say arabian of Arabia but those which come of Ishmael they call Arabi mus-araba as if they shall say arabian ingraff into the land of Arabia or arabian accidental because they be not original breed and bear in Arabia and then which afterward come into Africa they name in their language mustehgeme that be barbarous arabian and that because they join themselves unto stranger insomuch that not only their speech but their manner also be most corrupt and barbarous these be friendly reader the particular which for these ten year my memory can reserve as touch the original and diversity of the african and arabian in all which time I remember not that ever I read or see any history of that nation he that will know more let he have recourse unto Hibnu Rachu the historiographer beforenamed the manner and custom of the african people which inhabit the desert of Libya those five kind of people before rehearse to wit the people the people of Numidia of Zenega of Gansiga of of Leuta and of Bardeoa be call of the latin Numidae and they live all after one manner that be to say without all law and civility their garment be a narrow and base piece of cloth wherewith scarce half their body be cover some of they wrap their head in a kind of black cloth as it be with a scarf such as the turk use which be common call a turban such as will be discern from the common sort for gentleman wear a jacket make of blue cotton with wide sleeve and cotton-cloth be bring unto they by certain merchant from the land of Negro they have no beast fit to ride upon except their camel unto who nature between the bunch stand upon the hinder part of their back and their neck have allot a place which may fit serve to ride upon in stead of a saddle their manner of ride be most ridiculous for sometime they lay their leg across upon the camel neck and sometime again have no knowledge nor regard of stirrup they rest their foot upon a rope which be cast over his shoulder in stead of spur they use a truncheon of a cubit length have at the one end thereof a goad wherewith they prick only the shoulder of their camel those camel which they use to ride upon have a hole bore through the gristle of their nose in the which a ring of leather be fasten whereby as with a bit they be more easy curb and master after which manner I have see buffle use in Italy for bed they lie upon mat make of sedge and bulrush their tent be cover for the most part with course chamlet or with a harsh kind of wool which common grow upon the bough of their date-tree as for their manner wool grow upon the palm tree of live it will seem to any man incredible what hunger and scarcity this nation will endure bread they have none at all neither use they any seethe or roast their food be camel milk only and they desire no other dainty for their breakfast they drink off a great cup of camel milk for supper they have certain dry flesh steep in butter and milk whereof each man take his share eat it out of his fist and that this their meat may not stay long undigested in their stomach they sup off the foresay broth wherein their flesh be steep for which purpose they use the palm of their hand as a most fit instrument frame by nature to the same end after that each one drink his cup of milk and so their supper have a end these numidian while they have any store of milk regard water nothing at all which for the most part happen in the spring of the year all which time you shall find some among they that will neither wash their hand nor their face which seem not altogether to be unlikely for as we say before while their milk last they frequent not those place where water be common yea and their camel so long as they may feed upon grass will drink no water at all they spend their whole day in hunt and thieve for all their endeavour and exercise be to drive away the camel of their enemy neither will they remain above three day in one place by reason that they have not pasture any long for the sustenance of their camel and albeit as be aforesaid they have no civility at all nor any law prescribe unto they yet have they a certain governor or prince place over they unto who they render obedience and due honour as unto their king they be not only ignorant of all good learning and liberal science but be likewise altogether careless and destitute of virtue insomuch that you shall find scarce one among they all which be a man of judgement or counsel and if any injury party will go to the law with his adversary he must ride continual five or six day before he can come to the speech of any judge this nation have all learning and good discipline in such contempt that they will not once vouchsafe to go out of their desert for the study and attain thereof neither if any learned man shall chance to come among they can they love his company and conversation in regard of their most rude and detestable behaviour howbeit if they can find any judge which can frame himself to live and continue among they to he they give most large yearly allowance some allow their judge a thousand ducat yearly some more and some less according as themselves think good they that will seem to be account of the better sort cover their head as I say before with a piece of black cloth part whereof like a vizard or mask reach down over their face cover all their countenance except their eye and this be their daily kind of attire and so often as they put meat into their mouth they remove the say mask which be do they forth with cover their mouth again allege this fond reason for say they as it be unseemly for a man after he have receive meat into his stomach to vomit it out of his mouth again and to cast it upon the earth even so it be a undecent part to eat meat with a man mouth uncover the woman of this nation be gross corpulent and of a swart complexion they be fat upon their breast and pap but slender about the girdle (@) very civil they be after their manner both in speech and gesture sometime they will accept of a kiss but whoso tempt they far put his own life in hazard for by reason of jealousy you may see they daily one to be the death and destruction of another and that in such savage and brutish manner that in this case they will show no compassion at all and they seem to be more wise in this behalf then diverse of our people for they will by no mean match themselves unto a harlot the liberality of this people have at all time be exceed great and when any traveller may pass through their dry and desert territory they will never repair unto their tent neither will they themselves travel upon the common high way and if any carovan or multitude of merchant will pass those desert they be bind to pay certain custom unto the prince of the say people namely for every camel load a piece of cloth worth a ducat upon a time I remember that travel in the company of certain merchant over the desert call by they araoan it be our chance there to meet with the prince of Zanaga who after he have receive his due custom invite the say company of merchant for their recreation to go and abide with he in his tent four or five day howbeit because his tent be too far out of our way and for that we shall have wander far than we think good esteem it more convenient for we to hold on our direct course we refuse his gentle offer and for his courtesy give he great thanks but not be satisfy therewith he command that our camel shall proceed on forward but the merchant he carry along with he and give they very sumptuous entertainment at his place of abode where we be no soon arrive but this good prince cause camel of all kind and ostrich (@) and (@) use (@) victual which he have hunt and take by the way to be kill for his household provision howbeit we request he not to make such daily slaughter of his camel affirm moreover that we never use to eat the flesh of a geld camel but when all other victual fail we whereunto he answer that he shall deal uncivil if he welcome so worthy and so seldome-seene guest with the kill of small cattle only wherefore he wish we to fall to such provision as be set before we here may you have see great plenty of roast and sodden flesh their roast ostrich be bring to the table in wicker platter be season with sundry kind of herb and spice their bread make of mill and panic be of a most savoury and pleasant taste and always at the end of dinner or supper we have plenty of date and great store of milk serve in yea this bountiful and noble prince that he may sufficient show how welcome we be unto he will together with his nobility always bear we company howbeit we ever dine and sup apart by ourselves moreover he cause certain religious and most learned man to come unto our banquet who all the time we remain with the say prince use not to eat any bread at all but feed only upon flesh and milk whereat we be somewhat amaze the good prince gentle tell we that they all be bear in such place whereas no kind of grain will grow howbeit that himself for the entertainment of stranger have great plenty of corn lay up in store wherefore he bid we to be of good cheer say that (@) will eat only of such thing as his own native soil afford affirm moreover that bread be yet in use among they at their feast of Passover and at other feast also whereupon they use to offer sacrifice and thus we remain with he for the space of two day all which time what wonder and magnificent cheer we have make we will seem incredible to report but the three day be desirous to take our leave the prince accompany we to that place where we overtake our camel and company send before and this I dare most deep take my oath on that we spend the say prince ten time more than our custom which he receive come to we think it not amiss here to set down this history to declare in some sort the courtesy and liberality of the say nation neither can the prince aforesaid understand our language nor we he but all our speech to and fro be make by a interpreter and this which we have here record as touch this nation be likewise to be understand of the other four nation above mention which be disperse over the residue of the numidian desert the manner and custom of the arabian which inhabit Africa the arabian as they have sundry mansion and place of abode so do they live after a diverse and sundry manner those which inhabit between Numidia and Libya lead a most miserable and distress life differ much in this regard from those african who we affirm to dwell in Libya howbeit they be far more valiant than the say african and use common to exchange camel in the land of negro where the Barbary horse be breed they have likewise great store of horse which in Europe they call horse of Barbary they take wonder delight in hunt and pursue of dear of wild ass of ostrich and such like neither be it here to be omit that the great part of arabian which inhabit Numidia be very witty and conceit in pen of verse wherein each man will decipher arabian poem and verse his love his hunt his combat and other his worthy act and this be do for the most part in rhyme after the italian manner and albeit it they be most liberal mind yet dare they not by bountiful give make any show of wealth for they be daily oppress with manifold inconvenience they be apparel after the numidian fashion save that their woman differ somewhat from the woman of Numidia those desert which they do now enjoy be wont to be possess by african but the arabian with their army invade that part of Africa drive out the natural numidian and reserve the desert adjoin upon the land of date unto themselves but the numidian begin to inhabit those desert which border upon the land of Negro the arabian which dwell between mount Atlas and the Mediterran sea be far wealthy than these which we now speak of both for costliness of apparel for good horse-meat and for the stateliness and beauty of their tent their horse also be of better shape and more corpulent but not so swift as the horse of the numidian desert they exercise husbandry and have great increase of corn their drove and flock of cattle be innumerable insomuch that they can inhabit one by another for want of pasture they be somewhat more vile and barbarous than those which inhabit the desert and yet they be not altogether destitute of liberality part of they which dwell in the territory of Fez be subject unto the king of Fez. those which remain in Morocco and Duccala have continue this long time free from all exaction and tribute but so soon as the king of Portugal begin to bear rule over Azafi and Azamor there begin also among they strife and civil war wherefore be assail by the king of Portugal on the one side and by the king of Fez on the other and be oppress also with the extreme famine and scarcity of that year they be bring unto such misery that they free offer themselves as the arabian offer themselves slave to any that will relieve their extreme hunger slave unto the portugal submit themselves to any man that be willing to relieve their intolerable hunger and by this mean scarce one of they be leave in all moreover those which possess the desert border upon the kingdom of tremizen and Tunis may all of they in regard of the rest be call nobleman and gentleman for their governor receive every year great revenue from the king of Tunis divide the same afterward among their people to the end they may avoid all discord and by this mean all dissension be eschew and peace be keep firm and inviolable among they they have notable dexterity and cunning both in make of tent and in bring up and keep of horse in summer time they usual come near unto Tunis to the end that each man may provide himself of bread armour and other necessary all which they carry with they into the desert remain there the whole winter in the spring of the year they apply themselves to hunt insomuch that no beast can escape their pursuit myself I remember be once at their tent to my no little danger and inconvenience where I see great quantity of cloth brass iron and copper than a man shall oftentimes find in the most rich warehouse of some city howbeit no trust be to be give unto they for if occasion serve they will play the thief most sly and cunning notwithstanding they seem to carry some show of civility they take great delight in poetry and will pen most excellent verse their language be very pure and elegant if any worthy poet be find among they he be accept by their governor with great honour and liberality neither will any man easy believe what wit and decency be in their verse their woman according to the guise of that country go very gorgeous attire they wear linen gown die black with exceed wide sleeve over which sometime they cast a mantle of the same colour or of blue the corner of which mantle be very artificial fasten about their shoulder with a fine silver clasp likewise they have ring hang at their ear which for the most part be make of silver they wear many ring also upon their finger moreover they usual wear about their thigh and ankle certain scarf and ring after the fashion of the african they cover their face with certain mask have only two hole for their eye to peep out at if any man chance to meet with they they present hide their face pass by he with silence except it be some of their ally or kinsfolk for unto they they always discover their face neither be there any use of the say mask so long as they be in presence these arabian when they travel any journey as they oftentimes do they set their woman upon certain saddle make handsome of wicker for the same purpose and fasten to their camel back neither be they any thing too wide but fit only for a woman to sit in when they go to the war each man carry his wife with he to the end that she may cheer up her good man and give he encouragement their damsel which be unmarried do usual paint their face breast arm hand and finger with a kind of counterfeit colour which be account a most decent custom among they but this fashion be first bring in by those arabian which before we call african what time they begin first of all to inhabit that region for before then they never use any false or gloze colour the woman of Barbary use not this fond kind of paint but content themselves only with their natural hue they regard not such feign ornament howbeit sometime they will temper a certain colour with hens-dung and safron wherewithal they paint a little round spot on the ball of their cheek about the breadth of a french crown likewise between their kickshaw they make a triangle and paint upon their chin a patch like unto a olive leaf some of they also do paint their kickshaw and this custom be very high esteem of by the arabian poet and by the gentleman of that country howbeit they will not use these fantastical ornament above two or three day together all which time they will not be see to any of their friend except it be to their husband and child for these paint seem to be great allurement unto lust whereby the say woman think themselves more trim and beautiful how the arabian in the desert between Barbary and Egypt do lead their life the life of these man be full of misery and calamity for the place where they inhabit be barren and unpleasant they have some store of camel and other cattle howbeit their fodder be so scarce that they can well sustain they neither shall you find over all the whole region any place fit to bear corn and if in that desert there be any village at all which use to husband and manure their ground yet reap they small commodity thereby except it be for plentiful increase of date their camel and other of their cattle they exchange for date and corn and so the poor husbandman of the foresay village have some small recompense for their labour notwithstanding how can all this satisfy the hunger of such a multitude for you shall daily see in Sicilia great number of the arabian of barca lay their son to pawn unto the sicilian for corn their son lay to pawn because when they have not wherewithal to pay for the corn which they there buy they be constrain to leave their son behind they as pledge of future payment but the sicilian if their money be not pay they at the time appoint will challenge the arabian son to be their slave which day be once past if any father will redeem his child he must disburse thrice or four time so much as the due debt amount unto for which cause they be the most notable thief in the whole world if any strange fall into their hand deprive he of all that he have they present carry he to Sicily and there either sell or exchange he for come and I think that no merchant (@) at any time within these hundred year (@) for traffic sake upon any part of their coast for when they be to pass by with merchandise or about any other weighty affair they eschew that region five hundred mile at the least once I remember that I myself for my better (@) and to avoid the danger of those mischievous people go in company with certain merchant who in three ship sail along their coast we be no soon espy of they but forthwith they come run to the shore make sign that they will traffic with we to our great advantage howbeit we dare not repose any trust in they none of our company will depart the ship before they have deliver certain pledge unto we which be do we buy certain (@) or geld man and good store of butter of they and so immediate weigh our anchor we betake we to flight fear lest we shall have be meet withal by the sicilian and rhodian pirate and be spoil not only of our good but of our liberty also to be short the say arabian be very rude forlorn beggarly lean and hunger-starved people have God no doubt (@) displease against they by who vengeance they daily sustain such (@) calamity of the people call Soara namely which possess drove and flock of cattle and be african by birth do notwithstanding imitate the manner of the arabian you shall find many among the african which live shepherd or drover life inhabit upon the begin of mount Atlas and be disperse here and there over the same mountain they be constrain always to pay tribute either to the king of the same region where they dwell or else to the arabian except those only which inhabit Temesna who be free from all foreign superiority and be of great power they speak the same kind of language that other africane do except some few of they which converse with the inhabitant of the city call which be near unto Tunis who speak the arabian tongue moreover there be a certain people inhabit that region which divide Numidia from Tunis these oftentimes wage war against the king of Tunis himself which they put in practice not many year since when as the say king his son march towards they from Constantina with a army for the demand of such tribute as be due unto he fight a very unfortunate battle for no soon be they advertise of the king son the (@) and death of the ring of Tunis his son his approach but forthwith they go to meet he with two thousand horseman and at length vanquish and slay he at unaware carry home with they all the furniture bag and baggage which he have bring forth and this be do in the year of mahumets Hegeira 915. from that time their fame have be spread abroad in all place yea many of the king of Tunis his subject revolt from their king unto they insomuch that the prince of this people be grow so puissant that scarce be his equal to be find in all Africa of the faith and religion of the ancient african or moor the ancient african be much addict to idolatry even as certain of the persian be at this day some of who worship the sun and other the fire for their god for the say african have in time past magnificent and most stately temple build and dedicate as well to the honour of the sun as of the fire in these temple day and night they keep fire kindle give diligent heed that it may not at any time be extinguish even as we read of the roman vestal virgin all which you may read more full and at large in the persian and african chronicle those african which inhabit Libya and Numidia will each of they worship some certain planet unto who likewise they offer sacrifice and prayer some other of the land of Negro worship Guighimo that be to say the lord of heaven and this sound point of religion be not deliver unto they by any prophet or teacher but be inspire as it be from God himself after that they embrace the jewish law wherein they be say to have continue many year afterwards they profess the christian religion and continue christian until such time as the mahometan superstition prevail which come to pass in the year of the Hegeira 208. about which time certain of Mahomet disciple so bewitch they with eloquent and deceivable speech that they allure their weak mind to consent unto their opinion insomuch that all the kingdom of the negro adjoin unto Libya receive the mahometan law neither be there any region in all the negro land which have in it at this day any christian at all at the same time such as be find to be jew christian or of the african religion be slay every man of they howbeit those which dwell near unto the ocean sea be all of they very gross idolater between who and the portugal there have be from time to time and even at this present be great traffic and familiarity the inhabitant of Barbary continue for many year idolater but before the come of Mahomet above 250 year they be say to have embrace the christian faith which some think come to pass upon this occasion namely because that of part Barbary which contain the kingdom of Tripoli and Tunis be in time past govern by apulian and sicilian captain and the country of * * * trenizen Caesaria and of * * * * * Maroco and Fez Mauritania be suppose to have be (@) unto the goth at what time also many christian flee from the fury and madness of the goth leave their sweet native soil of Italy and at length arrive in Africa near unto Tunis where have settle their abode for some certain space they begin at length to have the dominion over all that region howbeit the christian which inhabit Barbaria not respect the rite and ceremony of the church of Rome follow the arrian (@) and form of live and one of the african christian be that most godly and learned father saint Augustine when the arabian therefore come to conquer that part of Africa they find christian to be lord over the region adjacent of who after sundry hot conflict the say arabian get the victory whereupon the arrian be deprive of all their dominion and good go part of they into Italy and part into Spain and so about two hundred year after the death of Mahumet almost all Barbary be infect with his law howbeit afterward civil dissension arise among they neglect the law of Mahumet they slay all the priest and governor of that region which tumult when it come to the ear of the mahometan Caliphas they send a huge army against the say rebel of Barbary to wit those which be revolt from the Calipha of Bagdet and severe punish their misdemeanour and even at the same time be lay the most (@) foundation of the mahometan law notwithstanding there have remain many heresy among they even until this very day as touch the patron of the mahometan law and likewise concern the difference in religion between the mahometan a book write by John Leo concern the mahometan religion of Africa and they of Asia we will by God grace write more in another several volume and in the mean season let these particular which we have note suffice the reader of the letter and character of the african those writer which record the history of the arabian do be all joint of opinion that the african be wont to use only the latin letter and they do most constant affirm the african use in time past none other kind of letter but the roman letter that the arabian when they first (@) Africa and especial Barbary which be the principal seat of the african find no letter nor character there beside the latin neither indeed do they deny that the african have a peculiar kind of language but this they firm avouch that they have the very same letter which the (@) or Florentinesa people of Italy have the arabian have no history * * * * * * * * * * * * * perhaps he mean the history of Sallust (@) Livius and other of african matter which be not first write in latin they have certain ancient author who write partly in the time of the arrian and partly before their time the name of all which be clean forget howbeit it be very likely that those latin author have write many volume for when their interpreter labour to persuade something unto we I remember they will say it be contain in the 70 book neither do they in translate of the say volume altogether follow the author order but take the history of some one prince they will conjoin his time and action with the history of the persian assyrian and chaldaean king or of the israelite which concern the same time but when as those which rebel against the Calipha of Bagdet as be aforesaid get the upper hand in Africa they burn all the african book for they be of opinion that the african so long as they have any knowledge of natural philosophy or of other good art and science will every day more and more arrogant contemn the law of Mahumet contrariwise some historiographer there be which affirm that the african have a kind of letter peculiar unto themselves which notwithstanding from the time wherein the italian begin first to inhabit Barbary and wherein the christian (@) out of Italy from the goth begin to subdue those province of Africa be utter abolish and take away for it be likely that a people vanquish shall follow the custom and the letter also of their conqueror and do not the same thing happen to the persian while the arabian empire stand for certain it be that the persian at the same time lose those letter which be peculiar unto their nation and that all their book by the commandment the mahometan Calisas cause all the book of the persian to be burn of the mahometan prelate be burn lest their knowledge in natural philosophy or their idolatrous religion may move they to contemn the precept of Mahumet the like also as we show before befall the barbarian when as the italian and the goth usurp their dominion in Barbary which may here I hope suffice the gentle reader howbeit this be out of doubt that all the (@) city and inland-city of Barbary do use latin letter only whensoever they will commit any epitaph or any other verse or prose unto posterity the consideration of all which former particular have make i to be of opinion that the african in time past have their own proper and peculiar letter wherein they describe their do and exploit for it be likely that the roman when they first subdue those province as conqueror usual do utter spoil and take away all their letter and memory and establish their own letter in the stead thereof to the end that the fame and honour of the roman people may there only be continue and who know not that the very same attempt be practise by the goth upon the stately building of the roman and by the arabian against the monument of the persian the very same thing likewise we daily see put in practice by the turk who when they have get any city or town from the christian do present cast forth of the temple all the image and memorial of their saint and to omit all the aforesaid may we not in our time see the like daily practise in Rome where sumptuous and stately building leave unperfect by reason of the untimely death of one pope be for some novelty utter ruin and destroy by his next successor or else do not the new pope cause his predecessor arm to be raze and his own in stead thereof to be set up or at the least if he will not seem so arrogant let his predecessor monument stand still do he not erect other for himself far more sumptuous and stately no marvel therefore though so long success of time and so many alteration have quite bereave the african of their letter concern those nine hundred year wherein the african use the letter of the arabian Rachich a most diligent writer of Africa do in his chronicle most large dispute whether the african ever have any peculiar kind of writing or no. and at last he conclude the affirmative part that they have for say he whosoever deny this may as well deny that they have a language peculiar unto themselves for it can be that any people shall have a proper kind of speech and yet shall use letter borrow from other nation and be altogether unfit for their mother-language of the situation of Africa as there be four part in Africa so the situation thereof be not in all place alike that part which lie towards the Mediterran sea that be to say from the streite of Gibraltar to the frontier of Egypt be here and there full of mountain southward it be extend about a hundred mile albeit in some place it be large and in some other narrow from the say mountain unto mount Atlas there be a very spacious plain and many little hillock fountain there be
