in this region great store which meet together at one head do send forth most beautiful river and crystal stream between the foresay mountain and the plain country be situate the mountain of Atlas which begin westward upon the ocean sea stretch itself towards the east as far as the border of Egypt over against Atlas lie that region of Numidia which bear date be every where almost sandy ground between Numidia and the land of Negro be the sandy desert of Libya situate which contain many mountain also howbeit merchant travel not that way when as they may go other way with more ease and less danger beyond the libyan desert begin the land of negro all place whereof be barren and sandy except those which adjoin upon the river of Niger or through the which any river or stream run of the unpleasant and snowy place in Africa all the region of Barbary and the mountain contain therein be subject more to cold then to heat for seldom come any gale of wind which bring not some snow therewith in all the say mountain there grow abundance of fruit but not so great plenty of corn the inhabitant of these mountain live for the great part of the year upon barley bread the spring and river issue forth of the say mountain represent the quality and taste of their native soil be somewhat muddy and impure especial upon the confine of Mauritania these mountain likewise be replenish with wood and lofty (@) and be great store with beast of all kind but the little hill and valley lie between the foresay mountain and mount Atlas be far more commodious and abound with corn for ' they be moisten with river spring out of Atlas and from thence hold on their course to the Mediterran sea and albeit wood be somewhat more scarce upon these plain yet be they much more fruitful then be the plain country situate between Atlas and the ocean sea as namely the region of Maroco of Duccala of tedle of Temesna of Azgara and the country lie towards the strait of Gibraltar the mountain the mountain of Atlas exceed cold of Atlas be exceed cold and barren and bring forth but small store of corn be woody on all side and engender almost all the river of Africa the fountain of Atlas be even in the midst of summer extreme cold so that if a man dip his hand therein for any long space he be in great danger of lose the same howbeit the say mountain be not so cold in all place for some part thereof be of such mild temperature that they may be right commodious inhabit yea and sundry place thereof be well store with inhabitant as in the second part of this present discourse we will declare more at large those place which be destitute of inhabitant be either extreme cold as namely the same which lie over against Mauritania or very rough and unpleasant to wit those which be direct opposite to the region of Temesna where notwithstanding in summer time they may feed their great and small cattle but not in winter by any mean for then the north wind so furious rage bring with it such abundance of snow that all the cattle which till then remain upon the say mountain and a great part of the people also be force to lose their life in regard thereof wherefore whosoever have any occasion to travel that way in winter time choose rather to take his journey between Mauritania and Numidia those merchant which bring date out of Numidia for the use and service of other nation set forth usual upon their journey about the end of October and yet they be oftentimes so oppress most wonder and terrible snow and overtake with a sudden fall of snow that scarce one man among they all escape the danger of the tempest for when it begin to snow over night before the next morning not only cart and man but even the very tree be so drown and overwhelm therein that it be not possible to find any mention of they howbeit the dead carcase be then find when the sun have melt the snow I myself also by the goodness of the extreme danger of snow which John Leo himself escape almighty God twice escape the most dreadful danger of the foresay snow whereof if it may not be tedious to the reader I will here in few word make relation upon a certain day of the foresay month of October travel with a great company of merchant towards Atlas we be there about the sun go down weather-beaten with a most cold and snowy kind of hail here we find eleven or twelve horseman arabian to our think who persuade we to leave our cart and to go with they promise we a good and secure place to lodge in for i own part that I may not seem altogether uncivil I think it not meet to refuse their good offer albeit I stand in doubt lest they go about to practice some mischief wherefore I bethink myself to hide up a certain sum of gold which I have as then about i but all be ready to ride I have no leisure to hide away my coin from they whereupon I feign that I will go ease myself and so depart a while their company and get i under a certain tree whereof I take diligent notice I bury my money between certain stone and the root of the say tree and then we ride on quiet till about midnight what time one of they think that he have stay long enough for his prey begin to utter that in word which secret he have conceive in his mind for he ask whether I have any money about i or no to who I answer that I have leave my money behind with one of they which attend the cart and that I have then none at all about i howbeit they be no whit satisfy with this answer command i for all the cold weather to strip myself out of my apparel at length when they can find no money at all they say in jest and scoff wise that they do this for no other purpose but only to see how strong and hardy I be and how I can endure the cold and tempestuous season well on we ride seek our way as well as we can that dark and dismal night and anon we hear the bleat of sheep conjecture thereby that we be not far distant from some habitation of people wherefore out of hand we direct our course thitherwards be constrain to lead our horse through thick wood and over steep and craggy rock to the great hazard and peril of our life and at length after many labour we find shepherd in a certain cave who have with much pain bring their cattle in there have kindle a lusty fire for themselves which they be constrain by reason of the extreme cold daily to sit by who understand our company to be arabian fear at the first that we will do they some mischief but afterward be persuade that we be drive thither by extremity of cold and be more secure of we they give we most friendly entertainment for they set bread flesh and cheese before we wherewith have end our supper we lay we along each man to sleep before the fire all of we be as yet exceed cold but especial myself who before with great horror and tremble be strip stark naked and so we continue with the say shepherd for the space of two day all which time we can not set forth by reason of continual snow but the three day so soon as they see it leave snow with great labour they begin to remove that snow which lie before the door of their cave which do they bring we to our horse which we find well provide of hay in another cave be all mount the shepherd accompany we some part of our way show we where the snow be of least depth and yet even there it touch our horse belly this day be so clear that the sun take away all the cold of the two day go before at length enter into a certain village near unto Fez we understand that our cart which pass by be overwhelm with the snow then the arabian see no hope of recompense for all the pain they have take for they have defend our cart from thief carry a certain jew of our company with they as their captive who have lose a great quantity of date by reason of the snow aforesaid to the end that he may remain as their prisoner till he have satisfy for all the residue from myself they take my horse and commit i unto the wide world and to fortune from whence ride upon a mule within three day I arrive at Fez where I hear doleful news of our merchant and ware that they be cast away in the snow yea they think that I have be destrose with the rest but it seem that God will have it otherwise now have finish the history of my own misfortune let we return unto that discourse where we leave beyond Atlas there be certain hot and dry place moisten with very few river but those which flow out of Atlas itself some of which river run into the libyan desert be dry up with the sand but other do engender lake neither shall you find in these country any place apt to bring forth corn notwithstanding they have date in abundance there be also certain other tree bear fruit but in so small quantity that no increase nor gain be to be reap by they you may see likewise in those part of Numidia which border upon Libya certain barren hill destitute of tree upon the low part whereof grow nothing but unprofitable thorn and shrub among these mountain you shall find no river nor spring nor yet any water at all except it be in certain pit and well almost unknown unto the inhabitant of that region moreover in six or seven day journey they have not one drop of water but such as be bring unto they by certain merchant upon camel back and that especial in those place which lie upon the main road from Fez to Tombuto or from tremizen to * * * Agadez Agad that journey likewise be very dangerous which be of late find out by the merchant of our day from Fez to alcair over the desert of Libya be it not for a huge lake in the way upon the bank whereof the Sinites and the goranite do inhabit but in the way which lead from Fez to Tombuto be certain pit environ either with the hide or bone of camel neither do the merchant in summer time pass that way without great danger of their life for oftentimes it fall out when the south wind blow that all those pit be stop up with sand and so the merchant when they can find neither those pit nor any mention thereof must needs perish for extreme thirst who carcase be afterward find lie scatter here and there and scorch with the heat of the sun one remedy they have a strange remedy use by the african merchant to quench their thirst in this case which be very strange for when they be so grievous oppress with thirst they kill forthwith some one of their camel out of who bowel they wring and express some quantity of water which water they they drink and carry about with they till they have either find some pit of water or till they pine away for thirst in the desert which they call azaoad there be as yet extant two monument build of marble upon which marble be a Epitaphe engrave signify that one of the say monument represent a most rich merchant and the other a carrier or transporter of ware which wealthy merchant buy of the carrier a cup of water for ten a merchant constrain by extreme thirst give ten thousand ducat for a cup of water thousand ducat and yet this precious water can suffice neither of they for both be consume with thirst this desert likewise contain sundry kind of beast which in the four part of this discourse concern Libya and in our treatise of the beast of Africa we will discourse of more at large I be determine to have write more concern those thing which happen unto myself and the rest of my company travel through the libyan desert unto Gualata for sometime be sore a thirst we can not find one drop of water partly because our guide stray out of the direct course and partly because our enemy have cut off the spring and channel of the foresay pit and well insomuch that the small quantity of water which we find be spare to be keep for that which will scarce suffice we for five day we be constrain to keep for ten but if I shall commit to write all thing worthy of memory a whole year be not sufficient for i the land of Negro be extreme hot have some store of moisture also by reason of the river of Niger run through the midst thereof all place adjoin upon Niger do mighty abound both with cattle and corn no tree I see there but only certain great one bear a kind of bitter fruit like unto a chestnut which in their language be call goron the fruit call goron (@) onion likewise in the same region grow cucumber onion and such kind of herb and fruit in great abundance there be no mountain at all either in Libya or in the land of negro howbeit diverse fen and lake there be which as man report the inundation of Niger have leave behind it neither be the wood of the say region altogether destitute of elephant and other strange beast whereof we will make relation in their due place what natural impression and motion the air of Africa be subject unto and what effect ensue thereupon throughout the great part of Barbary stormy and cold weather begin common about the midst of October but in December and januarie the cold grow somewhat more sharp in all place howbeit this happen in the morning only but so gentle and remisse that no man care great to warm himself by the fire February somewhat mitigate the cold of winter but that so inconstant that the weather change sometime five and sometime six time in one day in march the north and west wind usual blow which cause the tree to be adorn with blossom in April all fruit attain to their proper form and shape insomuch that cherry be common ripe about the end of April and the beginning of mayin the midst of may they gather their fig and in mid-Iune their grape be ripe in many place likewise their pear their sweet quince and their damascen attain unto sufficient ripeness in the month of june and julie their fig of autumn may be gather in August howbeit they never have so great plenty of fig and peach as in September by the midst of August they usual begin to dry their grape in the sun where of they make reisin which if they can finish in September by reason of unseasonable weather of their grape as then ungathered they use to make wine and must especial in the province of Rifa as we will in due place signify more at large in the midst of October they take in their honey and gather their pomegranate and quince in the olive of Africa November they gather their olive not climb up with ladder nor pluck they with their hand according to the custom of Europe for the tree of Mauritania and Caesarea be so tall that no ladder be long ynongh to reach unto the fruit and therefore their olive be full ripe they climb the tree beat they off the bough with certain long pole albeit they know this kind of beat to be most hurtful unto the say tree sometime they have great plenty of olive in Africa and sometime as great scarcity certain great olive-tree there be the olive whereof be eat ripe by the inhabitant because they be not so fit for oil no year fall out to be so unseasonable but that they have three month in the spring always temperate they begin their spring upon the fifteen day of February account the eighteen of May for the end thereof all which time they have most pleasant weather but if from the five and twenty of raine signify plenty or (@) April to the five of may they have no rain fall they take it as a sign of ill luck and the rainwater which fall all the time aforesaid they call naisan that be water bless of God some store it up in vessel most religious keep it as a holy thing their summer last till the sixteen of August all which time they have most hot and clear weather except perhaps some shower of rain fall in july and August which do so infect the air that great plague and most pestilent fever ensue thereupon with which plague whosoever be infect most hardly escape death their autumn they reckon from the 17. of August to the 16. of November have common in the month of August and September not such extreme heat as before howbeit all the time between the 15. of August and the 15. of September be call by they the furnace of the whole year for that it bring fig quince and such kind of fruit to their full maturity from the 15. of November they begin their winter-season continue the same till the 14. day of February so soon as winter come they begin to till their ground which lie in the plain but upon the mountain they go to plough in October the african be most certain persuade that every year contain forty extreme hot day begin upon the 12. of june and again so many day extreme cold begin from the 12. of December their be upon the 16. of march and the 16. of September for their they account the 16. of june and the 16. of December these rule they do most strict observe as well in husbandry and navigation as in search out the house and true place of the planet and these instruction with other such like they teach their young child first of all many countrie-people and husbandman there be in Africa the peasant and unlearned people of Africa cunning in astrology who know as they say never a letter of the book will notwithstanding most learned dispute of astrology and allege most profound reason and argument for themselves but whatsoever skill they have in the art of astrology they first learn the same of the latin yea they give those very name unto their month which the latin do moreover they have extant among they a certain great book divide into three volume which they call the treasury or storehouse of husbandry this book be then translate out of latin into their tongue when Mansor be lord of Granada in the say treasury be all thing contain which may seem in any wise to concern husbandry as namely the change and variety of time the manner of sow with a number of such like particular which I think at this day the latin tongue itself whereout these thing be first translate do not contain whatsoever either the african or the mahometan have which seem to appertain in any wise to their law or religion they make their computation thereof altogether according to the course of the moon their year be divide into 354. day for unto six month they the year of the arabian and african allot 30. day and unto the other six but 29 all which be add into one sum do produce the number aforesaid wherefore their year differ eleven day from the year of the latin they have at diverse time festival day and fast about the end of autumn for all winter and a great part of the spring they be trouble with boisterous wind with hail with terrible thunder and lightning yea than it snow much in some place of Barbary the eastern southern and southeasterne wind blow in May and june do very much hurt there for they spoil the corn and hinder the fruit from come to ripeness their corn likewise be great appair by snow especial such as fall in the daytime when it begin to flower upon the mountain of Atlas they divide the year into the year divide into two season one upon the mountaine of Atlas two part only for their winter continue from October to April and from April to October they account it summer neither be there any day throughout the whole year wherein the top of those mountain be not cover with snow in Numidia the year run away very swift for they reap their corn in May and in October they gather their date but from the midst of September they have winter till the beginning of (@) but if September fall out to be rainy they be like to lose most part of their date all the field of Numidia require water from the river but if the mountain of Atlas have no rain fall upon they the numidian river wax dry and so the field be destitute of water October be destitute of rain the husbandman have no hope to cast his seed into the ground and he despair likewise if it rain not in April but their date prosper more without rain whereof the numidian have great plenty then of corn for albeit they have some store of corn yet can it scarce suffice they for half the year howbeit if they have good increase of date they can want abundance of corn which be sell unto they by the arabian for date if in the libyan desert there fall out change of weather about the midst of October and if it continue rain there all December januarie and some part of February it be wonderful what abundance of grass and milk it bring forth then may you find diverse lake in all place and many fen throughout Libya wherefore this be the meet time for the barbarie-merchant to travel to the land of Negro here all kind of fruit grow soon ripe if they have moderate shower about the end of july moreover the land of Negro receive by rain neither any benefit nor yet any damage at all for the river Niger together with the water which fall from certain mountain do so moisten their ground that no place can be devise to be more fruitful for that which Nilus be to Egypt the same be Niger to the land of Negors for it increase like Nilus the increase of the river of Niger and Nilu from the fifteen of june the space of forty day after and for so many again it decrease and so at the increase of Niger when all place be overflow with water a man may in a bark pass over all the land of negro albeit not without great peril of drown as in the five part of this treatise we will declare more at large of the length and shortness of the african life all the people of Barbary by we before mention live unto 65. or 70. year of age and few or none exceed that number howbeit in the foresay mountain I see some which have live a hundred year and other which affirm themselves to be old who age be most healthful and lusty yea some you shall find here of fourscore year of age who be sufficient strong and able to exercise husbandry to dress vine and to serve in the war insomuch that young man be oftentimes inferior unto they in Numidia that be to say in the land of date they live a long time howbeit they lose their tooth very soon and their eye wax wonderful dim which infirmity be likely to be incident unto they first because they continual feed upon date the sweetness and natural quality whereof do by little and little pull out their tooth and second the dust and sand which be toss up and down the air with eastern wind enter into their eye do at last miserable weaken and spoil their eyesight the inhabitant of Libya be of a short life but those which be most strong and healthful among they live oftentimes till they come to threescore year albeit they be slender and lean of body the negro common live the short time of all the rest howbeit they be always strong and lusty have their tooth sound even till their die day yet be there no nation under heaven more prone to venery unto which vice also the libyan and numidian be to too much addict to be short the barbarian be the weak people of they all what kind of disease the african be subject unto the child and sometime the ancient woman of this region be subject unto baldness or unnatural shed of hair which disease they can hardly be cure of they be likewise oftentimes trouble with the headache which usual afflict they without any ague join therewith many of they be torment with the toothache which as some think they be the more subject unto because immediate after hot pottage they drink cold water they be oftentimes vex with extreme pain of the stomach which ignorant they call the pain of the hart they be likewise daily molest with inward gripe and infirmity over their whole body which be think to proceed of continual drink of water yea they be (@) subject unto bone-aches and gout by reason that they sit common upon the bare ground and never wear any shoe upon their foot their chief gentleman and nobleman prove gouty oftentimes with immoderate drink of wine and eat of dainty meat some with eat of olive nut and such course fare be for the most part infect with the scuruy those which be of a sanguine complexion be great trouble with the cough because that in the spring-season they sit too much upon the ground and upon friday I have no small sport and recreation to go and see they for upon this day the people flock to church in great number to hear their (@) sermon now if any one in the sermon-tile fall a sneeze all the whole multitude will sneeze with he for company and so they make such a noise that they never leave till the sermon be quite do so that a man shall reap but little knowledge by any of their sermon if any of Barbary be infect with the disease common call the french pox they die thereof for the most part and be seldom cure this disease begin with a kind of anguish and swell and at the french disease length break out into sore over the mountain of Atlas and throughout all Numidia and Libya they scarce know this disease insomuch that oftentimes the party infect travel forthwith into Numidia or the land of negro in which place the air be so temperate that only by remain there they recover their perfect health and (@) home sound into their own country which I see many do with my own eye who without the help of any physician or medicine except the foresay wholesome air be restore to their former health not so much as the name of this malady be ever know unto the african before (@) the king of Castille expel all jew out of Spain after the return of which jew when and by what mean the french (@) be bring into Africa into Africa certain unhappy and lewd people lie with their wife and so at length the disease spread from one to another over the whole region insomuch that scarce any one family be free from the same howbeit this they be most certain persuade of that the same disease come first from Spain wherefore they for want of a better name do call it the spanish pox notwithstanding at Tunis and over all Italy it be call the french disease it be so call likewise in Egypt and Syria for there it be use as a common proverb of curse the french pox take you among the hernia or the disease call (@) or the rupture barbarian the disease call in latin hernia be not so common but in Egypt the people be much trouble therewith for some of the egyptian have their cod oftentimes so swell as it be incredible to report which infirmity be think to be so common among they because they eat so much gum and salt cheese some of their child be subject unto the fall sickness but when they grow to any stature they be free from that disease this fall sickness likewise possess the woman of Barbary and of the land of negro who to excuse it say that they be take with a spirit in Barbary the plague be rife every ten fifteen or twenty year whereby great number of people be consume for they have no cure for the same but only to rub the plague-sore with certain ointment make of armenian earth in Numidia they be infect with the plague earth of (@) scarce once in a hundred year and in the land of negro they know not the name of this disease because they never be subject thereunto the commendable action and virtue of the african those arabian which inhabit in Barbary or upon the coast of the Mediterran sea be great addict unto the study of good art and science and those thing which concern their law and religion be esteem by they in the first place moreover they have be heretofore most studious of the mathematics of philosophy and of astrology but these art as it be aforesaid be four hundred year ago utter destroy and take away by the chief professor of their law the inhabitant of city do most religious observe and (@) those thing which appertain unto their religion yea they honour those doctor and priest of who they learn their law as if they be petie-god their church they frequent very diligent to the end they may repeat certain prescript and formal prayer most superstitious persuade themselves that the same day wherein they make their prayer it be not lawful for they to wash certain of their member when as at other time they will wash their whole body whereof we will by God help discourse more at large in the second book of this present treatise when we shall fall into the mention of Mahumet and of his religion moreover those which inhabit Barbary be of great cunning and dexterity for building and for mathematical invention which a man may easy conjecture by their artificial work most honest people they be and destitute of all fraud and guile not only embrace all simplicity and truth but also practise the same throughout the whole course of their life albeit certain latin author which have write of the same region be far otherwise of opinion likewise they be most strong and valiant people especial those which dwell upon the mountain the moor be a people of great fidelity they keep their covenant most faithful insomuch that they have rather die then break promise no nation in the world be so subject unto jealousy for they will rather lose their life than put up any disgrace in the behalf of their woman so desirous they be of riches and honour that therein no other people can go beyond they they travel in a manner over the whole world to exercise traffic for they be continual to be see in Egypt in AEthiopia in Arabia Persia India and Turkey and whithersoever they go they be most honourable esteem of for none of they will profess any art unless he have attain unto great exactness and perfection therein they have always be much delight with all kind of civility and modest behaviour and it be account heinous among they for any man to utter in company any bawdy or unseemly word they have always in mind this sentence of a grave author give place to thy superior if any youth in presence of his father his uncle or any other of his kindred do sing or talk aught of love matter he be deem to be worthy of grievous punishment whatsoever lad or youth there light by chance into any company which discourse of love no soon hear nor understand what their talk tend unto but immediate he withdraw himself from among they these be the thing which we think most worthy of relation as concern the civility humanity and upright deal of the barbarian let we now proceed unto the residue those arabian which dwell in tent that be to say which bring up cattle be of a more liberal and civil disposition to wit they be in their kind as devout valiant patient courteous hospital and as honest in life and conversation as any other people they be most faithful observer of their word and promise insomuch that the people which before we say to dwell in the mountain be great stir up with emulation of their virtue howbeit the say mountainer both for learning for virtue and for religion be think much inferior to the numidian albeit they have little or no knowledge at all in natural philosophy they be report likewise to be most (@) warrior to be valiant and exceed lover and practiser of all humanity also the moor and arabian inhabit Libya be somewhat civil of behaviour be plain dealer void of dissimulation favourable to stranger and lover of simplicity those which we before name white or tawny moor be most steadfast in friendship as likewise they indifferent and favourable esteem of other nation and whole endeavour themselves in this one thing namely that they may lead a most pleasant and jocund life moreover they maintain most learned professor of liberal art and such man as be most devout in their religion neither be there any people in all Africa that lead a more happy and honourable life what vice the foresay african be subject unto never be there any people or nation so perfect endue with virtue but that they have their contrary fault and blemish now therefore let we consider whether the vice of the african do surpass their virtue and good part those which we name the inhabitant of the city of Barbary be somewhat needy and covetous be also very proud and high-minded and wonderful addict unto wrath insomuch that according to the proverb they will deep engrave in marble any injury be it never so small and will in no wise blot it out of their remembrance so rustical they be and void of good manner that scarce can any stranger obtain their familiarity and friendship their wit be but mean and they be so credulous that they will believe matter impossible which be tell they so ignorant be they of natural philosophy that they imagine all the effect and operation of nature to be extraordinary and divine they observe no certain order of live nor of law abound exceed with choler they speak always with a angry and loud voice neither shall you walk in the daytime in any of their street but you shall see common two or three of they together by the ear by nature they be a vile and base people be no better account of by their governor then if they be dog they have neither judge nor lawyer by who wisdom and counsel they ought to be direct they be utter unskilful in trade of merchandise be destitute of banker and money-changer wherefore a merchant can do nothing among they in his absence but be himself constrain to go in person whithersoever his ware be carry no people under heaven be more addict unto covetise then this nation neither be there I think to be find among they one of a hundred who for courtesy humanity or devotions sake will vouchsafe any entertainment upon a stranger mindful they have always be of injury but most forgetful of benefit their mind be perpetual possess with vexation and strife so that they will seldom or never show themselves tractable to any man the cause whereof be suppose to be for that they be so greedy addict unto their filthy lucre that they never can attain unto any kind of civility or good behaviour the shepherd of that region live a miserable toilsome wretched and beggarly life they be a rude people and as a man may say bear and breed to theft deceit and brutish manner their young man may go a woo to diverse maid till such time as they have speed of a wife yea the father of the maid most friendly welcome her suitor so that I think scarce any noble or gentleman among they can choose a virgin for his spouse albeit so soon as any woman be marry she be quite forsake of all her suitor who then seek out other new paramour for their like concern their religion the great part of these people be neither mahometan jew nor christian and hardly shall you find so much as a spark of piety in any of they they have no church at all nor any kind of prayer but be utter estrange from all godly devotion they lead a savage and beastly life and if any man chance to be of a better disposition because they have no lawgiver nor teacher among they he be constrain to follow the example of other man life and manner all the numidian being most ignorant of natural domestical and commonwealth-matter be principal addict unto treason treachery murder theft and robbery this nation because it be most slavish will right glad accept of any service among the barbarian be it never so vile or contemptible for some will take upon they to be dung-farmer other to be scullion some other to be ostler and such like servile occupation likewise the inhabitant of Libya live a brutish kind of life who neglect all kind of good art and science do whole apply their mind unto theft and violence never as yet have they any religion any law or any good form of live but always have and ever will have a most miserable and distress life there can any treachery or villainy be invent so damnable which for Lucre sake they dare not attempt they spend all their day either in most lewd practice or in hunt or else in warfare neither wear they any shoe nor garment the negro likewise lead a beastly kind of life be utter destitute of the use of reason of dexterity of wit and of all art yea they so behave themselves as if they have continual live in a forest among wild beast they have great swarm of harlot among they whereupon a man may easy conjecture their manner of live except (@) conversation perhaps be somewhat more tolerable who dwell in the (@) (@) and city for it be like that they be somewhat more addict to (@) neither be I ignorant how much my own credit be (@) when the author of this work his apology for the former relation I myself write so homely of Africa unto which country (@) (@) debt both for my birth and also for the best part of my education howbeit in this regard I seek not to excuse myself but only to appeal unto the duty of a historiographer who be to set down the plain truth in all place and be blame-woorthie for flatter or favour of any person and this be the cause that have move i to describe all thing so plain without gloss or dissimulation wherefore here I be to request the gentle reader friendly to accept of this my most true discourse albeit not adorn with fine word and artificial eloquence as of certain unknown strange matter wherein how indifferent and sincere I have show myself it may in few word appear by that which follow it be report of a lewd countryman of we that be convict of some heinous crime he be adjudge to be severe beat for it howbeit the day follow when the (@) come to do his business the malefactor remember that certain year before he have some acquaintance and familiarity with he which make he to presume that he shall find more favour at his hand than a mere stranger but he be foul (@) for the executioner use he no better then if he have never know he wherefore this caitiff at the first exclaim upon his executioner oh say he my goodfriend what make you so stern as not to acknowledge our old acquaintance hereupon the executioner beat he more cruel than before friend quoth he in such business as this I use to be mindful of my duty and to show no favour at all and so continual lay on he cease not till the judicial sentence be fulfil it be doubtless a great argument of impartial deal when as respect of former friendship can take no place wherefore I think good to record all the particular aforesaid lest that describe vice only I shall seem to flatter they with who I be now present conversant or extol only the virtue of the african I may hereafter be say to sue for their favour which I have of purpose eschew to the end that I may have more free access unto they moreover may it please you for this purpose to hear another resemblance or similitude there be upon a time a most wily bird so endue by nature that she can live as well with the fish of the sea as with the fowl of the air wherefore she be right call this bird be summon before the king of bird to pay her yearly tribute determine forthwith to change her element and to delude the king and so fly out of the air she drench herself in the ocean sea which strange accident the fish wonder at come flock about salute she and ask she the cause of her come good fish quoth the bird know you not that all thing be turn so upside down that we wot not how to live secure in the air our tyrannical king what fury haunt he I know not command i to be (@) (@) to death whereas no silly bird respect ever his commodity as (@) (@) one which most unjust edict I no soon hear of but present (@) fish I come to you for refuge wherefore vouchsafe i I beseech (@) some odd corner or other to hide my head in and then I may just say that I have find more friendship among stranger then ever I do in my own native country with this speech the fish be so persuade that stay a whole year among they not pay one penny or halfpenny at the year end the king of fish begin to demand his tribute insomuch that at last the bird be (@) to pay great reason it be say the bird that each man shall have his due and for my part I be content to do the duty of a loyal subject these word be no soon speak but she sudden spread her wing and up she mount into the air and so this bird to avoid yearly exaction and tribute will eftsoon change her element out of this fable I will infer no other moral but that all man do most affect that place where they find least damage and inconvenience for i own part when I hear the african evil speak of I will affirm myself to be one of Granada and when I perceive the nation of Granada to be discommend then will I profess myself to be a african but herein the african shall be the more behold unto i for that I will only record their principal and notorious vice omit their small and more tolerable fault JOHN LEO his second book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein have in my first book make mention of the city bound division and some other notable and memorable thing contain in Africa we will in this second part more full particular large and distinct describe sundry province town mountain situation of place law rite and custom of people insomuch that we will leave nothing untouched which may any way serve to the illustrate and perfect of this our present discourse begin therefore at the west part of Africa we will in this our geographical history proceed eastward till we come to the border of Egypt and all this our narration follow we will divide into seven book whereunto God will we purpose to annex the eight which shall entreat of river of live creature of tree of plant of fruit of shrub and of such other most delightful matter of the region of Hea lie upon the west part of Africa hea be one of the province of Maroco be bound westward and northward with the main ocean southward with the mountain of Atlas and eastward with the river which they call (@) this river spring out of the foresay mountain discharge itself at length into the river of tensift and divide Hea from the province next adjacent of the situation and description of hea. this region of Hea be a uneeven and rough soil full of rocky mountain shady wood and chrystall-streame in all place be wonderful rich and well store with inhabitant they have in the say region great abundance of goat and ass but not such plenty of sheep ox and horse all kind of fruit be very scarce among they not that the ground be uncapable of fruit but because the people be so rude and ignorant in this behalf that very few of they be skilful in plant graft or prune of tree whereof I be easy persuade for I remember that I find among some gardiner of Hea great abundance of fruit of grain they have not much plenty except it be of barley mill and panic they have great abundance of honey which they use in stead of ordinary food but the wax they cast away little regard it because they know not the value thereof likewise there be find in this region certain thorny tree bear a gross kind of fruit not unlike unto those olive which be bring unto we from Spain the say fruit they call in their language arga. of this fruit they make a kind of oil be the fruit (@) arga. of a fulsome and strong savour which they use notwithstanding for sauce and for lamp the manner of live and the food of the people of (@) this people for the most part eat barlie-bread unleavened which be like rather unto a cake then to a loaf this bread be bake in a kind of earthen baking-pan somewhat like unto that wherewith in Italy they use to cover iuncat and dainty dish neither shall you find many in Hea which eat oven-bread they use also a certain unsavoury and base kind of meat which in their language be call Elhasid and be make in manner (@) follow they cast barlie-meale into boil water continual temper and stir the same about with a stick till they perceive it be sufficient sodden then set this pap or hastie-pudding upon the table and pour in some of their countrie-oile all the whole family stand round about the platter and eat the say pap not with spoon but with their hand and finger howbeit in the spring and summer season they temper the say meal with milk and cast in butter in stead of oil and this kind of meat be not usual among they but only at supper for in winter time they break their fast with bread and honey and in summer with milk butter and bread moreover sometime they use to eat sodden flesh whereunto some add onion other bean and some other a kind of season or sauce call by they (@) with they table and tablecloth be quite out of use in stead whereof they spread a certain round mat upon the ground which serve among this rude people both for table cloth and all the apparel and custom of the foresay people of hea. the great part of they be clad in a kind of cloath-garment make of wool after the manner of a coverlet call in their language elchise and not unlike unto those coverlet or blanket which the italian lie upon their bed in these kind of mantle they wrap themselves and then be they gird with a woollen girdle not about their waste but about their hip they have also a certain piece of cloth of ten handful in length and two in breadth wherewith they use to adorn their head these kind of ornament or head-tire they die with the juice of walnut-tree-roote be so put upon their head that their crown be always bare none of they wear any cap except it be a old man or a man of learning albeit learned man be very rare among they which cap of they be double and round not much unlike to the cap of certain physician in Italy you shall seldom find any linen shirt or smock among this people and that as I suppose either because their soil will yield no flax nor hemp or else for that they have none skilful in the art of weave their seat whereon they sit be nought else but certain mat make of hair and rush for bed they use a certain kind of hairy flockbed or mattress some of which bed be ten else in length some more and some less yea some you shall find of twenty else long but none long one part of these mattress they lie upon instead of a couch and with the residue they cover their body as it be with (@) and coverlet in the springtime always they lay the hairy side next unto their body because it be somewhat warm but in sommer-time not regard that side they turn the smooth side upward and thereon they rest themselves likewise of such base and harsh stuff they make their cushion be much like unto the stuff which be bring hither out of Albania and Turkey to serve for horse-cloathe the woman of Hea go common with their face uncover use for their housewifery turn vessel and cup of wood their platter dish and other their kitchen-vessel be for the most part of earth you may easy discern which of they be marry and who be not for a unmarried man must always keep his beard shave which after he be once marry he suffer to grow at length the say region bring forth no great plenty of horse but those that it do bring forth be so nimble and full of mettle that they will climb like cat over the steep and craggy mountain these horse be always unshod and the people of this region use to till their ground with no other cattle but only with horse and ass you shall here find great store of dear of wild goat and of hare howbeit the people be no whit delight in hunt which be the cause as I think why the say beast do so multiply and it be somewhat strange that so many river run through the country they shall have such scarcity of watermil but the reason be because every household almost have a wooden mill of their own whereat their woman usual grind with their hand no good learning nor liberal art be here to be find except it be a little skill in the law which some few challenge unto themselves otherwise you shall find not so much as any shadow of virtue among they they have neither physician nor surgeon of any learning or account but if a disease or infirmity befall any of they they present fear or cauterize cauterize the sick party with red hot iron even as the italian use their horse howbeit some chirurgeon there be among they who duty and occupation consist only in circumcise of their male child they make no soap in all the country but instead thereof they use to wash with lee make of ash they be at continual war but it be civil and among themselves insomuch that they have no leisure to fight against other nation whosoever will travel into a (@) country must take either a harlot or a wife or a religious man of the contrary part to bear he company they have no regard at all of justice especial in those mountain which be destitute of governor or prince yea even the principal man of this very region of Hea which dwell within town and city dare scarce prescribe any law or good order unto the people so great be their insolency in all place the city of Hea be few in number but they have great store of village town and most strong castle whereof God will we will hereafter speak more at large of tedn one of the city of hea. the ancient city of tedn be build by the african upon a most beautiful and large plain which they environ with a lofty wall build of brick and lime likewise a certain river run forth of the city serve to fill up the wall ditch in this city be certain merchant that sell cloth wherein the people of the same place be clad here be likewise utter a kind of cloth which be bring thither out of Portugal howbeit they will admit no artificer but tailor butcher carpenter and a few goldsmiths which be jew in this city there be no inn stove nor wine-tavern so that whatsoever merchant go thither must seek out some of his acquaintance to remain withal but if he have no friend (@) acquaintance in the town than the principal inhabitant there cast lot who shall entertain the strange merchant insomuch that no stranger be he never so mean shall their manner of entertain stranger at tedn want friendly entertainment but be always sumptuous and honourable accept of but whosoever be receive as a guest must at his departure bestow some gift upon his host in token of thankfulness to the end he may be more welcome at his next return howbeit if the say stranger be no merchant he may choose what great man house he will to lodge in be bind at his departure to no recompense nor gift to be short if any beggar or poor pilgrim the same way he have some (@) provide for he in a certain hospital which be found only for the relief of poor people and be maintain at the common charge of the city in the midst of the city stand a ancient temple be most sumptuous build and of a huge bigness which be think to be found at the very same time when as the king of Maroco bare rule in those place this temple have a great cistern stand in the midst thereof and it have many priest and such kind of people which give attendance thereunto and store it with thing necessary in this city likewise be diverse other temple which (@) they be but little yet be they most clean and decent keep there be in this city about a hundred family of jew who pay no yearly tribute at all but only bestow each of they some gratuity upon this or that nobleman who they think to favour they most to the end they may enjoy their favour still and the great part of the say city be inhabit with jew these jew have certain minting-house wherein they stamp silver coin of which 170. asper as they call they do weigh one ounce be like unto the common coin of Hungary save that this Asper be square and the hungarian coin be round the inhabitant of tedn be free from all tribute and yearly taxation howbeit if any sum of money be want for the erection of a public building or for any other common use the people be forthwith assemble and each man must give according to his ability this city be leave desolate in the year 918. of the Hegeira at what time all the citizen tedne leave desolate thereof flee unto the mountain and from thence to Maroco the reason they say be because the inhabitant be inform that their next neighbour the arabian join in league with the Portugal captain who as then hold the town of Azaphi and promise to deliver tedn into the hand of the christian which thing so daunt the citizen that they present seek to save themselves by flight myself I remember see this city utter ruin and deface the wall thereof be lay even with the ground the house be destitute of inhabitant and nothing at that time to be there see but only the nest of raven and of other bird all this I see in the 920. year of the Hegeira of tecule a town of hea. upon the foot of a hill eighteen mile eastward from tedn stand a town call by the african tecule and contain about one thousand household hard by this town run a certain river on both side whereof be most pleasant garden and all kind of tree within the wall of the say town be many pit or well whereout they draw most clear and pleasant water here also be to be see a most stately and beautiful temple as likewise four hospital and a monastery of religious person the inhabitant of this town be far wealthy than they of tedn for they have a most famous port upon the ocean sea common call by merchant goz. they have likewise great abundance of corn and pulse which grow in the fruitful field adjacent these also of tecule send wax into Portugal to be sell and they be very curious in their apparel (@) and about the furniture of their (@) when I myself be at tecule I find there a certain nobleman who be the precedent or chief of their senate this nobleman duty be both to procure tribute which be yearly to be pay unto the arabian and also to make atonement and reconciliation between they when they be at odds this man have gather great riches unto himself which he employ rather to purchase friend then to fill his coffer most liberal he be unto the poor most bountiful and favourable unto all his citizen insomuch that all man do reverence and honour unto he as unto their father and best protector of who courtesy I myself also make trial and be not mean but very sumptuous entertain by he I remain with he for a certain time and read in his house diverse history of african matter this good man together with his son be slay in a skirmish against the portugal which be do according to our computation in the year of the Hegeira 923. that be to say in the year of our lord 1514. after which misfortune tecule destroy by the portugal we hear that the city be raze that the people be part of they put to flight part lead captive and the residue (@) by the enemy all which particular we have declare more at large in that book which be now late 1514. print and publish concern african affair of Hadecchis a town of hea. the city of Hadecchis be situate upon a plain stand eight mile southward of tecule it contain seven hundred family and the wall church and house throughout this whole city be all build of free stone through the midst of the town run a large and fair stream have many vine and gallery on both side thereof there be many jew artificer in this city the citizen here go somewhat decent apparel their horse be good most of they exercise merchandise also they stamp a kind of coin and they have certain yearly fair or whereunto the nation adjoin do usual resort here be to be sell great store of cattle of butter oil iron and cloth and their say mart last fifteen day their woman be very beautiful white of colour fat comely and trim but the man bear a most savage mind be so extreme possess with jealousy that whosoever they find but talk with their wife they present go about to murder they they have no judge nor learned man among they nor any which can assign unto the citizen any function and magistracy according to their worthiness so that he rule like a king that excel the residue in wealth for matter of religion they have certain mahometan priest to administer they who neither pay tribute nor yearly custom even as they who we last before mention here I be entertain by a certain courteous and liberal mind priest who be exceed delight with arabian poetry wherefore be so love entertain I read unto he a certain brief treatise as touch the same argument which he accept so kind at my hand that he will not suffer i to depart without great and bountiful reward from hence I travel unto Maroco and afterward I hear that this town also in the year of the Hegeira Hadecchis sack by the portugal 922. be sack by the portugal and that the inhabitant be all flee into the next mountain and the very same year I return home to visit my 1513. native country which be in the year of our lord 1513. of Ileusugaghen a town of hea. this town be situate upon the top of a certain high mountain which be distant eight mile to the south of Hadecchis it consist of about two hundred family and by the foot of the hill run a small river here be no garden at all nor yet any tree which bear fruit the reason whereof be as I suppose because the inhabitant be such slothful and gross people that they regard nothing but their barley and their oil they be at continual war with their next neighbour which be perform with such monstrous bloodshed and manslaughter that they deserve rather the name of beast then of man they have neither judge priest nor lawyer to prescribe any form of live among they or to govern their commonwealth wherefore justice and honesty be quite banish out of their habitation those mountain be altogether destitute of fruit howbe it they abound great with honey which serve the inhabitant both for food and for merchandise to sell in the neighbour-country and because they know not what service to put their wax unto they cast it forth together with the other excrement of honey the say town of Ileusugaghen have a very small and narrow chapel which will scarce contain a hundred person whither notwithstanding the people do so slow resort that they need not to have any great so much do they neglect religion and piety whensoever they go abroad they carry a dagger or a iavelin about with they and you shall often hear of the slaughter of some one or other of their citizen no people under heaven can be more wicked treacherous or lewd addict than this people be I remember that I myself go once thither with a Seriffo or mahometan priest who make challenge unto the government of Hea to the end that we may arbitrate certain strife and contention for it be incredible to report what cruel war partly for murder and partly for robbery be practise among they but because the Seriffo have bring no lawyer with he nor any judge to decide controversy he will needs that I shall take that office upon i immediate the townsman come flock about we one complain that his neighbour have slay eight of his kindred and family his neighbour on the contrary allege that the former have slay ten of his family wherefore according to the ancient custom he demand to have a sum of money give he for say he there be some recompense due unto i sithence ten of my people have be slay and but eight of this my neighbour whereunto the other reply that the say ten person be just slay because they go about by violence to dispossess he of a certain piece of ground which his father have leave he by inheritance but that his eight be murder only for unjust revenge against all equity and law with these and such like frivolous allegation we spend that whole day neither can we decide any one controversy about midnight we see a great throng of people meet in the marketplace who make there such a bloody and horrible conflict that the sight thereof will have affright any man be he never so hard heart wherefore the say Seriffo fear lest those lewd varlet will make some treacherous conspiracy against he and think it better to depart thence immediate then to expect the conclusion of that fray we take our journey from that place to a town call aghilinghighil of the town of teijeut in hea. moreover the tower of Teijeut stand upon a plain ten mile westward of Ileusugaghen contain about three hundred household the house and wall of this town be build of brick the townsman exercise husbandry for their ground be most fertile for barley albeit it will scarce yield any other grain they have pleasant and large garden store with vine figtree and peach-tree also they have great abundance of goat about this town be many lion whereby the townsman be not a little endamage for they pray continual upon their goat and upon other of their cattle certain of we upon time come into these part for want of a lodging be constrain to repair unto a little cottage which we escry be so old that it be in danger of fall have provide our horse of provender we stop up all the door and passage of the say cottage with thorn and wood as circumspect as possible we can these thing happen in the month of April at what time they have extreme heat in the same country wherefore we ourselves get up to the top of the house to the end that in our sleep we may be near unto the open air about midnight we espy two monstrous lion who be draw thither by the send of our horse and endeavour to break down that fence of thorn which we have make whereupon the horse be put in fear keep such a neigh and such a stir that we misdoubt least the rot cottage will have fall and least ourselves shall have become a prey unto the lion but so soon as we perceive the day begin to break we forthwith saddle our horse and hie we unto that place where we know the prince and his army lay not long after follow the destruction of this town for the great part of the townsman be slay the rest be take by the portugal and be carry Teijeut destroy by the portugal as captive into Portugal this be do in the year of the Hegeira 920 and in the year of our lord 1513. of Tesegdelt a town of hea. the town of Tesegdelt be situate upon the top of a certain high mountain and natural environ with a high rock in stead of a wall contain more than eight hundred family it be distant from teijeut southward about twelve mile and it have a river run by it the name whereof I have forget about this town of Tesegdelt be most pleasant garden and orchard replenish with all kind of tree and especial with walnut-tree the inhabitant be wealthy have great abundance of horse neither be they constrain to pay any tribute unto the arabian there be continual war between the arabian and they and that with great bloodshed and manslaughter on both part the village lie near unto Tesegdelt do usual carry all their grain thither lest they shall be deprive thereof by the enemy who make daily inroad and invasion upon they the inhabitant of the foresay town be much the courtesy of the citizen of Tesegdelt towards stranger (@) unto courtesy and civility and for liberality and bounty unto stranger they will suffer themselves to be inferior to none other at every gate of Tesegdelt stand certain watchman or warder which do most love receive all incommer inquire of they whether they have any friend and acquaintance in the town or no if they have none then be they conduct to one of the best inn of the town and have have entertainment there according to their degree and place they be friendly dismiss and whatsoever his expense come to the stranger pay nought at all but his charge be defray out of the common purse this people of Tesegdelt be subject also unto jealousy howbeit they be most faithful keeper of their promise in the very midst of the town stand a most beautiful and stately temple whereunto belong a certain number of mahometan priest and to the end that justice may be most due administer among they they have a very learned judge who decide all matter in the common wealth except criminal cause only their field where they use to sow their corn be for the great part upon the mountain unto this very town I travel with the foresay Seriffo in the (@) of the Hegeira 919. that be to say in the year of our lord 1510. a description of the city of tagtess the most ancient city of tagtess be build round and stand upon the top of a hill on the side whereof be certain wind step hew out of the hard rock it be about fourteen mile distant from Tesegdelt by the foot of the say hill run a river whereout the woman of tagtess draw their water neither have the citizen any other drink and although this river be almost six mile from tagtess yet a man will think look down from the city upon it that it be but half a mile distant the way lead unto the say river be cut out of the rock in form of a pair of stair be very narrow the citizen of tagtess be addict unto theft and robbery and be at continual war with their neighbour they have no corne-field nor any cattle but only upon the say mountain they have great store of bore but such scarcity of horse that there be not one almost to be find in the whole city the way through their region be so difficult that they will suffer none to pass by without a public testimonial while I (@) be in that country there come such a swarm of locust that they devour the great part of their corn which be as then ripe insomuch that all the upper part of the ground be cover with locust which be in the year of the Hegeira 919. that be in the year of our lord 1510. the town of Eitdevet fifteen mile southward from tagtess stand another town call Eitdevet be build upon a plain and yet upon the high ground thereof it contain to the number of seven hundred family and have in the midst thereof most clear and cool fountain this town be environ on all side with rock and mighty wood in the say town be jew of all occupation and so i there be which affirm that the first inhabitant of this town come by natural descent from king David but so soon as the mahometan religion have infect that place their own law and religion cease here be great store of most cunning lawyer which be perfect well see in the law and constitution of that nation for I remember that I myself see a very age man who can most ready repeat a whole volume write in their language call by they Elmudevuana that be to say the body of the whole law the say volume be divide into three tome wherein all difficult question be dissolve together with certain counsel or commentary of a famous author which they call (@) they have a kind of tribunal or iudgement-hall wherein all contention happen between the citizen of this place and their neighbour-city be present decide and set through neither do the say lawyer deal only in commonwealth matter but also in case pertain to religion albeit in criminal case the people do not so great credit they for indeed their learning little serve they for that purpose be among they it be my hap to sojourn in the house of a certain lawyer who be a man of great learning this lawyer to the end he may give i more solemn entertainment will needs invite diverse learned man of his own profession to bear we company at supper after supper we have many question propound and among the residue this be one namely whether any man may just sell that person for a bondflave who be nourish by any commodity of the people there be in company at the same time a certain age sire have a grave beard and a reverend countenance unto who each one of they ascribe much honour he they call in their own language Hegazzare which name when I have hear thrice or four time repeat I demand of some that be in presence what be the true signification thereof they tell i that it signify a butcher for say they as a butcher know right well the true anatomy of every part of a beast even so can this age sire most learned dissolve all difficult question and doubt of law this people lead a most miserable and distress life their food be barley bread oil arganicke and goates-flesh they know no use of any other grain but barley their woman be very beautiful and of a lovely hue their man be strong and lusty have hair grow upon their breast and be very liberal and exceed jealous of culeihat Elmuridin that be to say the rock of disciple a castle of hea. this culeihat Elmuridin be a castle build upon the top of a certain high mountain have round about it diverse other mountain of a like height which be environ with craggy rock and huge wood there be no passage unto this castle but only a certain narrow path upon one side of the mountain by the one side thereof stand a rock and upon the other side the mountain of Tesegdelt be within half a mile and it be distant from Eitdevet almost eighteen mile this castle be build even in our time by a certain or renouncer of the mahometan religion call by they Homar seijef who be first a mahometan preacher unto a pestiferous mahometan preacher the people propound unto a great number of disciple and sectary who he have draw to be of his opinion certain new point of religion this fellow see that he prevail so with his disciple that they esteem he for some petie-god become of a false preacher a most cruel tyrant and his government last for twelve year he be the chief cause of the destruction and ruin of the whole province at length he be slay by his own wife because he have unlawful lie with her daughter which she have by her former husband and then be his perverse and lewd deal lay open unto all man for he be report to have be utter ignorant of the law and of all good knowledge wherefore not long after his decease all the inhabitant of the region gather their force together slay every one of his disciple and false sectary howbeit the nephew of the say be leave alive who afterward in the same castle endure a whole year siege of his adversary and repel they insomuch that they be constrain to depart yea even until this day he molest the people of Hea and those which inhabit near unto he with continual war live upon robbery and spoil for which purpose he have certain horseman which be appoint to watch and to pursue traveller sometime take cattle and sometime man captive he have likewise certain gunner who although traveller be a good distance off for the common high way stand almost a mile from the castle will put they in great fear howbeit all people do so deadly hate he that they will not suffer he to till one foot of ground or to bear any dominion without the say mountain this man have cause his grandfather body to be honourable bury in his castle suffer he to be adore of his people as if he be a god pass by that way upon a a treatise write by (@) Leo concern the mahometan religion certain time I escape their very bullet narrow the life religion and manner of the foresay Homar seijef I perfect learn by a disciple of he have at large declare the same in a certain brief treatise which I have write concern the mahometan religion of igilingigil a town of hea. moreover the african in old time build a certain town upon a hill call by the inhabitant igilingigil be distant from eitdevet about six mile southward and contain almost four hundred family in this town be sundry artificer employ themselves only about thing necessary to the end they may make their best gain and advantage thereby their ground be most fertile for barley as likewise they have great abundance of honey and of oil arganicke the passage or way unto this city be very narrow lie only upon one side of the hill and it be so hard and difficult that horse can without great labour and peril go upon it the inhabitant be most valiant people and well exercise in arm maintain continual war against the arabian and that for the most part with very prosperous success by reason of the natural and strong situation of the (@) a more liberal people than this you shall hardly find they general exercise themselves in make of earthen pot and vessel which I think none of their neighhour thereabouts can do of Tefethne a port and most famous mart-towne of hea. near unto the ocean sea stand a city most strong both for situation and building common call Tefethne be westward of ingilingigil about forty mile they say that this town be build by certain african and that it contain more than six hundred household here ship of mean burden may safe harbour themselves and hither the Portugal merchant resort to buy goats-skin and wax corne-field they have none but only certain hill which yield great increase of barley near unto this town run a certain river whereinto the ship put themselves in tempestuous weather the town-wall be build of white hew stone and of brick they gather their yearly custom and subsidy all the whole sum whereof be equal distribute among such citizen as be meet for the war in this town be great plenty of mahometan priest and of judge howbeit for the inquiry of murder and such like crime these judge have no authority for if any kinsman of the slay or wound party meet a punishment of murder with he that do the fact he be present without any judgement to have that be like for like inflict upon he but if he escape that he be banish seven year out of the city at the end of which seven year the malefactor have pay a certain sum of money to the friend of the wound or slay party be afterward receive into favour and account among the number of citizen all the inhabitant of Tefethne be of a most white colour be so addict unto friendship and hospitality that they favour stranger more than their own citizen they have a most stately and rich hospital howbeit those which be there place may for the most part remain in citizen house myself be in company with the Seriffo or mahometan prelate continue for the space of three day among this people which three day seem three year unto i both for the incredible number of flea and also for the most loathsome and intolerable stench of piss and of goat dung for each citizen have a flock of goat which they drive in the daytime to pasture and at night they house they at home in their own habitation yea even before their chamber-doore of the people call idevacal who inhabit the beginning of mount Atlas have hitherto make report of all the city of Hea which be worthy of memory I think good in this place to the end that nothing shall be want in this our discourse which may delight the reader to describe the inhabit mountain also wherefore the great part of the people of headwel upon mountain some where of be call idevacal for so be they name inhabit upon that part of Atlas which stretch itself from the ocean sea eastward as far as igilingigil and this ridge of mountain divide Hea from sus. the breadth of this mountain be three day journey for Tefethne whereat this mountain begin from the north be distant from the town of messa where it end southward as far as I can convenient ride in three day whosoever know this region as well as myself can sufficient bear i witness how it be replenish with inhabitant and countrey-village their ordinary food be barley goates-flesh and honey shirt they wear none at all nor yet any other garment which be sow together for there be no man among they which know how to use the needle but such apparel as they have hang by a knot upon their shoulder their woman wear silver ring upon their ear some three and some more they have silver button of so great a scantling that each one weigh a ounce wherewith they fasten their apparel upon their shoulder to the end it may not fall off the noble and rich sort of people among they wear silver ring upon their finger and leg but such as be poor wear ring only of iron or of copper there be likewise certain horse in this region be so small of stature and so swift as it be wonder here may you find great plenty of wild goat hare and dear and yet none of the people be delight in hunt many fountain be here to be find and great abundance of tree but especial of walnut-tree the great part of this people live after the arabian manner often change their place of habitation a kind of dagger they use which be broad and crooked like a woodknife and their sword be as thick as scythe wherewith they mow hay when they go to the war they carry three or four hunt toil with they in all the say mountain be neither judge priest nor temple to be find so ignorant they be of learning that not one among they either love or embrace the same they be all most lewd and wicked people and apply their mind unto all kind of villainy it be tell the Seriffo in my presence that the foresay mountain be able to afford twenty thousand soldier for a need of the mountain call Demensera this mountain also be a part of Atlas begin from the mountain last before mention and extend itself eastward for the space of about fifty mile as far as the mountain of nifif in the territory of Maroco and it divide a good part of Hea from the region of Sus before name it abound with inhabitant which be of a most barbarous and savage disposition horse they have great plenty they go to war oftentimes with the arabian which border upon they neither will they permit any of the say arabian to come within their dominion there be no town nor castle upon all this mountain howbeit they have certain village and cottage wherein the better sort do hide their head great store of noble man or governor they have in all place unto who the residue be very obedient their ground yield barley and mill in abundance they have every where many fountain which be disperse over the whole province do at length issue into that river which be call in their language Siffaia their apparel be somewhat decent also they possess (@) of iron great quantity of iron which be from thence transport into other place and these people be well give to thrift and good husbandry great number of jew remain in this region which live as stipendary soldier under diverse prince and be continual in arm and they be repute and call by other jew in Africa Carraum that be to say heretic they have store of box of mastic and of high walnut tree unto their argan for so they call a kind of olive which they have they put nut out of which two simple they express very bitter oil use it for a sauce to some of their meat and pour it into their lamp I hear diverse of their principal man avouch that they be able to bring into the field and twenty thousand most expert soldier in my return from Sus they do i exceed honour in regard of certain letter which I deliver unto they from my lord the Seriffo and to manifest their good will towards the say Seriffo they (@) i with most ample gift and gratuity this be do in the 920. year of the Hegeira that be to say in the year of our lord 1520. of the mountain of iron common call gebelelhadih this mountain be not to be account any part of Atlas for it begin northward from the ocean and southward it extend to the river of tensift and divide Hea from Duccala and Maroco the inhabitant be call Regraga upon this hill be waste desert clear fountain and abundance of honey and of oil Arganick but of corn and pulse great scarcity unless they make provision thereof out of Duccala few rich man be here to be find but they be all most devout and religious after their manner upon the top of this mountain be many hermit which live only upon the fruit of certain tree and drink water they be a most faithful and peaceable nation whosoever among they be apprehend for theft or any other crime be forthwith banish the country for certain year so great be their simplicity that whatsoever they see the hermit do they esteem it as a miracle they be much oppress with the often invasion of their neighbour the arabian wherefore this quiet nation choose rather to pay yearly tribute then to maintain war against the say arabian Mahumet the king of Fez direct his troop insomuch that they be constrain to leave their own country and to flee into the mountain but the people of the mountain be aid with Mahumet his force vanquish the arabian so that three thousand of they be slay and fower-score of their horse be bring unto k. Mahumet after which prosperous battle the say mountainer remain free from all tribute I myself while these thing be a do serve the king it be in the year of the Hegeira 921. that be to say in the year of our lord 1512. when this people undertake any war they bring common into the field a army of twelve thousand man of the region of sus. now come the region of Sus to be consider of be situate beyond Atlas over against the territory of Hea that be to say in the extreme part of Africa westward it begin from the ocean sea and southward from the sandy desert on the north it be bound with the utmost town of Hea and on the east with that mighty river whereof the whole region be name wherefore beginning from the west we will describe all those city and place which shall seem to be worthy of memory of the town of messa three small town be build by the ancient african upon the sea shore each be a mile distant from other in that very place where Atlas take his beginning all which three be call by one only name to wit messa and be environ with a wall build of white stone through these three run a certain great river call Sus in their language this river in summer be so destitute of water that a man may easy without peril pass over it on foot but it be not so in the winter time they have then certain small bark which be not meet to sail upon this river the place where the foresay three town
