be situate abound great with palm tree neither have they in a manner any other wealth and yet their date be but of small worth because they will not last above date which will last but one year one year all the inhabitant exercise husbandry especial in the month of September and April what time their river increase and in May their corn grow to ripeness but if in the two foresay month the river increase not according to the wont manner their harvest be then nothing worth cattle be very scarce among they not far from the sea side they have a temple which they great esteem and honour out of which historiographer say that the same prophet of who their great Mahumet foretell shall proceed yea some there be which stick not to affirm that the prophet jonas be cast forth by the whale upon the shore of messa when as he be send to preach unto the the rafter great store of whale and beam of the say temple be of whale bone and it be a usual thing among they to see whale of a huge and monstrous bigness cast up dead upon their shore which by reason of their hugeness and strange deformity may terrify and astonish the beholder the common people imagine that by reason of a certain secret power and virtue infuse from heaven by God upon the say temple each whale which will swim past it can by no mean escape death which opinion have almost persuade i especial when at my be there I myself see a mighty whale cast up unless a certain Jew have tell i that it be no such strange matter for quoth he there lie certain rock two mile into the sea on either side and as the sea move so the whale move also and if they chance to light upon a rock they be easy wound to death and so be cast upon the next shore this reason more prevail with i then the opinion of the people myself I remember be in this region at the same time when my lord the Seriffo bear rule over it be invite by a certain gentleman and be by he conduct into a garden where he show i a whale rib of so great a whale rib of incredible greatness a size that lie upon the ground with the convexe or bow side upward in manner of a arch it resemble a gate the hollow or inward part whereof aloft we can not touch with our head as we ride upon our camel back this rib he say have lie there above a hundred year and be keep as a miracle here may you find upon the seashore great store of amber which the Portugal and Fessan merchant fetch from thence for a very amber mean price for they scarce pay a ducat for a whole ounce of most choice and excellent amber amber as some think be make of whale dung and as other suppose of their or seed which be consolidate and harden by the sea be cast upon the next shore of Teijeut a ancient town of sus. TEijeut be as the report go build by the ancient african in a most pleasant place be divide into three part whereof each one be almost a mile distant from another and they all make a triangle or threesquare this teijeut contain four thousand family and stand not far from the river of sus. the soil adjacent be most fruitful for grain for barley and for all kind of pulse they have here likewise a good quantity of sugar store of sugar grow howbeit because they know not how to press boil and trim it they can have it but black and unsavoury wherefore so much as they can spare they sell unto the merchant of Maroco of Fez and of the land of Negro of date likewise they have plenty neither use they any money beside the gold which be dig out of their own native soil the woman wear upon their head a piece of cloth worth a ducat silver they have none but such as their woman adorn themselves with the least iron-coine use among they weigh almost a ounce no fruit take plentiful upon their soil but only fig grape peach and date neither oil nor olive be here to be find except such as be bring from certain mountain of Maroco a measure of oil be sell at Sus for fifteen ducat which measure contain a hundred and fifty pound italian weight their piece of gold because they have no certain nor proportionable money do weigh seven of they and one three part one ounce their ounce be all one with the italian ounce but their pound contain eighteen ounce and be call in their language Rethl and a hundred Rethl make one such measure of oil as be aforesaid for carry of merchandise from place to place their custom be to pay for a camel load that be for 700. pound of weight 3. piece of gold especial in the spring time for in summer they pay sometime 5. and sometime 6. piece of gold as the time require here be that excellent leather dress which be call leather of Cordovan leather of Maroco Maroco twelve hide where of be here sell for six ducat and at Fez for eight that part of this region which lie towards Atlas have many village town and hamlet but the south part thereof be utter destitute of inhabitant and subject to the arabian which border upon it in the midst of this city stand a fair and stately temple which they call the great and the chief through the very midst whereof they have cause a part of the foresay river to run the inhabitant be stern and uncivil be so continual exercise in war that they have not one day of quiet each part of the city have a several captain and governor who all of they together do rule the commonwealth but their authority continue never above three month which be expire three other be choose in their room their apparel be some what like unto that of the people of Hea save that some of they make their shirt and other of their garment of a certain kind of white stuff a can which be a measure proper to this region contain two else of course cloth be sell for half a piece of good sale for cloth gold but four and twenty else of Portugal or neatherlandish cloth if it be any thing fine be usual sell there for four piece of their gold likewise in this town be many judge and priest which be conversant only in matter of religion but in civil matter he that have most friend obtain great favour whensoever any one be slay all the friend of the slay party do forthwith conspire to kill the murderer which if they can bring to pass then be the malefactor by open proclamation banish out of the city for seven year unless he will in despite of all man continual defend himself by main force they which return from exile before the time prefix be punish in such manner as we will hereafter declare in place convenient but he that return after the seven year be once expire make a feast unto the burghmaster and so be restore again to his former liberty in this city dwell many jew and many notable artificer who be not compel to pay any yearly tribute or taxation at all except it be some small gratuity unto the principal citizen of tarodant a town of sus. the (@) of tarodant build by the ancient african contain about three thousand household it be distant from Atlas southward about four mile and five and thirty mile eastward of Teijeut for the fruitfulness of the soil and manner of the people it be all one with teijeut save that the town be somewhat lesser and the people somewhat more civil for when the family of marin (@) at Fez part of they also inhabit Sus and in those day Sus be the seat of the king of (@) he viceroy there be to be (@) even at this present a certain rock lie upon the (@) which be there place by the foresay king but the say family of marin decay the inhabitant recover their former estate their garment be make partly of linen and partly of woollen and they have many artificer of all sort all authority be commit unto their noble or principal man who govern four by four six month only they be whole give to peace neither do I read that ever they endamage any of their neighbour between this town and Atlas be many village and hamlet but to the south of this town lie the (@) desert the (@) pay large yearly tribute to the end that merchant may have safe and secure passage to and fro this town in our time of the castle of the castle of be build upon the top of Atlas in a most surprise by the portugal impregnable place overagainst that part of the ocean whereinto the river of Sus discharge his stream the soil be most profitable and fruitful this place about twenty year sithence the portugal surprise which cause the inhabitant of Hea and Sus forth with to arm themselves to the end they may recover the castle by main force which be by force take from they wherefore levy a mighty army as well of home-bornes as of stranger they choose for their captain a certain mahometan (@) be a man descend of the family of Mahumet and so besiege the castle but they have unhappy success in this their enterprise for they which come to the siege see that they can not prevail and that so many of their company be slay leave the castle and return home except some few which remain with the Seriffo to the end they may maintain war against the christian even till the last hour the inhabitant of Sus not be desirous to live in warfare allow the Seriffo money for the maintenance of five hundred horse who have with his money hire a great number of soldier and grow famous over all the region at last usurp the government thereof this I know for a certainty that the Seriffo when I come from his court have above three thousand horseman and such number of footman and sum of money as be almost innumerable of Tedsi a town of sus. be a very great town and build many year ago in a most pleasant and fertile place by the african contain more than four thousand family it be distant from tarodant eastward thirty mile from the ocean sea sixty mile and from Atlas twenty here grow store of sugar and of woad great abundance of corn of sugar and of wild woad you shall find in this city many merchant which come out of the land of negro for trafique sake the citizen be great lover of peace and of all civility and they have a flourish commonwealth the whole city be govern by six magistrate which be choose by lot howbeit their government last for sixteen month only the river of Sus be distant three mile from hence here dwell many jew which be most cunning goldsmith carpenter and such like artificer they have a very stately temple and many priest and doctor of the law which be maintain at the public charge every Monday great number of arabian both of the plain and of the mountain come hither to market in the year of the Hegeira 920. this city of their own accord yield themselves into the hand of the Seriffo and here the common council of the whole region be establish of the city of tagavost in all Sus there be no city comparable unto that which be common call tagavost for it contain above eight thousand household the wall thereof be build of rough stone from the ocean it be distant about threescore mile and about fifty mile southward of Atlas and the report be that the african build this city about ten mile from this place lie the river of Sus here be great store of artificer and of shop and the people of tagavost be divide into three part they have continual civil war among themselves and one part have the arabian always on their side who for better pay will take part sometime with one side and sometime with the contrary of corn and cattle here be great abundance but their wool be exceed course in this city be make certain kind of apparel which be usual carry for merchandise once a year to Tombuto to Gualata and to other place in the land of Negro their market be twice every week their attire be somewhat decent and comely their woman be beautiful but their man be of a tawny and swart colour by reason they be descend of black father and white mother in this city such carry the great authority and credit as be account the rich and the mighty I myself remain here thirteen day with the Seriffo his (@) chancellor who go thither of purpose to buy certain (@) for his lord in the year of the Hegeira 919. which be in the year of our lord 1510. of the mountain of Hanchisa this mountain begin westward from Atlas and from thence stretch almost forty mile eastward at the foot of this mountain stand messa with the residue of the region of sus. the inhabitant of this mountain be such valiant footman that one of they will encounter two horseman the soil will yield no corn at all but barley (@) honey there be in great abundance with snow they be almost at all time trouble but how patient and strong they can endure the cold a man may easy guess for that the whole year throughout they wear one single garment only this people my lord the Seriffo attempt often to bring under his subjection howbeit he have not as yet prevail against they of the mountain of Ilalem this mountain begin westward from the mountain aforesaid on the east it abut upon the region of Guzula and southward upon the plain of sus. the inhabitant be valiant have great store of horse they be at continual war among themselves for certain silver mine of silver mine so that those which have the better hand dig as much silver as they can and distribute to every man his portion until such time as they be restrain from dig by other the situation and estate of the region of Maroco this region begin westward from the mountain of Nefisa stretch eastward to the mountain of Hadimei and northward even to that place where the most famous river of tensift and asfinual meet together that be to say upon the east border of hea. this region be in a manner three square be a most pleasant country and abound with many drove and flock of cattle it be green every where and most fertile of all thing which serve for food or which delight the sense of smell or see it be altogether a plain country not much unlike to Lombardie the mountain in this region be most cold and barren insomuch that they will bring forth nought but barley wherefore according to our former order begin at the west part of this region we will proceed in our description eastward of Elgihumuha a town of Maroco upon that plain which be about seven mile distant from Atlas and not far from the river of Sesseva stand a town call by the inhabitant Elgihumuha which be build as they suppose by the african a while after it be bring under the subjection of certain arabian about that very time when the family of Muachidin aforesaid begin to revolt from the kingdom and at this day the ruin and relic of this town can scarce be see the arabian which now dwell thereabouts do sow so much ground only as to supply their own necessity and the residue they let lie untilled and fruitless howbeit when the country thereabouts be in flourish estate the inhabitant pay yearly unto the prince for tribute 100000. ducat and then this town contain above six thousand family travel that way I be most friendly entertain by a certain arabian and have good experience of the people liberality save that I hear of some that they be most treacherous and deceitful of the castle of Imegiagen the castle of Imegiagen be build upon the top of a certain hill of Atlas be so fortify by natural situation that it neither have nor need any wall it stand southward of Elgihumuha as I take it 25. mile this castle be in time pass under the jurisdiction of the noble man of that region until such time as it be take by one Homar essuef a from the mahometan religion as we will afterward declare the say Homar the (@) of Homar essuef use such monstrous tyranny in that place that neither child nor woman big with child can escape his cruelty insomuch that he cause the unborn infant to be rip out of their mother womb and to be murder this be do in the year of the Hegeira 900 and so that place remain destitute of inhabitant in the year 920. of the Hegeira the say region begin to be inhabit anew howbeit now there can but one side of the mountain only be till for the plain underneath be so dangerous both by reason of the daily incursion of the arabian and also of the portugal that no man dare travel that way of the town of Tenessa upon a certain hill of Atlas name Ghedmin stand a town which be build as some report by the ancient african and call by the name of Tenessa be a most strong and defensible place and be distant about eight mile eastward from the river of asifinuall at the foot of the say hill lie a most excellent plain which be it not for the lewd (@) arabian will yield a incomparable crop and because the inhabitant of Tenessa be deprive of this (@) commodity they till only that ground which be upon the side of the mountain and which lie between the town and the river neither do they enjoy that gratis for they yearly pay unto the arabian for tribute the three part of their corn of the new town of Delgumuha upon the top of a certain high mountain be build in our time a most large and impregnable fort be environ on all side with diverse other mountain and call by the inhabitant new Delgumuha beneath the say mountain spring asifinuall which word signify in the african tongue the river of rumour because that break forth by the side of the hill with a monstrous noise it make a most deep gulf much like unto that which the italian call tivoli the say fort contain almost a thousand family it be sometime govern by a certain tyrant which come thither out of the king of Maroco his court here may you find great store of soldier both horseman and fooreman they gather yearly tribute of the people border upon Atlas to the sum of a thousand crown they have always have great league and familiarity with the arabian each of who have accustom to salute and gratify the other with mutual gift for which cause they have oftentimes much provoke the king of Maroco against they they have always be great lover of civility and have wear neat and decent apparel neither shall you find any corner in the whole town which be not well people in this town be plenty of artificer for it be but fifty mile from the city of Maroco upon the say mountain there be great store of garden and orchard which yield the inhabitant yearly they reap likewise barley hemp and cotton and their goat be almost innumerable likewise they have many priest and judge but as touch their mind they be ignorant froward and exceed addict to jealousy in this town I abode certain day with a kinsman of i who while he dwell at Fez be impoverish with extreme study of alchemy be constrain to flee unto this town where in process of time he become secretary unto the governor of the city of Imizmizi upon a certain part of Atlas stand a city call Imizmizi westward it be distant from new Delgumuha about fourteen mile and this city the arabian be report to have build near unto this city lie the common high way to Guzula over the mountain of Atlas be common call Burris that be a way strew with feather because snow fall often thereupon which a man will think rather to be feather then snow not far from this town likewise there be a very fair and large plain which extend for the space of thirty mile even to the territory of Maroco this most fertile plain yield such excellent corn as to my remembrance I never see the like save that the arabian and soldier of Maroco do so much molest the say plain country that the great part thereof be destitute of inhabitant yea I have hear of many citizen that have forsake the city itself think it better to depart then to be daily oppress with so many inconvenience they have very little money but the scarcity thereof be recompense by their abundance of good ground and their plenty of corn in the time of my abode with they I go unto a certain hermit which they call * * * * * * * * * * sidi signify a saint in the arabian tongue sidi canon which famous and worthy man give i such friendly entertainment as I can easy express of the three town of Tumelgast these three town call by the name of Tumelgast be situate upon a plain about thirty mile from Maroco and fourteen mile northward of Atlas be replenish with palmtree vine and all other tree that bear fruit their field be very large and fertile be they not continual waste by the lewd arabian so few be the inhabitant of these three town that I think there be not in all above fifteen family all which be join in affinity and kindred unto the foresay hermit for which cause they be permit to till some part of that plain without pay of any tribute unto the arabian save only that they entertain the arabian when they travel that way their lowly and base habitation a man will take rather to be hogs-cote then dwell place for man hence it be that they be so continual vex with flea gnat and other such vermin their water be exceed salt this province also I peruse in the company of my dear friend sidi (@) who go thither to gather up the tribute of the country on the behalf of the king of Portugal this sidi be appoint governor over all that circuit which be call by they Azafi of the town of Tesrast this town be situate upon the bank of the river Asifelmel it stand westward of Maroco fourteen mile and about twenty mile from Atlas round about this town they have diverse garden and enclosure abound with date and corn and the chief part of the inhabitant earn their live with garden howbeit sometime the increase of their river be so great that it drown all their garden and corne-field and they be by so much the more miserable in regard that the arabian all summertime do possess the whole region devour all thing which the poor husbandman by their great care and industry have provide with these people I make no long tarry but only till I can have well bait my horse howbeit in that short time I hardly escape with life and good from certain arabian thief a most exact description of the great and famous city of Maroco this noble city of Maroco in Africa be account to be one of the great city in the whole world it be build upon a most large field be about fourteen mile distant from Atlas one joseph the son of the first founder of Maroco Tesfin and king of the tribe or people call Luntuna be report to have be the founder of this city at that very time when he conduct his troop into the region of Maroco and settle himself not far from the common high way which stretch from agmet over the mountain of Atlas to those desert where the foresay tribe or people do usual inhabit here may you behold most stately and wonder workmanship for all their building be so cunning and artificial contrive that a man can easy describe the same this huge and mighty city at such time as it be govern by Hali the son of king joseph contain more than 100000. family Maroco in time past contain above 100000. family it have four and twenty gate belong thereto and a wall of great strength and thickness which be build of white stone and lime from this city the river of tensift lie about six mile distant here may you behold great abundance of temple of college of bathstove and of inn all frame after the fashion and custom of that region some be build by the king of the tribe of Luntuna and other by Elmunchidin his successor but the most curious and magnificent temple of all be that in the midst of the city which be build by Hali the first king of Maroco and the son of joseph aforesaid be common call the temple of Hali be joseph howbeit one Abdul-Mumen which succeed he to the end he may utter abolish the name of Hali and may make himself only famous with posterity cause this stately temple of Maroco to be raze and to be re-edify somewhat more sumptuous than before howbeit he lose not only his expense but fail of his purpose also for the common people even till this day do call the say temple by the first and ancient name likewise in this city not far from a certain rock be build a temple by he that be the second usurper over the kingdom of Maroco Mansor the king of Maroco after who death his nephew Mansor enlarge the say temple fifty cubit on all side and adorn the same with many pillar which he command to be bring out of Spain for that purpose under this temple he make a cistern or vault as big as the temple itself the roof of the say temple he cover with lead and at every corner he make leaden pipe to convey rain water into the cistern underneath the temple the turret or steeple be build of most hard and well frame stone like unto Vespasian his at Rome contain in compass more than a hundred else and in height exceed the steeple of Bononia the stair of the say turret or steeple be each of they nine handful in breadth the utmost side of the wall be ten and * * * the thickness of the turret be five the say turret have seven loft unto which the stair ascend be very lightsome for there be great store of window which to the end they may give more light be make broad within than without upon the top of this turret be build a certain spire or pinnacle rise sharp in form of a sugarloaf and contain five and twenty else in compass but in height be not much more than two spear length the say spire have three loft one above another unto every of which they ascend with wooden ladder likewise on the top of this spire stand a golden half moon upon a bar of iron with three sphere of gold under it which golden sphere be so fasten unto the say iron bar that the great be low and the least high it will make a man giddy to look down from the top of the turret for man walk on the ground be they never so tall seem no big than a child of one year old from hence likewise may you plain escry the promontory of Azaphi which notwithstanding be a hundred and thirty mile distant but mountain you will say by reason of their huge bigness may easy be see a far off howbeit from this turret a man may in clear weather most easy see fifty mile into the plain country the inner part of the say temple be not very beautiful but the roof be most cunning and artificial vault the timber be frame and set together with singular workmanship so that I have not see many fair temple in all Italy and albeit you shall hardly find any temple in the whole world great than this yet be it very mean frequent for the people do never assemble there but only upon friday yea a great part of this city especial about the foresay temple lie so desolate and void of inhabitant that a man can without great difficulty pass by reason of the ruin of many house lie in the way under the porch great store of book in old time to be sell in Maroco of this temple it be report that in old time there be almost a hundred shop of sale-booke and as many on the other side over against they but at this time I think there be not one bookseller in all the whole city to be find and scarce be the three part of this city inhabit within the wall of Maroco be vine palmtree great garden and most fruitful corne-field for without their wall they can till no ground by reason of the arabian often inroad know you this for a certainty that the say city be grow to untimely decay and old age for scarce five hundred and six year be past since the first building thereof forasmuch as the foundation thereof be lay in the time of joseph the son of Tesfin that be to say in the 424. year of the Hegeira which decay I can impute to none other cause but to the injury of continual war and to the often alteration of magistrate and of the common wealth after king joseph succeed his son Hali and the son of Hali be ordain governor after his father decease in who time spring up a factious crew by the mean of a certain mahometan preacher name Elmaheli be a man both bear and bring up in the mountain the say Elmaheli have levy a great army wage war against Abraham his sovereign Lord whereupon king Abraham conduct another army against he have marvelous ill success and after the battle end his passage into the city of Maroco be so stop and restrain that he be force with a few soldier which remain yet alive to flee eastward to the mountain of Atlas but Elmaheli not be satisfy with expel his true sovereign out of his own kingdom command one of his captain call Abdul Mumen with the one half of his army to pursue the distress king while himself with the other half lay siege to Maroco the king with his follower come at length unto oran hope there to have renew his force but Abdul Mumen and his great army pursue the say king so narrow that the citizen of oran tell he in plain term that they will not hazard themselves for he wherefore this unhappy king be utter drive to despair set his queen on horseback behind he and so in the night time ride forth of the city but perceive that he be descry and know by his enemy he flee forthwith unto a certain rock stand upon the seashore the miserable death of Abraham king of Maroco and of (@) (@) where set spur to his horse-side he cast himself his most dear spouse and his horse down headlong and be within a while after find slay among the rock and stone by certain which dwell near unto the place wherefore Abdul Mumen have get the victory return in triumphant manner towards Maroco where the foresay Elmaheli be decease before his come in who place Abdul be choose king and mahometan prelate over the forty disciple and take ten person to be of his privy council which be a new invention in the law of Mahumet this Abdul Mumen have besiege the city of Maroco for the space of a whole year at last overcome it and kill Isaac the only son of king Abraham with his own hand he command all the soldier and a good part of the citizen to be slay this man posterity reign from the five hundred sixteen to the six hundred sixty eight year of the Hegeira and at length they be dispossess of the kingdom by a certain exact chronicler of the affair of Maroco and Abdul Malich partly we borrow out of that treatise which ourselves have write concern the law of Mahumet of the town of Agmet the town of Agmet build of old by the african upon the top of a certain hill which begin almost from Atlas be distant from Maroco about four and twenty mile in time past when Muachidin be prince thereof it contain more than six thousand family at what time the people be very civil and have such plenty and magnificence of all thing that many will not stick to compare this town with the city of Maroco it have on all side most (@) garden and great store of vine whereof (@) grow upon the mountain itself and other on the valley by the foot of this hill run a fair river which spring forth of Atlas fall at length into tensift the field which lie near unto this river be say to be so fruitful that it yield every year fifty fold increase the water of this river look always white albeit if a man steadfast behold the say river it may seem unto he in colour to resemble the soil of narnia or the river Niger of Vmbria in Italy and (@) there be which ariver run under the ground to Maroco affirm that the very same river run under ground to Maroco and not to break forth of the earth till it come to a certain place very near unto the say city (@) prince in time past be desirous to know the hide and intricate passage of the say river send certain person into the hollow cave who the better to discern the same carry candle and torch with they but have proceed a little way under ground there meet they such a flaw of wind that blow out their light and perforce drive they back to the great hazard of their life so that they say they never feel the like they affirm likewise that the river be full of rock which the water drive to and fro and by reason of the manifold channel and stream their passage be altogether hinder wherefore that secret remain unknown even till this day neither be there any man so hardy as to attempt the same enterprise again I remember that I read in some history that king joseph which build Maroco be forewarn by the conjecture of a certain ginger that the whole region shall perpetual be vex with war provide by arte-magique that the passage of this river shall always be unknown lest if any enemy shall afterward practice (@) he may cut off the course thereof from the say city near unto this river lie the common high way which cross over mount Atlas to Guzula aregion the desolation of Agmet of Maroco howbeit the city of Agmet which I have now describe unto you have at this day no other inhabitant but wolf fox dear and such other wild beast except only at my be there I find a certain hermit who be attend upon by a hundred person of his own sect all of they be well-horsed and do their best endeavour to become governor and commander but their force be insufficient with this hermit I stay as I remember for the space of ten day and find one among his follower with who I have old (@) and familiarity John Leo student at Fez. for we be certain year fellow-student together at Fez where be of one stand and seniority we hear that book of the mahometan religion expound which be common call the epistle of Nensefi of the town of Hannimei upon that side of Atlas which lie towards the plain country stand a certain town call by the inhabitant Hannimei be about 40. mile eastward of Maroco by which town on the same side of Atlas lie the direct way to Fez. from the say town the river of Agmet be almost fifteen mile distant and the field lie between the say river and town be a most fruitful soil like unto the field adjoin upon the city of Agmet before mention all the region between Maroco and the the (@) of (@) foresay river be in subjection unto the governor of Maroco but from the river unto Hannimei the townsman of Hannimei bear rule this town have a famous young captain who maintain continual war against the governor of Maroco and sometime against the arabian also he have likewise a most ample dominion upon the mountain of Atlas by natural disposition he be right liberal and valiant and have scarce attain to sixteen year of age he slay his own uncle and usurp his government whereof so soon as the arabian have intelligence join three hundred christian horseman which come out of Portugal unto their great force they march on the sudden even to the very gate of the town and the foresay captain with his army contain scarce a hundred horseman with a very few footman meet the arabian and give they such a valiant onset that the great part of they be slay and the christian be so discomfit that as I suppose not one of they return home into Portugal which they say come to pass both by reason that the christian be ignorant of the place and unskilful of the african manner of warfare these thing be do in the 920. year of the Hegeira and in the year of our lord 1511. afterwards be weary by the king of Fez his war which king demand tribute of the town man of Hannimei he be slay with a bullet whereupon the town remain tributary to the king of Fez. yea the decease captain wife deliver as prisoner certain burgess of the town unto the king himself and the king so soon as he have place a lieutenant over Hannimei depart from the same town in the 921. year of the Hegeira and in the year of our lord 1512. of the mountain of Nififa have before describe all the city and town of Maroco it now remain that we brief declare the situation and quality of the mountain there wherefore we will begin with the mountain of Nififa from whence the region of Maroco itself begin westward and be thereby divide from the province of hea. the say mountain have great store of inhabitant and albeit the top thereof be continual cover with snow yet do it yearly afford marvelous increase and abundance of barley the rude people there be so destitute of all humanity and civil behaviour that they do admire not only all stranger but also do even gaze and wonder at their apparel I myself remain two day among they in which space all the people of the town come flock about i great wonder at the white garment which I wear be such as the learned man of our country be usual clad in so that every one be desirous to handle and view this garment of i in two day it be turn from white to black and become all greasy and filthy here one of the townsman be allure with the strangeness and novelty of my sword which I buy at Fez for half a ducat will never leave entreat of i till I have exchange it with he for a horse which cost as himself affirm above ten ducat the reason of which fond and childish behaviour I think to be because they never travail unto Fez nor to any other city and be they never so desirous to travail yet dare they not adventure upon the common high way in regard of the great number of robber and thief of honey goat and oil Arganick they have wonder store for in this mountain begin the say oil to be put in use of the mountain call seem at the bound of Nififa a certain other mountain call by the inhabitant seem take his original and these two mountain be separate by the river of Sefsava seem extend eastward almost 20. mile the inhabitant whereof be most base and witless people great store of spring and fountain be here to be find the snow be perpetual all good law civility and honesty be quite banish from hence except perhaps the people be move thereunto by the advice of some stranger who they find to be of a modest and sober disposition here be entertain by a certain religious man of the same place who be have in great reputation by the people I be constrain to eat of such gross meat as the say people be accustom unto to wit of barley meal mingle with water and of goats-flesh which be extreme tough and hard by reason of the stalenes and long continuance after supper we have no other bed but the bare ground to lie upon the next morning be ready to take horse and desirous to depart fifty of the people come about i lay open each man their cause and suit unto i as our people use to do before a judge unto who I answer that I have never in all my life either know or hear of the manner and custom of that region forthwith come one of the chief man among they affirm that it be their custom never to dismiss any stranger till he have both hear and thorough decide all the quarrel and controversy of the inhabitant which word he have no soon John Leo constrain to play the judge utter but immediate my horse be take from i wherefore I be constrain for nine day and so many night long to abide the penury and misery of that region moreover my trouble be the great for that in such abundance of suit and affair there be not one man present which can set down so much as a word in writing wherefore I myself be fain to play both the judge and the notary upon the eight day they all of they promise to bestow some great reward upon i wherefore the night follow seem unto i a year long for I be in good hope the next morrow to have receive a mass of gold from my client so soon as the next day begin to dawn they place i in a certain church-porch whither after a usual and short prayer end each man full reverent present his gift unto i here some offer i a cock other bring i nut and onion and some other bestow a handful of garlic upon i the principal and headman among they present i with a goat and so by reason that there be no money in all the say mountain they proffer i not one farthing for my pain wherefore all the say gift I bequeath unto my host for his worthy entertain of i and this be all the notable reward which I reap in regard of so great and intolerable pain all thing be thus dispatch they send fifty horseman to accompany and guard i from thief in that dangerous way of the mountain call Seusava this mountain of Seusava take his beginning where seem end out of which spring a certain river have one name with the say mountain from whence it proceed never be the top of this mountain see destitute of snow the inhabitant lead a brutish and savage life wage continual war with their next neighbour for which purpose they use neither sword javelin nor any other warlike instrument but only certain sling out of which they discharge stone after a strange and wonder manner their victual consist of barley honey and goates-flesh in the same mountain great multitude of jew exercise handycrafte do inhabit likewise they make soap yron-hooke and horseshoe diverse mason be here to be find also they build their wall of no other matter but only of rough stone and lime and the roof of their house they use to cover with thatch neither have they any other kind of lime or brick they have among they also abundance of learned man and of skilful lawyer who counsel they use at all time among who I find some who have heretofore be my fellow-student at Fez and for our old acquaintance sake give i most courteous entertainment and to the end I may escape the danger of thief they conduct i a good part of my way of the mountain call upon this most lofty and cold mountain there be nothing almost to be find but continual snow and wood the inhabitant wear white cap and the region in all place be full of spring and fountain out of the say mountain spring a river which in the discourse before-going we call asifinuall all over this mountain be most deep and hollow cave wherein every year for the three cold month of November januarie and February they usual winter their cattle lay up so much fodder namely hay and the leaf of certain tree as they think will suffice they most of their victual be bring unto they from the next mountain because their own soil yield no come at all only in the spring time and in summer they have good plenty of new cheese and butter their old age they bear most lusty and stout sometime at ninety and sometime at a hundred year they give attendance to their cattle all their life long neither do they at any time or seldom see any stranger they wear no shoe at all but certain sandal only to defend the sole of their foot and their leg they wrap in a certain piece of cloth or list instead of a hose to keep themselves from the injury of the snow of the mountain call (@) this high and cold mountain have very many inhabitant upon the top whereof stand a town which be call by the name of the mountain itself in this town be great store of dweller and a most stately and beautiful temple it have likewise a most pleasant and (@) river this town be adorn with the monument of * * * * or Elmaheli Elmahdi who be in time past a most learned mahometan priest and of Abdul Mumen his disciple and albeit the inhabitant be account heretic by all other mahometan yet be there no kind of learning which they will not arrogate unto themselves because perhaps they be well read in the work of Elmahdi who be notwithstanding the ringleader of all the say heretic so that if any stranger come among they they present challenge he to dispute in matter of learning in their apparel they go very ragged and beggarly by reason that they have no tailor in the whole town their commonwealth be govern after a wild and savage manner albeit they have a certain priest which use all the policy and mean he can to bring it into good order their victual be barley-bread and oil of olive likewise they have great store of nut and of pine-tree of the
