pay unto the governor of this mountain great sum of money as concern religion they follow they especial which be call Carrain the top of this mountain be continual cover with snow when I first behold this mountain I think it have be cloud so great be the height thereof the side of this mountain be altogether destitute of herb and tree be in many place store with excellent white marble which the people may dig and make a good commodity thereof be they not so sluggish and so ignorant in hew and polish of the fame in this place be many pillar and arch which be most artificial and sumptuous build by those mighty prince who we have often before make mention of which pillar they will have use for the build of water-conduit have they not be hinder by the violence of war to be brief in the say mountain I see many notable thing whereof I will here make no discourse at all partly because they be out of my remembrance and partly for avoid tediousness to the reader because I have determine to pass over these small matter and to proceed unto great of the mountain call Adimmei from Hanteta begin another huge and high mountain call by the inhabitant Adimmei extend eastward to the river of Teseut upon this mountain stand that city the prince whereof as we say before be slay in battle against the king of Fez. this mountain be well store with inhabitant and abound with wood which bring forth acorn olive and quince the people here inhabit be most valiant possess beast and cattle of all sort their air be very temperate and their soil exceed fruitful spring they have great plenty and also two river issue forth of the say mountain whereof in due place we will discourse more at large wherefore have describe all the city and mountain of Maroco border southward upon Atlas let we now pass over the say mountain of Atlas and take a view of the region beyond it common call Guzzula of the region of Guzzula this region be exceed populous westward it abut upon Ilda a mountain of Sus northward it join unto Atlas and eastward it stretch unto the region of hea. it be inhabit with savage and fierce people be most needy of money and yet abound great in cattle great store of copper and iron be here dig out of mine and here be brazen (@) and copper (@) vessel make which be carry into other country to be sell and these vessel they exchange for linen and woollen cloth for horse and for other ware necessary for the say region in all this whole region there be neither town nor castle environ with wall great village they have which contain many of they more than a thousand family a piece they have neither king nor governor to prescribe any law unto they but every one be his own captain and commander whereupon they be at continual war among themselves neither have they any truce at all but three day (@) war (@) (@) only every week during which time every man may safe and free bargain with his enemy and may travel whither he list but these day of truce be past the wretched people of this region do continual commit most horrible slaughter the foresay day of truce a certain hermit appoint unto they who they honour and reverence like a god this hermit with one eye I myself see and find he to be a trusty sincere courteous and most liberal person the common attire of the people of Guzzula be a woollen jacket straight to their body and without (@) they wear crooked broad and two-edged dagger and their sword be like unto the sword of hea. once every year they have a fair of two month long all which time though the number of merchant be never so great they give free entertainment for merchant free entertainment unto all such as either bring ware with they or come thither to fetch away their ware when the time of their fair approach they forthwith make truce and each faction appoint a captain over a hundred soldier to the end they may keep themselves in safety and may defend their say fair from the invasion and injury of all lewd person if any offence be commit the captain immediate give sentence upon the guilty person and whosoever be convict of theft be forthwith slay like a brute beast and his thief carcase be throw out to be devour of dog wild beast and ravenous fowl the say fair be keep in a certain plain or valley between two hill all the ware be contain in tent and in certain cottage make of bough so that each particular kind of merchandise have a several place to lie in by itself they which sell drove of cattle be remove far from the tent and every tent have a cottage make of bough belong thereunto for their principal and head man to repose themselves in and in the say cottage or bower be merchant stranger as we note before free entertain and bourd also they have certain cater and purveyor among they which make provision of victual and take upon they the friendly and well entertain of stranger and albeit a huge deal of money be spend for this behalf yet make they a good gain thereof for thither do resort all the merchant of that region for traffic sake yea and a great number out of the land of negro who bring with they marvelous plenty of all kind of ware and although they be man of a dull and gross capacity yet be they very industrious in govern and maintain the say fair the beginning whereof be upon the birthday of that great deceiver Mahumet that be upon the twelve day of their month call Rabih which be the three Haraba of the year according to their account I myself be present at this fair in the company of my lord the (@) for the space of fifteen day in the year of the Hegeira 920. which be in the year of our lord 1511. abriefe description of the region of Duccala this region begin westward from the river of tensift northward it be bound with the ocean sea the south part thereof lie upon the river of habid and the east part abut upon the river Ommirabih it be three day journey long and about two day journey broad very populous it be the inhabitant be a rude people and most ignorant of all civility and humanity wall city it have but a few of all which we will in their due place particular discourse neither will we by God help omit any thing which may seem worthy of memory of the town of Azaphi it be build by the african and stand upon the shore of the ocean sea contain four thousand family inhabitant there be great store be for the most part very uncivil and barbarous in time pass there dwell many jew in this town which exercise diverse handicraft their soil be exceed fertile but so gross be their own unskilfulness and negligence that they know neither how to till their ground to sow their corn or to plant vineyard except perhaps some few of they who will seem to be more provident than the residue sow a quantity of potherb in their small garden after the king of Maroco give over the government of the say region the city of Azafi be usurp by certain which be say to fetch their original from Farchon howbeit in our day the say city be govern by a certain prince call this man for a greedy and ambitious desire of reign murder his own uncle after who death he govern the town for certain year he have a daughter of most excellent beauty who fall in love with a certain courtier who name be Hali be son unto one by the help of her mother and her wait maid enjoy oftentimes the company of her paramour which when her father have intelligence of he rebuke his wife threaten death unto she if she reform not the manner of her daughter howbeit afterward he dissemble his fury but the mother thorough know her husband intent tell her daughter paramour that the prince be not to be trust and therefore advise he to take heed unto himself whereupon Hali fear lest some mischief may light upon he begin to determine with himself the prince death and for the occasion of the prince of Azafilin his death his associate in this conspiracy he take a trusty friend of he who have be most familiar with he from his childhood and be captain over a certain band of footman wherefore both of they be alike mischievous bend against their prince expect nothing else but a fit place and opportunity to put their bloody determination in practice contrariwise the king seek by all mean a occasion to effect his purpose send word unto Hali upon a certain festival day that after their mahometan devotion be finish he shall come and walk with he appoint a place where he have lay a troop of man in ambush to kill Hali at his come which be do he go to church Hali suspect no harm at all tell his associate that now be the time wherein they may bring their purpose to effect and this intent of they they forthwith declare unto ten other of their adherent and to the end that the whole matter may go secure and certain forward they present assemble a great multitude of footman which they feign that they will send the next day unto Azamor that if they be constrain to fly they may have aid and succour in a readiness all their complice be arm they come to church at the very same time when as the king with all his train be enter thereinto and have place himself next unto the mahometan preacher the church be full of auditor and the king have his guard attend upon he who because they know the two foresay young gentleman to be very familiar with the king suspect none evil but suffer they to draw near unto his person wherefore one of the say young courtier as though he the prince of Azafi slay as he be hear of a mahometan sermon will have do obeizance unto the king come before he but Hali get in at his back and stab he through with a dagger and at the very same instant the other thrust he in with his sword and so this unhappy king imbrue in his own blood give up the ghost the king guard go about to apprehend the author of this fact but be overmatch by the contrary part and suspect lest the people be author of this conspiracy they seek to save themselves by flight and after they follow all the rest of the assembly till the author of the say murder be leave alone they also immediate come forth and persuade the people with many word that they have slay the king for none other cause but only in regard that he have attempt the utter overthrow both of themselves and of the whole people the citizen be to too credulous advance the two foresay conspirator to the government of the kingdom howbeit they agree not long thereabouts but the commonwealth be diverse toss hither and thither sometime incline to one and sometime to another wherefore the Portugal merchant which usual frequent that city in great number write unto their king to send forthwith a army of soldier thither for they be in good hope that he shall most easy and with small disadvantage win the say city howbeit the king be nothing move with this message of they will not send any force at all till he be more certain inform by his say merchant touch the death of the king of Azaphi and the dissension between the two new governor as also that they have make such a compact with a certain captain of the contrary faction that it be the easy matter in the world for he to conquer the town for they have build they a very strong castle upon the seashore wherein their merchandise may safe be bestow for the portugal have persuade the townsman that during the great tumult about the king death they be all of they in danger to lose both their life and good wherefore into this castle among their vessel of oil and other ware they cunning convey gun and all other kind of warlike instrument but the townsman be ignorant here of exact nothing of the portugal save only custom due for their ware now after the portugal have sufficient provide themselves of all kind of armour and warlike munition they seek by all mean a occasion to fight with the citizen at length it come to pass that a certain Portugal servant buy meat in the city do so provoke a butcher that after much quarrel they fall to blow whereupon the servant feel himself hurt thrust the butcher with his sword and lay he along upon the cold earth and then flee speedy to the castle wherein he know the merchant to be the people immediate rise up in arm and run all of they with one consent unto the castle to the end they may utter destroy it and cut the throat of all they which be therein but the gun and crossbow which be there in a readiness make such havoc among the townsman that it can be but they be great daunt at this first encounter there be a hundred and fifty citizen slay outright howbeit the residue will not therefore give over but give the castle daily assault at length the king of Portugal send aid unto his subject to wit five thousand footman two hundred horseman with a great number of gun which force when the citizen see to approach they present betake themselves to their foot and flee unto the mountain of Benimegher neither dare any man stay in the town but only he that be the author of build the castle and so it (@) win by the portugal come to pass that the Portugal force win the town without any peril or labour soon after the general of the whole army send the builder of the castle unto the king of Portugal but the king send he with a certain number of attendant back again to Azafi and appoint he governor of all the region adjacent for the Portugal king be not acquaint with their custom neither do he sufficient know how they govern their commonwealth soon after ensue the miserable desolation and ruin not only of the city but of the whole region thereabouts in this discourse we have be somewhat tedious to the end we may show of how great evil a woman may be the instrument and what intolerable mischief be breed by dissension these thing be a do as I remember John Leo ten year old at the win of (@) when myself be but ten year old and be fowerteene year of age I have some conference with the Portugal captain aforesaid this captain with a army of five hundred portugal and more than twelve thousand arabian horseman give battle to the king of Maroco conquer all the foresay province on the behalf of his master the Portugal king in the year of the Hegeira 920. as in our brief treatise concern the mahometan religion we will declare more at large of a town in Duccala this town be situate from Azafi about 20. mile and be say to have be build by the goth at the very same time when they possess the whole region of Duccala but now it be utter lay waste howbeit the field belong thereto be in subjection unto certain arabian which dwell in the say province of Duccala of tit a city in Duccala this ancient city of tit build of old by the african upon the ocean sea-shoare be about twenty mile distant from Azamur it have most large and fruitful field belong unto it the inhabitant be man of a gross conceit who regard neither husbandry nor civility their apparel indeed be somewhat decent by reason that they continual have so great traffic with the portugal at the the city of tit tributary unto the king of Portugal same time when Azamur be subdue this city also yield itself unto the king captain and for certain year pay tribute unto the king in our time the king of Fez attempt to set Duccala at liberty howbeit not speed of his purpose he cause a certain Christian which be his own treasurer and a Jew to be hang and that company which remain with he he bring unto Fez give they a certain portion of ground to dwell upon which be destitute of inhabitant be distant about twelve mile from Fez. of the famous city of Elmedina in Duccala ELmedina be in a manner the chief city of the whole region be according to the manner there environ with wall of no great force the inhabitant be homely as well in wit and behaviour as in apparel wear such cloth as be weave in their own country their woman wear certain silver ornament the man be valiant and have great store of horse they be all of they banish by the king of Fez out of his dominion for that he suspect they to be friend to the portugal for he have hear that a certain governor of that region have counsel his subject to pay tribute unto the Portugal king this governor I see barefoot lead so miserable captive that I can scarce refrain from tear because he do not aught upon treachery but be constrain for good man he think it much better to pay a little tribute unto the portugal then sudden to lose both his life and his good for the restore of who unto his former liberty diverse nobleman great labour and so at length for a great sum of money he be release but afterward the city remain void of Elmedina leave desolate inhabitant about the year of the Hegeira 921. of the town of Duccala call Centumputei this town be build upon a rock of excellent marble in the suburb whereof be certain cave wherein the inhabitant use to lay up their corn which be there so wonderful preserve that it will continue a hundred year without any ill savour or corruption of the number of corn preserve 100 year which cave resemble pit or well the town itself be call the inhabitant be of small reckon or account have no artificer dwell among they but certain jew when the king of Fez have force the inhabitant of Elmadin to come into his dominion he attempt also to bring thither the inhabitant of this town but they refuse to go into a strange place choose rather to inhabit near unto the town of Azafi then to forsake their own native soil which when the king understand he present cause the town to be sack wherein nothing be find but corn honey and other thing of small value of the town of subeit in the same region svbeit be a small town build upon the south side of the river of Ommirabih it be distant from Elmadin about forty mile and be say to be subject unto certain arabian dwell in Duccala honey and corn they have great abundance but such be their unskilfulness and ignorance that they have neither garden nor vineyard at the same time when Bulahuan be win the king of Fez bring all the people of subeit into his dominion and allot unto they a certain piece of ground near unto Fez which be never before inhabit so that subeit remain waste and void of inhabitant even until this day of the town of Temeracost also in Duccala near unto the river Ommirabih stand a certain small town which be build by the founder of Maroco from who the name thereof be think to be derive inhabitant it have great store and contain more than four hundred family it be subject in time pass unto the people of but Azamur be spoil by the portugal this town also come to nought and the people hereof go to Elmadin of the town call this town be distant about thirty mile from Azamur be situate near unto the river Ommirabih it be well people and contain about three hundred family in time past it be subject unto the inhabitant of Duccala but after the sack of Azafi Hali which fight against the portugal for certain day lay with his army in this town but afterward be repel thence by the king of Fez the town become so waste and desolate that from thencefoorth it be a habitation for owl and bat of the town of Bulahuan this town likewise stand upon the bank of Ommirabih and contain about five hundred family in time past it have most noble and worthy inhabitant especial in that street which lie next unto the river upon the high way to Maroco in this town be a famous hospital build which have many room and mansion wherein all stranger travail that way be sumptuous and free entertain at the common charge of the town the inhabitant be most rich both in cattle and corn every cititizen almost have a 100 yoke of ox and some of they yearly reap two thousand some three thousand measure of corn so that the arabian do carry grain from thence sufficient to serve they all the year follow in the 919. year of the Hegeira the king of Fez send his brother to govern and defend the region of Duccala who come unto this town be inform that the captain of approach thither with a great army of purpose to destroy the town and to lead the people captive whereupon the king of Fez his brother send immediate unto the say town two captain with two thousand horseman and eight hundred archer but the very same time when they enter the town they meet there the Portugal soldier accompany with two thousand arabian by who be few in number they be so miserable slay that scarce twelve archer of all the eight hundred can escape with the horseman unto the next mountain howbeit afterward the arabian renew the skirmish and 150. of the Portugal horseman be slay they put the enemy to flight whereupon the king of Fez his brother pass on to Duccala require tribute of the people and promise that as long as he live he will stand between they and their enemy afterwards be vanquish he return home to Fez unto the king his brother but the inhabitant see that the king brother have receive tribute of they and have stand they in no stead they present forsake the town and flee unto the mountain of tedle for they fear least the portugal army will come upon they and exact a great sum will lead they present captive which can not disburse it at all these accident I myself be present and see the foresay slaughter of the archer for I stand about a mile distant from they and be mount upon a swift courser at the same time I be travel to Maroco be send by the king of Fez to declare unto the king of Maroco and unto the Seriffo that the king of Fez his brother be present to depart unto Duccala for which cause they be request to provide soldier for the better resistance of the portugal army of the city of Azamur a town of Duccala be build by the african upon that part of the ocean sea shore where the river of * * * * or (@) Ommirabih disemboqu be distant from Elmadina southward about thirty mile very large it be and well inhabit and contain to the number of five thousand family here do the Portugal merchant continual reside the inhabitant be very civil and decent apparel and albeit they be divide into two part yet have they continual peace among themselves pulse and corn they have great plenty though their garden and orchard bring forth nought else but figs. they have such plenty of fish that they receive yearly for they sometime six thousand and sometime seven thousand ducat and their time of fish dure from October to the end of April they use to fry fish in a certain pan with oil whereby they gather a incredible quantity of trane neither use they any other oil to put into their lamp once a year the portugal make a voyage hither and do carry away so great abundance of fish that they only do disburse the sum of ducat aforesaid hence it be that the king of Portugal be allure for gain have often send most warlike fleet to surprise this town the first whereof in regard of the general indiscretion be the great part disperse and sink upon the sea afterwards the king send another navy of two hundred sail well furnish at the very sight whereof the citizen be so discomfit that they all betake themselves to flight and the throng be so great at their entrance of the gate that more than fourscore citizen be slay therein yea a certain prince which come to aid they be for his safety constrain to let himself down by a rope on the far side of the city the inhabitant be present disperse hither and thither some flee on horseback and other on foot neither can you I know have refrain from tear have you see the weak woman the silly old man and the tender child run away barefooted and forlorn but before the christian give any assault the jew which short after compound with the win by the portugal king of Portugal to yield the city to he on condition that they shall sustain no injury with a general consent open the gate unto they and so the christian obtain the city and the people go to dwell part of they to Sala and part to Fez. neither do I think that god for any other cause bring this calamity upon they but only for the horrible vice of sodomy whereunto the great part of the citizen be so notorious addict that they can scarce see any young stripling who escape their lust of the town call Meramei this town be build by the goth upon a plain almost fourteen mile distant from Azafi and it contain to the number of four hundred family the soil thereabouts abound great with olive and corn it be govern in time pass by the prince of Azafi but afterward be surprise by the portugal and the inhabitant be all put to flight it remain well nigh one whole year destitute of people howbeit soon after make a league with the portugal each man retire unto his own home and now I think it not amiss to report as concern the mountain of Duccala those thing which may seem worthy of memory of the mountain call Benimegher BEnimegher be distant from Azafi about twelve mile contain diverse artisan of all sort every one of which have a house at Azafi this mountain be so exceed fruitful for oil and corn that a man will scarce believe it it be once in subjection unto the prince of Azafi but the inhabitant of Azafi be put to flight as have be aforesaid have no other place for their refuge but only this mountain of Benimegher afterwards they pay tribute for certain year unto the portugal but when the king of Fez come thither with his army he carry with he part of they unto Fez and the residue return to Azafi for they be determine rather to endure any injury then to submit themselves to the christian government of the green mountain this mountain be of a exceed height begin eastward from the river of Ommirabih and extend westward to the hill call in their language Hasara and it divide Duccala from some part of tedle likewise this mountain be very rough and full of wood afford great the fruit call by the italian Frutto africano store of acorn and pineapple and a certain kind of red fruit which the italian common call africano many hermit also do inhabit upon this mountain live with no other kind of victual but such as the wood yield unto they for they be above five and twenty (@) distant from all town and city here be great store of fountain and of altar build after the mahometan fashion and many ancient house also erect by the african at the foot of this mountain there be a notable lake very like unto the lake of Bolsena in the roman territory in which lake be find infinite number of fish as namely eel pickerel and of diverse other sort which to my remembrance I never see in Italy but there be no man that go about to take any fish in this lake no marvel therefore though the number be so great upon a certain time when Mahumet the king of Fez travel great plentic of fish that way towards the kingdom of Maroco he encamp his army eight day upon the side of this lake some of his company he license to fish the same among who I see certain that take off their shirt and coat sow up their sleeve and collar and put certain hoop within they to keep they from close together and so use they in steed of net wherewith notwithstanding they catch many thousand fish but other which have net indeed get more than they and all by reason that the fish as we will now declare be perforce drive into the net for king Mahumet be there accompany with fourteen thousand arabian horseman which bring a great many more camel with they and have five thousand horseman under the conduct of his brother with a huge army of fooreman cause they all at once to enter the lake insomuch that there be scarce water enough to satisfy the camel thirst wherefore it be no marvel though the fish come so fast into the net upon the bank of this lake be many tree bear leaf like unto pine-leave among the bough whereof such abundance of turtle do nestle that the inhabitant reap wonder commodity by they Mahumet have refresh himself eight day by the foresay lake be then desirous to view the green mountain aforesaid myself with a great number of courtier and learned man attend upon he so often as he see any altar he will command his army there to make a stand and low kneel on his knee will say these word follow thou know oh lord my God that I come hither for none other cause but to release the people of Duccala from the arabian and cruel christian which attempt of i if thou think to be unjust let i only feel the punishment of this offence for these my follower be guiltless and thus we range up and down the green hill one whole day but at night we return unto our tent the next day it be king mahumets pleasure to go on hunt and hawk whereupon his hound and hawk which he have in great abundance be bring forth howbeit that sport yield nought but wild goose duck turtle-dove and other fowl but the day follow the king call for his hound falcon and eagle their game be hare dear porcupike roe-deere wolf quail and starling and by reason that none have hunt or hawk there a hundred year before they have very good pastime and after we have here stay certain day the king with his army march unto the say Elmadin a town of Duccala will all his learned man and priest which he have John Leo send ambassador from the king of Fez unto Maroco bring with he to return unto Fez. but myself as ambassador and a certain number of soldier he send unto Maroco this be do in the 922. year of the Hegeira and in the year of our lord 1512. a description of the region of Hascora this region be bound northward with certain mountain which adjoin upon Duccala westward with a river run by the foot of mount Hadimmei which we call before tensift and eastward by the river quadelhabid that be the river of servant which river divide Hascora from tedle and so likewise the hill of Duccala do separate Hascora from the ocean sea the inhabitant of this region be far more civil than the people of Duccala this province yield great abundance of oil of Marockin skin and of goat of who hair they make cloth and saddle and hither do all the border region bring their goatskin whereof the foresay marockin or Cordovan leather be make this people have great traffic with the portugal with who they exchange the foresay leather and saddle for cloth their coin be all one with the coin of Duccala also the arabian usual buy oil and other necessary our of this region now let we in order describe all the town and city of the say region of Elmadin a town in Hascora this town of Hascora be call by the inhabitant Elmadin be build upon the side of mount Atlas and contain (@) then two thousand family it stand almost fourscore and ten mile eastward of Maroco and about 60. mile from Duccala here may you find many leatherdresser and all other kind of artisan with a great multitude of jewish merchant this town be environ with a certain wood which be full of olive and walnut-tree the inhabitant be continual in a manner oppress with war among themselves and against a certain little town be four mile distant from thence neither dare any come upon the plain lie between these two town save woman only and slave except he be well and strong guard so that (@) man be fain to maintain a harquebusy or archer for his defence who he monethlyallow ten or twelve piece of gold which be worth sixteen ducat italian likewise in Elmadin there be certain man of great and profound learning which be appoint to be judge and notary whatsoever tribute or custom stranger do pay be deliver unto certain treasurer and customer of the town which employ it afterward for the public benefit they be likewise constrain to pay certain tribute unto the arabian for sundry possession which they enjoy in the foresay valley but that money gain they at the arabian hand ten time so much or more in my return from Maroco I think good to travel by this town where I be right sumptuous entertain by one of Granada my countryman who be exceed rich have serve as a archer in this region for fifteen year and albeit the town of Elmadin have a stately hospital wherein all merchant travel that way be entertain at the common charge yet my countryman will not suffer we there to lodge but for three day together most courteous welcome myself nine courtier and all the servant and retinue which we bring with we unto which company of we the townsman present some of they calf some lamb and some other bring hen see upon a time so many goat in the town I merry demand of my countryman why he give we no kids-flesh to eat he answer that that be account among they of all other the most base and homely meat their fair and beautiful woman be so fond of stranger that if secret occasion be offer they will not refuse their dishonest company of the city of Alemdin near unto the foresay town stand another common call Alemdin be situate four mile to the west thereof in a valley amid four most high hill whereupon the place be exceed cold the inhabitant be merchant artisan and gentleman and family it contain to the number of one thousand this town have be at continual war with the town last before mention but in our time both of they be by the mean of a certain merchant bring in subjection unto the king of Fez as we will now declare there be a merchant of Fez which have a paramour in this by what mean the town of Elmadin and (@) become subject unto the king of Fez. town who he determine forthwith to marry but when the marriage day be come this merchant be beguile of his love by the governor of the town himself which disappointment grieve he full sore albeit he dissemble the matter as well as he can return home to the king of Fez the say merchant present unto he most rich and costly gift make humble suit unto his majesty that he will allow he a hundred principal archer three hundred horseman and four hundred footman say that himself will maintain they all at his own cost and charge and will win the say town of Alemdin for the king behalf and will assure the king seven thousand ducat for yearly tribute this offer please the king right well and that he may declare his princely liberality he will not suffer the merchant to give wage unto any but only to the archer and so with all expedition he command his governor of tedle to provide the say merchant so many horseman and so many footman and two captain over the army at length come before Alemdin they besiege it six day which be expire the townsman tell their governor in plain term that they will not for his cause incur the king of Fez his displeasure nor suffer any inconvenience whereupon he put himself in a beggar weed attempt to escape away but be know and apprehend he be bring before the merchant who commit he to prison and so the townsman present open their gate receive the merchant with all his troop and yield themselves to he and to the king of Fez. the parent of the foresay maid protest unto the merchant' that the governor by main force have deprive they of his paramour howbeit she herself be big with child by the governor but after the merchant know that she be deliver of her child he bear her affection again and at length marry she and the wretched governor be the same day by the judge pronounce guilty of fornication and be stone to death well the merchant remain governor and lord of both town establish most firm peace between they and due pay unto the king of Fez all the yearly tribute which he have promise I myself afterward come to the foresay town grow familiar acquaint with this famous merchant the same year depart from Fez I take my journey towards Constantinople of tagoda a town in Hascora this town be build upon the top of a certain high mountain have four other high mountain round about it between which four mountain and the say town be diverse most large and beautiful garden replenish with all kind of fruit quince here be of a incredible bigness their vine disperse themselves upon the bough of tree do make most pleasant bower and walk the grape whereof be red be for their bigness call in the language of that people hen egg they have here grape of marvelous bigness white honey great (@) of oil and most excellent honey some of their honey be white and some yellow this town have many fountain about it which join into one stream do serve for many watermil thereabouts here be likewise great store of artisan who exercise themselves only about thing necessary the inhabitant be somewhat civil their woman be most beautiful be most gorgeous deck with silver jewel their oil they carry unto the next city southward of they on this side Atlas but they send their leather unto Fez and Mecnasa their plain be almost six mile long the soil be most fruitful for corn in regard whereof the townsman pay certain yearly tribute unto the this town have judge priest and a great number of gentleman upon a time as I travel this way it be my hap to meet with a certain ancient governor of the same place who be grow blind with extreme age this age sire as by some I understand be in his youth a most valiant and stout person insomuch that after many other noble exploit he slay with his own hand four captain which be most deadly enemy unto the people of tagodast and afterward he handle the matter so wise that he join those in perfect league which before time have wage continual war here no commonwealth-matter be conclude by the magistrate of the town without his special advice and (@) by this worthy senator myself with fourscore (@) be honourable entertain and have dainty meat every day set before we of game which be new hunt he recount most familiar unto we all his labour which he have bestow in conclude of the forefaid league neither have this good man any so entire and hide secret which he reveal not unto we as to his love friend at my departure I offer he money for myself and my company but he like a liberal man will by no mean accept of it say that albeit he ought the king of Fez much duty and good will yet do he not bestow that liberality for his sake but that whatsoever wealth he enjoy his parent bequeath unto he upon this condition that he shall show himself kind and bountiful unto all his kindred acquaintance and stranger travel that way and although he be free from that condition yet his love towards God and the liberality which God have plant in he can require no less at his hand yea he say that by God good blessing and providence he have reap the same year seven thousand bushel of corn insomuch that himself and all his neighbour be provide for in abundance moreover that he possess of sheep and goat more than a hundred thousand the wool whereof only and some small portion of butter he reserve to himself but as for the cheese and milk he give it all frank unto his shepherd in this town there be none that sell either cheese butter milk or any otber such commodity though each one have great abundance of cattle howbeit their hide oil and wool they utter in the province thereabouts the reverend sire add this moreover if it shall please say he the king of Fez to return home from Duccala through this my region I will come forth to meet he and will submit myself whole unto he as unto my most liege and sovereign prince thus myself a mere stranger be so honourable dismiss by this worthy senator can not sufficient commend his courtesy and bounteous deal towards stranger of the city of Elgiumuha near unto the foresay town within five mile stand Elgiumuha it be in our time build upon the top of a high mountain and contain to the number of five hundred family beside so many family comprise in the village of that mountain here be innumerable spring and fountain and most pleasant and fruitful garden in all place here be likewise walnut-tree huge and tall the little hill environ this mountain do yield barley and olive in great abundance in the say town be great number of artisan as smith leatherdresser and such like and because they have here notable yron-mine they make plenty of horseshoe and whatsoever commodity proceed of their labour they carry it to foreign region where they think it be want from whence they bring home slave woad and the skin of certain beast whereof they make most defensive and warlike shield these shield they transport unto Fez exchange they there for weapon cloth and other such thing as they stand in need of this town stand so near unto the high way that the boy will stand gaze and wonder at merchant as they come by especial if they wear any strange attire the residue of inhabitant upon this mountain be all command and govern by they of the town they say that the people of tagodast aforesaid be the first founder of this town for so upon a time it befall that whereas the principal man of tagodast grow to dissension among themselves the common sort favour neither faction build Elgiumuha and leave tagoda to be inhabit by their governor hence it be that even at this day they be here only ignoble and base people whereas there they be all gentleman of Bzo a town in Hascora the ancient town of Bzo be build upon a high hill about twenty mile westward from the town last mention within three mile of Bzo run the foresay river of Guadelhabid the townsman be honest people exercise merchandise and go decent apparel to they which inhabit the desert they carry cloth oil and leather their mountain abound with olive corn and all kind of fruit and of their grape they make every year most excellent and sweet raisin fig they have great plenty and their walnut-tree be so high that a puttock may secure build his nest upon the top for it be impossible for any man to climb up on each side of the way which lead from hence to the river guadelhabid there be most pleasant and beautiful garden myself I remember be here present when their orange fig and other fruit be grow to ripeness and be entertain by a certain priest who dwell not far from a stately mahometan temple stand by that river which run through the marketplace of the town of the mountain call tenueve this mountain be situate over against Hascora upon that part of Atlas which trend southward it have many most valiant and warlike inhabitant both horseman and footman and a great number of horse of small stature it yield abundance of woad and barley but other grain they have none at all so that they have no other but barley bread to eat at all time of the year you shall here see plenty of snow here be likewise sundry nobleman and gentleman all which be subject unto one prince to this prince they pay great yearly tribute for the maintenance of his soldier for he wage continual war with the inhabitant of mount the say prince have (@) 1000 most valiant horseman always in a readiness and so many likewise do the nobleman of this mountain continual keep at their own cost and charge moreover the prince have a hundred soldier part of they bowman and part harquebusier to guard and attend upon his person in all place come myself to see this mountain it be my chance to find out the say prince who be desirous exceed to be praise of all man but for liberality courtesy and civility his like I think be not to be find unto the arabian tongue albeit he be ignorant thereof he bear a marvelous affection and be great delight to hear any man expound a sentence or verse which be pen to his own commendation the uncle of (@) Leo send ambassador to the king of Tombuto at the very same time when my uncle be send ambassador from the king of Fez to the king of Tombuto I myself also travail in his company we be no soon enter the region of dara which be a hundred mile distant from the say prince dominion but he hear of my uncle fame who be a excellent orator and a most witty poet send letter unto the prince of dara request he that he will persuade my uncle to travail unto Tombuto by mount tenueve for he have a great desire to see he and to speak with he howbeit my uncle answer that it beseem not a king ambassador to visit any prince far out of his way and so to defer his master weighty affair but to the end that he may in some sort satisfy the say prince he promise to send i his nephew unto he which may in his name salute he and do he due honour afterwards he deliver i certain costly gift to present the prince withal as namely a curious pair of stirrup double gilt and fine wrought after the morisco fashion which cost as I remember five and twenty ducat and a rich pair of spur of fifteen ducat price moreover he send two band of silk artificial entwine with gold one whereo be tawny and the other blue he send also a most excellent book contain the life of certain famous and devout man of Africa together with certain verse in the commendation of the prince himself thus be furnish with the thing aforesaid I set forth on my journey take two horseman to accompany i unto the foresay mountain and so as I ride I invent verse in the prince praise at our first arrival there the prince with a great train of his nobility be ride forth on hunt who be inform of my come cause i forthwith to be send for and after salutation have he ask i how my uncle do I answer that he be in good health and at his highness disposition then he command i to be carry unto a stately lodging where after my tedious journey I may repose myself till he be return from hunt and so within night return from his game he send for i immediate to come into his chamber of presence where have first perform due obeisance unto he I present he with my uncle gift which as I suppose be most acceptable unto he at length I give he the verse which my uncle have indict which he present command one of his secretary to read and as he be expound each sentence and word unto the prince it be a wonder to see what exceed alacrity and joy appear in his countenance the verse be read he sit down to supper will i not only to be his guest but also to sit next unto his person his table be furnish with mutton veal roast and sodden and with bread bake like a cake diverse other dish likewise be serve in but I remember not all the particular supper be end I greet the prince in this wise your highness my lord have receive all those gift which your humble servant my uncle in token of his loyal disposition and that he may be have of your highness in remembrance have send you now I be both his sister son and his scholar have nought else but a few word to present your princeliness withal may it please you therefore to accept of such homely the excellent wit and towardliness of John Leo at 16. year of age stuff as my wit can sudden afford in the time of my journey these word end I begin to read my verse unto he and be as then but sixteen year of age the prince give right joyful and diligent ear unto i and whatsoever he understand not sufficient he will cause it to be (@) now be weary with his hunt and perceive the night to be far spend he wish all of we to go to bed early the next morning I be send for to a stately breakfast after the conclusion whereof he cause a hundred ducat to be deliver i for a present unto my uncle together with three slave which shall attend upon he in his journey but on i he bestow fifty ducat and a good horse and to each of my two servant he give ten ducat give my uncle to understand that his mean gift which he bestow be send not in regard of his worthy present but for a recompense of his excellent verse for as touch my uncle gift he say he will defer the requital thereof till his return from Tombuto what time he will more full manifest his good will towards he then command one of his secretary to direct we on our way and most courteous bid we farewell he tell we that the same day he be go to make a assault upon his enemy and so depart from he I return to my uncle thus much I think good to set down for to show that even Africa be not utter destitute of courteous and bountiful person of the mountain call be a part of Atlas begin westward from the mountain last before mention eastward extend to mount deed and southward border upon the desert of dara this mountain be well store with inhabitant have more than fifty castle about it the wall whereof be build of lime and rough stone and by reason of the southerly situation it be ever almost destitute of rain all the say castle stand not far from the river of dara some being three and some four mile distant there from the great prince in all this region have under his command well nigh fifteen hundred horseman and about so many footman as the prince of tenueve before name and albeit these two prince be most near conjoin in blood yet can neither of they refrain from most cruel war against the other it be a wonder to see what plenty of date this mountain afford the inhabitant give themselves partly to husbandry and partly to traffic barley they have in great abundance but of other grain and of flesh their scarcity be incredible for that region have no flock nor drove at all the prince of this mountain common receive for yearly tribute twenty thousand piece of gold every of which piece contain not so much by one three part as a italian ducat there have always be so great amity between the king of Fez and this prince that either often send rich gift unto other myself I remember once see a most stately and rich present a most magnificent gift present to the say king in the name of this prince to wit fifty man slave and fifty woman slave bring out of the land of negro ten eunuch twelve camel one Giraffa sixteen civet-cat one pound of civet a pound of amber and almost six hundred skin of a certain beast call by they elamt whereof they make shield (@) skin be worth at Fez eight ducat twenty of the man slave cost twenty ducat a piece and so do fifteen of the woman slave every (@) be value at forty every camel at fifty and every civet-cat at two hundred ducat and a pound of civet and amber be sell at Fez for threescore (@) beside these be send diverse other particular which for brevity sake I omit I myself be in presence when these gift be offer to the king the prince ambassador be a negro bear be gross and of a (@) stature and for his speech and behaviour most barbarous this fellow deliver a letter unto the king which be most absurd and rude pen but the oration which he make in the behalf of his prince be well worse so that at the pronounce thereof the king and all that be in presence can hardly (@) from laughter but be fain to hold their hand and garment before their face lest they shall have seem too uncivil howbeit his oration be end the king cause he to be most honourable entertain by the priest of the chief temple with who himself and all his company have remain fourteen day be at length by the king liberality frank and free dismiss of the mountain call gogideme near unto the foresay mountaive stand another call gogideme this mountain Abraham before in the description of the city of Maroco Abraham king of Maroco be vanquish and expel out of his kingdom by his disciple Elmaheli he flee unto this mountain the inhabitant move with the king distress endeavour though to small purpose all that they can to succour he whereof his disciple Elmaheli be no soon inform but come with a huge army and with great fury upon they he destroy all their mansion and village and the inhabitant he partly put to flight and partly to the sword and those which now remain there be most base beggarly and slavish people howbeit they sell some quantity of oil and barley neither indeed will their soil afford any other commodity they have plenty of goat and mule but their mule and horse be but of mean stature the situation and quality of this mountain will not suffer the inhabitant to be liberal of the two mountain call Tesevon TEsevon consist of two mountain stand together begin westward from gogideme and end at the mountain of tagodast the inhabitant be oppress with extreme poverty for their ground will yield nothing but barley and mill forth of this mountain spring a certain river which run through most pleasant field but because the mountainer never descend into the same field hence it be that the arabian only enjoy that river to have say thus much of these may suffice now let we come unto the description of tedle a description of the region of tedle the small region of tedle begin westward at the river of Guadelhabid and stretch to that part of the great river Ommirabih where guadelhabid take his beginning southward it border upon Atlas and northward it extend unto that place where Guadelhabid fall into Ommirabih this region be in a manner three square for the say two river spring out of Atlas run northward till approach by little and little they meet all in one of Tefza the principal town in tedle the chief town of all tedle be build by the african upon the side of mount Atlas some five mile from the plain the town wall be build of most excellent marble which be call in their language Tefza and hereupon the town be so call likewise here do reside most rich merchant of all sort of Jew here be two hundred family who exercise merchandise and diverse other trade and here you shall find many outlandish merchant which buy from hence certain black mantle with hood common call Ilbernus of these there be great number both in Ilbernus Italy and Spain neither be there in Fez any kind of ware which be not here to be buy if any merchant will exchange his ware for other he may the soon be dispatch for the townsman be furnish with diverse kind of merchandise as namely with slave horse woad leather and such like whereas if the foreigner be desirous to sell their ware for ready money they shall never attain to the value of they they have golden coin without any image or superscription their apparel be decent and their woman be beautiful and of good behaviour in this town be diverse mahometan temple and many priest and judge their commonwealth be wont always to be most prosperous and well-governed but degenerate from better to worse they be afterward so turmoil with dissension and war that certain be expel hence come unto the king of Fez humble beseech he that by force he will restore they to their native country conditional that all matter well succeed on their side they shall deliver the town unto the king this condition be accept and the king have a thousand brave horseman ready to do the feat join five hundred horse and two hundred gunner on horseback unto they moreover he write unto certain arabian which be common call Zuair and have almost four thousand horeseman at command that if need so require they will come in and aid his troop over the say army the king appoint as captain one Ezzeranghi a most valiant and redoubt warrior who have pitch his tent near unto the town begin present to give the townsman a assault but when he have do his best the warlike citizen easy give he the repulse moreover the arabian call Benigeber be come with five thousand horseman to succour the town which so soon as captain Ezzeranghi be advertise of he raise his siege and go sudden to meet with the foresay arabian who after he have discomfit in three day he then safe return to lay new siege the citizen see themselves cut off from all hope of the arabian aid begin serious to treat of peace with the enemy which the easily to obtain they promise to defray all the king charge lay out in this expedition and to pay he for yearly tribute more than ten thousand ducat howbeit with this proviso that they for who cause the king have send the say army if they enter the town shall be seclude from all magistracy and government but they hear of these condition speak unto the captain in manner follow sir if it shall please you to restore we unto our former dignity and state we will procure you above a hundred thousand ducat neither be there cause why any man shall fear any injury or violence for we protest unto you that no man shall be a farthing endamage by we only we will exact at our adversary hand the revenue of our possession which they have these three year unjust detain from we the sum whereof will amount unto thirty thousand ducat all which we be most willing to bestow upon you in regard of those labour which you have undergo for our sake moreover the revenue of the whole region shall be you which will come to twenty thousand ducat and the jew tribute shall yield you ten thousand more upon these speech the captain return answer unto the citizen that his master the king of Fez have most faithful promise those which move he unto this war that he will never forsake they till they have attain their heart desire for which cause he be more willing to have they govern than the townsman which be now in possession and that for many reason wherefore say he if you be determine to yield unto the king assure yourselves that no inconvenience shall light upon you but if you will to the end remain perverse and obstinate be you assure also that the king will deal most extreme with you this message be no soon know unto the people but forthwith they begin to be distract into diverse faction some there be which stand for the king and other choose rather manful to fight it out then that the king shall be admit insomuch that the whole city resound with brawl quarrel and contention this tumult come at length by spy unto the captain ear who present cause half his force to take arm and by their mean in three hour space he win the city with little slaughter on his part for those townsman that favour the king do what they can on the inside to set open the gate and so do the assailant on the outside neither do any resist their attempt by reason of the foresay civil dissension whereupon captain Ezzeranghi enter the city cause the king colour to be advance in the marketplace and upon the wall charge his horseman to range about the city that no citizen may escape by flight and last of all make a proclamation unto all his soldier that they shall not upon pain of death offer any injury unto the townsman then he cause all the chieftain of the contrary faction to be bring prisoner unto he to who he threaten captivity and thraldom till they shall disburse so much as the king have spend in that expedition the total sum be twelve thousand ducat which the wife and kinsfolk of the captive present pay neither can they yet obtain their liberty for the exile for who cause the king have send that army demand restitution of all their good which the other have for certain year detain from they the captive therefore be commit that night and the next morning lawyer and attorney come to plead on both side before a judge and the captain howbeit after a great deal of tedious fend and prove have conclude nothing at all the captain be so weary that he leave they and go to supper afterwards he cause the captive to be bring forth wish they to pay the sum demand for say he if you come before the king of Fez he will make you to disburse more than twice the value at which word be terrify they write unto their wife if they will ever see they alive to procure they money by some mean eight day after the woman bring as many gold ring bracelet and other such jewel as be value at eight and twenty thousand ducat for they have rather bestow these for the ransom of their husband then to reveal their great wealth bring forth all their costly ornament as if their money have be quite exhaust when therefore the king and the exile be full satisfy insomuch that nothing seem now to let the say captive from liberty the captain speak unto they in this wise sir I have signify though unwilling unto my master the king all matter which have here pass between we for I dare by no mean release you till the king letter authorize i so to do howbeit I wish you to be of good cheer for sithence you have honest restore to every man his own there be no doubt but yourselves shall short be set at liberty the same night the captain a notable and effectual practice to wring more money out of the (@) purse call a friend of he who counsel he find oftentimes to take good effect and ask he by what mean he may without suspicion of guile or treachery wring any more sum of money from they whereunto his friend reply make they believe quoth he that you be will by the king letter to put they all to death howbeit that you will not for pity sake deal so extreme with innocent person but that you will send they to Fez to receive punishment or pardon at the king pleasure hereupon the king letter be counterfeit which the day follow the captain with a lamentable voice publish unto his two and forty prisoner my friend quoth he so it be that the king have receive some sinister and wrong information that you shall go about to make a conspiracy most firm enjoin i by these his letter to put each one of you to death which though it be full sore against my will yet needs I must obey my prince if I will not witting run upon my own destruction and then shed some feign tear sithence quoth he we can upon the sudden device no better course I think it most convenient to send you with a troop of horseman unto the king who wrath perhaps you may by some mean pacify whereupon the captive grow far more pensive than before recommend themselves unto God and to the captain clemency request his good will with many tear and forthwith there come one in among they who advise they to make up some round sum of money and therewithal to try if they can appease the king and seem likewise to entreat the captain that he will by his letter stand their friend to the king hereunto the captive agree with one voice promise that they will give the king a great sum of gold and will most liberal reward the captain the captain as though forsooth this condition much dislike he ask at length how much gold they mean to send the king one say that he will disburse a thousand ducat another that he will give five hundred and the three eight hundred but the captain make show that this be too little say that he be loath to make signification of so small a sum unto the king howbeit better it be for you quoth the captain to go yourselves unto the king with who perhaps you shall make a more reasonable end than you be aware of but they fear hard measure if they shall be carry unto the king be far more importunate with the captain then before that he will to his power be good unto they wherefore the captain as though at length he have be move with their vehement petition speak unto they in this wise here be of you my master two and forty noble and rich person if you will promise two thousand ducat a man I will signify on your behalf so much unto the king and so I hope to persuade he but if this condition will not please he then must I needs send you to make answer for yourselves this condition they all of they yield unto howbeit with this proviso that every man shall give proportionable to his wealth and that they may have for the payment fifteen day of far respite the twelve day follow the captain feign that he have receive letter from his king signify that the king for his sake will show the captive more favour the fifteen day he have pay unto he eighty four thousand ducat neither can he sufficient wonder how in so small a town among two and forty inhabitant only such huge sum of money can so ready be find then write he unto his king how all matter have pass demand what shall be do with the gold and so the king forthwith send two of his secretary with a hundred horseman to fetch home the say gold unto Fez. the captive be restore to their liberty present the say captain with horse slave civet and such like gift to the value of two thousand ducat give he exceed thanks for their liberty and request he to take their present in good worth for have not their treasure be quite consume they say they will have bestow far great upon he wherefore from thence forward that region be subject unto the king of Fez and to the foresay captain Ezzeranghi till he be treacherous slay by certain arabian moreover the king receive from that city even at this present twenty thousand ducat for yearly tribute I have in this narration be indeed somewhat more large than need require howbeit perhaps I do it because I myself be present in all the expedition and be a earnest mediator for the citizen release neither see I ever to my remembrance a great mass of gold than be by subtlety draw from they yea the king himself never have so much gold in his coffer at one time for albeit he receive yearly thirty thousand ducat yet never can he store himself with so much at once nor his father before he these thing be do in the year of the Hegeira 915. and in the year of our lord 1506. and here I will have the reader to consider what man industry and wit may do in get of money the king marvel much at this sum of gold but afterward he have great cause to wonder at the wealth of a certain Jew who pay more out of his own purse than all the forename captive and his riches be the cause why the king of Fez exact fifty thousand ducat from the jew for that they be say to favour his enemy I myself bear he company that go in the king name to receive the say sum of the jew of Efza a town of tedle this town stand two mile from Tefza natural inhabitant be either artificer or husbandman be in subjection to the governor of Tefza their woman be excellent spinster whereby they be say to gain more than the man of the town between this town and Tefza run a certain river call by the inhabitant derne which spring forth of Atlas run through the plain of that region till at length it fall into Ommirabih on both side of this river be most beautiful and large garden replenish with all kind of fruit the townsman here be most liberal and courteous people and will permit merchant travel that way free to come into their garden and to take thence as much fruit as they will no people be slow than they for pay of debt for albeit the merchant lay down ready money to receive Bernussi within three month yet be they sometime fain to stay a whole year myself be in this town when the king army lie in tedle and then they yield themselves to the king the second time that the king general of his army come unto they they present he with fifteen horse and as many slave afterwards they give he fifteen kine in token that they be the king loyal subject of Cithiteb this town be build by the african upon a high hill almost ten mile westward of Efza well people it be with rich and noble inhabitant and because Bernussi be here make it be always frequent with * ilbernus store of merchant the top of the say high mountain be continual cover with snow the field adjoin to the town be full of vineyard and garden which bring forth fruit in such abundance that they be nought worth to be sell in the market their woman be beautiful fat and comely be adorn with much silver their eye and hair be of a brown colour the inhabitant be so stout and sullen that when the other city of tedle yield to the king they alone stand out yea they assemble under a certain captain a army of a thousand horseman wherewith they so vex the king force that he be often in danger to have lose all that which he have get afterwards the king send his brother with a new supply of man to aid his lieutenant but he also have hard success at length have maintain war for three whole year the king command a jew to poison their captain and so at last the king win this city also in the year of the Hegeira 921. of the town of Eithiad this town be build by the african upon a certain hillock of Atlas contain to the number of three hundred family it be wall only towards the mountain for that side which respect the plain be so fortify natural with rock that it seem not to need any wall from cithiteb it be about twelve mile distant the temple of this town be little but most beautiful round about which run a mote in manner of a river the inhabitant be wealthy and noble they have great store of merchant as well townsman as foreigner the jew here inhabit be partly artificer and partly merchant about this town be abundance of spring which break through the rock of the mountain do fall into a certain river under the town on both side of this river be diverse garden wonderful replenish with grape fig and walnut likewise the side of the mountain itself abound great with olive their woman be no less beautiful than civil be adorn with much silver and wear fine ring upon their finger and arm their valley be fruitful for all kind of grain but their hill be meet only for barley and for goates-pasture in my time one raoman Benguihazzan usurp this town and enjoy it to his die day myself be once entertain by a priest of this place in the year of the Hegeira 921. of seggheme a mountain of tedle albeit this mountain stand much southerly yet be it to be account one of the mountain of tedle westward it begin from the mountain of tesavon extend itself eastward to mount Magran from whence the famous river of Ommirabih be say to take his beginning the south part border upon mount deed the inhabitant be say original to be descend from the people of Zanaga they be personable cheerful valiant and warlike people their weapon be dart turkish sword and daggers they sling stone likewise with great dexterity and force they be at continual war with the inhabitant of tedle insomuch that no merchant can pass that way without public safe-conduct and without great expense of money their house be so homely build that sometime three or four room be contain in one of goat they have great abundance as likewise of mule scarce so big as ass which range so far into the forest to seek their food that they be often devour of lion they will never submit themselves to any prince for their mountain be so rough and steep that it seem almost impregnable in my time the same captain which have win the town of tedle go about to assail they in like manner which when the mountainer understand assemble a great army they shroud themselves in a certain part of the mountain near which they know their enemy will pass and so soon as they see all the enemy horseman ascend up the hill sudden rush forth they give they the onset the skirmish be not so long as bloody for the captain army be too weak for the mountainer can neither march on nor retire wherefore they be constrain to fight it out by handblowe many of they with their horse be throw headlong down the rock be miserable crush in piece the residue be either take or slay so that I think scarce one man of they escape but of all other the captive be most miserable for the mountainer themselves will not slay they but deliver they over to their wife to be torment who as if they have be she-tigres or lioness put they to a most horrible and vile death from thencefoorth they have no traffic nor familiarity with the people of tedle neither seem they great to stand in need of their friendship for they have great store of barley of cattle and of sweet fountain unless it be for that they be exclude from all trade of merchandise of the mountain call Magran somewhat beyond the foresay mountain of seggheme stand mount Magran southward it border upon the region of Farcala near unto the lybian desert westward it begin at seggheme and extend eastward to the foot of mount deed it be continual cover with snow the inhabitant have such abundance of small and great cattle that they can long remain in one place together they build their house of the bark of certain tree the roof whereof depend on slender spar fashion like unto the hoop environ the lid of such chest or trunk as the woman of Italy when they travel carry upon their mule so likewise these these people live like the tartar people transport their whole house up and down by the strength of mule till they have find a fit place of abode where so soon as they arrive they plant their say house remain there with their whole family so long as they have grass sufficient to feed their cattle howbeit all the spring time they settle themselves in one place make certain low stable or cottage and (@) they with the bough of tree which serve for their cattle to lie in a night and to the end that the cold may not pinch they overmuch they kindle certain huge fire near unto their say stable whereupon sometime the wind so violent drive the fire that unless the cattle escape by flight they be in great danger to be consume and as their house be destitute of wall so be their (@) they be continual molest and haunt with lion and wolf in their apparel and custom they whole agree with the foresay people of seggheme save that these have house of bark and wood and the other of stone I myself in the 917. year of the Hegeira be in this mountain as I travel from dara to Fez. a description of mount deed this high and cold mountain great abound with fountain and wood westward it begin at mount Magran extend thence almost as far as the mountain of adesan and southward it border upon the plain of Todga the length thereof be almost fourscore mile upon the very top of this mountain there be a city build in ancient time whereof a few ruinous monument be to be see at this present namely certain wall of white stone wherein be diverse letter and word grave which the inhabitant themselves do not understand many be of opinion that this city be build long ago by the roman howbeit I myself can never find so much affirm by any african writer nor yet the city itself mention save that (@) Essacalli in a certain story of he make mention of Tedsi which he say be near unto segelmesse and dara but he declare not whether it be build upon mount deed or no. howbeit for my own part I think it to be the very same for there be no other city in the whole region the inhabitant of deed be in very deed most base people of who the great part dwell in cave under the ground their food be barley and Elhasid that be to say barley meal sod with water and salt which we mention before in our description of Hea for here be nothing but barley to be have goat and ass they have in great abundance the cave wherein their cattle lodge be exceed full of * * * * or Salt-peter nitre so that I very think if this mountain be near unto Italy the say nitre will yearly be worth five and twenty thousand ducat but such be their negligence and unskilfulness that they be utter ignorant to what purpose nitre serve their garment be so rude that they scarce cover half their nakedness their house be very loathsome be annoy with the stink smell of their goat in all this mountain you shall find neither castle nor wall town when they build a house they pile one stone upon another without any mortar at all the roof whereof they make of certain rubbish like as they do in some place of Sisa and Fabbriano the residue as we have say do inhabit in cave neither see I ever to my remembrance great swarm of flea then among these people moreover they be treacherous and strong thief so give to steal and quarrel that for one unkind word they will not only contend but seek also the destruction one of another they have neither judge priest nor any honest governor among they no merchant resort unto they for be give to continual idleness and not exercise any trade or handiecraft they have nothing meet for merchant to buy if any merchant bring any ware into their region unless he be safe conduct by their captain he be in danger to be rob of altogether and if the ware serve not for their own necessary use they will exact one four part of they for custom their woman be most forlorn and sluttish go more beggarly apparel then the man so continual and slavish be the toil of these woman that for misery the life of ass be not comparable to they and to be brief never be I so weary of any place in all Africa as I be of this howbeit in the year of the Hegeira 918. being command by one to who I be in duty bind to travel unto segelmesse I can not choose but come this way JOHN LEO his three book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein a most exact description of the kingdom of Fez. the kingdom of Fez begin westward at the famous river Ommirabih and extend eastward to the river Muluia northward it be enclose partly with the ocean and partly with the Mediterran sea the say kingdom of Fez be divide into seven province to wit Temesna the territory of Fez Azgar * * * elhabet Errif garet and * * * * * Chauz or Cheuz Elchauz every of which province have in old time a several governor neither indeed have the city of Fez always be the king royal seat but be build by a certain mahometan be govern by his posterity almost a hundred and fifty year after which time the family of marin get the upper hand who here settle their abode be the first that ever call Fez by the name of a kingdom the reason why they do so we will declare more at large in our small treatise concern the mahometan religion but now let we as brief as we may describe the foresay seven province of Temesna one of the province of Fez. westward it begin at the river Ommirabih and stretch to the river Buragrag eastward the south frontier thereof border upon Atlas and the north upon the ocean sea it be all over a plain country contain in length from west to east almost fourscore mile and in breadth from Atlas to the ocean sea about threescore this province have ever almost be the principal of the seven before name for it contain to the number of forty great town beside three hundred castle all which be inhabit by barbarian african in the 323. year of the Hegeira this province be by a certain heretic against the mahometan religion call chemim the son of Mennal free from pay of tribute this bad fellow persuade the people a dangerous seducer of Fez to yield no tribute nor honour unto their prince and himself he profess to be a prophet but a while after he deal not only in matter of religion but in commonwealth-affaire also at length wage war against the king of Fez who be himself then war with the people of Zenete it so befall that a league be conclude between they conditional that chemim shall enjoy Temesne and that the king shall contain himself within his signiory of Fez so that from thencefoorth neither shall molest other the say chemim govern the province of Temesne about five and thirty year and his successor enjoy it almost a hundred year after his decease but king joseph have build Maroco go about to bring this province under his subjection whereupon he send sundry mahometan doctor and priest to reclaim the governor thereof from his heresy and to persuade he if it be possible to yield unto the king by fair mean whereof the inhabitant be advertise they consult with a certain kinsman of the foresay governor in the city call to murder the king of Maroco his ambassador and so they do soon after levy a army of fifty thousand man he march towards Maroco intend to expel thence the family of Luntuna and joseph their king king joseph hear of this news be drive into wonder perplexity of mind wherefore prepare a huge and mighty army he stay not the come of his enemy but on the sudden within three day have conduct his force over the river of Ommirabih he enter Temesne when as the foresay fifty thousand man be so dismay at the king army that they all pass the river Buragrag and so flee into Fez. but the king so dispeople and waste Temesne that without all remorse he put both man woman and child to the sword this army remain in the region eight day in which space they so raze and demolish all the town the horrible desolation of Temesne and city thereof that there scarce remain any fragment of they at this time but the king of Fez on the other side hear that the people of Temesne be come into his dominion make a truce with the tribe of Zenete and bend his great army against the say Temesnites and at length have find they half famish near unto the river of buragrag he so stop their passage on all side that they be constrain to run up the craggy mountain and thicket at last be environ with the king force some of they be drown in the river other be throw down headlong from the rock and the residue be miserable slay by their enemy and for the space of ten month there be such havoc make among the temesnite that a silly remnant of they be leave alive but king joseph prince of the luntune return forthwith to Maroco for the repair of his force to the end he may bid the king of Fez a battle howbeit Temesne be bereave of her people be leave to be inhabit of wild beast neither have that province any new colony or supply of inhabitant till that about 150.
