year after king Mansor return from Tunis bring thence certain arabian with he unto who he give the possession of Temesne and these arabian enjoy the say province for fifty year till such time as king Mansor himself be expel out of his kingdom and then be they also expolled by the (@) and be bring unto extreme misery afterwards the king of the family of marin bestow the say province upon the people of Zenete and Haoara hence it come to pass that the say people of Zenete and Haoara be always great friend unto the marin family and be think to have defend they from the fury of the king of Maroco from which time they have peaceable enjoy Maroco and now they be grow in less than a hundred year so mighty that they stand not in fear of the king of Fez. for they be able to bring threescore thousand horseman to the field and have two hundred castle at their command myself have great familiarity and acquaintance with they and therefore I will not stick to record all memorable thing which I see among they of a town in Temesna this famous town be build by the roman upon the ocean sea shore northward of Atlas sixty eastward of azamursixtie and westward of forty mile the citizen thereof be most civil and wealthy people the field thereto adjoin be exceed fruitful for all kind of grain neither do I think that any town in all Africa be for pleasant situation comparable thereto the plain round about it except it be to the sea northward be almost fourscore mile over in old time it be fraught with stately temple rich warehouse and shop and beautiful palace which the monument as yet remain do sufficient testify they have also most large and fair garden out of which they gather great abundance of fruit especial of melon and pome-citron even at this day all which be perfect ripe by mid-Aprill so that the inhabitant usual carry their fruit unto Fez by reason that the fruit of Fez be not so soon ripe their attire be trim and decent and they have always have great traffic with the portugal and the English likewise they have many learned man among english traffic they howbeit two reason be allege of the destruction of this town first because they be too desirous of liberty and second for that they maintain certain galley or foist wherewith they daily molest the island of Cadiz and the portugal wherefore at length the king of Portugal send a strong navy of fifty sail against they the consideration whereof strike such terror into the inhabitant that take such good as they can carry foam flee to and other to Sela and so their town be destroy by the portugal leave naked to the spoil of the enemy but the general of the king fleet not know that they be flee put all his force into battell-array howbeit after a while be advertise how the matter stand he conduct his soldier into the city which in one day space they so deface burn the house and lay the wall even with the ground that until this day it have remain void of inhabitant myself be in this place I can scarce refrain from tear when I serious behold the miserable ruin of so many fair building and temple whereof some monument be as yet extant the garden albeit they bring forth some fruit yet be they more like unto wood than garden and now by reason of the king of Fez his weakness and default this place be fall into so great desolation as I utter despair that ever it will be inhabit again of the city of Mansora this town be build by Mansor the king and mahometan patriarch of Maroco upon a most pleasant field be two mile distant from the ocean sea five and twenty mile from and five and twenty from it contain in time pass almost four hundred family by this town run a certain river call by the inhabitant guir on both side whereof in time past be most beautiful garden but now there be no fruit at all to be find for upon the surprise of the inhabitant of this town flee unto fear lest they also shall have be assail by the portugal howbeit the wall of this town remain all whole save that the arabian of Temesne break it down in certain place this town also I can not but with great sorrow behold for easy it be to repair it and to furnish it with new inhabitant if but a few house be save from ruin but such be the malice of the arabian thereabouts that they will suffer no people to re-edify the same of the town of Nuchaila this little town call by the inhabitant Nuchaila be build almost in the midst of Temesne it be well people in time past and then so long as the foresay chemim and his successor bare rule there be fair yearly hold whereunto all the inhabitant of Temesne usual resort the townsman be exceed wealthy for the plain stretch almost forty mile right forth from each side of their town i red as I remember in a certain story that they have in time past such abundance of corn as they will give a camel burden thereof for a pair of shoe howbeit when king joseph of Maroco destroy all the region of Temesne this town be lay waste together with all the town and city of the same province howbeit at this day certain fragment thereof be to be see namely some part of the town-wall and one high steeple here also in the large and pleasant garden you may see many vine and tree plant which be so old and sear that they yield no fruit at all the husbandman thereabouts have finish their day work do lay up their rake and other such country tool in the say steeple suppose that by virtue of a certain holy man which lie there bury no man dare remove they out of their place I have often see this town as I travel between and Maroco of the town of this town be situate among certain hill almost fifteen mile from mount Atlas and five and twenty mile from the town last name the soil near unto it be exceed fruitful for corn not far from the wall thereof spring a certain river about which place be great store of palmtree be but low and fruitless the say river run through certain valley and rock where iron-mine be say to have be of old iron-mine which may seem probable for the earth resemble iron in colour and the water in taste here be nothing now to be see but a few relic and ruin of house and pillar overturn for this town be destroy at the same time when the whole region as be before declare be lay waste of the town of tegeget this town be build by the african upon the bank of Ommirabih near unto the high way lead from tedle to Fez. it have in time past civil and wealthy inhabitant for it stand not far from the way which pass over Atlas into the desert hither be all the neighbour-people wont to resort for to buy corn and albeit this town be raze with all the residue in the province yet be it after long time replant with inhabitant hither do all the arabian of Temesne bring their corn deliver it unto the townsman to be keep here be no shop nor artificer at all but certain smith only which make tool of husbandry and horseshooe the townsman be straight enjoin by the arabian their governor courteous to entertain all stranger travel that way merchant pay custom there for each pack of cloth to the value of a rial but for their horse and camel they give no custom at all often travel the same way the town do not great please i albeit the ground about it do plentiful abound with cattle and corn of the town call hain Elchallu this small town stand on a certain plain not far from Mansora about this town grow abundance of wild cherrie-tree and of other thorny tree bear a round fruit not much unlike to a cherry save that it be yellow it be somewhat big than a olive and the utter part thereof be nothing pleasant in taste the fen and marsh on all side of the town be full of snail and toad which toad as the inhabitant tell i be no whit venomous there be not any african historiographer which make description or mention of this town because perhaps they think it not worthy the name of a town or for that it be long since destroy neither be it as I conjecture build by the african but either by the roman or some other foreign people a description of this great and famous town be build not many year ago by Mansor the king and mahometan patriarch of Maroco upon the ocean sea shore by the east part thereof run the river Buragrag beforenamed and there discharge itself into the main sea the rock whereon this town be found stand near the mouth of the say river have the river on the one side thereof and the sea on the other in build it much resemble Maroco which Mansor will to be a pattern thereof save that it be a great deal less than Maroco some say that the reason why it be build why king Mansor build the town of upon the seashore in this place be for that king Mansor possess the kingdom of Granada and a great part of Spain beside and consider that Maroco be so far distant that if any war shall happen he can not in due time send new force against the christian determine to build some town upon the sea shore where he and his army may remain all summer time some persuade he to lie with his army at Ceuta a town upon the streite of Gibraltar but Mansor see that by reason of the barrenness of the soil he can not maintain a army royal for three or four month in the town of Ceuta he cause this town of in short space to be erect and to be exceed beautify with temple college palace shop stove hospital and other such building moreover on the south side without the wall he cause a certain high tower like the tower of Maroco to be build save that the wind stair be somewhat large insomuch that three horse abreast may well ascend up from the top whereof they may escry ship a huge way into the sea so exceed be the height thereof that I think there be no where the like building to be find and to the end that great store of artificer and merchant may hither from all place make resort he appoint that every man according to his trade and occupation shall be allow a yearly stipend whereupon it come to pass that within few month this town be better store with all kind of artificer and merchant than any town in all Africa beside and that because they reap a double gain here use Mansor with his troop to remain from the begin of April till the month of September and whereas there be no water about the town meet to be drink for the sea run ten mile up into the river and the well likewise yield salt-water Mansor cause fresh water to be convey to the town by certain pipe and channel from a fountain twelve mile distant and the conduct he make arch-wise like unto the conduct of Italy in many place and special at Rome so soon as the say water-conduct be derive unto the town he cause it to be divide and send into sundry place as namely some pipe thereof to the temple some to the college other to the king palace and the rest into the common cistern throughout all the city howbeit after king mansor death this town grow into such decay that scarce the ten part thereof now remain the say notable water-conduct be utter fordo in the war between the marin-family and the successor of Mansor and the famous town itself decay every day more than other so that at this present a man shall hardly find throughout the whole town four hundred house inhabit the residue be change into field and vineyard about the foresay rock be two or three street with a few shop in they which notwithstanding be in continual danger for they daily fear lest the portugal shall surprise they because the Portugal king often determine their overthrow think if he may but win that the kingdom of Fez be easy to be conquer howbeit the king of Fez have always endeavour to defend the same and strong to fortify it against the enemy but compare their former felicity with the present alteration whereinto they be fall I can but great lament their miserable case of the town of sella this town be build by the roman upon the river of buragrag two mile from the ocean sea and a mile from from whence if a man will go to the sea he must take in his way this town also be destroy when as be aforesaid king joseph spoil all Temesne howbeit afterward king Mansor cause it to be wall round about and build therein a fair hospital and a stately palace into which his soldier may at their pleasure retire themselves here likewise he erect a most beautiful temple where king Mansor be bury wherein he cause a goodly hall or chapel to be set up which be curious carve and have many fair window about it and in this hall when he perceive death to seize upon he he command his subject to (@) his corpse which be do they lay one marblestone over his head and another over his foot whereon sundry (@) be engrave after he likewise all the honourable personage of his family and blood choose to be inter in the same hall and so do the king of the marin-family so long as their commonwealth prosper myself on a time enter the same hall behold there thirty monument of noble and great personage and diligent write out all their epitaph this I do in the year of the Hegeira 915. of the town call mader this town be build in my time by a certain treasurer of the mahometan prelate Abdulmumen upon the bank of buragrag some say it iron-mine be build only for yron-mine from mount Atlas it be ten mile distant and between it and Atlas be certain shady wood full of terrible lion lion and leopard and leopard so long as the founder posterity govern this town it be well store with people with fair building temple inn and hospital but the marin-family prevail daily more and more it be at length by they utter destroy part of the inhabitant be slay and part take prisoner and the residue by flight escape to sella the king of Maroco send force to succour the town but the citizen be vanquish before their come be constrain to forsake the same and to yield it unto the marin-soldier howbeit the king of Maroco his captain come upon the marin-captaine with round force drive he and he forth of the town and take possession thereof himself at length the king of the say marin-family march with a army against Maroco take his journey by this town whereat the governor be dismay leave the say town and before the king approach betake himself to flight but the king put all the inhabitant to the sword leave the town itself so deface and desolate that by report it have lie dispeople ever since the towne-walle and certain steeple be as yet to be see myself see this town when the king of Fez have conclude a league with his cousin take his journey to Thagia for to visit the sepulchre of one account in his life time a holy man call * * * * or sidi which be in the year of the Hegeira 920. dom. 1511. of Thagia a town in Temesne this little town be in ancient time build by the african among certain hill of mount Atlas the air be extreme cold and the soil dry and barren it be environ with huge wood which be full of lion and other cruel beast their scarcity of corn be sufficient countervail with abundance of honey and goat civility they have none at all and their house be most rude build for they have no use of lime in this town be visit the sepulchre of one account for a most holy man who be report in the time of Habdulmumen to have wrought many miracle against the fury of lion whereupon he be repute by many as a great prophet I remember that I read in a certain writer of that nation common call etdedle a whole catalogue of the say holy man miracle which whether he wrought by arte-magique or by some wonder secret of nature it be altogether uncertain howbeit his great fame and honourable reputation be the cause why this town be so well fraught with inhabitant the people of Fez have solemnize their Passover do yearly frequent this town to visit the say sepulchre and that in such huge number that you will esteem they to be a whole army for every principal man carry his tent and other necessary with he and so you shall see sometime a hundred tent and sometime more in that company fifteen day they be in perform of that pilgrimage for Thagia stand from Fez almost a hundred and twenty mile myself be a child go thither on pilgrimage oftentimes with my father as likewise be grow up to man estate I repair thither as often make supplication to be deliver from the danger of lion of the town of Zarfa this town the african build upon a certain large and beautiful plain water with pleasant river and christall-fountaine about the ancient bound of this city you may behold many shrub together with figtree and cherrie-tree which bear such cherry as at Rome be call Marene here be likewise certain thorny tree the fruit whereof be by the arabian call Rabich somewhat lesser it be then a cherry resemble in taste the fruit call or jujuba here also may you find great store of wild palmtree from which they gather a kind of fruit like unto spanish olive save that the stone or (@) be great and not so pleasant in taste before they be ripe they taste somewhat like unto seruice-apple this town be destroy when king joseph aforesaid spoil Temesne now the arabian of Temesne sow their (@) where the town stand with great increase and gain of the territory of Fez. westward it begin at the river of buragrag and stretch eastward to the river call inaven which two river be almost a hundred mile distant asunder northward it border upon the river * * * * or (@) and southward upon the foot of Atlas the soil both for abundance of corn fruit and cattle seem to be inferior to none other within this province you shall see many exceed great village which may for their bigness not unfit be call town the plain of this region have be so waste with former war that very few inhabitant dwell upon they except certain poor silly arabian some of who have ground of their own and some possess ground in common either with the citizen of Fez or with the king or else with some (@) but the field of Sala and Mecnase be till by other arabian of better account and be for the most part subject to the king of Fez. and now those thing which be worthy of memory in this region let we here make report of of the city or town of sella this most ancient city be build by the roman and sack by the goth and afterward when the mahometan army be enter into the same region the goth give it to Tarick one of their captain but ever since the time that Fez be build Sela have be subject unto the governor thereof it be most pleasant situate upon the ocean seashore within half a mile of both which town the river Buragrag separate insunder the building of this town carry a show of antiquity on they be artificial carve and stately support with marble pillar their temple be most beautiful and their shop be build under large porch and at the end of every row of shop be a arch which as they say be to divide one occupation from another and to say all in a word here be nothing want which may be require either in a most honourable city or in a flourish commonwealth moreover hither resort all kind of merchant both christian and other here the genoese venetian english traffic english and low dutch use to traffic in the 670. year of the Hegeira this town be surprise by a certain castilian captain the inhabitant Sela win by a captain of Castilia and recover forthwith by the king of Fez. be put to flight and the christian enjoy the city and when they have keep it ten day be on the sudden assail by jacob the first king of the marin-family who can not they think surcease his war against tremizen they be put to the worst the great part be slay and the residue put to flight from thencefoorth that prince favour of all his subject enjoy the kingdom after who lineal succeed those of his own race and blood and albeit this town be in so few day recover from the enemy yet a world it be to see what a wonder alteration both of the house and of the state of government happen many house of this town be leave desolate especial near the towne-walle which albeit they be most stately and curious build yet no man there be that will inhabit they the ground adjoin upon this town be sandy neither be they fit for corn but for cotton-wool in diverse place very profitable the inhabitant diverse of they do weave most excellent cotton here likewise be make very fine comb which be sell in all the kingdom of Fez for the region thereabouts yield great plenty of box and of other wood fit for the same purpose their government be very orderly and discreet even until this day for they have most learned judge umpire and decider of doubtful case in law this town be frequent by many rich merchant of Genoa who the king have always have in great regard because he gain much yearly by their traffic the say merchant have their abode and diet partly here at sella and partly at Fez from both which town they mutual help the traffic one of another these genoese I find in their affair of merchandise to be exceed liberal for they will spend frank to get a courtier favour not so much for their own private gain as to be esteem bountiful by stranger in my time there be a honourable a merchant of Genoa gentleman of Genoa in the king of Fez his court call messer Thomaso Marino a man both learn and wise and high repute of by the king this man have continue almost thirty year in the Fessan court he there decease and request on his deathbed to have his corpse inter at Genoa the king command the same to be transport thither after his decease he leave many son in the Fessan king court who all of they prove rich and be great favour by the king of the town call Fanzara this town be not very large be build by a certain king of the family call Muachidin on a beautiful plain almost ten mile from sella the soil there about yield corn in great plenty without the town wall be very many clear fountain ' and well which Albuchesen the occasion of the bloody war move by Sahid the king of Fez cause there to be dig in the time of abusaid the last king of the marin-family his cousin call sahid be take by Habdilla the king of Granada whereupon by letter he request his cousin the king of Fez to send he a certain sum of money require by the king of Granada for his ransom which when the (@) king refuse to yield unto Habdilla restore his prisoner to liberty and send he towards Fez to destroy both the city and the king afterwards sahid with the help of certain the city of Fez besiege for seven year together wild arabian besiege Fez for seven year together in which space most of the town village and hamlet throughout the whole kingdom be destroy but at length such a pestilence invade sahids force that himself with a great part of his army in the * * * * * * * * * * * * this number as I take it shall rather be 819. 918. year of the Hegeira die thereof howbeit those desolate town never receive from thencefoorth any new inhabitant especial Fanzara which be give to certain arabian captain that come to assist sahid of the town of Mahmora this town be build upon the mouth of the great river by a certain king of the muachidin-familie be almost half a mile distant from the sea and about twelve mile from sella the place near unto it be sandy and barren it be build they say of purpose to keep the enemy from enter the mouth of the say river not far from this town stand a mighty wood the tree whereof bear a kind of nut or acorn about the bigness of damascen-plum be sweet in taste then chestnut of which nut certain arabian dwell near unto the place convey most cruel and (@) lion great plenty unto the city of Fez and reap much gain thereby howbeit in go to gather this fruit unless they take good heed unto themselves they be in great danger of the most cruel and devour lion in all Africa which there oftentimes do seize upon they this town a hundred and twenty year ago be raze in the foresay war of Sahid against the king of Fez nothing but a few ruin thereof remain whereby it appear the portugal attempt to build a fort within the mouth of the river defeat of their purpose and slay to have be of no great bigness in the 921. year of the Hegeira the king of Portugal send a army to build a fort in the foresay river mouth which they according attempt to do but have lay the foundation and rear the wall a good height the king of Fez his brother so defeat they of their purpose that he slay of they in one night almost three thousand in manner follow on a certain morning before sunrise three thousand portugal march towards the king of Fez his camp determine to bring thence all the ordinance and field-piece unto their new-erected for it howbeit most rash and inconsiderate themselves be but three thousand and the king army contain fifty thousand footman and four thousand horseman and yet the portugal hope so sly and close to perform this attempt that before the moor be ready to pursue they they shall convey all their ordinance unto the fort which be two mile distant the moor which keep the ordinance be seven thousand man be all asleep when the portugal come whereupon the portugal have so good success that they have carry the ordinance almost a mile before the enemy be aware thereof but at last some rumour or alarm be give in the moor camp they all betake themselves to arm and fierce pursue the portugal who likewise arrange their whole company into battell-array and albeit the enemy environ they on all side yet they make such stout and valiant resistance that they have all escape to their fort in safety have not certain villain in the king of Fez his army cry out amain in the Portugal tongue hold your hand fellow soldier and throw down your weapon for the king brother will make a truce which the portugal no soon yield unto but the savage and merciless moor put they every one to the sword save three or four only who be save at the request of a captain in the moor camp the portugal general be sore dismay with this slaughter for thereby he have lose all his principal soldier crave aid of a certain other captain which by chance arrive there with a mighty fleet be accompany with a great number of nobleman and gentleman howbeit he be so hinder by the moor who daily do he all the villainy they can and sink diverse of his ship that he be not able to perform that which he desire in the mean space news be publish among the portugal of the king of Spain death whereupon diverse ship be provide and many portugal be send into Spain likewise the captain of the say new fort see himself destitute of all succour leave the fort embark himself in those ship which then lie upon the river but the great part of the fleet be cast away at their set forth and the residue to escape the moor shot run themselves aground on the flat and shall of the river and be there miserable slay by the moor many of their ship be here burn and their ordinance sink in the sea so many christian be then slay some say a lamentable slaughter to the number of ten thousand that the sea-water in that place continue red with their blood for three day after soon after the moor take up four hundred great piece of brass out of the sea this huge calamity befall the portugal for two cause first because they will with such a small number make so rash a assault upon the moor who they know to be so strong and second whereas the portugall-king may at his own cost have send another fleet for a new supply he will by no mean join his own people and castilian together for by reason of the diversity of counsel and of people there be nothing more pernicious then for a army to consist of two nation yea the moor certain expect the upper hand when they be to fight with such a army I myself be present in the foresay John Leo his (@) to (@) war and see each particular accident a little before my voyage to Constantinople of the town call Tefelfelt this town be situate upon a sandy plain fifteen mile eastward of Mahmora and almost twelve mile from the ocean sea not far from this town run a certain river on both side whereof be thick wood haunt with more fierce and cruel lion than the last before mention fierce lion which great endanger those traveller that have occasion to lodge thereabouts without this town upon the high way to Fez stand a old cottage with a plancherd chamber therein here the mulettier and carrier be say to take up their lodging but the door of the say cottage they stop as sure as they can with bough and thorn some affirm that this rot cottage while the town be inhabit be a most stately inn but it be deface in the foresay war of Sahid a description of Mecnase this town be so call after the name of the mecnasite who be the founder thereof from Fez it be 36. mile about fifty from sella and from Atlas almost 15. mile distant it be exceed rich and contain family to the number of six thousand the inhabitant hereof while they dwell in the field live a most peaceable life howbeit at length they fall to dissension among themselves and the weak part have all their cattle take from they and have nothing in the field to maintain their estaste agree among themselves to build this city of Mecnase in a most beautiful plain near unto this town run a little river and within three mile thereof be most pleasant garden replenish with all manner of fruit quince there be of great bigness and of a most fragrant smell and pomegranate likewise which be very great and most pleasant in taste have no stone within they and yet they be sell exceed cheap likewise here be plenty of damascen of white plum and of the fruit call jujuba which be dry in the sun they eat in the spring and carry a great number of they to Fez. they have likewise great store of fig and grape which be not to be eat but while they be green and new for their fig be dry become so brittle that they waste all to powder and their grape when they be make raisin prove unsavoury peach and orange they have in so great quantity that they make no store of they but their lemon be waterish and unpleasant olives be sell among they for a ducat and a half the which measure contain a hundred pound italian moreover their field yield they great plenty of hemp and flax which they sell at Fez and Sela. in this town be most stately and beautiful temple three college and ten bathstove every Monday they have a great market without the towne-walle whereunto the border arabian do usual resort here be ox sheep and other such beast to be sell butter and wool be here plentiful and at a easy rate in my time the king bestow this town upon a certain noble man of he where as much fruit be reap as in the three part of the whole kingdom of Fez. this town have be so afflict by war that the yearly tribute thereof have be diminish sometime forty thousand and fifty thousand ducat and sometime more and I have red that it have be besiege for six or seven year together in my time the governor thereof the king of Fez his cousin rely upon the favour of the people rebel against his kinsman and sovereign whereupon the Fessan king with a great army besiege the town two month together and because it will not yield so waste and destroy all the country thereabouts that the governor lose by that mean five and twenty thousand ducat of yearly revenue what then shall we think of the six and seven year siege before mention at length those Mecnase reduce under (@) by the king of Fez. citizen which favour the king of Fez open the gate and stout resist the contrary faction give the king and his soldier entrance thus by their mean the king win the city carry home to Fez the rebellious governor captive who within few day escape from he this most strong and beautiful city have many fair street whereinto by conduct from a fountain three mile distant be convey most sweet and wholesome water which serve all the whole city the mill be two mile distant from the town the inhabitant be most valiant warlike liberal and civil people but their wit be not so refine as other some of they be merchant some artificer and the residue gentleman they count it unseemly for any man to send a horselode of seed to his husbandman or farmer they be at continual jar with the citizen of Fez but whereupon this dissension of they shall arise I can well determine their gentleman wife never go forth of the door but only in the night season and then also they must be so veil and muffle that no man may see they so great be the jealousy of this people this town be so dirty in the spring-time that it will irk a man to walk the street of a town call Gemiha elchman this ancient town stand on a plain near unto certain bath be distant southward of Mecnase fifteen mile westard of Fez thirty and from Atlas about ten mile by this town lie the common high way from Fez to tedle the field of this town be possess by certain arabian and the town itself utter destroy in the war of Sahid howbeit in certain place the wall be yet remain and diverse tower and temple stand without roof of the town call Metgara this town be build by certain african in the field of Zuaga almost fifteen mile westward from Fez. without this town for two mile together be most pleasant and fruitful garden but by the cruel war of Sahid all be lay waste and the place itself remain void of inhabitaut a hundred and twenty year howbeit when part of the people of Granada come over into Africa this region begin to be inhabit anew and whereas the granatines be great merchant of silk they cause for the breed of silkworm great store of white mulberry tree to be bring hither here likewise they plant abundance of sugarcane which prosper not so well in this place as in the province of Andaluzia in time past the inhabitant of this place be very civil people but in our time they have not be so by reason that all of they exercise husbandry of the town of Banibasil this town be build by the african upon a certain small river just in the mid way between Mecnase and Fez be distant from Fez about eighteen mile westward out of their field many river take their original which field be by the arabian sow all over with barley and hemp neither indeed will the soil yield any other commodity both by reason of the barrenness and also for that it be for the most part overflow with water whatsoever commodity arise out of this place redound to the priest of the principal mahometan temple in Fez and it amount almost yearly to twenty thousand ducat here also in time past be most large pleasant and fruitful garden as appear by the monument and relic thereof howbeit they be like other place lay waste by the war of Sahid the town itself remain destitute of inhabitant a hundred and ten year but as the king of Fez return home from Duccala he command part of his people to inhabit the same albeit their incivility make they loath so to do of Fez the principal city of all Barbary and of the founder thereof FEz be build in the time of one aron a mahometan patriarch in the year of the Hegeira 185. and in the year of our lord 786. by a certain heretic against the religion of Mahumet but why it shall so be call some be of opinion because when the first foundation thereof be dig there be find some quantity of gold which mettle in the arabian language be call Fez. which etymology seem to i not improbable albeit some will have it so call from a certain river of that name but howsoever it be we leave that to be discuss by other affirm for a undoubted truth that the founder of this city be one idris be the foresay aron his near kinsman this idris ought rather to have be mahometan idris the first founder of fe patriarch because he be nephew unto Hali the cousin-german of Mahumet who marry falerna mahumets own daughter so that idris both by father and mother be of mahumets lineage but aron be nephew unto one the uncle of Mahumet be of kindred only by the father side howbeit both of they be exclude from the say patriarkship for certain cause mention in the african chronicle although aron usurp the same by deceit for Aaron uncle be a most cunning and crafty man and feign himself to bear great favour unto the family of Hali and to be most desirous that the patriarkship shall light thereon send his ambassador almost throughout the whole world whereupon the dignity be translate from vmeve to Habdulla Seffec the first patriarch which vmeve be inform of wage war against the family of Hali and so prevail that some of they he chase into Asia and some into India howbeit a ancient religious man of the same family remain still alive at Elmadina who be very old no whit regard the dignity but this ancient sire leave behind he two son who when they be come to man estate grow into so great favour with the people of Elmadin that they be chase thence by their enemy the one be take and hang and the other who name be idris escape into Mauritania this idris dwell upon mount Zaron about thirty mile from Fez govern not only the commonwealth but matter of religion also and all the region adjacent pay he tribute at length idris decease without lawful issue leave one of his maid big with child which have be turn from the goth religion to the moor be deliver of her son they call he after his father name idris this child the inhabitant choose for their prince cause he to be most careful bring up and as he grow in year to the end they may train he up in feat of chivalry they appoint one Rasid a most valiant and skilful captain to instruct he insomuch that while he be but fifteen idris his (@) valour at fifteen year of age year of age he grow famous for his valiant act and stratagem and begin wonderful to enlarge his dominion wherefore his troop and family increase every day more and more he set his mind upon building of a city and change of his habitation and so he send for cunning builder into all nation who have diligent peruse all place in the region at last make choice of that where the city of Fez now stand for here they find great store of fountain and a fair river which spring forth of a plain not far of run pleasant almost eight mile amid the little hill till at length it cast itself upon another plain southward of the place they find a wood which they know will be right commodious for the town here therefore upon the east bank of the say river they build a town contain three thousand family neither omit they ought at all which may be require in a flourish commonwealth after the decease of idris his son erect another town direct over against the foresay on the other side of the river but in process of time either town so increase that there be but a small distance between they for the governor of each labour might and main to augment their own jurisdiction a hundred and fourscore year after there fall out great dissension and civil war between these two city which by report continue a hundred year together at length joseph king of Maroco of the luntune-familie conduct a huge army against both these prince take they prisoner carry they home unto his dominion and put they to a most cruel death and he so vanquish the citizen that there be slay of they thirty thousand then determine king joseph to reduce those two town into firm unity and concord for which cause make a bridge over the river and beat down the wall of either town right against it he unite both into one which afterward he divide into twelve region or ward now let we make report of all such memorable thing as be there to be see * * * 1526. at this day a most exact description of the city of Fez. a world it be to see how large how populous how well-fortified and wall this city be the most part thereof stand upon great and little hill neither be there any plain ground but only in the midst of the city the river enter the town in two place for it be divide into a double branch one whereof run by new Fez that be by the south side of the town and another come in at the west side and so almost infinite disperse itself into the city it be derive by certain conduct and channel unto every temple college inn hospital and almost to every private house unto the temple be certain square conduct adjoin have and receptacle round about they each one of which have a cock whereby water be convey through the wall into a trough of marble from whence flow into the sink and gutter it carry away all the filth of the city into the river in the midst of each square conduct stand a low cistern be three cubit in depth four in breadth and twelve in length and the water be convey by certain pipe into the foresay square conduct which be almost a hundred and fifty in number the most part of the house be build of fine brick and stone curious paint likewise their bay-windowe and portal be make of particoloured brick like unto the stone of Majorica the roof of their house they adorn with gold azure and other excellent colour which roof be make of wood and plain on the top to the end that in summertime carpet may be spread upon they for here they use to lodge by reason of the exceed heat of that country some house be of two and some of three story high whereunto they make fine stair by which they pass from one room to another under the same roof for the middle part of the house be always open or uncover have some chamber build on the one side and some on the other the chamber-doore be very high and wide which in rich man house be frame of excellent and carve wood each chamber have a press curious paint and varnish belong thereunto be as long as the chamber itself be broad some will have it very high and other but six handful in height that they may set it on the tester of a bed all the portal of their house be support with bricke-piller fine plaster over except some which stand upon pillar of marble the beam and transom uphold their chamber be most curious paint and carve to some house likewise belong certain square cistern contain in breadth six or seven cubit in length ten or twelve and in height but six or seven handful be all uncover and build of brick trim plaster over along the side of these cistern be certain cock which convey the water into marbletroughe as I have see in many place of Europe when the foresay conduct be full of water that which flow over run by certain secret pipe and conveyance into the cistern and that which overflow the cistern be carry likewise by other passage into the common sink and gutter and so into the river the say cistern be always keep sweet and clean neither be they (@) but only in summer (@) when man woman and child bathe themselves therein moreover on the top of their house they usual build a turret with many pleasant room therein whither the woman for recreation sake when they be weary of work retire themselves from whence they may see well-nigh all the city over of mahometan temple and oratory there be almost seven hundred in the number and (@) of the mahometan (@) in Fez. this town fifty whereof be most stately and sumptuous build have their conduct make of marble and other excellent stone unknown to the italian and the chapiter of their pillar be artificial adorn with paint and carve the top of these temple after the fashion of christian church in Europe be make of ioise and plank but the pavement be cover with mat which be so cunning sow together that a man can see the breadth of a finger uncover the wall likewise on the inner side be line a man height with such mat moreover each temple have a turret or steeple from whence certain be appoint with a loud voice to call the people at their set-time of prayer every temple have one only priest to say service therein who have the bestow of all revenue belong to his own temple as occasion require for thereby be maintain lamp to burn in the night and porter to keep the door be pay their wage out of it and so likewise be they that call the people to ordinary prayer in the night season for those which cry from the say tower in the daytime have no wage but be only release from all tribute and exaction the chief the principal temple of Fez (@) caruven mahometan temple in this town be call caruven be of so incredible a bigness that the circuit thereof and of the building long unto it be a good mile and a half about this temple have one and thirty gate or portal of a wonder greatness and height the roof of this temple be in length 150. and in breadth about fourscore florentine cubit the turret or steeple from whence they cry amain to assemble the people together be exceed high the breadth whereof be support with twenty and the length with thirty pillar on the east west and north side it have certain walk or gallery forty cubit in length and thirty in breadth under which gallery there be a cell or storehouse wherein oil candle mat and other such necessary for the temple be lay up every night in this temple be burn nine hundred light for every arch have a several lamp especial those which extend through the mid-quire some arch there be that have 120. candle apiece there be likewise certain brasse-candlestickes so great and with so many socket as they will hold each one fifteen hundred candle and these candlestick be report to have be make of bell which the king of Fez in time past take from christian about the wall of the say temple be diverse pulpit out of which those that be learn in the mahometan law instruct the people their winter-lecture begin present after sunrise and continue the space of a hour but their summer-lecture hold on from the sun go down till a hour and a half within night and here they teach as well moral philosophy as the law of Mahumet the summer-lecture be perform by certain private and obscure person but in winter such only be admit to read as be repute their great clerk all which reader and professor be yearly allow most liberal stipend the priest of this great temple be enjoin only to read prayer and faithful to distribute alm among the poor every festival day he bestow all such corn and money as he have in his custody to all poor people according to their need the treasurer or collector of the revenue of this church have every day a ducat for his pay likewise he have eight notary or clerk under he every one of which gain six ducat a month and other six clerk who receive the rent of house shop and other such place as belong to the temple have for their wage the twenty part of all such rent and duty as they gather moreover there belong to this temple twenty factor or bailiff of husbandry that without the citie-walle have a eye to the labourer ploughman vine-planters and gardener and that provide they thing necessary their gain be three ducat a month not far from the city be about twenty lime-kils and as many bricke-kils serve for the reparation of their temple and of all house thereto belong the revenue the revenue of the great temple and how they be bestow of the say temple daily receive be two hundred ducat a day the better half whereof be lay out upon the particular aforesaid also if there be any temple in the city destitute of live they must all be maintain at the charge of this great temple and then that which remain after all expense be bestow for the behoof of the commonwealth for the people receive no revenue at all in our time the king command the priest of the say temple to lend he a huge sum of money which he never repay again moreover in the city of Fez be two most stately college of which diverse room be adorn with curious paint all their beam be carve their wall consist both of marble and freestone some college here be which contain a hundred study some more and some few all which be build by diverse king of the marin-family one there be among the rest most beautiful and admirable to behold which be erect by a certain king call Habu Henon here be to be see a excellent fountain of marble the cistern whereof contain two pipe through this college run a little stream in a most clear and pleasant channel the brim and edge whereof be workmanly frame of marble and stone of Majorica likewise here be three cloister to walk in most curious and artificial make with certain eight-square pillar of diverse colour to support they and between pillar and pillar the arch be beautiful overcast with gold azure and diverse other colour and the roof be very artificial build of wood the side of these cloister be so close that they which be without can see such as walk within the wall round about as high as a man can reach be adorn with plaister-worke of Majorica in many place you may find certain verse which declare what year the college be build in together with many epigram in the founder commendation the letter of which verse be very great and black so that they may be red a far off this college-gate be of brass most curious carve and so be the door artificial make of wood in the chapel of this college stand a certain pulpit mount nine stair high which stair be of ivory and some affirm that the king have build this college be desirous to know how much money he have spend in build it but after he have peruse a leaf or two of his account-booke find the sum of forty thousand ducat he rend it asunder and throw it into the foresay little river add this sentence out of a certain arabian writer each precious and amiable thing though it cost dear yet if it be beautiful it can choose but be good cheap neither be any thing of too high a price which please a man affection howbeit a certain treasurer of the king make a particular account of all the say expense find that this excellent building stand his master in 480000. ducat the other college of Fez be somewhat like unto this have every one reader and professor some of which read in the forenoon and some in the afternoon in time past the student of these college have their apparel and victual allow they for seven year but now they have nothing but their chamber for the war of Sahid destroy many possession whereby learning be the (@) of learning and learned man a principal cause of disorderly and base government maintain so that now the great college of all have yearly but two hundred and the second but a hundred ducat for the maintenance of their professor and this perhaps may be one reason among many why the government not only of Fez but of all the city in Africa be so base now these college be furnish with no scholar but such as be stranger and live of the citie-alme and if any citizen dwell there they be not above two or three at the most the professor be ready for his lecture some of his auditor read a text whereupon the say professor dilate and explain obscure and difficult place sometime also the scholar dispute before their professor a description of the hospital and bath in the city of Fez. many hospital there be in Fez no whit inferior either for building or beauty unto the foresay college for in they whatsoever stranger come to the city be entertain at the common charge for three day together there be likewise as fair and as stately hospital in the suburb in time past their wealth be marvelous great but in the time of sahids war the king stand in need of a great sum of money be counsel by some of his greedy courtier to sell the live of the say hospital which when the people will in no case yield unto the king orator or speaker persuade they that all those live be give by his majesty predecessor and therefore because when the war be end they shall soon recover all again that it be far better for they by that mean to pleasure their sovereign then to let his kingly estate fall into so great danger whereupon all the say live be sell the king be prevent by untimely and sudden death before he can bring his purpose to effect and so these famous hospital be deprive of all their maintenance the poor indeed and impotent people of the city be at this day relieve but no stranger be (@) save only learn man or gentleman howbeit there be another hospital for the relief of sick and disease stranger who have their diet only allow they but no physician or medicine certain woman there be which attend upon they till they recover their former health or die in this hospital likewise there be a place for frantic or distraught person where they be bind in strong iron chain whereof the part next unto their walk be strengthen with mighty beam of wood and iron the governor of these distraught person when he bring they any sustenance have a whip of purpose to chastise those that offer to bite strike or play any mad part sometime it fall out that these frantic people will call unto they such as pass by declare how unjust they be there detain and how cruel they be handle by the officer when as notwithstanding they affirm themselves to be restore unto their right mind and have thus persuade the commers-by approach near and near unto they at length they take hold with one hand on their garment and like villain with the other hand they shameful defile their face and apparel with dung and though all of they have their privy and close stool yet will they be poison in their own filth if the servant do not often wash their lodging so that their abominable and continual stink be the cause why citizen never visit they likewise this hospital have many room for the purveyor notary cook and other officer John Leo in his youth a notary of a hospital for two year together belong to the sick person who each of they have some small yearly stipend be a young man I myself be notary here for two year which office be worth three ducat a month in this city be more than a hundred bathstove very artificial and stately build which though they be not of equal bigness yet be they all of one fashion each stove have four hall without which be certain gallery in a high place with five or six stair to ascend unto they here man put off their apparel and hence they go naked into the bath in the midst they always keep a cistern full of water first therefore they that mean to bathe themselves must pass through a cold hall where they use to temper hot water and cold together than they go into a room somewhat hot where the servant cleanse and wash they and last of all they proceed into a three hothouse where they sweat as much as they think good of the say water they give unto every man two vessel only but he that will have more and will be extraordinary wash must give to the servant one Liardo at the least and to the master of the stove but two farthing the fire that heat their water be make of nought else but beast dung for which purpose many boy be set on work to run up and down to stable and thence to carry all the dung and to lay it on heap without the towne-walle which be parch in the sun for two or three month together they use for fuel likewise the woman have their stove apart from the man and yet some hothouse serve both for man and woman but at sundry time namely for man from the three to the fourteen hour of the day and the residue for woman while woman (@) bathe themselves they hang out a rope at the first entrance of the house which be a sign for man that they may then proceed no far neither may husband here be permit to speak with their own wife so great a regard they have of their honesty here man and woman both after they have do bathe use to banquet and make merry with pleasant music and sing young stripling enter the bath stark naked without any shame but man cover their privity with a linen cloth the rich sort will not enter the common bath but that which be adorn and fine set forth and which serve for nobleman and gentleman when any one be to be bathe they lay he along upon the ground anoint he with a certain ointment and with certain instrument do away his filth the rich sort have a carpet to lie on their head lie on a wooden cushion cover with the same carpet likewise here be many barber and surgeon which attend to do their office the most part of these bath pertain to the temple and college yield unto they a great sum of money for yearly rend for some give a hundred some a hundred and fifty ducat a year neither must I here omit the festival day which the servant and officer of the bathe yearly celebrate who with trumpet and pipe call their friend together go forth of the town and there gather a wild onion put it in a certain brazen vessel and cover the same with a linen cloth wet in lee afterward with a great noise of trumpet and pipe they solemn bring the say onion unto the hothouse door and there they hang it up in the little brazen vessel or laver say that this be a most happy bode or sign of good luck unto their stove howbeit I suppose it to be some such sacrifice as the ancient moor be wont in time past when they be destitute of law and civility to offer and that the same custom have remain till this very day the like be to be see even among christian who celebrate many feast whereof they can yield no reason likewise every african town have their peculiar feast which when the christian once enjoy Africa be utter abolish and do away of the inn of Fez. in this city be almost two hundred inn the great whereof be in the principal part of the city near unto the chief temple every of these inn be three story high and contain a hundred and twenty or more chamber apiece likewise each one have a fountain together with sink and water-pipe which make avoidance of all the filth never to my remembrance do I see great building except it be the spanish college at Bologna or the palace of the cardinal di San giorgio at Rome of which inn all the chamber-doore have walk or gallery before they and albeit the inn of this city be very fair and large yet they afford most beggarly entertainment to stranger for there be neither bed nor couch for a man to lie upon unless it be a course blanket and a mat and if you will have any victual you must go to the shambles yourself and buy such meat for your host to dress as your stomach stands-to in these inn certain poor widow of Fez which have neither wealth nor friend to succour they be relieve sometime one and sometime two of they together be allow a chamber for which courtesy they play both the chamberlain and cook of the inn the innkeeper of Fez be all of one family call Elcheva go apparel like woman and shave their beard and be so delight to imitate woman that they will not only counterfeit their speech but will sometime also sit down and spin each one of these have his concubine who he deny as if she be his own lawful wife albeit the say concubine be not only ill-favoured in countenance but notorious for their bad life and behaviour they buy and sell wine so free that no man control they for it none resort hither but most lewd and wicked people to the end they may more bold commit villainy the innkeeper have a consul over they and they pay tribute unto the governor of the city and when the king have occasion to send forth a army than they as be most meet for the purpose be constrain large to victual the camp have not the strait law of history enforce i to make relation of the foresay particular as they stand I will much rather have smother such matter in silence as tend so extreme to the disgrace of Fez which be reform there be not any city in all Africa for the honesty and good demeanour of the citizen comparable thereunto for the very company of these innkeeper be so odious and detestable in the sight of all honest man learned man and merchant that they will in no wise vouchsafe to speak unto they and they be firm enjoin not to enter into the temple into the burse nor into any bath neither yet be they permit to resort unto those inn which be next unto the great temple and wherein merchant be usual entertain all man in a manner be in utter detestation of these wretch but because the king army have some use of they as be aforesaid they be bear withal whether the citizen will or no. of the mill of Fez. in this city be mill in four hundred place at least and every of these place contain five or six mill so that there be some thousand of mill in the whole city every mill stand in a large room * * * * * * like unto our horse-mil upon some strong pillar or post whereunto many countrie-people use to resort certain merchant there be in Fez which hire mill and shop buy corn and sell it ready ground unto the citizen whereby they reap exceed gain for the great part of the citizen be poor and not able to lay up corn sufficient in store be fain to buy meal of they but the rich sort buy their own corn and send it to some common mill where they pay a shilling for the grind of each measure all the say mill pertain either to the temple or college for he must be very rich that have a mill of his own for every mill gain the owner two ducat a description of the occupation the shop and the market each trade or occupation have a peculiar place allot thereto the principal whereof be next unto the great temple for there first you may behold to the number of fourscore notary or scrivener shop whereof some join upon the temple and the residue stand over against they every of which shop have always two notary then westward there be about thirty stationer or bookseller the shoo-merchant which buy shoe and buskin of the shoemaker and sell they again to the citizen inhabit on the south side of the temple and next unto they such as make shoe for child only their shop be about fifty on the east side dwell those that sell vessel and other commodity make of brass over against the great gate of the say temple stand the fruit-market contain fifty shop where no kind of fruit be want next unto they stand the waxe-merchant very ingenious and cunning workman and much to be admire here be merchant factor likewise though they be but few then follow the herbe-market wherein the pome-citron and diverse kind of green bough and herb do represent the sweet and flourish spring and in this market be about twenty tavern for they which drink wine will shroud themselves under the shady and pleasant bough next unto they stand the milke-seller who have great store of such (@) vessel by they as the italian call Maiolica but their milk they cause to be bring thither in certain vessel of wood bind with iron-hoop be narrow-mouthed and broad at the bottom from these milke-seller some there be which daily buy great store of milk to make butter thereof and the residue of their milk they sell either curd or sometime sour unto the citizen so that I think there pass scarce one day over their head wherein they utter not five and twenty ton of milk next unto these be such as sell cotton and they have about thirty shop then follow those that sell hemp rope halters and such other hempen commodity then come you to the girdler and such as make pantofle and leather-bridle embroider with silk next their shop adjoin that make sword-scabberds and comparison for horse immediate after dwell those that sell salt and lime and upon they border a hundred shop of potter who frame all kind of earthen vessel adorn with diverse colour then come you to the sadlers-shop and next of all to the street of porter who as I suppose be the porter of Fez. above three hundred these porter have a consul or governor who every week allot unto part of they some set business the gain which redound thereof they put into a coffer divide it at the week end among they which have wrought the same week strange it be to consider how exceed these porter love one another for when any of they decease the whole company maintain his widow and fatherless child at their common charge till either she die or marry a new husband the child they careful bring up till they have attain to some good art or occupation whosoever of they marry and have child by his wife invite most part of his company unto a banquet who be thus invite present each of they some gift or other unto the good man or his wife no man can be admit into their company unless first he banquete the principal man thereof otherwise he be to have but half a share of the common gain free they be from all tribute and exaction yea their bread be bake of free cost if any of they be take in any heinous offence he be not public but private punish while they be at work they all wear short garment of one colour and at vacant time they be apparel as themselves think good but howsoever it be they be most honest and faire-conditioned people next unto the porter company dwell the chief cook and victualler here also stand a certain square house cover with reed wherein pease and turnep-roote be to be sell which be so great esteem of in Fez that none may buy they of the countrie-people at the first hand but such as be appoint who be bind to pay toll and tribute unto the customer and scarce one day pass wherein more than 500 sack of pease and turnip be not sold. and albeit as we have say they be so much esteem of yet be they sell at a most easy price for a man may buy 30 or at least 20. pound weight for one * * * * * * * * * * (@) in his italian (@) call it Baioco Liardo green bean likewise in time of year be sell good cheap not far from the place before mention be certain shop wherein lump or steak of flesh beat in a mortar and then fry with oil and season with much spice be to be buy every one of the say lump or steak be about the bigness of a fig and be make only of dry beef on the north side of the temple be a place whither all kind of herb be bring to make salad withal for which purpose there be 40. shop appoint next whereunto be the place of smoke so call by reason of continual smoke here be certain fritter or cake fry in oil like unto such as be call at Rome Pan Melato of these fritter great store be daily utter for every day they use to break their fast therewith and especial upon festival day unto which fritter they add for a conclusion either roast-meat or honey sometime they steep they in a homely kind of broth make of bruise meat which be sod they bray the second time in a mortar make pottage thereof and colour it with a kind of red earth they roast their flesh not upon a spit but in a oven for make two oven one over another for the same purpose in the low they kindle a fire put the flesh into the upper oven when it be well you will not believe how fine their meat be thus roast for it can be spoil either by smoke or too much heat for they be all night roast it by a gentle fire and in the morning they set it to sale the foresay steak and fritter they sell unto the citizen in so great abundance that they daily take for they more than 200. ducat for there be 15. shop which sell nothing else likewise here be sell certain fish and flesh fry and a kind of excellent savoury bread taste somewhat like a fritter which be bake with butter they never eat but with butter and honey here also be the foot of certain beast sodden wherewith the husbandman betimes in the morning break their fast and then hie they to their labour next unto these be such as sell oil salt butter cheese olive pome-citron and caper their shop be full of fine earthen vessel which be of much great value than the thing contain in they their butter and honey they sell by certain crier which be porter appoint for the same office neither do they admit every one to fill their vessel but that work be reserve for certain porter appoint to do it which also fill the measure of oil when merchant buy the same the say vessel be sufficient to contain a hundred and fifty pound of butter for so much butter the countrie-people put into each vessel then follow the shambles consist of about forty shop wherein the butcher cut their flesh a piece and sell it by weight they kill no beast within the shambles for there be a place allot for this purpose near unto the river where have once dress their flesh they send it to the shambles by certain servant appoint for that end but before any butcher dare sell his flesh unto the citizen he must carry it to the governor of the shambles who so soon as he see the the governor of the shambles in Fez. flesh he set down in a piece of paper the price thereof which they show together with their meat unto the people neither may they in any case exceed the say price next unto the shambles stand the market where course clothes be sell which contain at least a hundred shop the say cloth be deliver unto certain crier which be about threescore in number who carry the cloth from shop to shop tell the price thereof and for the sell of every duckats-woorth they have two * * * * * * * * * * in the italian copy they be call Baiochi liardos allow they this traffic of cloth endure from noon till night to the merchant great advantage then follow their shop that scour and sell armour sword javelin and such like warlike instrument next unto they stand the fishmonger who sell most excellent and great fish take both in the river of Fez and in other water exceed cheap for you may buy a pound of fish for two farthing only there be great abundance of the fish call in Rome and that especial from the begin of October till the month of April as we will declare more at large when we come to speak of the river next unto the fishmonger dwell such as make of a certain hard reed coop and cage for fowl their shop be about forty in number for each of the citizen use to bring up great store of hen and capon and that their house may not be defile with hennes-dung they keep they continual in coop and cage then follow their shop that sell liquid soap but they be not many for you shall find more of they in other part of the city neither make they soap at Fez only but also in the mountain thereabouts from whence it be bring unto the city upon mule back next of all be certain of their shop that sell meal albeit they be diverse disperse throughout the whole city next unto they be such as sell seed-graine and seed-pulse which you can buy of any citizen because that every one have rather keep his corn in store many there be likewise in the same place that will carry pulse or corn to mule or horse whithersoever you will have they a mule use to carry three measure of pulse upon his back which the be enjoin to measure in three sack lie one upon another then be there ten shop of they that sell straw next they be the market where thread and hemp be to be sell and where hemp use to be kempt which place be build after the fashion of great house with four gallery or spare-roome round about it in the first whereof they sell linnen-cloth and weigh hemp in two other sit a great many woman have abundance of sale-threed which be there sell by the crier who carry the same up and down from noon till night in the midst of this place grow diverse mulberry tree affoordiug pleasant shade and shelter unto the merchant and hither such swarm of woman resort that a man shall hardly withdraw himself from among they good sport it be sometime to see how they will barret and scold one at another yea and oftentimes you shall see they fall together by the ear let we now come to the west part which stretch from the temple to that gate that lead unto Mecnase next unto the smoky place before mention their habitation direct stand that make leather-tankard to draw water out of well of who there be some fourteen shop unto these adjoin such as make wicker-vessel and other to lay up meal and corn in and these enjoy about thirty shop next they be 150. shop of tailor and next the tailor be those that make leather-shielde such as I have often see bring into Europe then follow twenty shop of laundress or washer be people of a base condition to who the citizen that have not maid of their own carry their shirt and other foul linen which after few day be restore unto they so clean and white as it be wonder these laundress have diverse shop adjoin together in the same place but here and there throughout the city be above two hundred family of such person next unto the laundress be those that make tree for saddle who dwell likewise in great number eastward right in the way to the college found by king Abuhinan upon these adjoin about forty shop of such as work stirrup spur and bridle so artificial as I think the like be not to be see in Europe next stand their street that first rude make the say stirrup bridle and spur from thence you may go into the street of saddler which cover the saddle before mention threefold with most excellent leather the best leather they lie uppermost and the worst beneath and that with notable workmanship as may be see in most place of Italy and of they there be more than a hundred shop then follow their long shop that make pike and lance next stand a rock or mount have two walk thereupon the one whereof lead to the east gate and the other to one of the king palace where the king sister or some other of his kindred be usual keep but this be by the way to be note that all the foresay shop or market begin at the great temple howbeit that I may not invert my set-order I have only describe those place that be round about the say temple mind last of all to speak of the merchant station or burse of the station or burse of merchant in Fez. this burse you may well call a city which be wall round about have twelve gate and before every gate a iron chain to keep horse and cart from come in the say burse be divide into 12. several ward or part two whereof be allot unto such shoemaker as make shoe only for nobleman and gentleman and two also to silke-merchant or haberdasher that sell ribbon garter scarf and such other like ornament and of these there be about fifty shop other there be that sell silk only for the embroder of shirt cushions and other such furniture make of cloth possess almost as many shop as the former then follow those that make woman girdle of course wool which some make of silk but very gross for I think they be (@) then two finger thick so that they may serve almost for cable to a ship next unto these girdler be such as sell woollen and linen clothe bring out of Europe which have also silke-stuffe cap and other like commodity to sell. have pass these you come to they that sell mat mattress cushion and other thing make of leather next adjoin the customer office for their cloth be send about by certain crier to be sell who before they can pass must go to the customer to have the say cloth seal and to pay toll unto the customer crier here be to the number of sixty which for the cry of every cloth have one * * * * or (@) Liardo allow they next of all dwell the tailor and that in three several street then come you to the linendraper which sell smock and other apparel for woman and these be account the rich merchant in all Fez for their ware be the most gainful of all other next unto these be certain woollen garment to be sell make of such cloth as be bring thither out of Europe every afternoon cloth be sell in this place by the crier which be lawful for any man to do when necessary occasion urge he last of all be that place where they use to sell wrought shirt towel and other embroider work as also where carpet bed and blanket be to be sold. the reason why this part of the city be call Caesaria the foresay burse or station of merchant be in time past call Caesaria according to the name of that renown conqueror (@) Caesar the reason whereof some affirm to be because all the city of Barbary be in those day first subject to the roman and then to the goth and each city always have either roman or goth to receive and take charge of the tribute howbeit because the people often make civil a (@) use in Africa how to keep the prince tribute and merchant good in security war and assault upon they their determination be in every city to build some strong wall place where both the tribute and the principal good of the citizen may remain in safety hope by this mean that the citizen will be as careful of the prince good as of their own which course have the italian imitate they have never be spoil so often of their good for in civil war it many time befall that the greedy soldier not be satisfy with the enemy good will prey upon the wealth of their friend of the grocer apothecary and other tradesman and (@) of Fez. next unto the say burse on the north side in a straight lane stand a hundred and fifty grocer and apothecary shop which be fortify on both side with two strong gate these shop be guard in the night season by certain hire and arm watchman which keep their station with lantern and mastiff the say apothecary can make neither (@) ointment nor electuary but such thing be make at home by the physician and be of they to be buy the physician house adjoin for the most part unto the apothecary howbeitvery few of the people know either the physician or the use of his physic the shop here be so artificial build and adorn that the like I think be no where else to be find John Leo be at Tauris in persia. be in Tauris a city of Persia I remember that I see diverse stately shop curious build (@) certain gallery but very dark so that in my judgement they be far inferior unto the shop of Fez. next the apothecary be certain artificer that make comb of box and other wood eastward of the apothecary dwell the needle-maker possess to the number of fifty shop then follow those that turn ivory and such other matter who because their craft be practise by some other artisan be but few in number unto the turner adjoin certain that sell meal soap and broom who dwell next unto the threed-market beforementioned be scarce twenty shop in all for the residue be disperse in other place of the city as we will hereafter declare among the cotton-merchant be certain that sell ornament for tent and bed next of all stand the fowler who though they be but few yet be they store with all kind of choice and dainty fowl whereupon the place be call the fowler market then come you to their shop that sell cord and rope of hemp and then to such as make high cork slipper for nobleman and gentleman to walk the street in when it be foul weather these corke-slipper be fine trim with much silk and most excellent upper leather so that the cheap will cost a ducat (@) some there be of ten ducat and some of five and twenty ducat price such slipper as be account most fine and costly be make of black and white mulberie-tree of black walnut-tree and of the jujubatree albeit the corke-slipper be the most durable and strong unto these adjoin ten shop of spanish moor which make crossbow as also those that make broom of a certain wild palm-tree such as be daily bring out of (@) to Rome these broom they cartie about the city in a great basket either sell they or exchange they for bran ash or old shoe the bran they sell again to shepherd the ash to such as white thread and the old shoe to cobbler next unto they be smith that make nail and cooper which make certain great vessel in form of a bucket have corne-measure to sell also which measure when the officer appoint for the same purpose have make trial of he be to receive a farthing apiece for his fee then follow the wooll-chapman who have buy wool of the butcher put it forth unto other to be scour and wash the sheepskin they themselves dress but as for oxe-hides they belong to another occupation and be tan in another place unto these adjoin such as make certain langols or withe which the african put upon their horse foot next of all be the brazier then such as make weight and measure and those likewise that make instrument to card wool or flax at length you descend into a long street where man of diverse occupation dwell together some of which do polish and enamel stirrup spur and other such commodity as they receive from the smith rough and rude hammer next who dwell certain cartwright's plow-wrights mill-wrights and of other like occupation dyer have their abode by the river side and have each of they a most clear fountain or cistern to wash their silke-stuffe in over against the dyer dwell maker of bulwark or trench in a very large place which be plant with shady mulberietree be exceed pleasant in the summertime next they be a company offarrier that shoe mule and horse and then those that make the ironwork of crossbow then follow smith that make horseshoe and last of all those that white linnen-cloth and here the west part of the city end which in time past as be aforesaid be a city by itself and be build after the city on the east side of the river a description of the second part of Fez. the second part of Fez situate eastward be beautify with most stately palace temple house and college albeit there be not so many trade and occupation as in the part before describe for here be neither merchant tailor shoemaker etc. but of the mean sort
