here be notwithstanding thirty shop of grocer near unto the wall dwell certain bricke-burners and potter and not far from thence be a great market of white earthen vessel platter cup and dishes next of all stand the corne-market wherein be diverse granary to lay up corn over against the great temple there be a broad street pave with brick round about which diverse handicraft and occupation be exercise there be likewise many other trade diverse disperse over this east part of the city the draper and grocer have certain peculiar place allot unto they in this east part of Fez likewise there be five hundred and twenty weaver house very stately and sumptuous build have in each of they many worke-house and loom which yield great rent unto the owner (@) there be by report in this city twenty thousand and as many miller moreover in this part of Fez be a hundred shop for the whiting of thread the principal whereof being situate upon the river be exceed well furnish with kettle cauldron and other such vessel here be likewise many great house to see wood in which work be perform by christian captive and whatsoever wage they earn redound unto their lord and master these christian captive be not suffer to rest from their labour but only upon friday and upon eight several day of the year beside whereon the moor feast be solemnize here also be the common stew for harlot which be favour by great man and sometime by the chief governor of the city likewise there be certain vintner who be free permit to keep harlot and to take filthy hire for they here be also more than six hundred clear fountain wall round about and most chary keep every one of which be several convey by certain pipe unto each house temple college and hospital and this fountain-water be account the best for that which come out of the river be in summer oftentimes dry up as likewise when the conduct be to be cleanse the course of the river must of necessity be turn out of the city wherefore every family use to fetch water out of the say fountain and albeit in summertime the chief gentleman use river-water yet they will often call for fountain-water because it be more cool and pleasant in taste but in the spring-time it be nothing so these fountain have their original for the most part from the west and south for the north part be all full of mountain and marble-rock contain certain cave or cell wherein corn may be keep for many year of which cave some be so large that they will hold two hundred bushel of corn the citizen dwell near those cave and such as possess they do sufficient maintain themselves in take yearly every hundred bushel for rent the south part of east Fez be almost half destitute of inhabitant howbeit the garden abound with fruit and flower of all sort every garden have a house belong thereunto and a christall-fountaine environ with rose and other odoriferous flower and herb so that in the spring-time a man may both satisfy his eye and solace his mind in visit this part of the city and well it may be call a paradise sithence the nobleman do here reside from the month of April till the end of September westward that be towards the king palace stand a castle build by a king of the luntune-familie resemble in bigness a whole town wherein the king of Fez before the say palace be build keep their royal residence but after new Fez begin to be build by the marinking the say castle be leave only to the governor of the city within this castle stand a stately temple build as aforesaid what time it be inhabit by prince and noble many place be afterward deface and turn into garden howbeit certain house be leave unto the governor partly to dwell in and partly for the decide of (@) here be likewise a certain prison for captive support with many pillar and be so large that it will hold as diverse be of opinion three thousand man neither be there any several room in this prison for at Fez one prison serve for all by this castle run a certain river very commodious for the governor of the magistrate the administration of justice and of the apparel use in Fez. in the city of Fez be certain particular judge and magistrate and there be a governor that define civil controversy and give sentence against malefactor likewise there be a judge of the canon law who have to do with all matter concern the mahometan religion a three judge there be also that deal about marriage and divorcement who authority be to hear all witness and to give sentence according next unto they be the high advocate unto who they appeal from the sentence of the say judge when as they do either mistake themselves or do ground their sentence upon the authority of some inferior doctor the governor gain a great sum of money by condemn of party at several time their manner of proceed against a malefactor be this the punishment of malefactor in Fez. have give he a hundred or two hundred stripe before the governor the executioner put a iron-chaine about his neck and so lead he stark-naked his privity only except through all part of the city after the executioner follow a sergeant declare unto all the people what fact the guilty person have commit till at length have put on his apparel again they carry he back to prison sometime it fall out that many offender chain together be lead about the city and the governor for each malefactor thus punish receive one ducat and one four part and likewise at their first entrance into the jail he demand of each one a certain duty which be pay particular unto he by diverse merchant and artificer appoint of purpose and among his other live he gather out of a certain mountain seven thousand ducat of yearly revenue so that when occasion serve he be at his proper cost to find the king of Fez three hundred horse and to give they their pay those which follow the canon-law have neither stipend nor reward allow they for it be forbid by the law of Mahumet that the judge of his religion shall reap any commodity or fee by their office but that they shall live only by read of lecture and by their priesthood in this faculty be many advocate and proctor which be extreme idiote and utter void of all good learning there be a place also in Fez whereinto the judge useto cast the citizen for debt or for some light offence in all this city be four officer or sergeant only who from midnight till two a clock in the morning do walk about all part of the city neither have they any stipend but a certain fee of such malefactor as they lead about in chain according to the quality of every man crime moreover they be free permit to sell wine and to keep harlot the say governor have neither scribe nor notary but pronounce all sentence by word of mouth one only there be that gather custom and tribute over all the city who daily pay to the king use thirty ducat this man appoint certain substitute to watch at every gate where nothing be it of never so small value can pass before some tribute be pay yea sometime they go forth of the city to meet with the carrier and muleteer upon the high way to the end they may not conceal nor close convey any merchandise into the city and if they be take in any deceit they pay double the set order or proportion of their custom be this namely to pay two ducat for the worth of a hundred for onix-stone which be bring hither in great plenty they pay one four part but for wood corn ox and hen they give nothing at all neither at the enter of the city do they pay any tribute for ram but at the shambles they give two * * * * or Baiochi liardos apiece and to the governor of the shambles one the say governor of the shambles have always twelve man wait upon he and oftentimes he ride about the city to examine the weight of bread and find any bread to fail of the due weight he cause the baker to be beat with cudgel and to be lead in contempt up and down the city the say office be wont to be allot unto man of singular honesty but now adays every ignorant and lewd person enjoy it the citizen of Fez go very civil and decent attire in the spring-time wear garment make of outlandish cloth over these shirt they wear a jacket or cassock be narrow and halfe-sleeved whereupon they wear a certain wide garment close before on the breast their cap be thin and single like unto the nightcap use in Italy save that they cover not their ear these cap be cover with a certain scarf which be twice wreathe about their head and beard hang by a knot they wear neither hose nor breech but in the spring-time when they ride a journey they put on boot mary the poor sort have only their cassock and a mantle over that call * * * * or (@) and a most course cap. the doctor and ancient gentleman wear a certain garment with wide sleeve somewhat like to the gentleman of Venice the common sort of people be for the most part clad in a kind of course white cloth the woman be not altogether unseemly apparel but in sommer-time they wear nothing save their smock only in winter they wear such a wide sleeve garment be close at the breast as that of the man before mention when they go abroad they put on certain long breech wherewith their leg be all cover have also after the fashion of Syria a veil hang down from their head which cover their whole body on their face likewise they wear a mask with two little hole only for their eye to peep out at their ear they adorn with golden earring and with most precious jewel the mean sort wear (@) of silver and gilt only upon their arm the lady and gentlewoman wear golden bracelet and the residue silver as likewise gold or siluer-rings upon their leg according to each one estate and ability of their manner of eat and drink let we now speak somewhat of their victual and manner of eat the common sort set on the pot with fresh meat twice every week but the gentleman and rich sort every day and as often as they list they take three meal a day their breakfast consist of certain fruit and bread or else of a kind of liquid pap make like unto frumenty in winter they sup off the broth of shall flesh thicken with course meal to dinner they have flesh salad cheese and olive but in summer they have great cheer their supper be easy of digestion consist of bread melon grape or milk but in winter they have sodden flesh together with a kind of meat call Cuscusu which be make of a lump of dough be set first upon the a kind of (@) call Cuscusu fire in certain vessel full of hole and afterward be temper with butter and pottage some also use often to have roast-meat and thus you see after what sort both the gentleman and common people lead their life albeit the (@) fare somewhat more dainty but if you compare they with the nobleman and gentleman of Europe they may seem to be miserable and base fellow not for any want or scarcity of victual but for want of good manner and cleanliness the table whereat they sit be low uncover and filthy seat they have none but the bare ground neither knife or (@) but only their ten talon the say Cuscusu be set before they all in one only platter whereout as well gentleman as other take it not with spoon but with their claw five the meat and pottage be putal in one dish out of which every one rake with his greasy fist what he think good you shall never see knife upon the table but they tear and greedy devour their meat like hungry dog neither do any of they desire to drink before he have well stuff his paunch and then will he sup off a cup of cold water as big as a milke-bowle the doctor indeed be somewhat more orderly at meal but to tell you the very truth in all Italy there be no gentleman so mean which for fine diet and stately furniture excel not the great potentate and lord of all Africa the manner of solemnize marriage as touch their marriage they observe these course follow so soon as the maid father have espouse she unto her lover they go forthwith like bride and bridegroom to church accompany with their parent and kinsfolk and call likewise two notary with they to make record before all that be present of the covenant and dowry the mean sort of people usual give for their daughter dowry thirty ducat and a woman-slave of fifteen ducat price as likewise a particoloured garment embroider with silk and certain other silk skarf or iag to wear upon her head in stead of a hood or veil then a pair of fine shoe and two excellent pair of startup and last many pretty knack curious make of silver and other metal as namely comb perfuming-pan bellows and such other trinket as woman have in estimation which be do all the guest present be invite to a banquet whereunto for great dainty be bring a kind of bread fry and temper with honey which we have before describe then they bring roast-meat to the board all this be at the bridegroom cost afterward the bride father make a banquet in like sort who if he bestow on his daughter some apparel beside her dowry it be account a point of liberality and albeit the father promise but thirty ducat only for a dowry yet will he sometime bestow in apparel and other ornament belong to woman two hundred yea sometime three hundred ducat beside but they seldom give a house a vineyard or a field for a dowry moreover upon the bride they bestow three gown make of costly cloth and three other of silk chamlet or of some other excellent stuff they give her smock likewise curious wrought with fine veil and other embroider vesture as also pillow and cushion of the best sort and beside all the former gift they bestow eight carpet or coverlet on the bride four whereof be only for seemliness to spread upon their press and cupboard two of the courser they use for their bed and the other two of leather to lay upon the floor of their bedchamber also they have certain rug of about twenty else compass or length as likewise three quilt be make of linen and woollen on the one side and stuff with flock on the other side which they use in the night in manner follow with the one half they cover themselves and the other half they lie under they which they may easy do when as they be both way about ten else long unto the former they add as many coverlet of silk very curious embroider on the upperside and beneath line double with linen and cotton they bestow likewise white coverlet to use in summertime only and last they bestow a woollen hang divide into many part and fine wrought as namely with certain piece of gild leather whereupon they sow iag of particoloured silk and upon every iag a little ball or button of silk whereby the say hang may for ornament sake be fasten unto a wall here you see what be the appurtenance of their dowry wherein some do strive so much to excel other that oftentimes many gentleman have bring themselves unto poverty thereby some italian think that the husband bestow a dowry upon his wife but they altogether mistake the matter the bridegroom be ready to carry home his bride cause she to be place in a wooden cage or cabinet eight-square cover with silk in which she be carry by porter her parent and kinsfolk follow with a great noise of trumpet pipe and drum and with a number of torch the bridegroom kinsman go before with torch and the bride kinsfolk follow after and so they go unto the great market place and have pass by the temple the bridegroom take his leave of his father in law and the rest hie he home with all speed and in his chamber expect the presence of his spouse the father brother and uncle of the bride lead she unto the chamber-door and there deliver she with one consent unto the mother of the bridegroom who as soon as she be enter touch her foot with he and forthwith they depart into a several room by themselves in the mean season the banquet be come forth and a certain woman stand before the (@) door expect till the bridegroom have deflower his bride reach she a napkin stain with blood which napkin she carry incontinent and show to the guest proclaim with a loud voice that the bride be ever till that time a unspotted and pure virgin this woman together with other woman her companion first the parent of the bridegroom and then of the bride do honourable entertain but if the bride be find not to be a virgin the marriage be make frustrate and she with great disgrace be turn home to her parent at complete marriage they make for the most part three banquet the first the same day when the bridegroom and bride be join in wedlock the second the day follow for woman only and the three seven day after whereat all the kinsfolk and friend of the bride be present and this day the bride father according to his ability send great store of dainty dish unto his son in law but so soon as the new marry man go forth of the house which be for the most part on the seven day after the marriage he buy great plenty of fish which he cause his mother or some other woman to cast upon his wife foot and this they from a ancient superstitious custom take for a good bode likewise at the bridegroom father they use to make two other feast the one upon the day before the bride be marry and so that night they spend in dance and disport the morrow after a company of woman go to dress the bride to comb her lock and to paint her cheek with vermillion her hand and her foot they die black but all this paint present lose the fresh hue and this day they have another banquet the bride they place in the high room that she may be see of all and then those that dress the bride be condign entertain be come to the bridegroom house his parent salute the new bride with certain great cup full of new wine and cake with other iuncat which we will here pass over in silence all which be bestow upon the bridegroom companion the same night which we say be spend in dance there be present at the bridall-house certain minstrel and singer which by turn sometime use their instrument and sometime voice-musicke they dance always one by one and at the end of each galliard they bestow a largesse upon the musician if any one will honour the dancer he bid he kneel down before he and have fasten piece of money all over his face the musician present take it off for their fee the woman dance alone without any man at the noise of their own musician all these thing use to be perform when the bride be a maid but the marriage of the marriage of widow widow be conclude with less ado their cheer be boil beef and mutton and stew hen with diverse iuncate dish among in stead of trencher the guest be ten or twelve in number have so many great round platter of wood set before they and this be the common custom of gentleman and merchant the mean sort present their guest with certain sop or bruesse of bread like unto a pan-cake which be dip in flesh-pottage they eat out of a great platter not with spoon but with their finger only and round about each great platter stand to the number of ten or twelve person likewise they make a solemn feast at the circumcision of their male child which be upon the seven day after their birth the circumcision of their child and at this feast the circumciser together with all their friend and kinsfolk be present which be do each one according to his ability bestow a gift upon the circumciser in manner follow every man lay his money upon a lad face which the circumciser bring with he whereupon the lad call every one by his name give they thanks in particular and then the infant be circumcise they spend that day with as great jollity as a day of marriage but at the birth of a daughter they show not so much alacrity of their rite observe upon festival date and their manner of mourn for the dead among the people of Fez there have remain certain relic (@) christian ceremony (@) among the (@) of festival day institute of old by the christian whereupon they use certain ceremony which themselves understand not upon Christmas even they eat a salad make of diverse herb they see likewise that night all kind of pulse which they feed upon for great dainty upon newyear day the child go with mask and vizard on their face to the house of gentleman and merchant and have fruit give they for sing certain carol or song when as the feast of saint John Baptist be hallow among christian you shall here see all about great store of fire make with straw and when their child tooth begin to grow they make another feast call according to the latin Dentilla they have also many other rite and custom of divine or soothsay the like whereof I have see at Rome and in other city of Italy as touch their feast prescribe by the mahometan law they be at large set down in that brief treatise which we have write concern the same law the woman have by death lose their funeral their husband father or any other of their dear friend assemble forthwith a great multitude of their own sex together who strip themselves out of their own attire put on most vile sackcloth and defile their face with much dirt then call they certain man clad in woman attire bring great fower-square drum with they at the noise of which drum the women-mourner sing a funeral song tend as much as may be to the commendation of the party decease and at the end of every verse the say woman utter most hideous shriek and outcry tear their hair and with much lamentation beat their cheek and breast till they be all-imbrued with blood and so these heathenish superstition continue for seven whole day together at which seven day end they surcease their mourn for the space of 40. day and then they begin anew to torment themselves for three day together in manner aforesaid howbeit these kind of obsequy be observe only by the base people but the gentleman and better sort behave themselves more modest at this time all the widow friend come about she to comfort she and send diverse kind of meat unto she for in the mourn house they may dress no meat at all till the dead corpse be carry forth the woman herself that lose her husband father or brother never go forth with the funeral but how they wash and bury the dead corpse and what superstition they use thereabouts you shall find record in my little treatise above mention of their dove-house diverse there be in this city that take much pleasure in keep of dove which be here in great plenty of all colour these dove they keep in certain cage or locker on the top of their house which locker they set open twice a day to wit morning and evening delight great to see they fly for those that out-flie the residue be account the best oftentimes it fall out that neighbour dove will be mingle together for which cause you shall see the owner go together by the ear some have a certain net bind unto two long cane wherewith they use to take their neighbour dove as they come fly forth of their lover among the collier you shall find seven or eight shop only of those that sell dove their manner of game at Fez. the citizen use most of all to play at chess and that from ancient time other game there be also but very rude and use only by the common people at certain time of the year the boy of one street will fight with club against the boy of another street and that sometime with so great fury that they (@) themselves to other weapon and slay one another especial upon their festival day what time they will challenge and provoke one another forth of the citie-walle and have fight hard all the whole day at night they fall to throw of stone till at length the citie-officer come upon they take some and beat they public throughout the city sometime it fall (@) that the young stripling arm themselves and go by night out of the city range up and down the field and garden and if the contrary faction of yoonker and they mere it be wonder what a bloody skirmish ensue howbeit they be often most severe punish for it of the african poet in Fez there be diverse most excellent poet which make verse in their own mother tongue most of their poem and song entreat of love every year they pen certain verse in the commendation of Mahumet especial upon his birthday for then betimes in the morning they resort unto the palace of the chief judge or governor ascend his tribunall-seate and from thence read their verse to a great audience of people and he reward for poet in Fez. who verse be most elegant and pithy be that year proclaim prince of the poet but when as the king of the marin-family prosper they use to invite all the learned man of the city unto their palace and honourable entertain they they command each man in their hear to recite their verse to the commendation of Mahumet and he that be in all man opinion esteem the best poet be reward by the king with a hundred ducat with a excellent horse with a woman-slave and with the king own robe wherewith he be then apparel all the rest have fifty ducat apiece give they so that none depart without the king liberality but a hundred and thirty year be expire since this custom together with the majesty of the Fessan kingdom decay a description of the grammar-schoole in Fez. of school in Fez for the instruct of child there be almost two hundred every one of which be in fashion like a great hall the schoolmaster teach their child to write and read not out of a book but out of a certain great table every day they expound one sentence of the Alcoran and have red quite through they begin it again repeat it so often till they have most firm commit the same to memory which they do right well in the space of 7. year then read they unto their scholar some part of orthography howbeit both this and the other part of grammar be far more exact teach in the college then in these trivial school the say schoolmaster be allow a very small stipend but when their boy have learn some part of the Alcoran they present certain gift unto their master according to each one ability afterwards so soon as any boy have perfect learn the whole Koran his father invite all his son schoolfellow unto a great banquet and his son in costly apparel ride through the street upon a gallant horse which horse and apparel the governor of the royal citadel be bind to lend he the rest of his schoolfellow be mount likewise on horseback accompany he to the banquet house sing diverse song to the praise of God and of Mahumet then be they bring to a most sumptuous banquet whereat all the kinsfolk of the foresay boy father be usual present every one of who bestow on the schoolmaster some small gift and the boy father give he a new suit of apparel the say scholar likewise use to celebrate a feast upon the birthday of Mahumet and then their father be bind to send each man a torch unto the school whereupon every boy carry a torch in his hand some of which weigh thirty pound these torch be most curious make be adorn round about with diverse fruit of wax which be light betimes in the morning do burn till sunrise in the mean while certain singer resound the praise of Mahumet and so soon as the sun be up all their solemnity cease this day use to be very gainful unto the schoolmaster for they sell the remnant of the wax upon the torch for a hundred ducat and sometime for more none of they pay any rent for his school for all their school be build many year ago and be free bestow for the train up of youth whatsoever ornament or toy be upon the (@) the schoolmaster divide they among their scholar and among the singer both in these common school and also in the college they have two day of recreation every week wherein they neither teach nor study of the fortune-teller and some other artisan in Fez. we have say nothing as yet of the leatherdresser who have diverse mansion by the river side pay for every skin a halfpenny custom which amount yearly almost unto three hundred ducat here be likewise surgeon and barber who because they be so few I think not to have mention in this place now let we speak of the fortune-teller and diviner of who there be a great number and three kind for one three sort of diviner in Fez. sort use certain geomanticall figure other pour a drop of oil into a vial or glass of water make the say water to be transparent and bright wherein as it be in a mirror they affirm that they see huge swarm of devil that resemble a whole army some whereof be travel some be pass over a river and other fight a land-battell who when the divine see at quiet he demand such question of they as he be desirous to be resolve of and the devil give they answer with beckon or with some gesture of their hand or eye so inconsiderate and damnable be their credulity in this behalf the foresay glasse-viall they will deliver into child hand scarce of eight year old of who they will ask whether they see this or that devil many of the city be so besot with these vanity that they spend great sum upon they the three kind of diviner be women-witche which be affirm to have familiarity with devil some devil they call red some white and some black devil and when they will tell any man fortune they perfume themselves with certain odour say that then they possess themselves with that devil which they call for afterward change their voice they feign the devil to speak within they then they which come to inquire ought with great fear and tremble ask these vile and abominable witch such question as they mean to propound and last offer some fee unto the devil they depart but the wise and honest sort of people call these woman sahaoat which in latin signify fricatrice because they have a damnable custom to commit unlawful venery among themselves which I can express in any modest term if fair woman come unto they at any time these abominable witch will burn in lust towards they no otherwise then lusty yoonker do towards young maid and will in the devil behalf demand for a reward that they may lie with they and so by this mean it often fall out that think thereby to fulfil the devil command they lie with the witch yea some there be which be allure with the delight of this abominable vice will desire the company of these witch and feign themselves to be sick will either call one of the witch home to they or will send their husband for the same purpose and so the witch perceive how the matter stand will say that the woman be possess with a devil and that she can no way be cure unless she be admit into their society with these word her silly husband be persuade do not only permit she so to do but make also a sumptuous banquet unto the damn crew of witch which be do they use to dance very strange at the noise of drum and so the poor man commit his false wife to their filthy disposition howbeit some there be that will soon conjure the devil with a good cudgel out of their wife other feign themselves to be possess with a devil will deceive the say witch as their wife have be deceive by they of the conjurer enchanter and juggler in Fez. in Fez likewise there be a kind of juggler or conjurer call Muhazzimin who of all other be report to be most speedy caster out of devil and because their necromancy sometime take effect it be a wonder to see into what reputation they grow thereby but when they can cast forth a devil they say it be a airy spirit their manner of adjure devil be this first they draw certain character and circle upon a ash-heape or some other place then describe they certain sign upon the hand and forehead of the party possess and perfume he after a strange kind of manner afterwards they make their enchantment or conjuration inquire of the devil which way or by what mean he enter the party as likewise what he be and by what name he be call and last charge he to come forth other there be that work by a certain cabalistical rule call Zairagia this rule be contain in many write for it be think to be natural magic neither be there any other necromancer in all Fez that will more certain and true resolve a doubtful question howbeit their art be exceed difficult for the student thereof must have as great skill in astrology as in cabala myself in time past have attain to some knowledge in this faculty continue I remember a whole day in describe one figure only which kind of figure be describe in manner follow first they draw many circle within the compass of a great circle in the first circle they make a cross at the four extremity whereof they set down the four quarter of the world to wit east west north and south at each end of one of the say cross line they note either pole likewise about the circumference of the first circle they paint the four element then divide they the same circle and the circle follow into four part and every four part they divide into other seven each one be distinguish with certain great arabian character so that every element contain eight and twenty character in the three circle they set down the seven planet in the four the twelve sign of the zodiac in the five the twelve latin name of the month in the six the eight and twenty house of the moon in the seven the 365. day of the year and about the convexity thereof the four cardinal or principal wind then take they one only letter of the question propound multiply the same by all the particular aforenamed and the product or sum total they divide after a certain manner place it in some room according to the quality of the character and as the element require wherein the say character be find without a figure all which be do they mark that figure which seem to agree with the foresay number or sum produce wherewith they proceed as they do with the former till they have find eight and twenty character whereof they make one word and of this word the speech be make that resolve the question demand this speech be always turn into a verse of the first kind which the arabian call Ethavil consist of eight and twelve according to the meet of the arabian tongue whereof we have entreat in the last part of a arabian grammar write by John leo. our arabian grammar and the verse consist of those character comprehend always a true and infallible answer unto the question propound resolve first that which be demand and then expound the sense of the question itself these practitioner be never find to err which cause their art of cabala to be have in great admiration which although it be account natural yet never see I any thing that have more affinity with supernatural and divine knowledge I remember that I see in a certain open place of king Abulunan his college in Fez upon a floor pave with excellent smooth marble the description of a figure each side of this floor or court be fifty (@) long and yet two three part thereof be occupy about the figure and about the thing pertain thereto three there be that make the description every one attend his appoint place and they be a whole day in set it down another such figure I see at Tunis draw by one that be marvelous cunning in the art who father have write two volume of commentary or exposition upon the precept of the same art wherein whosoever have exact skill be most high esteem of by all man I myself never see but three of this profession namely one at Tunis and two other at Fez likewise I have see two exposition upon the precept of the say art together with a commentary of one margian father unto the foresay cabalist which I see at Tunis and another write by Ibnu caldim the historiographer and if any be desirous to see the precept and commentary of that art he may do it with the expense of fifty ducat for sail to Tunis a town near unto Italy he may have a sight of all the particular aforesaid I myself have fit opportunity divination and soothsay forbid by the law of (@) of time and a teacher that offer to instruct i in the same art howbeit I think good not to accept his offer because the say art be forbid and account heretical by the law of Mahumet for mahumets law affirm all kind of divination to be vain and that God only know secret and thing to come wherefore sometime the say cabalist be imprison by the mahometan inquisitour who cease not to persecute the professor of that art of certain rule and stition observe in the Mahumet a law here also you may find certain learned man which will have themselves call wizard and moral philosopher they observe certain rule which Mahumet never prescribe by some they be account catholic or true mahumetan and by other they be hold for heretic howbeit the great part of the common people reverence they as if they be god notwithstanding they commit many thing unlawful and forbid diverse mahometan sect by the mahometan law as namely whereas the say law forbid any love-matter to be express in any musical ditty or song these moralist affirm the contrary in the foresay mahometan religion be a great number of rule or sect every of which have most learned patroness and protector the foresay sect spring up fourscore year after Mahumet the first author thereof be call Elhesen Abilhasen and be bear in the town of Basora this man teach his disciple and follower certain precept but write he leave none behind he about a hundred year after there come another notable doctor of that sect from bagaded call Elharit Ibnu ese who leave volume of write unto his disciple afterwards those that be find to be his follower be all condemn by the mahometan patriarch and lawyer howbeit 80. year after that sect begin to revive again under a certain famous professor who draw after he many disciple unto who he publish his doctrine this man at length and all his follower be by the patriarch and lawyer condemn to die which he understanding write forthwith unto the patriarch request that he may be license to dispute with the lawyer as touch his doctrine of who if he be convince he will most willing suffer death otherwise that it will be against all equity that so many innocent shall perish upon a unjust accusation the patriarch think his demand to be reasonable condescend whole thereunto but when the matter come to disputation the party condemn soon put all the lawyer to silence which when the patriarch perceive he revoke the sentence as unjust and cause many college and monastery to be erect for the say party and his follower after which time this sect continue about a hundred year till the emperor Malicsach of the turkish race come thither out of Asia the great and destroy all the maintainer thereof whereupon some of they flee unto cairo and the rest into Arabia be disperse here and there for the space of twenty year till in the reign of Caselsah nephew unto one of his counsellor and a man of a high spirit be addict unto the say sect so restore erect and confirm the same that by the help of one Elgazzuli a most learned man who have write of the same argument a notable work divide into seven part he reconcile the lawyer with the disciple of this sect conditional that the lawyer shall be call conserver of the prophet Mahumet his law and the sectary reformer of the same this concord last between they till bagade be sack by the tartar which befall in the year of the Hegeira (@) sack by the tartar 656. at what time those sectary so increase that they swarm almost over all Africa and Asia neither will they admit any into their society but such as be very learned and train up in all kind of liberal science to the end they may the better defend their own opinion and confute their adversary but now adays they admit all kind of rude and ignorant person affirm all sort of learning to be needless for the holy spirit say they reveal the knowledge of the truth unto such as be of a clean hart and they allege many reason for the confirmation of this their opinion though not very forcible wherefore despise their ancestor rite and the strict observation of the law they addict themselves to nought else but delight and pleasure feast often and sing lascivious song sometime they will rend their garment either allude thereby to the verse that they sing or be move thereunto by their corrupt and vile disposition say false that they be then ravish with a fit of divine love but I rather impute it to their abundance of meat and gluttony for each one of they will devour as much meat as may well suffice three or which be more likely they utter those passionate clamour and out-cry because they be inflame with unlawful and filthy lust for sometime it happen that some one of the principal of they with all his scholar and disciple be (@) to the marriage of some gentleman and at the begin of the banquet they will rehearse their devout orison and song but so soon as they be rise from the table the elder of the company be about to dance tear their garment and if any one in the midst of their dance that have drink immoderate chance to fall down he be take up forthwith by one of the scholar and to too lascivious kiss whereupon this proverb grow among the people of Fez the heremite banquet which they use in reproach of those master that make their scholar their minion of diverse other rule and sect and of the superstitious credulity of many among these sect there be some that have not only a diverse law but also a different belief from the residue whereupon by some other they be call heretic some there be also which hold that a man by good work by fast and abstinence may attain unto the nature of a angel which good work fast etc. do say they so purge and free the mind from all contagion of evil that by no mean it can sin any more though it will never so fain howbeit they think themselves not capable of this felicity before they have ascend thereunto by the degree of fifty discipline or science and although they fall into sin before they be come to the fifty degree yet they say that God will not impute that sin unto they these fellow indeed in the beginning lead a most strict life and do even macerate and consume themselves with fast but afterward they give themselves to all licentiousness and pleasure they have also a most severe form of live set down in four book by a certain learned man of their faction call sehravard and bear in the city of Corasan likewise there be another author call ibnul Farid that describe all their religion in witty verse which be fraught with allegory seem to entreat of nought but love wherefore one Elfargani expound the say verse with a commentary and thereout gather the canon and order of the sect and show the degree to the attainment of felicity moreover the say verse be so sweet and elegant that the maintainer of this sect will sing and repeat none other in their banquet for these three hundred year no author have so adorn their language as the say ibnul these sectary take the heaven the element the planet and the fix star to be one god and that no law nor religion be erroneous for every man say they may lawful worship that which his mind be most addict to worship they think that all the knowledge of God be infuse into one man who they call in their language Elcorb this man they say be elect by god and be make equal in knowledge to he forty there be among they call all by the name of elauted which signify in our language a block or stock of a tree out of this number when their decease they create another in his room namely seventy person that have the authority of election commit unto they there be likewise 765. other who name I do not well remember who be choose into the say elector room when any of they decease these 765. be bind thereunto by a certain canon or rule of their order be constrain always to go unknown and they range almost all the world over in a most vile and beggarly habit so that a man will take they for mad man and estrange from all sense of humanity for these lewd miscreant under pretence of their religion run like rogue naked and savage throughout all Africa have so little regard of honesty or shame that they will like brute beast ravish woman in public place and yet forsooth the gross common people reverence they as man of wonder holiness great swarm of these filthy vagabond you may see in Tunis but many more in Egypt and especial at alcair whereas in the market call bain elcasrain I see one of these villain with i own eye in the presence of much people deflower a most beautiful woman as she be come forth of the bath which be do the fond people come flock about the say woman strive to touch her garment as a most holy thing say that the adulterer be a man of great sanctity and that he do not commit the sin but only seem to commit it which when the silly cuckold her husband understand he show himself thankful to his false god with a solemn banquet and with liberal give of alm the magistrate of the city will have punish the adulterer but they be in hazard to be slay of the people for their labour who as be before say adore these varlet for saint and man of singular holiness other more villainous act I see commit by they which I be ashamed to report of the caballiste and certain other sect likewise there be another sort of man which we may fit call cabalist these fast most strait neither do they eat the flesh of any live creature but have certain meat and garment allot unto they they rehearse likewise certain set-praier appoint for every hour of the day and for the night according to the variety of day and month and they use to carry about certain square table with character and number engrave therein they feign themselves to have daily conference with the angel of who they learn they say the knowledge of all thing they have once a famous doctor of their sect call (@) who be author of their canon prayer and square table which when I see i think their profession have more affinity with magic then with cabala their art be divide into eight part whereof the first be call Elumha Enormita that be the demonstration of light the which contain prayer and fast the second call semsul Meharif that be the sun of science contain the foresay square table together with their use and profit the three part they call (@) Lasmei Elchusne this part contain a catalogue of those 99 virtue which they say be contain in the name of God which I remember I see at Rome in the custody of a certain Venetian Jew they have also a certain other rule call Suvach that be the rule of heremite the professor and follower whereof inhabit wood and solitary place neither have they any other food but such as those wild desert will afford the conversation of these heremite no man be able exact to describe because they be estrange from all human society but if I shall take upon i to describe the variety of mahometan sect I shall digress too far from my present purpose he that desire to know more of this matter let he read over the book of Elefacni who discourse at large of the sect 72. principal sect in the religion of Mahumet belong to the mahometan religion the principal whereof be 72. every one of which defend their opinion to be true and good and such as a man may attain salvation by at this day you shall find but two principal sect only the one of Leshari be disperse over all Africa Egypt Syria Arabia and Turkey the other of Imamia which be authorize throughout the whole kingdom of Persia and in certain town of Corasan and this sect the great sophi of Persia maintain insomuch that all Asia have like to be destroy thereabouts for whereas before they follow the sect of Leshari the great sophi by force of arm establish his own of Imamia and yet one only sect stretch over all the mahometan dominion of such as search for treasure in Fez. moreover in the city of Fez there be certain man call Elcanesin who suppose to find treasure under the foundation of old house do perpetual search and delve these gross fellow use to resort unto certain den and cave without the citie-walle certain persuade themselves that when the roman be chase out of Africa and drive into baetica or Granada in Spain they hide great abundance of treasure in the bowel of the earth which they can not carry with they and so enchant the same by art-magique that it can by no mean be attain unto but by the same art wherefore they seek unto enchanter to teach they the art of dig up the say treasure some of they there be that will steadfast affirm that they see gold in this or that cave other that they see silver but can not dig it out by reason that they be destitute of perfume and enchantment fit for the purpose so that be seduce with this vain opinion and deep delve into the earth they turn upside down the foundation of house and sepulchre and sometime they proceed in this manner ten or twelve day journey from Fez yea so fond they be and so besot that they esteem those book that profess the art of dig gold as divine oracle before my departure from Fez these fantastical people have choose they a consul and get licence of certain owner to dig their ground when they have dig as much as they think good they pay the say owner for all damage commit of the alchemisst of Fez. in this city likewise there be great store of alchemist which be mighty addict to that vain practice they be most base fellow and contaminate themselves with the steam of sulphur and other stink smell in the evening they use to assemble themselves at the great temple where they dispute of their false opinion they have of their art of alchemy many book write by learned man among which one geber be of principal account who live a hundred year after Mahumet and be a greek bear be say to have renounce his own religion this geber his work and all his precept be full of allegory or dark borrow speech likewise they have another author that write a huge volume of the same art entitle by the name of Attogrehi this man be secretary unto the sultan of bagaded of who we have write in the life of the arabian philosopher a book write by John (@) of the life of the arabian philosopher also the song or article of the say science be write by one Mugairibi of Granada whereupon a most learned mamaluch of Damascus write a commentary yet so that a man may much more easy understand the text than the exposition thereof of alchemisst here be two sort whereof the one seek for the elissir that be the matter which colour brass and other metal and the other be conversant about multiplication of the quantity of metal whereby they may convenient temper the same but their chief drift be to coin counterfeit money for which cause you shall see most of they in Fez with their hand cut off of charmer andinchanter of snake in this city likewise there be a great swarm of base people such as the italian common call Ciurmatori these sing foolish song and rhyme in all the street of the city and broach mere trifle with the music of drum harp and cittern they sell unto the rude people certain scroll or brief charm instead of preservative unto these you may add another kind of refuse people of one family and disposition with the former who carry dance ape up and down and have their neck and arm all entwine with (@) snake these also profess geomancy and persuade woman that they can foretell they their (@) likewise they carry stone-horse about with they which for a certain fee they will let other have to cover their mare I can here reckon up more sort of people but let it suffice to have admonish in this place that the great part of the forename be people of most base condition and such as bear little good will to stranger albeit there be but a few in this city by reason it be distant more than a hundred mile from the sea the way thither also be rough and dangerous their gentle man be very stately and high mind and will have little or no familiarity at all with the citizen so likewise the doctor and judge of principal account will admit but few unto their acquaintance this city itself be most beautiful and right commodious situate where albeit in winter time the street be so miry that you can walk in they without startup yet they let pass such abundance of water out of their conduct that all the filth be wash clean away where conduct be want they carry all the dirt in cart unto the next part of the river a description of the suburb without the foresay city of Fez. without the wall of this city westward stand a suburb contain almost five hundred family the house whereof be but mean and the inhabitant base as namely driver of camel water-bearer and cleaver of wood for the king palace yet here you may find diverse shop and all kind of artificer here likewise dwell all the charmer and roguish minstrel before name as also great swarm of sluttish and filthy harlot in the principal street of this suburb you shall find certain cave most artificial hew out of excellent marble wherein the noble man of Fez be wont to lay up their corn but after that by reason of the war it be often take from thence they have since usual convey their corn into new Fez and there store it up and from that time to this the marble-cave have remain desolate it be a wonder to see how wide and large these cave be for the least of they will contain more than a thousand measure of corn there be above a hundred and fifty of they in all but now they lie waste and open insomuch that diverse fall into they at unaware for which cause their brim be environ with wall here every one may play the vintner and the bawd so that this suburb may just be call the sink of Fez. from the twenty hour you shall see none at all in their shop for then every man run to the tavern to disport to spend riotous and to be drunken another suburb there be allot unto the leper of who there be two hundred family these leprous person the habitation of leper in Fez and their governor have a governor which gather certain yearly revenue from the nobleman and take such care of the say leper that they want no necessary thing he be bind by his office to discharge the city of all leprous person and to compel all such as he understand to be infect with that disease to depart into the foresay suburb if any leper chance to die without issue part of his good be employ to the common benefit of the leper and part fall to the governor share but if he have any child they enjoy his good among the leper also those be place which be infect with white botch or with any other incurable malady next beyond stand another suburb inhabit only with muleteer plasterer and woodmonger which although it be but little yet contain it about a hundred and fifty family moreover upon the way lead westward from the city there be another great suburb of more than four hundred house howbeit they be low and base and the inhabitant be beggarly which neither can nor will dwell among any other people by this suburb there be a certain broad plain which lead to the river two mile off and extend westward almost three mile upon this plain every week there be a exceed great market of cattle likewise the shopkeeper of the city resort hither and sell their ware in tent also a certain company of gentleman use to come hither and to divide a ram among themselves leave the head unto the butcher for his fee but the foot and the skin they sell unto the wooll-chapman for those ware that be here sell they pay so little tribute to the king that it be not worth the mention but this one thing I must in no wise pass over in silence namely that I never see neither in Asia Africa nor Italy a market either more populous or better furnish with ware not far from Fez stand certain high rock environ with a ditch of two mile compass out of which rock certain matter be hew to make lime withal near unto the say ditch be many furnace some whereof be so large that they will contain more than six thousand measure of lime and this lime be make at the cost of the rich citizen in Fez. westward without the wall of Fez by the river side stand about a hundred cottage which be only inhabit by they that white linen cloth hither in the spring and in summer use the citizen to bring their linen cloth spread it upon the meadow and as often as they see it dry in the sun cast water thereupon which water they fetch either out of the river or out of some cistern in certain leather tankard make for the same purpose but at night each one carry his cloth into the foresay cottage neither be the meadow wherein they bleach their cloth ever destitute of grass a most gallant prospect it be to behold a far off the white clothes disperse over the green meadow and the crystal stream of the river which seem to be of a azure hue run along all which the poet have celebrate in their verse a description of the common place of burial without the city many field there be without the city which have be give by certain nobleman for the burial of the dead upon their sepulchre for the most part they lay a long threesquare stone when any noble man or any principal citizen decease they lie one stone over his head and another over his foot whereon use to be engrave some epitaph with the day and year when the party decease I myself bestow much labour in gather of epitaph which I see both about Fez and in other place of Barbary all which be set down in a book I give unto the king brother the matter of their epitaph be diverse some tend to consolation and other to sorrow of the sepulcher of the king of Fez. northward of the city upon a certain high hill stand a palace wherein be the monument of diverse marin king be most artificial hew out of marble with epitaph upon they so that I can condign express the majesty and beauty thereof a description of their garden without the north east and south part of the city be great store of garden replenish with all kind of fruit and with stately tree through the midst of these gardenn they derive some small vain of the river some whereof be so full of tree that you will take they for grove rather than for garden these garden they manure not at all but only water they continual in the month of May whereupon they have great abundance of fruit all their fruit save their peach only be of a most delicate taste whereof so soon as they be ripe above five hundred cart-loades be daily carry into the market beside grape which here I do not mention but the say fruit be carry unto a certain place in Fez where tribute be pay for they they be sell by crier unto the fruiterer there present in the same place likewise after pay of tribute they sell certain negro-slave towards the east of Fez lie a plain fifteen mile broad and thirty mile long this plain be full of fountain and freshet and be reserve for the use of the great temple it be farm out unto gardiner who sow thereupon such abundance of hemp melon turnip or navewe radish and other such like root and herb that every summer there be say to be gather thereof above fifteen thousand cartload and as many in winter howbeit the air be very unwholesome thereabouts for the inhabitant be continual vex with fever and be of a yellowish colour of that part of Fez which be call new Fez. new Fez be environ with a high and impregnable wall and situate on a most beautiful plain not far from the river side be almost a mile distant from old Fez and that upon the east and south side thereof between the wall of either town to the northward enter a certain arm of the river where the foresay mill do stand and the other part of the river be sever into two branch one whereof run between new Fez and old Fez not far from the edge of the rock and the other pass through certain valley and garden trend at length southward the other part of the river hold on his course by the rock and so by the college of king * * * * or Aburinan Abutiman this city of new Fez jacob the son of Abdultach cause to (@) build who be the first king of the marin family and expel the king of Maroco and usurp the kingdom unto himself but the founder of new Fez. the king of Telensin to the end he may make the people of Maroco behold unto he and may subvert the prosperous success of the marin family go about to hinder the king of Fez his attempt against Maroco wherefore king jacob have finish the war of Maroco determine to revenge himself to the uttermost for the injury offer by they of Telensin but consider with himself that the strong town of his own kingdom be far distant from Telensin he think it a better course to build this city whereunto the seat royal of all Maroco may be translate which be erect he call the white city but it be afterward name by the inhabitant new Fez. this city king jacob the founder divide into three part whereof the first contain his royal palace and diverse noble man house unto every one of which he allot a most pleasant garden not far from his palace he build a most stately and sumptuous temple in another part of this city he build a large and fair stable for the king horse to stand in then also he cause other palace to be erect for his captain and principal courtier from the west gate to the east he appoint the market place the distance between which gate be a mile and a half and on both side he place artificer and merchant shop at the west gate he cause a fair portal to be set up to harbour the watchman and warder of the city not far from thence he erect two stable sufficient to contain three hundred horse which he may use for the protection of his own palace the three part of the city be appoint for the king guard and attendant which be most of they bear eastward of Fez neither have they any other weapon but hand-bowe for crossbow be not then use in that kingdom unto which attendant the king allow a large stipend but now the same place be full of beautiful temple and stove near unto the king palace stand the mint have in the midst a fower-square court with certain portal or cell round about it wherein the money-minters dwell likewise there be another lodging in the midst of the same court where the governor of the mint with his scribe and notary have their abode here as well as in any other place whatsoever commodity be raise redound whole to the king near unto the mint stand the goldsmith shop who consul or governor keep the seal and stamp of the coin in Fez neither ring nor any other jewel or commodity can be make of silver or gold before the metal be seal for the offender be most severe punish and the metal be seal whatsoever be make thereof be weigh as if it be money the great part of goldsmith dwell in new Fez be jew who carry their vessel of gold and silver unto a certain place of old Fez near unto the grocer shop and there sell they for in old Fez neither gold nor silver be coin nor any mahometan be suffer to be goldsmith because they have usurer among they which will sell any piece of wrought silver or gold dear than the weight require albeit the same privilege be by the governor of the city grant unto the jew some there be also that only make plate for the citizen who be pay hire only for their work that part of the city which the king attendant or guard once possess be now inhabit by jew for now a day the king use no such guard the jew indeed first dwell in old Fez but upon the death of a certain king they be all rob by the moor whereupon king abusabid cause they to remove into new Fez and by that mean double their yearly tribute they therefore even till this day do occupy a long street in the say new city wherein they have their shop and synagogue and their number be marvellous increase ever since they be drive out of Spain these jew be have in great contempt by all man neither be any of they permit to wear shoe but they make they certain sock of sea-rush on their head they wear a black * * * orturbant dulipan and if any will go in a cap he must fasten a red cloth thereunto they pay unto the king of Fez monthly four hundred ducat at length within the space of a hundred and forty year this new city be environ with most impregnable wall and adorn with temple college palace and other such building as serve to beautify a city so that I engine for the conveyance of water think there be more bestow in garnish of the city then in building of the wall without the citie-walle be build many huge wheel or engine for the convey of river-water over the say wall into cistern from whence it be convey in certain channel and pipe unto the temple garden and palace the say wheel be build not full a hundred year past before which time water be bring unto the city by a certain conduct from a fountain ten mile distant of which artificial conduct a certain genovese be then in great favour with the king be report to have be the author but the wheel they say be invent by a Spaniard and in they there be marvelous cunning workmanship for to the conveyance of so huge a quantity of water each wheel be turn about but four and twenty time only in a day and a night to conclude here be but few gentleman in this city except such as attend upon the court for the residue be base and mechanical people but such as carry any show of honesty do so hate and disdain the king courtier and gentleman that they will by no mean vouchsafe to marry their daughter unto they of the fashion and custom use in the king court among all the prince of Africa I never red of any that be create by the common suffrage and consent of the people unto his kingdom or princedom or that be call from any strange province or city to bear rule also by the law of Mahumet no man may bear any secular authority which may be call lawful save only the mahometan patriarch and prelate howbeit the say patriarch authority decrease daily more and more the ringleader of such people as range up and down the desert begin to invade place inhabit and civilize and by force of arm against mahumets law and maugre his prelate to ordain sundry prince as for example in the east whereas the turk cordian and tartar have usurp dominion over such as be not able to repel they so likewise in the west part first the family of Zeneta and Luntuna than the seditious mahometan preacher and afterward the family of marin get the upper hand howbeit the family of Luntuna be report to have aid the western region and to have release they from the fury of the seditious heretic wherein they show themselves friend and not enemy but afterward their tyranny begin to show itself and this be the reason why they do not now a day attain unto government by hereditary succession or by election of the people or of the nobility but the prince himself when he feel death seize upon he call about he all his peer and noble and bind they by oath to establish his son brother or any other who he most favour in his kingdom but they after the prince decease neglect their oath will choose any other who they list and this be ordinary the election of the king of Fez who so soon as he be proclaim king choose forthwith some one of his noble to be his chief counsellor and on he he bestow the three part of all his kingly revenue the manner of choose officer in the court of Fez. then choose another to be his secretary treasurer and high steward of his household then be create the captain of the horseman appoint for the king guard and these horseman with their horse live most common in the field last he appoint a new governor over every city unto who all the tribute and revenue of the same place redound with condition that as often as any war betide he shall maintain a certain company of horse to the king service after a while also he place certain deputy and commissioner over his people inhabit the mountain and over the arabian subject unto he the governor of city diverse administer justice according to the custom of the place some there be also appoint by the king to collect all the tribute and revenue of his kingdom and due to pay the same unto he likewise there be other choose who they call in their language keeper or guardian and unto every one of these the king give some castle or village whereby he may procure his own maintenance and be able to serve the king in time of war moreover the king of Fez maintain a troop of light horseman who so long as they serve the king in his camp have their diet allow they out of the king provision but in time of peace he find they corn butter and pouldered flesh for the whole year but money they have very seldom once a year they be apparel at the king cost neither do they provide for their horse either within the city or without for the king furnish they with all necessary those that give attendance to their horse be christian captive which go shackle in great chain and fetter but when the army remove any whither the say christian be carry upon camel back another officer there be that give attendance only to the camel assign certain pasture unto the herdsman and divide field among they and make such provision for the king camel as himself shall think expedient each camel-driver have two camel which be lade with the king furniture according to the appointment of the governor likewise the king have a certain purveyor or steward who office be to provide keep and distribute corn both to the king household and to his army this man in time of war have ten or twelve tent to lay up corn in and every day with change of camel he send for new corn lest the army shall be unprovided of victual he have also cook at his command moreover there be a governor or mastergroome of the stable who provide for the king horse mule and camel and be furnish with all necessary by the steward there be another also appoint overseer of the corn who duty it be to provide barley and other provender for the beast and this man have his scribe and notary about he who diligent set down all particular expense for they must give up a perfect account unto the chief steward they have also a certain captain over fifty horseman which horseman may well be call pursuivant for they be send by the secretary in the king name to do his business likewise the Fezzan king have another captain of great name be as it be governor of his guard who in the king name may compel the judge to do justice and to put their sentence in execution this man authority be so great that sometime he may commit principal nobleman to ward and may severe punish they according to the king commandment moreover the say king have a most trusty chancellor who keep the great seal and write and sign the king letter he have also a great number of footman the governor of who accept and dismiss who he think good and give to every one wage according to his agility and desert and whensoever the king come in place of judgement the say governor always attend upon he and be in a manner his high chamberlain also there be another that take charge of the carriage and baggage of the army and cause the tent of the light horseman to be carry up and down on mule and the tent of the other soldier on camel there be likewise a company of ensigne-bearer who in march on a journey carry their colour wrap up but he that go before the army have his banner display and of a great height and every one of the say standard-bearer know most exact always ford of river and passage through wood wherefore they be for the most part appoint to guide the army the drummer of who there be great store in the king host play upon certain drum of brass as big as a great kettle the low part whereof be narrow and the upper broad be cover with a skin these drummer ride on horseback have always on the one side of their horse a great weight hang down to counterpoise the heaviness of their drum on the other side they be allow most swift horse because the moor account it a great disgrace to loose a drum the say drum make such a loud and horrible noise that they be not only hear a far off but also strike exceed terror both upon man and horse and they be beat only with a bull pizzle the musician be not maintain at the king charge for the city be bind at their cost to send a certain number of they to the war who according to their demeanour in the war be admit or not admit unto the king table this king have also a certain master of ceremony who sit at his foot in the senate-house and command each man to sit down and to speak according to his dignity all the maidservant in the king family be negro-slave which be partly chamberlain and partly waiting-maid and yet his queen be always of a white skin likewise in the king of Fez his court be certain christian captive be partly Spanish and partly Portugal woman who be most circumspect keep by certain eunuch that be negro-slave the king of Fez have very large dominion but his revenue be small to wit scare three hundred thousand ducat the five part whereof redound not to the king for the remainder be divide into sundry portion as we have before signify yea the great part of the say revenue be pay in corn cattle oil and butter all which yield but small store of money in some place they pay a ducat and one four part tribute for every acre but in other place a whole family pay but so much in some other region each man above fifteen year of age pay as much tribute also neither be the people of this great city more vex with any thing then with pay of their tribute and imposition here also be to be note that the mahometan governor the priest only except may not exact great revenue than those that Mahumet have allot unto they namely of every of their subject which possess 100 ducat in ready money they be to have two ducat and a half for yearly tribute every husbandman likewise be bind to pay for tribute the ten part of all his corn and all the say tribute he appoint to be pay unto the patriarch who shall bestow that which be superfluous for the prince to have upon common use namely for the relieve of poor impotent people and widow and for maintain of war against the enemy but since the patriarch begin to decay the prince as we have beforesaid exercise tyranny for it be not sufficient for they to exact all the forename tribute and riotous to consume the same but also to urge people unto great contribution so that all the inhabitant of Africa be so oppress with daily exaction that they have scarce wherewithal to feed and apparel themselves for which cause there be almost no man of learning or honesty that will seek any acquaintance with courtier or will invite they to his table or accept any gift be they never so precious at their hand think that whatsoever good they have be get by theft and bribery the king of Fez continual maintain the king of Fez his guard six thousand horseman five hundred crossbow and as many harquebusier be at all assay prepare for the war who in time of peace when the king go on progress lie within a mile of his person for be at home in Fez he need not so strong a guard when he wage how the king of Fez ride on progress war against the arabian that be his enemy because the forename garrison be not sufficient he require aid of the arabian his subject who at their own cost find he a great army of man better train to the war than his own soldier beforementioned the pomp and ceremony of this king be but mean neither do he willing use they but only upon festival day and when mere necessity require when the king be to ride forth the master of ceremony signify so much unto certain herbenger or post whereupon the herbenger give notice thereof unto the king * * * * * or kine folk parent unto his nobility his senator captain guardian and gentleman who present arrange themselves before the palace gate at the king come forth of the palace the herbenger appoint unto each man his place and order of ride first and foremost go the standard-bearer next the drummer then follow the chief groom of the stable with his servant and family after he come the king pensioner his guard his master of ceremony his secretary his treasurer and last of all his chief judge and his captain general at length come the king accompany with his principal counsellor or with some other great peer before the king also ride certain officer belong to his person whereof one carry his sword-royall another his shield and the three his crossbow on each side of he march his footman one carry a payer of stirrup another the king partisan the three a cover for his saddle and the four a halter for his horse and so soon as the king be dismount they forthwith cover his saddle and put the foresay halter upon his horsehead likewise there be another footman that carry the king pantofle most artificial wrought after the king follow the captain of the footman than the eunuch the king family the light horseman and last of all the crossbow and harquebusier the apparel of the king be then very moderate and plain insomuch that if a man know he not he will think he to be absent for the attendant be far more sumptuous attire moreover no mahometan king or prince may wear a crown diadem the king of Fez his (@) of warfare or any such like ornament upon his head for that be forbid by the law of Mahumet when the king lie with his army in the field first his own great tent be pitch in a four square form like unto a castle each side of the say square be fifty else in length at every of the four corner stand a little sharp turret make of cloth with a gallant sphere on the top which glister like gold this royal pavilion have four gate every one of which be keep by eunuch within the say pavilion be contain diverse other tent among which be the king lodging be frame in such wise that it may easy be remove from place to place next unto it stand the tent of the nobleman and of such as be most in the king favour then the lodging of the principal guard be make of goates-skinne after the arabian fashion and in the midst of all stand the king kitchen and his pantry not far from hence the light horseman have their abode who all of they be victual out of the king storehouse notwithstanding their attire be very base next of all be the stable wherein their horse be marvelous well tend without this circuit keep such as carry the tent and the king furniture from place to place here be also butcher victualler and such like all merchant and artificer that resort hither take up their abode next unto the tent-carrier so that the king pavilion be pitch like a strong city for it be so environ with the lodging of the guard and with other tent adjoin that there be very difficult passage to the king round about the say royal pavilion there be certain appoint to watch and ward all night long howbeit they be base and unarmed people in like sort there be a watch keep about the stable but sometime so negligent that not only some horse have be steal but there have be find enemy in the king own pavilion that come to murder he the king live the great part of the year in the field both for the safeguard of his kingdom and also that he may keep his arabian subject in obedience and sometime he recreate himself with hunt and sometime with play at chess I know right well how tedious I have be in the description of this city but because it be the metropolitan not only of Barbary but of all Africa I think good most particular to decipher every parcel and member thereof of the town of Macarmeda this town stand almost twenty mile eastward of Fez and be build by the family of Zeneta upon the bank of a most beautiful river it have in time past a large territory and great store of inhabitant on both side of the say river be many garden and vineyard the king of Fez be wont to assign this town unto the governor of their camel but in the war of sahid it be so destroy and waste that at this day scarce be there any mention of wall to be find but the field thereof be now in the possession of certain gentleman of Fez and of the peasant of the castle of hubbed this castle stand upon the side of a hill about six mile from Fez and from hence you may behold the city of Fez and all the territory adjacent it be found by a certain hermit of Fez be repute for a man of singular holiness the field thereto belong be not very large because the house be demolish it be utter destitute of inhabitant the wall only and the temple as yet remain in this castle I live four summer because it stand in a most pleasant air be separate from concourse of people and a solitary place fit for a man to study in for my father have get a lease of the ground adjoin to this castle from the governor of the temple for many year of the town of Zavia the town of Zavia be found by joseph the second king of the marin-famy and be distant from Fez about fowerteene mile here king joseph build a stately hospital and command that his corpse shall be inter in this town but it be not his fortune here to be bury for
