he be slay in the war against tremizen from thencefoorth Zavia fall to decay and grow destitute of inhabitant wherein at this present the hospital only remain the revenue of this place be give unto the great temple of Fez but the field thereof be till by certain arabian dwell in the region of Fez. of the castle of Chaulan the ancient castle of Chaulan be build upon the river Sebu eight mile a (@) (@) southward of Fez. not far from this castle there be a certain hot bath whereunto Abulhezen the four king of the marin-famy add a fair building unto this bath once a year in the month of April the gentleman of Fez usual resort remain there four or five day together there be no civility to be find in this castle for the inhabitant be base people and exceed covetous of the mountain of zelag this mountain begin eastward from the river of Sebu extend thence almost fowerteene mile westward and the high part thereof to the north be seven mile distant from Fez. the south part of this mountain be utter destitute of inhabitant but the north side be exceed fertile and plant with great store of castle and town most of their field be employ about vineyard the grape whereof be the sweet that ever I taste and so likewise be their olive and other fruit the inhabitant be very rich have most of they house in the city of Fez. and so likewise most part of the gentleman of Fez have vineyard upon the say mountain at the north foot of this mountain the field be replenish with all kind of grain and fruit for all that plain be water southward with the river Sebu and here the gardiner with certain artificial wheel and engine draw water out of the river to moisten their garden in this plain be wellnigh two hundred acre of ground the revenue whereof be give unto the king master of ceremony howbeit he make thereof not above five hundred ducat a year the ten part of all which revenue amount to three thousand bushel of corn belong to the king provision of mount Zarhon this mountain begin from the plain of Esais lie ten mile distant from the city of Fez westward it extend thirty mile and be almost ten mile broad this mountain be all cover with waste and desert wood be otherwise well store with olive in this mountain there be of sheepefolde and castle to the number of fifty and the inhabitant be very wealthy for it stand between two flourish city that be to say Fez on the east and Mecnase on the west the woman weave woollen cloth according to the custom of that place and be adorn with many silver ring and bracelet the man of this mountain be most valiant and be much give to pursue and take lion whereof they send great hunt of lion use by the king of Fez. store unto the king of Fez. and the king hunt the say lion in manner follow in a large field there be certain little cell make be so high that a man may stand upright in they each one of these cell be shut fast with a little door and contain within every of they a arm man who open the door present himself to the view of the lion then the lion (@) the door open come run towards they with great fury but the door be shut again he wax more furious than before then bring they forth a bull to combat with the lion who enter a fierce and bloody conflict wherein if the bull kill the lion that day sport be at a end but if the lion get the victory than all the arm man be ordinary twelve leap forth of their cell and invade the lion each one of they have a iavelin with a pike of a and a half long and if these arm man seem to be too hard for the lion the king cause their number to be diminish but perceive they too weak the king with his company from a certain high place where he stand to behold the sport kill the lion with their crossbow and oftentimes it fall out that before the lion be slay some one of the man die for it the residue be sore wound the reward of those that encounter the lion be ten ducat apiece and a new garment neither be any admit unto this combat but man of redoubt valour and such as come from mount Zelagi but those that take the lion first be inhabitant of mount Zarhon of Gualili a town of mount Zarhon this town be build by the roman upon the top of the foresay mountain what time they be lord of Granada in south Spain it be environ around with mighty thick wall make of smooth and hew stone the gate be large and high and the field be manure for the space of six mile about howbeit this town be long sithence destroy by the african but afterward when the schismatic idris come into this region he begin to repair this desolate town and to replant it so with inhabitant that within short time it grow very populous howbeit after his decease it be neglect by his son be whole addict as be beforesaid unto the build of Fez. and yet idris lie bury in this town who sepulchre be visit with great reverence almost by all the people of Barbary for he be as high esteem as if he have be some patriarch because he be of the lineage of Mahumet at this present there be but two or three house in all the town which be there build for the honour and maintenance of the sepulchre the field adjacent be exceed well husband and their garden be most pleasant by reason of two sweet freshet run through they the which diverse wind themselves about the little hill and valley do water all that plain of a certain town call the palace of Pharaoh this town be found by the roman upon the top of a hill about eight mile distant from Gualili the people of this say mountain together with some historiographer be most certain persuade that this town be build by Pharaoh king of Egypt in the time of Moses and take the name from the first founder which notwithstanding I think to be otherwise for I can read in no approve author that either Pharaoh or any other egyptian ever inhabit these region but I suppose that this fond opinion be take out of that book which one Elcabi write concern the word of Mahumet for the say book affirm from the authority of Mahumet that there be four king only that govern the whole world two whereof be faithful and the other two ethnic the faithful he (@) be Alexander the great and Solomon the son of David and the ethnic be Nimrod and Pharaoh but I be rather of opinion by the latin letter which be there engrave in the wall that the roman build this town about this town run two small river on either side thereof the little hill and valley adjacent do great abound with olive not far from hence be certain wild desert frequent with lion and leopard of the town call Pietra Rossa or the red rock PIetra Rossa be a small town build by the roman upon the side of the foresay mountain be so near the forest that the lion will come tame (@) daily into the town and gather up bone in the street yea they be so tame and familiar that neither woman nor child be afeard of they the wall of this town be build very high and of great stone but now they be ruin in many place and the whole town be diminish into one street their field be join unto the plain of Azgara abound with olive and all kind of pulse of the town of Maghilla MAghilla be a little town found of old by the roman upon that side of the foresay hill which look towards Fez. about this town be most fertile field and great enrich with olive there be a plain likewise contain many fresh fountain and well store with hemp and flax of the castle of shame this ancient castle be build at the foot of the say mountain near unto the high way from Fez to Mecnase and it be call by this name because the inhabitant be most shameful addict to covetise like unto all the people thereabouts in old time it be report that a certain king pass by who the inhabitant of the castle invite to dinner request he to change the ignominious name of the place which when the king have condescend unto they cause according to their custom a company of ram to be slay and certain bladder and vessel to be fill with milk to serve for the king breakfast the morrow after but because the say vessel be very large (@) consult together to put in half milk and half water hope that (@) king shall never perceive it the day follow albeit the king be not very hasty of his breakfast yet his servant urge he thereunto he perceive the milk to be half water whereat smile he say friend that which nature have give no man can (@) away and with that say he depart now this castle be raze to the ground and utter destroy but the territory thereof be occupy by certain miserable arabian of the region of beni guariten the region of beni guariten lie eastward of (@) about eighteen mile it be altogether hilly and mountainous abound with all kind of pulse and with store of good pasture and medow-ground and contain almost two hundred village their house be in all place rude build and the inhabitant be base people neither have they any vineyard or garden nor any tree that bear fruit this region the king of Fez usual divide among his young brother and sister the inhabitant have great store of corn and wool and albeit they be pass rich yet go they very mean attire they ride only upon ass for which cause they be have in great derision by their neighbour of the region call Aseis this region be distant to the west of Fez almost twenty mile and be by the inhabitant call Aseis it consist of a perpetual plain whereupon some conjecture that it have have in old time many village and castle whereof now there be no mention at all nor so much as a sign of any building only the name of place yet remain this region extend westward eighteen and southward almost twenty mile the soil be most fertile and bring forth black and small grain well and fountain be here very rare it be wont to be subject unto certain arabian husbandman but now it be assign by the king unto the governor of that city of mount togat this mountain stand almost seven mile westward of Fez be very high and but of small breadth eastward it extend to the river Bunafe be about five mile distant all that side which look towards Fez and the top thereof and that part which lie over against essich be wonderful replenish with vine and with all kind of grain upon the top of this mountain be diverse cave and hollow place where the searcher of treasure suppose that the roman hide up their wealth as we have before signify the say treasure-searcher so soon as the vintage be past use to take great pain in dig of the rock and albeit they find nothing yet will they not give over all the fruit of this mountain be most unpleasant both to the (@) and to the taste and yet they be soon ripe than the fruit of other place thereabouts of mount this mountain be near unto Atlas be almost forty mile distant from Fez. from hence spring a certain river which run westward fall into the river bath this mountain stand between two most large and spacious plain whereof the one to Fez ward be as we have before say call Aseis and the other lie southward be name adecsen which adecsen be most fertile both for corn and pasture and they be possess by certain arabian call zuhair be vassal unto the king of Fez but the king assign for the most part this plain unto his brother or some other of his kinsfolk out of which they yearly gather ten thousand ducat the foresay arabian be continual molest by certain other arabian call Elhusein which live in the desert for in summertime they usual invade the plain wherefore the king of Fez for the defence of this region maintain a certain number of horseman and of crossbow this plain be water with christall-fountaine and pleasant river near unto the say plain be diverse wood and forest where lion keep Tame lion which be so gentle and tame that any man may drive they away with a staff neither do they any harm at all now let we proceed unto the description of Azgara a description of Azgara one of the seven principal region belong to the kingdom of Fez. this region border northward upon the ocean-sea westward upon the river of buragrag eastward upon the mountain partly of Gumera partly of Zarhon and partly of zalag and southward it be enclose with the river of Bunasar this region consist altogether of plain ground be a most fertile soil and in old time very populous and adorn with many town and castle which be now so deface and ruin by reason of war that small village only be leave for the inhabitant to hide their head in the length of this region be about fourscore and the breadth almost three score mile through the midst thereof run the river of subu the arabian inhabitant be call Elculoth be descend from the family of muntafic they be subject to the king of Fez and pay unto he large tribute howbeit they be rich and curious in their apparel and be such valiant soldier that the king of Fez levy his whole army of they only when he have any war of great moment to achieve this region abundant furnish not only Fez but all the mountain of Gumera with victual horse and other cattle and here the king of Fez usual remain all winter and the spring by reason of the temperature and wholesomeness of the air here be great plenty of roe and hare and yet very few wood of Giumha a town in Azgara this town the african build in our time by a river side upon that plain over which the way lie from Fez to the city of Harais and it be distant from Fez about thirty mile it be in time pass very populous but now it lie so desolate by reason of the war of Sahid that it serve only for cave and receptacle for the arabian to lay up their corn in for the safeguard whereof they pitch certain tent near unto the place of the town of Harais this town be found by the ancient african upon the ocean sea shore near unto the mouth of the river Luccus one side thereof adjoin upon the say river and the other side upon the main ocean when the moor be lord of Arzilla and Tangia this town be well inhabit but those two town be win by the christian Harais remain destitute of inhabitant almost twenty year together howbeit afterward the king of Fez his son fear the portugal invasion cause it strong to be fortify and keep with a perpetual garrison the passage unto this town by the river mouth be very dangerous and difficult likewise the king son cause a castle to be build wherein be maintain a garrison of two hundred crossbow a hundred harquebusier and three hundred light horseman near unto the town be diverse meadow and fen where the townsman take great store of eel and of water-fowle upon this river side be huge and solitary wood haunt with lion and other wild beast the inhabitant of this town use to transport coal by sea to Arzilla and Tangia whereupon the moor use for a common proverb a ship of Harais which they allege when a man after great brag and promise perform trifle for these ship have sail of cotton which make a gallant show be lade with nought but base coal for the territory of this city abound great with cotton of the town call Caesar Elcabir that be the great palace this large town be build in the time of Mansor the king and patriarch of Maroco of who this notable history be report namely that the say king as he ride on hunt be separate from his company by tempestuous weather come unto a certain unknown place where if he continue all night fear lest he shall die in the fen he look round about he and at length espy a fisher get of eel can you a pleasant discourse how king Mansor be entertain by a fisher (@) friend quoth the king conduct i to the court the court say the fisher be ten mile distant howbeit the king entreat hard to be conduct if king Mansor himself be present quoth the fisher I can not at this present conduct he for fear lest he shall be drown in the fen then answer Mansor what have thou to do with the king life or safety marry quoth the fisher I be bind to love the king as well as i own life then have you obtain some singular benefit at his hand say the king what great benefit quoth the fisher can be expect at the king hand than justice love and clemency which he vouchsafe unto his subject by who favour and wisdom I silly fisher with my poor wife and child live a most quiet and content life so that I can even at midnight have free egress and regress unto this my cottage amid these valley and desert fen no man lie in wait to do i injury but gentle sir whatsoever you be if you please to be my guest for this night you shall be right welcome and to morrow morning betimes I will attend upon you at your pleasure then the king go unto the fisher cottage where after his horse be provide for the fisher cause some eel to be roast for his supper while he sit dry of his garment by the fire but the king not be content with this fare demand if his host have any flesh in the house sir quoth he I have a she-goat and a kid and they be all my substance of cattle but because by your countenance you seem to be some honourable personage I will adventure my kid for your sake and so without any more word he cause his wife to kill it and roast it thus the king remain the fisher guest all night and the next morning about sunrise be scarce go out of the door with his liberal host he espy a great company of his gentleman and hunter whoop and hallow for their king amid the fen but when they see he they all great rejoice then Mansor turn he to the fisher tell he what he be promise that his liberality shall not be unrewarded near unto the place be certain fair castle and palace which the king at his departure give unto the fisher in token of thankfulness and be by the fisher request for declaration of his far love to environ the say building with wall he condescend thereunto from thencefoorth the fisher (@) lord and governor of that new city which in process of time grow so large that within these few year it contain four hundred family and because the soil (@) unto it be so fertile the king use to make his abode thereabouts all summer time which be a great benefit to the town by the wall of this town run read Osorius lib. 2. (@) this town the river Luccus which sometime increase so that it flow to the citie-gate in this town be practise diverse manuary art and trade of merchandise also it have many temple one college of student and a stately hospital they have neither spring nor well but only cistern in stead thereof the inhabitant be liberal honest people though not so (@) as some other their apparel be but mean be make of cotton-cloth and wrap often about their body in the suburb be great store of garden replenish with all kind of fruit their grape be unsavoury because the soil be fit for medow-ground every likewise the governor of this town with three hundred horseman continual encounter and sometime proceed even to the gate of Arzilla of the region of Habat this region begin southward from the river of Guarga and border northward upon the ocean westward it adjoin unto the fen of Argar and eastward it abut upon those mountain which be next unto the streite of Gibraltar in breadth it stretch four score and in length almost a hundred mile the fruitfulness of the soil and the abundance of corn can easy be describe it be almost a perpetual plain water with many river howbeit heretofore it have be more noble and famous by reason of the ancient city build partly by the roman and partly by the goth and I think it to be the same region which Ptolemey call Mauritania but since Fez be first build it have fall into wonder decay moreover idris the founder of Fez leave ten son behind he bestow this region upon the elder afterward ensue a rebellion of diverse mahometan heretic and lord one faction of who sue for aid at the governor of Granada and other seek aid from certain governor of cairaoan they be all vanquish and put to flight by the mahometan patriarch of cairaoan who have thus subdue the region leave it under garrison and return home afterwards the great chancellor of Cordova levy a huge army conquer all this country even to the border of the region of zab. fifty year after king joseph of the luntune family chase out the people of Granada obtain the say province by force and last of all the king of Fez enjoy it of Ezaggen a town of Habat this town be build by the ancient african upon the side of a mountain almost ten mile distant from Guarga all which distance be plain ground serve for cornfield and garden howbeit the hill be far more fruitful this town be distant from Fez almost threescore and ten mile and contain to the number of five hundred family out of the territory whereof there be the sum of ten thousand ducat yearly gather for tribute with which tribute the governor of the same town be bind to maintain on the king behalf four hundred horseman for the defence of the whole region for they be often molest with invasion of the portugal who proceed waste and spoil the country sometime forty and sometime fifty mile here be but little civility to be find neither be the people but homely apparel though they be very rich they have a privilege grant they by the ancient king of Fez to drink wine which be otherwise forbid by the law of Mahumet and yet none of they all will abstain from drink it of the town call bani teude this ancient town be build also by the african on a large plain by the river of Guarga five and forty mile from the city of Fez. in the prosperity thereof it contain to the number of eight thousand family but afterward it be so destroy by the war of the (@) of cairaoan that now the town wall be only remain at my be there I see diverse monument and sepulcher of nobleman and certain conduct curious build say town be five mile distant the inhabitant love to be account gentleman albeit they be covetous ignorant and destitute of all goodness of the town of tansor TAnsor stand upon a little hill almost ten mile from and contain three hundred family but very few artificer the inhabitant be rude and barbarous people have neither vineyard nor garden but only exercise husbandry and possess abundance of cattle this town stand in the mid way between Fez and mount Gumera which I think be the occasion that the inhabitant be so covetous and void of humanity of the town of Agla this ancient town be build by the african upon the bank of the river Guarga the fruitful field thereof be manure by the arabian but the town itself have be so waste with war that now there be nothing to be see but in a few place the ruin of house and wall and certain pit in the suburb there be every week a great market whereunto the next arabian usual resort and so do some merchant of Fez likewise to buy oxe-hides wool and wax which be the principal commodity of that place hereabout keep great store of lion but they be by nature so fearful that they will flee at the voice of a child hence come the proverb so rife in Fez a lion of Agla which they apply unto the (@) of a proverb such a one as make great brag and be but a mere dastard of the castle of Narangia the castle of Narangia build by the african upon a little hill not far from the river Luccus be almost ten mile distant from Ezaggen it have most fruitful cornfield but no plain belong unto it along the river side be huge desert wherein grow great store of wild fruit especial cherry such as the italian call Ciriegie marine this castle be surprise and sack by the portugal in the year of the Hegeira 895. which be in the year of our lord 1486. of the isle of Gesira the isle of Gesira lie not far from the mouth of the river Luccus be distant from the sea about ten and from Fez about a hundred mile there be in time past a little ancient town upon this island which be abandon when the portugal first make war upon Barbary about the say river be many desert but a attempt and defeat of the portugal very few cornfield in the year of the Hegeira 894. the king of Portugal send hither a great army which be land on the isle the general of the field build a strong fort thereupon by mean whereof he hope to be free from the enemy invasion and to enjoy the field adjacent but the king of Fez namely his father that * * * 1562. now reign foresee the damage that he shall sustain if he permit the say fort to be finish levy a mighty army to withstand the Portugal proceed howbeit so great be the force of their ordinance that the moor dare not approach within two mile of the Portugal camp wherefore the Fessan king be almost out of hope be persuade by some that be about he to stop up the river with post and rafte two mile from the island by which mean the moor be defend and have cut down all the wood adjoin the portugal perceive the passage of the river in short time to be choke and stop up with great tree and that there be no possibility for they to depart then the king hope easy to overcome the portugal determine to assail their fort but consider he can not do it without great slaughter of his people he covenant with the Portugal general that beside a great sum of money pay unto he the say general shall obtain of the Portugal king to have certain daughter of the king of Fez his governor which be at that time prisoner in Portugal to be restore and that then he will free dismiss he and his company which be do the Portugal army return home of the town of Basra this town contain almost two thousand family be build by Mahumet the son of idris which be the founder of Fez upon a certain plain between two mountain be distant from Fez about fourscore and from Caesar southward almost twenty mile and it be name Basra for the memory of a city in Arabia call by that name where Hali the four mahometan patriarch after Mahumet and great grandfather unto idris be slay it be in time past environ with most high and impregnable wall and so long as it be govern by the posterity of idris the people be very civil for idris his successor use always to remain there in summer time by reason of the pleasant situation of the place the hill and valley be beautify with sweet garden and yield corn in abundance and that both by reason of the vicinity of the town and of the neighbourhood of the river Luccus moreover in old time this town be very populous be adorn with many fair temple and inhabit with most civil people but the family of idris decay it become a prey unto the enemy at this present the ruin of the wall be only to be see and certain forlorn garden which because the ground be not manure bring forth naught english have good success take the city and so waste it with fire and sword that scarce one citizen escape so that it remain almost thirty year void of inhabitant but afterward when the mahometan patriarch of Cordova be lord of Mauritania it be again re-edify and by all mean augment enrich and fortify the inhabitant be rich learned and valiant the field adjacent yield grain and pulse of all they determine to build a city which for beauty may match the earthly paradise wherefore he compass the same with wall of brass and the roof of the house he cover with gold and silver for the building his six son slay all in one night recovery thereof but in the midst of his dance and disport be advertise that it be lose he will not so much as interrupt his vain pastime wherefore by god just portugal Almandali who have obtain the government of this town and get licence to repair it environ the same with new wall and build a impregnable castle therein compass with a deep ditch afterwards make continual war against the portugal he extreme molest and endamage their town of Caesar and Tangia for with three hundred valiant horseman of Granada he make daily incursion and inroad upon the christian and those that he take he put to continual labour and toil about the build of his fort upon a time I myself travel this way see three thousand christian captive who be clad in course sackcloth be constrain in the night to lie fetter in deep dungeon this captain be exceed liberal unto all african and mahometan stranger that pass by howbeit within these few year one of his eye be thrust out with a dagger and the other wax dim with age he decease leave the town after his death unto his nephew who be a most valiant man of the mountain of Habat a among the mountain of Habat there be eight more famous than the rest all which be inhabit by the people of Gumera who use one general form and custom of live for all of they maintain mahumets religion albeit they drink wine contrary to his precept they be proper man of personage and much addict to industry and labour but for the war they be very unfit subject they be unto the king of Fez who impose such heavy tribute upon they so that beside a few of who we will speak hereafter the residue be scarce able to find themselves apparel of mount Rahona this mountain be near unto Ezaggen contain in length thirty mile and in breadth twelve mile it abound with oil honey and vine the inhabitant be principal employ about make of soap and try of wax wine they have great store both brown and white they pay unto the king of Fez for yearly tribute three thousand ducat which be allow unto the governor of Ezaggen he maintain four hundred horseman in the king service of the mountain call beni-fenescare this mountain of Fenescare adjoin unto mount Rahon be about five and twenty mile long and eight mile broad it be better people than Rahon have many leatherdresser and weaver of course cloth and yield great abundance of wax every Saturday they have a great market where you may find all kind of chapman and of ware insomuch that the genovese come hither to buy oxe-hides and wax which they convey into Portugal and Italy out of this mountain be yearly collect for tribute the sum of six thousand ducat three thousand whereof be allow unto the governor of Ezaggen the residue be pay into the king exchequer of the mountain call beni-haros this mountain stand near unto Caesar extend northward eight and westward 20 mile it contain but six mile only in breadth it be wont to be well people and inhabit with gentleman who territory of the mountain call beni chessen this mountain be of a exceed height and very hard to be encounter for beside the natural fortification thereof it be inhabit with most valiant people these inhabitant be oppress with the tyranny of their governor rise up at length in arm against they and bring they to great misery and distress whereupon a young gentleman one of their say governor disdain to submit himself unto the yoke of his inferior go to serve in the king of Granada his war where be train up a long time in martial discipline against the christian he prove a expert warrior and so at length return unto one of his native mountain he gather a certain troop of horseman and valiant defend the say mountain from the portugal invasion whereof the king of Fez be advertise send he a hundred and fifty crossbow which he employ to the subdue of that mountain and to the conquest of the mountain of his enemy but after he begin to usurp the king tribute in the same mountain the king wax wroth send forth a huge army against he howbeit upon his repentant submission the king pardon he and ordain he governor of seusavon and of all the region adjacent after he succeed in the same war between the king of Granada and the spaniard where the inhabitant only of this mountain prevail more than all the arm Moor beside upon the say mountain be bear one call by they Hellul this Hellul achieve many worthy exploit against the spaniard the history whereof be set down partly in verse and partly in prose and be as rife in Africa and Granada as be the story of Orlando in Italy but at length in the spanish war wherein joseph Enesir king and patriarch of Maroco be vanquish this Hellul be slay in a castle of Catalonia call by the moor the castle of the eagle in the same battle be slay threescore thousand moor so that none of they escape save the threescore thousand moor slay king and a few of his noble this be do in the year of the Hegeira 609 which be in the year of our lord 1160. from thenceforth the spaniard have always good success in their war so that they recover all those city which the moor have before take from they and from that time till the year wherein king no tribute unto the king of Fez unless it be for their field which be very little they reap much commodity out of those mountain for there grow great abundance of box whereof the Fessan comb be make a description of Errif one of the seven region of Fez. westward this region begin near unto the streite of (@) and extend eastward to the river of nocor which distance contain about a hundred and forty mile northward it border upon the Mediterran sea and stretch forty mile southward unto those mountain which lie over against the river Guarga and the territory of Fez. this region be very uneeven be full of exceed cold mountain and waste desert which be replenish with most beautiful and straight tree here be no corn grow they have great store of vine fig olive and almond the inhabitant of this region be valiant people but so excessive give to drink that they scarce reserve wherewithal to apparel themselves head-cattell they have but few howbeit upon their mountain they have great plenty of goat ass and ape their town be but few and their castle and village be very homely build without any plancher or story much like to the stable of Europe and be cover with thatch or with the bark of tree all the inhabitant of this region have the ball of their throat-pipe very great and be uncivil and rude people of the town of this small town as some think build by the goth upon the shore of the Mediterran sea be distant from the streite of Gibraltar about fourscore mile and contain to the number of five hundred family the town wall be of no force the inhabitant be most part of they fisher who get great abundance of fish salt they and carry they to sell almost a hundred mile southward this town be in time pass well store with people but since the portugal enter the same region it have fall great to decay not far from this town grow abundance of (@) upon the ragged and cold mountain and albeit the inhabitant be valiant yet be they rustical and void of all humanity of otherwise call (@) this ancient town build upon the Mediterran sea shore and (@) by the spaniard de Gumera contain about six hundred family some writer there be that affirm it to be build by the african and other by the goth so that it remain as yet uncertain who be the true founder thereof it stand between two high mountain and not far from it there be a fair and large valley from whence come a little river or stream to the town always when it rain in the midst of the town stand the market place which contain great store of shop here be also a very stately temple to be see water for drink be exceed scarce among they for they be all constrain to resort unto one pit or well be in the suburb near unto the sepulchre of a certain man that be in time pass very famous among they howbeit in the night it be dangerous to fetch water from thence because it be so full of bloodsucker or horseleech the townsman be of two sort for some be fisher and the residue be pirate which daily do great harm unto the christian upon the mountain grow great store of wood very commodious for the build of ship and of galley the inhabitant of which mountain be almost whole employ about carry of the say wood from place to place they have very little corn grow for which cause most of they eat barley bread their principal food be certain fish which the italian call Sardelli together with other like fish they have such abundance of fish that one man alone be not able to draw up a net wherefore whosoever will assist the fisherman in that business be reward with good store of fish for their labour yea sometime they will free bestow fish upon such as pass by they salt the foresay Sardelli and send they to the mountain to be sold. in this town there be a long street inhabit with jew wherein dwell sundry vintner that sell excellent wine so that in calm evening the citizen use to carry wine aboard their bark in the sea and to spend their time in drink and sing in this town stand a fair castle but not strong wherein the governor have his abode and near unto this castle the say governor have a palace whereunto belong a most pleasant garden upon the shore the governor build galley and other ship wherewith they great molest the christian whereupon Ferdinando king of Spain take a certain island within a mile of the town build a fort thereon and so plant it with ordinance and soldier that neither their temple nor themselves walk in the street be free therefrom but be daily slay wherefore the governor of the town be constrain to crave aid from the king of Fez who send out a great (@) against the christian but they be partly take and partly slay so that very few escape back unto Fez. the christian keep this isle almost two year and then it be betray by a false treacherous Spaniard who slay the governor of the isle because he have take his wife from he into the moor possession and all the christian be slay not a man of they escape save only the spanish traitor who in regard of his treason be great reward both by the governor of and also by the king of Fez. be at Naples I hear the whole relation of this matter from a certain man that be present at all the former exploit who say that they be do about the year of our lord 1520. but now the say island be most diligent keep by a garrison of soldier send from Fez for be the near haven-towne unto Fez upon the Mediterran sea shore although it be a hundred and twenty mile distant every year or every second year the venetian galley use to resort unto this isle and to exchange ware for ware with the inhabitant or sometime to buy for ready money which ware the venetian transport unto Tunis Venice Alexandria and sometime to Barutto of the town of jelles this town be build upon the Mediterran sea shore be almost six mile distant from the haven thereof be very commodious and much frequent by ship in foul and tempestuous weather not far from this town be diverse mountain and waste desert grow full of pine tree in my time it remain void of inhabitant by reason of certain spanish pirate which haunt the same and now there be but a few poor cottage of fisher who stand in daily dread of the spaniard keep continual and circumspect watch to see if they can escry any ship make towards they which if they do they flee forthwith unto the next mountain bring from (@) a sufficient number of arm man to withstand the attempt of the spaniard or portugal of the (@) of Tegassa this town though it be but little be well store with inhabitant and stand upon a river side about two mile from the Mediterran sea family it contain to the number of five hundred the building thereof be very rude and homely all the inhabitant be fisher and seafaring man who from thence carry victual unto other city for their own town be (@) with mountain and wood they have no corn at all howbeit certain vine there be and very fruitful tree without which the whole region be in a miserable case beside barley-bread the inhabitant have nought to live on save a few little fish and onion I myself can hardly for one day endure the extreme stink smell of their fish which stinch miserable infect the whole province of the town of Gebha be a little town wall round about and build by the african upon the Mediterran sea shore from it be above four and twenty mile distant sometime it have inhabitant and sometime none according to the custom of that region all the field adjacent be unfit for corn be full of fountain and wood here also be certain vine and other fruit but no building of any account of the town of mezemme it be a very large sea-town stand upon a certain hill which border upon the province of garet near unto this town lie a very large plain the length whereof stretch southward be eight and twenty and the breadth almost ten mile and through the midst of it run the river call nocore which divide the region of errif from that of garet this plain be occupy by certain arabian husbandman who reap such plenty of corn there that they be constrain to pay about five thousand bushel a year unto the governor of this city be wont in time past to be well people and be the metropolitan of the whole region although it be continual molest with inconvenience for first it be almost utter destroy by the patriarch of cairaoan who because the townsman refuse to pay he his wont tribute burn it down and behead the governor thereof who head be carry to cairaoan upon the pike of a iaveline this be do in the year of the Hegeira 318. from thencefoorth for fifteen year after it remain destitute of inhabitant and then under the same patriarch the foresay town be by certain nobleman inhabit a new last it be take by a certain great man of Cordova he see this city stand within fower-score mile of his confine for so broad be the sea between malaga in Granada and this part of Barbary begin to demand tribute of the citizen which when they refuse to pay he take their town with a small number of man for the patriarch can not in so short they any corn but panic whereof they make black and most unsavoury bread they live also upon onion and garlic their fountain be very muddy they have great store of goat the milk whereof they keep as a oil likewise they use to kill their he and she goat who flesh be so unsavoury that it can be eat unless it be fry of mount beni Razin this mountain border upon the Mediterran sea not far from the inhabitant live a secure and pleasant life for the mountain be impregnable and abound with all kind of grain neither be they constrain to pay any tribute at all they have likewise good plenty of olive and wine and their ground be exceed fruitful especial upon the side of the mountain their woman partly keep goat and partly till the ground of mount Seusaoen there be no mountain in all Africa for and the inhabitant wear most base attire they have abundance of goat and ox of so little a stature that a man will take they to be calf of half a year old every week they have a market be furnish with very few commodity hither do the merchant of Fez resort and the muletter or carrier which convey fruit out of this mountain unto Fez. in time past it be subject unto a certain prince of the king of Fez his kindred and there be collect out of this mountain almost two thousand ducat of yearly tribute of mount beni jerso this mountain in time past be exceed well people here be likewise a fair college build wherein the mahometan law be public teach for which cause the inhabitant be free from all tribute and exaction afterwards a certain tyrant be assist by the king of Fez make this mountain to become tributary unto he but first he put the inhabitant to flight and then destroy the college wherein be find book worth more than four thousand ducat and the learned and famous man he cruel put to the sword this be do in the 918. year of the Hegeira which be in the year of our lord 1509. of mount Tezarin this mountain call by the inhabitant Tezarin stand near unto the foresay beni jerso and abound great with fountain desert and vineyard upon the top thereof stand diverse ancient building which so far forth as I can conjecture be erect by the roman and here as be before signify certain fond people continual search in cave and hole of the earth for the roman treasure all the inhabitant of this mountain be most ignorant people and great oppress with exaction of mount beni Busibet this be a most cold mountain and therefore it yield neither corn nor cattle both by reason of the extreme coldness and the barrenness thereof moreover the leaf of the tree be not fit for goat to feed upon they have so great plenty of nut that they abundant furnish the city of Fez and all other neighbour city and town therewith all their grape be black whereof they make a certain pleasant meat call Zibibbo they make likewise great store of must and wine they be clad Zibibbo in certain woollen cloak or mantle such as be use in Italy these mantle have certain hood which cover their head and visage so that you can scarce discern they to be man and they be particoloured with black and white spot in winter the merchant that resort unto this mountain to carry away nut and raisin unto Fez can scarce find any meat to eat for there be neither corn nor flesh but only onion and certain salt fish which be extreme dear they use likewise to eat sodden must and bean dress after their manner and this be the dainty fare that this mountain can afford and their sodden must they eat with much bread of mount beni gualid it be a exceed high and steep hill and the inhabitant be very rich for of their black grape they make the foresay meat call Zibibbo almond fig and olive they have in great abundance neither pay they any tribute unto the king of Fez but only each family one four part of a ducat to the end they may have free liberty to buy and sell in Fez market and if any citizen of Fez do they any wrong when they take he or any of his kindred in their mountain they will not suffer he to return home to Fez till sufficient recompense be make these people go decent apparel and they have a privilege grant that whatsoever person be banish out of Fez may free remain in their mountain yea they will bestow their live upon such banish person so long as they continue among they and doubtless if this mountain be subject unto the king of Fez it will afford he yearly for tribute six thousand ducat for it contain more than six hundred rich family of mount Merniza this mountain standeth just by the former the inhabitant be endue with the same nobility liberty and wealth that the people of the former be endue with the woman of this mountain for any light injury offer by their husband leave forthwith their say husband and child will depart unto some other mountain and seek they new paramour fit for their humour for which cause they be at continual war one with another neither will they be reconcile till he that be last possess of the woman pay her former husband all such money as he spend in the solemnize of her marriage and for this purpose they have certain judge that make their poor client spend almost all their whole substance of mount haugustian it be a exceed high and a cold mountain contain great store of spring and abundance of vine bear black grape together with plenty of fig of honey and of quince howbeit the sweet and fair quince grow upon a plain at the foot of the hill likewise they be well store with oil and be free from all tribute and yet there be not one of they but in token of a thankful mind will send great gift unto the king of Fez hence it be that they may free and secure traffic with the people of Fez of who they buy great store of corn wool and cloth they be most civil and decent apparel especial such as dwell upon the principal part of this mountain who be most of they either merchant or artificer and a great many of they gentleman of mount beni jedir this be a great and well people mountain but it yield nought but grape whereof they use to make the foresay Zibibbo and wine the inhabitant be in time past free from all tribute howbeit in regard of their daily robbery and outrage commit against other people the governor of be aid with some soldier of Fez subdue they all and deprive they of their liberty in this mountain there be about fifty farm or grange which scarce pay four hundred ducat for tribute of mount Lucai this mountain be of a wonderful height and very difficult to ascend the inhabitant be exceed rich have great abundance of raisin fig almond oil quince and pome-citron and dwell but five and thirty mile distant from Fez they carry all their fruit and commodity thither they be almost all gentleman and very proud and high mind so that they will never pay any tribute at all for they know that their mountain be so fortify by nature that it can easy be subdue here likewise all such as be banish out of Fez except only adulterer be friendly entertain for the inhabitant be so jealous that they will admit no adulterer into their society the king of Fez grant they many privilege and favour in regard of the great commodity which he reap out of their mountain of mount beni guazevall this mountain be almost thirty mile long and about fifteen mile broad it be divide into three part and between this and the mountain aforesaid run certain little river the inhabitant be most valiant and warlike people but extreme oppress and burden with exaction by the governor of Fez who every year demand of this mountain for tribute eighteen thousand ducat the mountain indeed abound with grape olive fig and flax whereby great sum of money be raise howbeit whatsoever they can gather go present to the governor of Fez who have his officer and receiver in the mountain which do miserable oppress and bribe the inhabitant in this mountain be a great number of village and hamlet that contain some a hundred and some two hundred family and above of most expert and train soldier they have above five and twenty thousand and be at continual war with those that border upon they but the king of Fez for those that be slay on both part require great sum of money so that he gain much by their dissension in this mountain there be a certain town indifferent well people and furnish with all kind of artificer whereunto the field belong marvellous abound with grape quince and pome-citron all which be sell at Fez here be likewise great store of linen weaver and many judge and lawyer they have also a good market whereunto the inhabitant of the neighbour mountain resort upon the top of this mountain there be a certain cave a cave or hole that perpetual cast up fire or hole that perpetual cast up fire some wonder great at the matter have cast in wood which be sudden consume to ash I myself never see the like miracle in any other place so that a great many think it to be hell-mouth of mount benigueriaghell it stand near unto the mountain last mention and yet the inhabitant of these mountain be at continnal war and discord at the foot of this mountain there be a large plain which extend to the territory of Fez and through the same run that river which the inhabitant call Guarga this mountain great abound with oil corn and flax for which cause here be great store of linnen-weavers the great part of all their commodity be gather for the king use so that they which otherwise will prove exceed rich become by this mean stark beggar and that especial by reason of the courtier continual extortion they be people of a ingenuous and valiant disposition soldier they have almost twelve thousand and to the number of threescore village of mount beni achm this mountain be eighteen mile long and seven mile broad it be very steep and contain many waste desert and yield likewise great store of grape olive and fig howbeit the soil be not so apt for corn all the inhabitant be continual oppress with the exaction of the Fessan king at the foot of this mountain be diverse spring and small stream the water whereof be muddy and unpleasant in taste for in regard of the nature of the sand or earth it taste of chalk there be many in this place the ball of who throte-pipe be very great and stick far out like unto those abovementioned all of they drink pure wine which wine that will last fifteen year be boil will last fifteen year howbeit they boil not all their wine but some they keep unboyled and they yearly make great quantity of boil wine which they use to put in vessel that be narrow at the bottom and broad at the top they have every week a great market where wine oil and raisin be to be sold. the people of this mountain likewise be extreme poor and beggarly as a man may conjecture by their apparel they have have continual and ancient quarrel among themselves which make they oftentimes fall together by the ear of mount beni jeginesen this mountain border upon beni achm and stretch in length almost ten mile and between it and mount beni achm run a certain small river the inhabitant be too much addict to drunkenness by reason that their wine be so excellent no fruit grow upon this mountain but only great abundance of grape goat they have which live continual in the wood neither have they any other flesh to eat but goates-flesh I myself have great acquaintance with the inhabitant by reason that my father have some possession upon the mountain but he hardly get any rent or money at their hand for they be the worst paymaster that ever I know of mount beni Mesgalda this mountain border upon the mountain last mention and upon the river of Guarga the inhabitant make great store of liquid soap for they know not how to make hard soap at the foot of this mountain there be a large plain possess by certain arabian who have often combat with they of the mountain they pay yearly to the k. of Fez a huge sum of money and it be a wonder to see with what new exaction they be daily burden in this mountain be many doctor of the mahometan law and diverse inferior student who put the inhabitant to great damage themselves forsooth will drink wine and yet they persuade the people that it be (@) for they to drink it albeit some do give they little credit the inhabitant of this mountain pay in respect of other no great tribute and that perhaps because they maintain the foresay doctor and student of mount beni Guamud this mountain stand so near unto the territory of Fez that they be divide only by a river all the inhabitant make soap out of which commodity the king of Fez reap six thousand ducat of yearly tribute the village of this mountain be about five and twenty in number all the side thereof bring forth corn and cattle in great abundance save that they be sometime destitute of water the inhabitant be very rich and carry all kind of ware to Fez where they gain exceed by they this mountain yield nothing but be commodious for man use from Fez it be almost ten mile distant of garet one of the seven province of the Fessan kingdom have describe all the chief town and mountain of the province of errife it now remain that we say somewhat of garet which be the six province of Fez. this province begin westward from the river Melulo and border eastward upon the river Muluia southward it be enclose with the mountain next unto the numidian desert and northward it extend to the Mediterran sea the breadth of this region along the sea shore stretch from the river to the foresay river of Muluia the southern breadth be bound with the river Melulo and westward with the mountain of Chauz the length of this province be fifty and the breadth forty mile the soil be rough untilled and barren not much unlike to the desert of Numidia the great part have be destitute of inhabitant especial ever since the spaniard take two of the principal town in all the province as we will in due place record of the town of Melela in garet this great and ancient town build by the african upon a certain bay or haven of the Mediterran sea contain almost two thousand family it be in time pass well store with inhabitant as be the head-city of the whole province it have a great jurisdiction or territory belong thereto and collect great abundance of iron and honey whereupon the town itself be call Mellela which word in their language signify honey in the haven of this town they fish for pearl and get great store of oyster wherein pearl do breed this town be once subject unto the goth but fall afterward into the mahometan possession the goth be chase thence flee over to Granada which city be almost a hundred mile distant to wit so far as the breadth of the sea be over in my time the king of Spain send a great army against this town before the arrival whereof the townsman send unto the king of Fez for aid who make war as then against the people of Temesna can send but small force to succour they which the townsman be advertise of and fear lest their small force will prove too weak for the spaniard great armada they take all the bag and baggage that they can carry and flee unto the mountain of Buthoia howbeit the captain of the Fessan soldier both to be revenge upon the townsman cowardice and also to leave nothing for the spaniard to enjoy burn down all the house temple and (@) this be do in the year of the Hegeira 896 which be in the year of our lord 1487. but the spaniard for all (@) enjoy and re-edify by the spaniard they find the city so waste will not depart thereupon but first build a strong castle and afterward by little and little repair the towne-walle and by that mean have keep possession thereof even till this day of the town of Chasasa this town be from Mellela above twenty mile distant it have be a famous town and strong wall with a royal haven belong thereunto which be yearly frequent by venetian ship the townsman have always have great traffic with the people of Fez to the exceed commodity of they both at length while the king of Fez be serious employ in the war don Ferdinando king of Spain come with great take by the spaniard force against it and win it very easy for the inhabitant be advertise of the spaniard approach betake themselves whole to flight of the town of (@) it stand upon a high mountain adjoin the government of this town be commit unto one of the blood-royal namely of the family of (@) who father be not very rich but be a weaver he teach his son the same occupation afterwards the valiant young man be advertise of the estate and nobility of his ancestor leave his loom and go to serve the king at where he continue a horseman for a certain time but because he be a excellent musician the king love he most entire for his skill in music a while after the governor of Tezzota require the king aid against the christian this worthy young gentleman with three hundred horseman be send to succour he who as he have valiant behave himself oftentimes before so now also he appear to be a most resolute commander howbeit the king regard not his valour so much as his excellent skill in music which the young gallant disdain go at length to garet unto certain gentleman of his acquaintance there who join fifty horseman unto he appoint he governor of the castle of Meggeo and afterward he be so well belove by all the inhabitant of the next mountain that each man according to his ability pleasure and gratify he at length the governor of have assemble a army of three hundred horseman and a thousand footman go about to expel the foresay young governor out of Meggeo who present with that small troop which he have so valiant encounter his enemy that he put they to flight and so grow famous in regard of his manifold victory the king of Fez bestow very large revenue upon he which he have give beforetime unto the governor of to the end he may whole endeavour himself to expel the spaniard out of that region and of this noble governor the moor learn great skill in warlike affair the king of Fez have now double his yearly allowance so that at this present he have two hundred horseman at command who be of great force then two thousand soldier of any other captain there about of mount Echebdevon this mountain extend from Chasasa eastward as far as the river Muluia and from the Mediterran sea southward it stretch unto the desert of garet the inhabitant be exceed rich and valiant and the mountain itself abound with honey barley and all kind of cattle here be likewise great store of pleasant and green pasture but since that Chasasa be take by the spaniard the people of this mountain see that for want of soldier they be not able to withstand the violence of their enemy abandon their own mountain burn their house and flee unto the mountain next adjoin of mount beni Sahid westward this mountain extend almost to the river for the space of four and twenty mile the inhabitant be rich valiant and liberal and entertain all stranger with great courtesy and bounty they have abundance of iron and of barley and their pasture be very commodious abound with store of cattle and yet in those pasture be their iron-mine where they sometime lack water neither pay they any tribute at all their house that dig the iron be not far distant from the iron-mine this iron the merchant sell at Fez in rude lump because they use not to frame it into bar neither indeed have they the cunning so to frame it also they make culter spade and such like tool of husbandry and yet their iron have no steel at all in it of mount Azgangan this mountain begin southward from Chasasa be inhabit with most rich and valiant people for beside the great plenty of all thing in the void of inhabitant ever since the take of Chasasa of mount beni teuzin the south part of this mountain border upon the mountain last mention the length whereof from the desert of garet to the river Nocor be almost ten mile and on the one side thereof lie most beautiful and pleasant plain the inhabitant be all free pay no tribute at all and that perhaps because they have more soldier than Tezzota and can afford moreover they be think in time pass so to have assist the governor of Meggeo that by their aid he attain unto that government they have always be great friend with the people of Fez by reason of that ancient familiarity which they have before Fez be govern by a king afterwards a certain lawyer dwell at Fez who be bear in this mountain so represent unto the king the say ancient familiarity that he obtain freedom for his countryman at length also they be great belove by the marin-family perhaps because the mother of (@) sahid the three king of the say family be bear of noble parentage in the foresay mountain of mount Guardan the north part of this mountain join unto the former and it stretch in length towards the Mediterran sea twelve mile and in breadth to the river of nocor almost eight mile the inhabitant be valiant and rich every Saturday they have a great market upon the bank of a certain river and hither resort many people from the mountain of garet and diverse merchant of Fez who exchange iron and bridle for oil for in these mountain grow great plenty of olive they have little or no wine at all notwithstanding they be so near unto mount Arif where the people carouse wine in abundance they be for a certain time tributary to the governor of but afterward by the mean of a learned mahometan preacher the king grant they favour to pay each man so much tribute as themselves please so that send yearly to the king some certain sum of money with certain horse and slave they be put to no further charge of the extreme part of the desert of garet the province of garet be divide into three part the first whereof contain the city and town the second the foresay mountain the inhabitant whereof be call Bottoia and the three comprehend the desert which begin northward at the Mediterran sea and extend south to the desert of Chauz be bound westward with the foresay mountain and eastward with the river of Muluia the length of these desert be 60. mile and the breadth thirty they be unpleasant and dry have no water but that of the river Muluia there be many kind of beast in this desert such as be in the lybian desert next unto Numidia in summer time many arabian take up their abode near unto the river Muluia and so do another kind of fierce people call Batalisa who possess great abundance of horse camel and other cattle and maintain continual war against the arabian that border upon they a description of Chauz the seven province of the kingdom of Fez. this province be think to comprehend the three part of the kingdom of Fez. it begin at the river Zha from the east and extend westward to the river Guruigara so that the length thereof be a hundred fourscore and ten and the breadth a hundred threescore and ten mile for all that part of mount Atlas which lie over against Mauritania join upon the breadth of this region likewise it contain a good part of the plain and mountain border upon Lybia at the same time when Habdulach the first king of the marin-famy begin to bear rule over Mauritania and those other region his kindred begin also to inhabit this region this king leave four son behind he whereof the first be call abubdar the second abuichia the three abusahid and the four jacob this jacob be afterward choose king because he have vanquish Muachidin the king of Maroco and have conquer the city of Maroco itself the other three brother die in their nonage howbeit before jacob have win Maroco the old king assign unto each of they three one region a piece the other three part be divide into seven which be distribute among the four kindred of the marin-famy and two other tribe or family that be grow in great league with the same family insomuch that this region be account for three region they which possess the kingdom be ten in number and the region only seven the foresay king Habdulach be author of the say partition who leave the region of Chauz after his decease in such estate as we will forthwith orderly describe of the town of Teurerto this ancient town be build upon a mountain by the african not far from the river Zha the field hereof not be very large but exceed fruitful adjoin upon a certain dry and barren desert the north part of the same border upon the desert of garet and the south upon the desert of adurha eastward thereof lie the desert of Anghad which be near unto the kingdom of * * * * or Tremisen Telensin and westward it be enclose with the desert of Tafrata which border likewise upon the town of Tezza this Teurerto be in time past a most populous and rich town and contain about three thousand family here also be stately palace temple and other such building to be see the town wall be build of most excellent marble ever since the marin-family enjoy the western kingdom of Fez this town be a occasion of great war for the marin-famy will have it belong to the crown of Fez but the king of Telensin challenge it as his own of the town of Haddagia this town be build by the african in manner of a isle for it be environ with the river Mululo which not far from hence fall into the river Muluia it be in time past a most populous and flourish town but after the arabian become lord of the west it fall by little and little to decay for it border upon the desert of Dahra which be inhabit with most lewd and mischievous arabian at the same time when Teurerto be sack this town be utter destroy also whereof nothing remain at this day but the town wall only of the castle of Garsis it stand upon a rock by the river Muluia fifteen mile distant from Teurerto here as in a most impregnable place the family of beni marin lay their provision of corn when as they inhabit the desert afterwards it become subject unto Abuhenan the five king of the marin-family it have no great quantity of arable or pasture ground belong thereto but it have a most pleasant garden replenish with grape peach and fig and environ on all side with most thick and shady wood so that it be a paradise in respect of other place thereabouts the inhabitant be rude and uncivil people neither do they ought but keep such corn as the arabian commit unto their custody if a man behold the castle a far off he will think it rather to be a cottage then a castle for the wall be in many place ruin make show of great antiquity and the roof be cover with certain black stone or slate of the town of Dubdu this ancient town be build by the african upon a exceed high and impregnable mountain and be inhabit by certain people of the family of Zeneta from the top of this mountain diverse spring come run into the town from this town the next plain be distant almost five mile and yet they seem to be but a mile and a half off for the way be very crooked and wind all the jurisdiction long to this town be only upon the top of the mountain for the plain underneath be unpleasant and barren except certain garden on either side of a little river run by the foot of the hill neither have the townsman corn grow upon the same hill sufficient for their provision unless they be supply with great store of corn from Tezza so that this town be build for a fortress only by the family of marin what time they be dispossess of the western kingdom afterwards it be inhabit by a certain family call beni Guertaggen who be lord of the say town even till this day but when the marin-famy be expel out of the kingdom of Fez the next arabian endeavour to win the town howbeit by the aid of one mose Chamu who be one of the say family the arabian be so valiant resist that they conclude a truce with the people of marin and so mose Ibnu remain governor of the town after who death his son acm succeed he who tread just in his father virtuous step keep the say town in great tranquillity even till his die day after he succeed one Mahumet a man high (@) for his noble valour and great skill in martial affair this Mahumet have before time conquer many city and castle upon the foot of the mount Atlas southward whereof border the land of Numidia but have get this town in possession he beautify it exceed with store of fair house and building likewise he great alter and reform the government of the great courtesy of Mahumet towards stranger this town and show such extraordinary courtesy unto all stranger that he grow very famous moreover the say Mahumet consult how to get Tezza from the king of Fez and offer great matter to the performance of his intent and that he may the easily attain his purpose he determine to go to the market of Tezza in a simple habit and so to make a assault upon the captain of the town for he hope that a great part of the townsman who he know to be his friend will assist he in that enterprise howbeit this practice be at length discover unto the king of Fez which king be call Saich and be the first of the family of Quattas and father unto the king that * * * 1526. now reign who present assemble a huge army and march of purpose against Dubdu utter to destroy it and so come unto the foot of the mountain he there encamp the people of the mountain have gather a army of six thousand man hide themselves crafty behind the rock suffer their enemy to ascend by certain difficult and correced reading passage from whence they be sure they can hardly escape and so at length they break forth on the sudden and encounter their say enemy be weary of ascend and because the way be very troublesome and narrow the king of Fez his soldier can not endure their assault but be constrain to give back be more than a thousand of they throw down headlong and slay in this skirmish be slay in all to the number of three thousand Fessan soldier and yet the king not be dismay with so great a overthrow prepare forthwith a band of five hundred crossbow and three hundred harquebuzier and determine to make a new assault upon the town but Mahumet see that he can no long withstand the king resolve to go himself unto he that he may if it be possible obtain peace and to release his country from the fury of the enemy wherefore put on the habit of a ambassador he go and deliver a letter with his own hand unto the king which the king have peruse ask he what he think concern the governor of Dubdu mary I think quoth Mahumet he be not well in his wit in that he go about to resist your majesty then say the king if I have conquer he as I hope to do within these few day I will cause he to be dismember and tear in piece but what if he shall come hither say Mahumet to submit himself and to acknowledge his offence may it then please the king to admit he into favour then the king answer I swear unto thou by this my head that if he will come and acknowledge his fault in manner as thou have say I will not only receive he into favour but will espouse my daughter unto his son and will bestow most ample and princely dowry upon they but I be sure be distraught of his wit as thou have say that he will by no mean come and submit himself then say Mahumet he will soon come I assure you if it please the king to protest this for a certainty unto his noble I think say the king it have be sufficient protest and affirm sithence I have bind it with a solemn oath in the presence of these four for here stand my chief secretary the general of my force my father in law and the chief judge and patriarch of Fez the testimony of which four may well satisfy you whereupon Mahumet humble fall at the king foot (@) here the man quoth he that submiss acknowledge his fault and crave the king gracious pardon with that the king himself lift he from the ground embrace he and salute he with friendly speech then cause he both his daughter to be call which he bestow upon mahumets son all which be do he remove his army from that mountain and return conqueror unto Fez. this be do in the year of the Hegeira 904. which be in the year of our lord 1495. and in the year of the Hegeira 921. I myself be at the city of Dubdu where I be most courteous entertain by the foresay Mahumet in regard of certain letter of commendation which I bring from the king of Fez and his brother neither will he cease inquire how all thing pass at the king of Fez his court of the city of Teza or Tezza this great noble and rich city of Tezza be build by the african five mile from mount Atlas be distant from Fez fifty from the ocean a hundred and thirty and from the Mediterran sea seven mile and stand in the way from garet to Chasasan it contain in time pass about five thousand family the building of this town be not very stately except nobleman palace college and temple which be somewhat beautiful out of Atlas spring a little river which run through the chief temple of this city and sometime it fall out that certain people border upon the city upon some quarrel with the citizen will cut off this river from the city and turn the course thereof some other way which breed great inconvenience unto the citizen for than they can neither build house nor get any water to drink but only corrupt water which they take out of certain cestern for which cause they be often constrain to make a league with those borderer this city both for wealth civility and abundance of people be the three city of all the kingdom and have a great temple then that at Fez here be likewise three college with diverse bathstove and a great number of hospital each trade and occupation have a several place in this city like as they have in Fez the inhabitant be of a more valiant and liberal disposition than they of Fez here be also great store of learned and rich man and the field adjacent be exceed fruitful without the city wall be very large plain and many pleasant stream that serve to water their garden which be replenish with all kind of fruit here be abundance of vine also yield very sweet grape whereof the jew be five hundred family make excellent wine such as I think all Africa scarce afford better in this town stand a fair castle where the governor have his abode the king of Fez assign the government of this town unto his second son be rather a meet place for the king own residence in regard of the wholefome air both in summer and winter here be the noble of the marin-famy wont to remain all summer both in respect of the holesomenes of the place and also that they may defend those region from the arabian dwell in the desert which arabian resort yearly to Tezza to the end they may there furnish themselves with victual and other necessary and bring date thither from Segelmese to exchange for come the citizen also receive of the arabian for corn great sum of money whereupon all of they in a manner grow exceed rich neither be they annoy so much with any inconvenience as with dirty street in winter I myself be acquaint in this city with a certain age sire who the townsman adore as if he have be a god he be marvellous rich both in fruit ground and other commodity which the people bestow upon he in great abundance the citizen of Fez use to come fifty mile for so far be Fez distant only to visit the say old man myself conceive some great opinion of this age sire but after I have see he I can find no such superexcellency in he save only that he delude the fond people with strange device the jurisdiction of this city be very large contain diverse mountain under it as we will forthwith declare in order of mount Matgara this mountain be very high and difficult to ascend both by reason of the vast desert and the narrow passage and it be distant from Teza almost five mile the top of this hill be most fruitful ground and full of clear fountain the inhabitant be burden with no exaction gather yearly great store of corn flax and oil they have likewise abundance of cattle and especial of goat neither do they any whit regard prince have upon a day vanquish the king of Fez in battle they carry a certain captain of Fez take prisoner unto the top of the hill where in the king own presence they put he to a most cruel and miserable death whereupon the say inhabitant have be at continual discord with the people of Fez they have almost a thousand soldier and their mountain contain about fifty village and hamlet of mount Gavata this mountain be as difficult to ascend as the former stand westward of Fez almost fifteen mile both the side and top of this mountain be very fruitful for barley and flax it be extend in length from east to west eight mile and in breadth about five mile many desert here be haunt with ape and leopard the great part of the inhabitant be linnen-weavers people they be of a frank disposition neither can they till the field adjoin to their mountain by reason of their continual dissension with the king of Fez unto who they will pay no tribute nor custom at all perhaps because of the strong situation of their mountain and for that it abound with all thing necessary for man sustenance so that albeit this mountain be besiege ten year together yet can it by no mean be win neither be it ever destitute of water for thereupon be two huge fountain which run down into the plain become the head of two river of mount Megesa this mountain also be somewhat difficult to ascend it be rough and full of wood and yield little corn but great plenty of olive the inhabitant be most part weaver for their soil yield good store of flax be in the war right valiant both on foot and horseback their face be white and that perhaps for the coldness of the mountain neither do these pay any tribute at all here also the exile of Fez and Teza have safe abode and albeit they have great store of garden and vineyard yet be they no wine-drinker soldier they have to the number of seven thousand and almost forty village of mount this mountain stand fifteen mile northward of Teza the inhabitant be rich and mighty and possess great store of horse neither do they pay any tribute at all this hill abound with plenty of corn fruit and grape and yet they make no wine at all their woman be white and fat and adorn themselves with much silver in this place also they entertain exile but if any of they offer to have familiarity with their wife they punish he most severe for of all injury they can endure this of the mountain call beni guertenage this be a exceed high and impregnable mountain both in regard of the ragged rock and of the vast desert be distant from Teza about thirty mile this mountain afford great store of corn flax olive pome-citron and excellent quince they have likewise all sort of cattle in great abundance except horse and ox the inhabitant be valiant and liberal and as decent apparel as any citizen the village and hamlet of this mountain be about thirty five and the soldier almost three thousand of mount Gueblen this high cold and large mountain contain in length about thirty and in breadth about fifteen mile eastward it border upon the (@) of Dubdu and westward upon mount beni-iazga and it be distant from Teza almost fifty mile southward at all time of the year the top of this mountain be cover with snow the inhabitant in time past be most rich and valiant people and live in great liberty but afterward when they begin to play the tyrant the people of all the mountain adjoin have gather great force invade this mountain slay they every one and so burn and waste their town and village that unto this
