day it have remain void of inhabitant except only a few which detest the cruel tyranny of their parent convey themselves and all their good unto the top of the mountain where they live a abstinent and virtuous life wherefore these be spare and their posterity remain in the mountain till this present they be all learned and of honest conversation and well esteem of by the king of Fez one of they in my time be a very learned and famous old man be use by the king of Fez both about treaty of peace and in other serious affair and in this man the king repose all his confidence as if he have be some petie-god for which cause all the courtier have he in great detestation of mount beni jesseten this mountain be subject unto the governor of Dubdu be inhabit with most base and beggarly people their house be make of sea-rush and so likewise be their shoe make of such rush when they travel any journey whereby a man may conjecture the miserable estate of this people the mountain yield nought but panic whereof they make bread and other victual but at the foot thereof be certain garden replenish with grape date and peach their peach they cut into four quarter and cast away the nut or stone they dry they in the sun and keep they a whole year which they esteem for great dainty upon this mountain be many iron-mine and they frame their iron iron-mine in manner of horseshoe which serve themsometimes in stead of money whereof they have great want in this mountain unless the smith by their art keep this money in store who beside horseshoe make certain dagger with blunt point their woman wear iron-rings upon their finger and ear for a great bravery but they be more base apparel then the man and remain continual in the wood both to keep goat and to gather fuel they have neither civility nor learning but live after a brutish manner without all discretion and humanity of mount Selelgo this woody mountain be full of pine-tree and fountain their house be not make of stone but of sea-rush so that they may easy be remove from place to place which be very commodious to the inhabitant for every spring they leave the mountain and descend into the valley from whence about the end of may they be expel by the arabian which inhabit the desert who by reason of their abundance of goat and other cattle forsake the say desert seek unto the fountain and moist place but in winter because their camel be so impatient of cold they resort unto the wood and warm region in this mountain be great store of lion leopard and ape and from the say mountain run lion leopard and ape a certain stream of water with such violence that I have see a stone of a hundred pound weight carry with the force thereof and here subu take his beginning which be the great river of all Mauritania of mount beni jasga the inhabitant of this mountain be rich and civil people it stand so near the mountain last mention that they be only separate with the foresay river and to the end they may the easy pass from one mountain to another they have make a certain strange bridge in the midst a wonderful bridge and that in manner follow on either side stand certain post through the which run a rope upon a truckle or pulley unto which rope be fasten a great basket that will contain ten person and that in such sort that so often as they will pass over to the opposite mountain they enter into the basket and draw the rope whereon it hang they be easy carry aloft in the air over the river by the help of the foresay pulley but sometime with great hazard of their life especial if the basket or the rope be wear in any place yea and the distance of place be often a occasion of great terror in this mountain there be great store of cattle but little wood it abound likewise with most excellent fine wool whereof their woman make cloth comparable unto silk which be sell at Fez for a great price here also be great plenty of oil the king of Fez be lord of this mountain the yearly tribute whereof amount well nigh to eight thousand ducat be pay to the governor of old Fez. of mount Azgan this mountain border eastward upon Selelgo westward upon mount Sofroi southward upon the mountain by the river Maluia and northward upon the territory of Fez contain in length forty and in breadth about fifteen mile it be of a exceed height and so intolerable cold that only that side thereof be habitable which look towards Fez. it abound great with olive and other fruit and from thence also run great store of fountain into the plain and field adjacent which be most fruitful for barley flax and hemp in my time there be abundance of mulberietree plant upon this plain which bear white berry and bring forth silkworm the inhabitant in winter dwell in most base cottage their water be most extreme cold insomuch that I myself know one who with drink only a cup thereof suffer most intolerable gripe and torture in his bowel for three month after of the town of Sofroi this town be situate at the foot of mount Atlas and stand about fifteen mile southward of Fez almost in the way to Numidia be build by the african between two river on either side whereof grow great abundance of grape and all kind of fruit the town for five mile compass be environ with olive-tree but the field be apt only for hemp and barley the inhabitant be very rich notwithstanding they go in mean apparel and greasy with oil the occasion whereof be in that they carry oil unto Fez to sell. there be no memorable thing in all their town save only a certain temple through the midst whereof run a large river and at the door stand a fountain of most pure water howbeit the great part of this town be fall to decay by the negligence of one of the king brother that now reign and be ruin in many place of the town of Mezdaga this town be situate likewise at the foot of Atlas and stand about eight mile westward of Sofroi be compass with a fair wall and albeit the house thereof be but mean yet every one have a fountain of clear water belong unto it most of the inhabitant be potter because Porcellan they have such abundance of porcelaine earth whereof they make great store of earthen vessel and send they to be sell at Fez from whence they be but twelve mile distant southward their field be most fruitful for barley flax and hemp and they gather yearly great abundance of fig and of other fruit in the forest about this town as also about the former be marvelous store of lion be not very hurtful for any man may drive they away with a little stick of the town of beni Bahlul this (@) town stand upon the side of Atlas towards Fez be distant from Fez about twelve mile not far from the high way lead to Numidia through the midst of this town run certain little river from the next mountain neither do it differ much in situation from Mezdaga save that the south frontier thereof be full of wood whereout the inhabitant get timber and fuel and carry it unto Fez to be sell they be oppress with continual exaction of courtier and other neither have they any civility at all among they of the town call ham Lisnan this town build by the african upon a certain plain environ with mountain in the way from Sofroi to Numidia borrow the name thereof from the fountain of a idol upon the occasion follow at the same time while the african be as yet idolater they have a temple stand near unto this town whither at certain time of the year resort in the night great multitude of people both man and woman where have end their sacrifice they use to put out their light and every man to commit adultery with that woman which he first touch but the woman which be present at this abominable sport be forbid to lie with any man for a year after and the child beget in the say adultery be keep and bring up by the priest of the temple as be dedicate to sacred use in the same temple there be a fountain which be to be see at this day but neither the temple itself nor any monument or mention of the town be remain because they be utter demolish by the mahometan of the town of Mahdia this town be situate upon a plain between mount Atlas and certain wood and river be about ten mile distant from the former the founder thereof be a certain mahometan preacher of that nation which be bear in the next mountain and it begin to be build at the same time when the family of Zeneta be lord of the Fessan kingdom but when king joseph of the luntune family get possession of the say kingdom this town be so waste and destroy that the beautiful temple with some part of the town wall only be leave stand and the inhabitant become tributary to the king of Fez this be do in the year of the Hegeira 515. of sahblel Marga that be the plain of the valiant man this plain contain in longth forty and in breadth almost thirty mile near unto it be certain mountain which border upon mount Atlas and in these mountain be waste desert full of goodly timber here be likewise a great number of cottage inhabit with collier for the most part who carry abundance of coal from the say mountain to (@) the lion that be here do so haunt the poor collier that sometime they devour they from hence likewise be carry to Fez store of excellent and great beam of timber all the plain be so barren and dry that it will scarce bring forth any good thing at all of the plain call Camaren this plain also be environ around with woody mountain be a kind of medowe-ground for it be cover all over with most pleasant herb and grass wherefore in the summer time they use to keep their cattle here and to defend they with high and strong hedge from the fury of the lion of mount Centopozzi upon this high mountain be great store of most ancient building near unto the which there be a hole or dry pit of so great a depth that the bottom thereof can in no wise be see into this pit some mad fellow will have themselves let down by rope carry a candle or torch in their hand and beneath they say it be divide into many room and as it be chamber and last of all they come to a most large place hew out of the rock with instrument and compass about as it be with a wall in which wall be four door which lead to other more narrow place where they say that fountain of spring water be and sometime it fall out that some miserable end their life here for if their light chance to be blow out with any sudden blast of wind they can by no mean find the place where the rope hang but be there constrain to die for extreme famine it be tell i by a certain nobleman of Fez that there be ten person who be desirous to see the wonder of this pit and be prepare for the same purpose go first three of they down who when they be come to the foresay four door two of they go one way and the three go alone another way and be thus divide after they have proceed almost a quarter of a mile there come great swarm of bat fly about their light insomuch that one light be put out at length be come to the spring fountain they find there certain white bone of man and five or six candle whereof some be new and other be old and wear with long lie there but have find nothing but water in the say fountain they return back again the same way that they come and they have scarce go half way but their other light also be blow out with a sudden blast afterwards seek earnest up and down and be weary of many fall that they catch among the rock they find that there be no hope of return wherefore in this desperate case commit themselves with tear into the hand of God they vow if they (@) (@) this danger never to adventure any more they that stand at the (@) mouth be ignorant of their companion mishap expect their (@) and have stay over long at length they let down themselves by the rope and begin with light to seek their fellow make a great noise and at length find they heavy and sad but the three who be wander up and down those dark place they can by no mean find wherefore leave he they return forth of the cave and he that be leave behind hear at length a noise like the bark of little dog and shape his course towards they he find immediate four strange and as it shall seem newborn beast after which follow the * * * * * * the beast call Dabah dam be not much unlike to a shee-woolfe save that she be big wherefore he begin exceed to fear howbeit there be no danger for be about to flee the beast come towards he fawn gentle upon he with her tail and so at length after long seek he find the hole mouth with great joy and escape the danger for within a while he say that he begin to see some glimmer of light as they do which have long be in the dark but after a certain time this cave be fill with water up to the top of the mountain of raven call Cunaigel this mountain stand very near the former and be full of wood and lion here be no city nor any other place of habitation perhaps by reason of the extreme coldness of the place from this mountain run a certain little river and here be a rock of a exceed height whereupon keep infinite swarm of crow and raven which some think to have be the occasion of the name of this mountain sometime the terrible northerly wind bring such abundance of snow upon this mountain that such as travel from Numidia towards Fez loose their life thereby as have be signify in the first book every summer the arabian next inhabit be call beni essen usual resort unto this mountain in regard of the cool water and pleasant shadow notwithstanding they know it to be haunt with great store of lion and leopard of the town of Tezerghe this little town be by the african build in manner of a fort upon the side of a small river which run by the foot of the foresay mountain both the inhabitant and their house be most base and destitute of all civility their field be environ with the mountain adjoin bring forth some small quantity of barley and peach the inhabitant be all subject unto certain arabian call devil Chusein of the town call vman Giunaibe this ancient town be destroy by the arabian be situate about twelve mile from Tezerghe upon the south side of Atlas it be so dangerous a place by reason of the often invasion of certain arabian that none almost dare travel that way there lie a way near this town which a man may not pass without dance and leap unless he will fall into a ague the certainty where of I have hear many avouch of mount beni merasen the inhabitant of this exceed high and cold mountain have great plenty of horse and ass here be store of mule likewise which carry ware up and down without either bridle or saddle their house be build not with wall of stone but of rush the people be very rich and pay no tribute to the king perhaps in regard of the strong situation of their mountain of mount Mesettaza this mountain extend in length from east to west almost thirty mile and twelve mile in breadth the west part thereof adjoin upon the plain of edecsen which border upon Temesna it be like unto the foresay mountain both in regard of the inhabitant and also for plenty of horse and mule at Fez there be great store of learned man which be bear in this mountain they pay no tribute at all but only send the king such gift as themselves please of the mountain of ziz. these mountain be think to have borrow their name from a certain river spring out of they eastward they begin at Mesettaza and extend westward to the mountain of Tedla and Dedis southward they border upon that part of Numidia which be call segelmesse and northward upon the plain of (@) and Guregra in length they contain a hundred and in breadth almost forty mile in number they be fifteen be extreme cold and difficult to ascend and send forth many stream of water the inhabitant be call Sanaga and be man most patient of all boisterous and cold weather they wear but one coat at all season of the year over which they cast a kind of cloak or mantle their leg and (@) they wrap in certain clothes as it be in swath band and they go at all time bareheaded in this mountain be great store of mule ass and other cattle but very few desert the inhabitant be a most lewd and villainous generation be whole addict to theft and robbery they be at continual dissension with the arabian and practice daily mischief and inconvenience against they and to the end they may provoke they to great fury they will sometime throw their camel down headlong from the top of some high mountain in these mountain there happen a certain strange and incredible matter for there be serpent so familiar with man that at dinnertime they will come like dog and (@) and tame serpent cat and gather up the crumb under the table neither will they hurt any body unless they be offer some injury the wall of their house be make of chalk and the roof be cover with thatch there be also another kind of inhabitant in these mountain who possess more drove of cattle than the former and dwell for the most part in cottage make of rush and these carry unto Segelmese butter and wool to be sell but at that time only when the arabian inhabit the desert for it often fall out that they be encounter by they and spoil of their good these people be most valiant warrior for they will fight even to the last gasp rather than be take of their enemy they carry four or five javelin about with they wherewith they know right well how to defend themselves from the enemy they fight always on foot neither can they be vanquish but with a great number of horseman and they use to carry sword and dagger with they also in my time they obtain safe conduct of the arabian and the arabian of they likewise which be a cause that the merchant of both part travel more secure of the town of Gerseluin this ancient town be build by the african at the foot of one of the foresay mountain not far from the river of ziz. it be environ with a impregnable and stately wall the founder whereof be a certain king of the marin-family in regard of the wall and bulwark it be a most beautiful town but be once enter thereinto you shall see most base and beggarly house and scarce any inhabitant dwell in they and that by the injury of certain arabian who when they revolt from the marin-family take this town and grievous oppress the citizen their dry and barren field lie open to the north upon the river be diverse mill and by the side thereof be many garden replenish with grape and peach which they use to dry in the sun and to keep a whole year they have great scarcity of cattle which cause they to live a most (@) life this town be build by the family of Zeneta in stead of a fort to the end it may be a place of refuge only in their journey to Numidia but afterward it be surprise and utter destroy by the family of Luntuna here also be great store of such domestical serpent as we report to be in the mountain of ziz. here end the three book JOHN LEO his four book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein a description of the kingdom of * * * * or tremizen Telensin this kingdom begin westward from the river of Zha and Muluia eastward it border upon the great river southward upon the desert of Numidia and northward upon the Mediterran sea this region be call by the roman Caesaria and be by they inhabit howbeit after the roman be expel it be full possess by the ancient governor thereof call beni Habdulguad and be a generation of the family of Magrava and it remain unto they and their successor three hundred year until such time as a certain mighty man call ghamrazen the son of Zeijen take possession thereof his posterity change at length their ancient name be call beni Zeijen that be the son of Zeijen and they enjoy this kingdom for the space almost of 380. year at length the king of Fez of the marin-family great molest they so that those ten king which succeed Zeijen be some of they unfortunate in battle some slay some take captive and other expel their kingdom and chase to the next mountain neither be they free from vexation of the king of Tunis howbeit the kingdom of Telensin remain still to this family and they continue in peace for almost a hundred and twenty year be endamage by no foreign power save that one Abu Feris king of Tunis and his son hutman make they to pay tribute for certain year unto Tunis till the decease of the say hutman this kingdom stretch in length from east to west 380. mile but in breadth from north to south that be from the Mediterran sea to the desert of Numidia not above five and twenty mile which be the occasion that it be so often oppress by the arabian inhabit the numidian desert the king of Telensin have always endeavour by great gift to gain the good will and friendship of the numidian but they can never satisfy their insatiable covetise a man shall seldom travel safe through this kingdom howbeit here be great store of merchant perhaps either because it adjoin to Numidia or else for that the way to the land of Negro lie through it it have two most famous and frequent haven-towne the one call * * * * or oran horam and the other * * * * or Mersalcabir Marsa Elcabir whither use to resort great store of Genoveses and venetian but afterward both these town be take by don Ferdinando the catholic king to the great inconvenience of all this kingdom for which cause the king then reign call Abuchemmeu be expel his kingdom and put to flight by his own subject afterward Abuzeijen be restore to the kingdom who have for certain year be imprison by his nephew Abuchemmeu howbeit he enjoy the kingdom but a very short space for he be at length miserable slay by Barbarossa the Turk who conquer the kingdom of tremizen (@) king of tremizen restore to his kingdom by the emperor Charles the five by force of war whereof Abuchemmeu that be expel by his own subject have intelligence send to crave aid of the emperor Charles the five whereby he hope to recover his kingdom which request be grant he levy a puissant army and make war against Barbarossa and have drive he out he recover his kingdom and severe punish they that have conspire his banishment and then he give the spanish soldier their pay send the captain home with great reward and allow Charles the emperor a large yearly revenue so long as he live after his decease succeed his brother Habdulla who neglect the league make before between the emperor and his brother and rely upon Soliman the great Turk refuse to pay any more tribute unto the emperor Charles and have keep possession of the kingdom till * * * 1526 this present the great part of this region be untilled dry and barren especial towards the south howbeit the sea coast be somewhat more fertile the territory adjacent to the city of Telensin be full of wood save that the western part towards the sea be mountainous likewise the region of tenez and alger contain mountain abound with all kind of commodity in this part eat but few city and castle howbeit it be a most fruitful and bless place as we will hereafter declare in particular of the desert of Angad this barren dry and untilled desert be utter destitute of water and wood be situate upon the western frontier of the kingdom of Telensin and extend in length fourscore and in breadth almost fifty great store of ostrich mile here be great store of roe dear and ostrich such merchant as travel from Fez to Telensin pass over this desert not without great danger by reason of certain arabian which live only upon theft and robbery especial in winter when as the soldier appoint to defend the say desert from those lewd vagabond do usual retire themselves into Numidia many shepherd there be in this desert who be daily vex with multitude of fierce lion which sometime seize not only upon cartel but also upon man of the castle of Temzegzet this castle stand in the same place where the foresay desert adjoin unto the territory of Telensin and build by the african upon a rock be in time pass very strong and often annoy by the people for it stand in the high way from Fez to Telensin through the field adjacent run a certain river call in their language tefme the say field adjacent sufficient abound with all thing necessary for the sustenance of the inhabitant heretofore be subject unto the king of Telensin it well deserve the name of a city but since the arabian get possession thereof it have prove more like to a stable for here they keep their corn only and the natural inhabitant be quite expel by reason of their bad demeanour of the castle of Izli this ancient castle of Izli build by the african upon a certain plain border upon the foresay desert have some field adjoin unto it apt only for barley and punic it be in time pass well store with inhabitant and environ with stately wall but afterward by the injury of war it be raze to the ground and the inhabitant expel howbeit a few year after it begin to be inhabit anew by certain religious person have in great reverence both by the king of Telensin and by all the arabian these religious person with great courtesy and liberality give entertainment for three day unto all stranger that pass by and then dismiss they without pay of aught all their house be very base and low build their wall be of clay and the roof of straw not far from this castle run a river out of which they water all their field for this region be so hot and dry that unless the field be continual water they will yield no fruit at all of the town of Guagida this ancient town build by the african upon a large plain stand southward of the Mediterran sea forty mile and about the same distance from the city of Telensin the south-west part of the say plain border upon the desert of Angad and it contain most fruitful field and pleasant garden exceed replenish with fig and grape through the midst of this town run a certain river which afford good water to drink and to seethe meat withal in time past the towne-walle and all the building be most sumptuous and stately and the inhabitant exceed rich civil and valiant but afterward by reason of certain war wage by the king of Fez against the king of Telensin this town be leave desolate and the inhabitant all put to flight but the say war be end new inhabitant re-edify it and dwell therein howbeit they can not reduce it to the former state neither do it now contain above fifteen hundred family the townsman lead now a miserable life be constrain to pay tribute both to the king of Telensin and also to the arabian of Angad and wear most base apparel ass and mule they have great store whereof they make round sum of money they speak after the ancient manner of the arabian neither be their language so corrupt as the language of the people round about they of the city call Ned Roma this ancient town build by the roman while they be lord of Africa stand upon a large plain almost two mile from a certain mountain and about twelve mile from the Mediterran sea and near unto it run a little river the historiographer of those time report that this town be in all respect build after the fashion of Rome whereupon they say it borrow the name for Ned in the arabian tongue signify like the wall of this town be as yet to be see but all the ancient building of the roman be so destroy that now there scarce remain any ruin thereof it begin in some place to be repair and re-edify anew but nothing comparable to the former building the field adjacent be exceed fruitful and contain many garden replenish with such tree as bear carob be a fruit like unto cassia fistula which in the suburb they use for food this town be indifferent well inhabit especial with weaver who make great store of cotton-cloth and be free from all tribute the governor of the town be choose only at their assignment and that they may have more free traffic with the people of Telensin they send many gift unto the king of the town of Tebecrit this little town build by the african upon a certain rock near unto the Mediterran sea be almost twelve mile distant from the former all the next mountain be exceed high and barren and yet well store with inhabitant in this town dwell great store of weaver and here they have abundance of carob and honey be in continual fear of the christian they keep every night most diligent watch and ward for they be not of sufficient ability to maintain a garrison of soldier their field be no less barren than untilled and yield only very small quantity of barley and panic the townsman be most base apparel and utter destitute of humanity of the town of Hunain this town be found by the african and be famous both for stately build and civil inhabitant have a little haven belong thereunto well fortify with two turret stand one on the one side and another on the other side the town-wall also be very high and beautiful especial on that side which stand next unto the sea hither do the venetian yearly bring great store of merchandise and do traffic with the merchant of Telensin for the city of Telensin be but fourteen mile from hence since the time that oran be surprise by the christian the venetian will no long frequent oran sear lest the spaniard have it in possession shall work they some mischief wherefore then they begin to repair unto this port the townsman in time past be most civil people the great part be weaver of cotton and of linen their house be most stately build and have every one fountain belong unto they likewise here be many vine run pleasant upon bower or arbour their house be pave with mat of diverse colour and their chamber and vault be curious paint and carve howbeit so soon as the inhabitant be advertise of the loss of oran they flee from Hunain and leave it void of inhabitant save that the king of Telensin maintain here a garrison of footman who give notice when any merchant ship approach their field abound with cherry peach fig olive and other fruit howbeit they reap but little commodity thereby I myself pass this way can not but bewail the extreme calamity whereinto the inhabitant of this town be fall at the same time there arrive a certain ship of a ship of great (@) Genoa which one ship bring commodity sufficient to serve Telensin for five year the ten part whereof amount to fifteen thousand ducat be pay for tribute to the king of the town of Haresgol the great and ancient town of Haresgol be build upon a rock environ on all side with the Mediterran sea save on the south where lie a way from the firm land to the town it stand northward of Telensin fourteen mile and be in time pass well store with inhabitant the governor thereof be one idris uncle unto that idris that be the founder of Fez the posterity of who enjoy the same government for the space of a hundred year at length there come a certain king and patriarch of cairaoan who utter destroy this town so that it remain void of inhabitant almost a hundred year after which time it be reinhabit by certain people of Granada which come thither with Mansor which Mansor repair the town to the end it may always be a place of refuge for his soldier after who decease and the death of his son Mudaffir all the soldier be expel by the tribe or people of Zanhagia and Magraoa and this second desolation of that town happen in the year of the Hegeira 410. of the great city of Telensin other wise call tremizen TElensin be a great city and the royal seat of the king but who be the first founder thereof it be uncertain howbeit most certain it be that this city be very small at the beginning and begin great to be augment at the same time when Haresgol be lay waste for then a certain family call Abdulguad bear rule it increase so exceed that in the reign of king Abu Tesfin it contain sixteen thousand family and then it be a honourable and well-governed city howbeit joseph king of Fez continual molest it and with a huge army besiege it for seven year together this joseph have build a fort upon the east side of the town put the besiege citizen to such distress that they can no long endure the extreme famine wherefore with one accord they all go unto their king beseech he to have compassion upon their want the king to make they acquaint with his dainty fare which he have to supper show they a dish of sodden horseflesh and barley and then they well perceive how little the king estate be better than the estate of the mean citizen of they all soon after the king have procure a assembly persuade his people that it be much more honourable to die in battle for the defence of their country then to live so miserable a life which word of the king so inflame all their mind to the battle that the day follow they resolve to encounter the enemy and valiant to fight it out but it fall out far better for they then they expect for the same night king joseph be slay by one of his own people which news be bring unto the citizen with (@) courage they march all out of the town easy vanquish and kill the confuse multitude of their enemy after which unexpected victory they find victual sufficient in the enemy camp to relieve their long and tedious famine about forty year after the four king of Fez of the marin-family call Abulhesen build a town within two mile westward of the city of Telensin then he besiege Telensin for thirty month together make daily and fierce assault against it and every night erect some new fort so that at length the Fessan force next unto Telensin easy enter the city and have conquer it carry home the king thereof the king of Telensin take prisoner and behead captive unto Fez where he be by the king of Fez behead and his carcase be cast forth among the filth of the city and this be the second and the great damage that Telensin sustain after the decay of the marin-family (@) begin in many place to be repair and replenish with new inhabitant insomuch that it increase to twelve thousand family here each trade and occupation have a peculiar place after the manner of Fez save that the building of Fez be somewhat more stately here be also many and beautiful temple have their mahometan priest and preacher likewise here be five college most sumptuous build some by the king of Telensin and some by the king of Fez. here also be store of goodly bath and hothouse albeit they have not such plenty of water as be at Fez. also here be very many inn build after the manner of Africa unto two of which inn the merchant of Genoa and Venice do usual resort a great part of this city be inhabit with jew who be in time past all of they exceed rich upon their head they wear a * * * * or turban dulipan to distinguish they from other citizen but in the year of the Hegeira 923 upon the death of king Abuhabdilla they be all so rob and spoil that they be now bring almost unto beggary moreover in this city there be many conduct the fountain whereof be not far from the citie-walle so that they may easy be stop by any foreign enemy the citie-wall be very high and impregnable have five great gate upon it at every one of which there be place a guard of soldier and certain receiver of the king custom on the south side of the city stand the king palace environ with most high wall and contain many other palace within it which be none of they destitute of their fountain and pleasant garden this royal palace have two gate one lead into the field and the other into the city and at this gate stand the captain of the guard the territory of Telensin contain most pleasant habitation whither the citizen in summertime use to retire themselves for beside the beautiful pasture and clear fountain there be such abundance of all kind of fruit to delight both the eye and the taste that to my remembrance I never see a more pleasant place their fig they use to dry in the sun and to keep until winter and as for almond peach melon and pome-citron they grow here in great plenty three mile eastward of this city be diverse mill upon the river of Sefsif and some other there be also not far from the city upon the mountain of Elcalha the south part of the city be inhabit by jew lawyer and notary here be also very many student and professor of diverse art which have maintenance allow they out of the five forename college the citizen be of four sort to wit some artificer some merchant other scholar and doctor and all the residue soldier the merchant be man most just trusty liberal and most zealous of the common good who for the most part exercise traffic with the negro the artificer live a secure quiet and merry life the king soldier be all of a comely personage and of great valour receive very large and liberal pay for they be monthly allow three piece of the gold-coine of Telensin which be worth three italian ducat and one second part all student before they attain to the degree of a doctor live a bare and miserable life but have attain thereunto they be make either professor or notary or priest the citizen and merchant of this city be so neat and curious in their apparel that sometime they excel the citizen of Fez in bravery the artificer wear short garment carry seldom a dulipan upon their head and content themselves with plain cap their shoe reach up to their leg of all other the soldier go worst apparel for wear a shirt or jacket with wide sleeve they cast over it a large mantle make of cotton and thus they be clad both summer and winter save that in winter they have certain jacket of leather with hood upon they such as traveller use in Italy and by this mean their head be defend from rain and from snow the scholar and student be diverse apparel according to their ability and according to the fashion of their native country the doctor judge and priest go in more sumptuous and costly attire the custom and rite observe in the king of Telensin his court a wonder it be to see how stately and magnificent the king of Telensin behave himself for no man may see he nor be admit to parley with he but only the principal noble of his court each one of who be assign to bear office according to their place and dignity in this court be sundry office and dignity and the king lieutenant be principal officer allot unto each one such place of dignity as may be correspondent to their honour and this lieutenant levy the king army and sometime conduct they against the enemy the second officer be the king chief secretary who write and record all thing pertain to the King the three be the high treasurer who be bind by (@) office to receive tribute and custom the four be the king or almoner who bestow such liberality as the king vouchsafe the five be the captain of the king guard who so often as any noble be admit to the king presence conduct the guard unto the palace-gate then be there other mean officer as namely the master of the king stable the overseer of his saddle and stirrup and his chief chamberlain who give attendance only at such time as any courtier be admit unto the king audience for at other time the king wife with certain christian captive and eunuch do perform that duty the king sometime in sumptuous and costly apparellride upon a stately stead rich trap and furnish in ride he observe not much pomp nor many ceremony neither indeed do he carry so great a train for you shall scarce see a thousand horseman in his company except perhaps in time of war when as the arabian and other people give attendance when the king go forth with a army there be not many carriage transport therein neither can you then discern the king by his apparel from any mean captain and though he conduct never so great a guard of soldier yet a man will not think how spare he be of his coin gold-money he coin of base gold then that whereof the italian money call Bislacchi be coin but it be of a great size for one piece thereof waigh a italian a passage from Europe to Acthiopia through the kingdom of tremizen ducat and one four part he stamp likewise coin of silver and of brass his dominion be but slender inhabit howbeit because the way from Europe to Aethiopia lie through his kingdom he reap much benefit by the ware that pass by especial since the time that oran be surprise by the christian at the same time Telensin itself be make tributary which be ever before a free city whereupon the king that be the author thereof be extreme hate of his subject till his die day afterwards his son that succeed he demand custom and tribute likewise for which cause be expel out of his kingdom by the people he be enforce to crave aid of the emperor Charles the five by who mean as be beforesaid he be restore unto his say kingdom when oran be subject unto the king of Telensin the region thereabout pay unto the king for yearly tribute sometime three thousand and sometime four thousand ducat the great part whereof be allow unto the king guard and to the arabian soldier I myself continue certain month in this king court have good experience of his liberality I have indeed omit many particular in the description of this court of Telensin but because they agree for the most part with those thing which we report of Fez I have here pass they over lest I shall seem too tedious unto the reader of the town of hubbed this town be build in manner of a castle stand about a mile and a half southward of Telensin it contain store of inhabitant who be for the most part dyer of cloth in this town be bury one Sadi Bu median be repute a man of singular holiness who they adore like a god ascend up to his monument by certain step here be likewise a stately college and a fair hospital to entertain stranger in both which be build by a king of Fez of the marin-family as I find record upon a certain marble stone of the town of Tefesra TThis town stand upon a plain fifteen mile from Telensin have great store of smith therein by reason of the iron-mine which be mine of (@) there the field adjacent be exceed fruitful for corn and the inhabitant be for the most part blackesmithe be destitute of all civility of the town of Tessela this ancient town be build by the african upon a certain plain extend almost twenty mile in length here grow such abundance of excellent corn as be almost sufficient for the whole kingdom of Telensin the inhabitant live in tent for all the building of this town be destroy though the name remain still these also in time past pay a great yearly tribute unto the king of Telensin of the province call beni Rasid this region extend in length from east to west fifty and in breadth almost five and twenty mile the southern part thereof be plain ground but towards the north it be full of fruitful mountain the inhabitant be of two sort for some of they dwell upon the mountain in house of indifferent good building and these employ themselves in husbandry and other necessary affair other be of a more noble condition live only upon the plain in tent and there keep their camel horse and other cattle they be molest with daily inconvenience and pay yearly tribute unto the king of Telensin upon the foresay mountain be sundry village among which there be two principal whereof the one call Chalath Haoara and build in manner of a castle upon the side of a certain hill contain to the number of forty merchant and artificer house the other call elmo Hascar be the seat of the king lieutenant over those region and in this village every Thursday there be a great market where abundance of cattle corn raisin fig and honey be to be sell here be likewise cloth-merchant and diverse other chapman which for brevity sake I pass over in silence I myself continue for some time among they find to my hindrance what cunning thief they be the king of Telensin collect yearly out of this province the sum of five and twenty thousand ducat and it contain so many most expert soldier of the town of Batha this great rich and populous town be build in my time upon a most beautiful and large plain which yield great abundance of corn the tribute which the king of Telensin have here amount to the sum of twenty thousand ducat howbeit this town be afterward destroy in that war which happen between the king and certain of his kinsman for they grow mighty by the king of Fez his aid win many town in the kingdom of Telensin and whatsoever town they think themselves not able to keep by force of arm they burn it quite down and thus they serve Batha whereof now there remain but very few ruin not far from this town run a little river on both side whereof there be many garden and field replenish with all kind of fruit moreover the foresay plain be utter destitute of inhabitant till a certain eremite a (@) (@) with his follower who they reverence as a man of singular holiness repair thither this eremite in short time grow so rich in ox horse and other cattle that no man almost throughout the whole region be comparable unto he neither he nor his follower pay any tribute at all when as notwithstanding as I hear of his disciple he reap yearly eight thousand bushel of corn and at this time possess five hundred horse ten thousand small cattle and two thousand ox and beside all the former have yearly send unto he from diverse part of the world four or five thousand ducat so great have the fame of his false holiness spread over all Africa and Asia disciple he have to the number of five hundred who he maintain at his own cost neither employ he they to aught else but daily to read a few prayer for which cause many resort unto he desire to be of the number of his disciple who after he have instruct in certain ceremony he send they thither from whence they first come he have about a hundred tent pitch whereof some be for stranger other for shepherd and the residue for his own family this holy eremite have four wife and a great many women-slave wear most sumptuous apparel his son likewise have their wife and family insomuch that the whole family of this eremite and of his son contain five hundred person he be great honour by all the arabian and by the king of Telensin himself myself be once desirous to try what manner of man this eremite be and for three day I be entertain by he in the most secret place of his habitation where among other thing he show i certain book entreat of art-magique and of (@) and he endeavour by all mean to persuade i that magic be a most true and undoubted art whereby I perceive that himself be a magician albeit he never use nor regard the art except it be in invocate of God by certain name of the town of oran this great and populous town contain about six thousand family and build many year ago by the african upon the Mediterran sea shore be distant from Telensin a hundred and forty mile here may you see great store of stately building as namely of temple college hospital bathstove and inn the town be compass with most high and impregnable wall have on the one side a fair plain and on the other side diverse mountain the great part of the inhabitant be weaver and the residue live of their yearly revenue the territory of this town yield but small store of corn so that the townsman make all their bread of barley howbeit they be most courteous and friendly to all stranger this town be great frequent with merchant of Catalonia and of Genoa and one street thereof be at this present call the street of the genovese they be at perpetual enmity with the king of Telensin neither will they ever accept of any governor but one which receive the king tribute but the townsman choose one of their chief burgo-master to judge of case civil and criminal the merchant of this town maintain at their own cost certain foist and brigandine of war which commit many piracy upon the coast of Catalonia and insomuch that oran be full of christian captive afterwards don Ferdinando king of Spain encounter oran with a great armada determine to release the say christian out of captivity but he have very hard success howbeit within a few month after be oran take by the spaniard aid by the Biscayne and the cardinal of Spain he take oran for the moor issue forth with great fury upon the christian army leave the town utter destitute of soldier which the spaniard perceive begin to assail the town on the other side where be resist by none but by woman they have easy entrance whereupon the moor see the christian banner advance upon their wall they return back into the town and be there put to so great a slaughter that few of they escape thus be oran take by the spaniard in the year of Mahomet his Hegeira 916. of the town Mersalcabir this town be build in my time by the king of Telensin upon the Mediterran sea not far from oran and Mersalcabir in the moor language signify a great or large haven for I think there be not the like haven to be find in the whole world beside so that here infinite number of ship and galley may find most safe harbour in any tempestuous Mersalcabir surprise by the spaniard weather hither the venetian ship make often resort when they perceive any tempest to approach and from hence they will cause all their ware to be transport to oran in other vessel this town also be at length take by the spaniard as well as oran of the town of Mezzagran this town also be build by the african upon the Mediterran sea near unto the place where the river disemboqueth it be well people and much molest by the arabian the governor thereof have little authority within the town and less without of the town of Mustuganin MVstuganin be found by the african upon the Mediterran sea stand almost three mile from Mezzagran on the other side of the river it be in time pass very populous but since the kingdom of Telensin begin to decay this town have be so vex by the arabian that at this present the three part thereof scarce remain family it contain to the number of fifteen hundred and it have a most beautiful and stately temple in this town be great store of weaver and the house be most sumptuous build have clear fountain belong unto they through the midst of the town run a river on each side whereof stand diverse mill not far from the town there be most pleasant garden but they lie now untilled and desolate their field be exceed fruitful there belong haven unto this town whereunto many merchant of Europe use to resort albeit they find not much traffic here because the (@) be so destitute of money of the town of Bresch this ancient town build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea stand many mile distant from Mustuganin it contain great store of inhabitant which be many of they weaver the people of this town use to paint a black cross upon their cheek and two other black cross upon the palm of their hand and the like custom be observe by all the inhabitant of the mountain of alger and Bugia the occasion whereof be think to be this namely that the goth when they first begin to invade these region release all those from pay of tribute as our african historiographer affirm that will embrace the christian religion but so often as any tribute be demand every man to eschew the payment thereof will not stick to profess himself a Christian wherefore it be then determine that such as be christian indeed shall be distinguish from other by the foresay cross at length the goth be expel they all revolt unto the mahometan religion howbeit this custom of paint cross remain still amongthem neither do they know the reason thereof likewise the mean sort of people in Mauritania use to make such cross upon their face as we see use by some people of Europe this town abound great with fig and the field thereof be exceed fruitful for flax and barley the townsman have continue in firm league and friendship with the people of the mountain adjoin by who favour they live a hundred year together without pay of any tribute at all but Barbarossa the Turk have win the kingdom of Telensin put they to great distress from hence they use to transport by sea great store of fig and flax unto alger Tunis and Bugia whereby they gain great store of money here also you may as yet behold diverse monument of the roman ancient building of the town of sersell this great and ancient town build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea be afterward take by the goth and last by the mahometan the wall of this town be exceed high strong and stately build and contain about eight mile in circuit in that part of the town next unto the Mediterran sea stand a most beautiful and magnificent temple build by the roman the inward part whereof consist of marble they have also in time past a impregnable for it stand upon a rock by the Mediterran sea their field be most fruitful and albeit it this town be much oppress by the goth yet the mahometan enjoy a great part thereof for the space almost of five hundred year and then after the war of Telensin it remain void of inhabitant almost three hundred year at length when Granada be win by the christian diverse moor of Granada flee hither which repair the house and a good part of the castle afterward they begin to build ship wherewith they transport their merchantable commodity into other region and they increase so by little and little that now they be grow to twelve hundred family they be subject not long since unto Barbarossa the Turk unto who they pay but three hundred ducat for yearly tribute of the city of Meliana this great and ancient city common call now by the corrupt name of Magnana and build by the roman upon the top of a certain hill be distant from the Mediterran sea almost forty mile upon this mountain be many spring and wood abound with walnut the city itself be environ with most ancient and high wall one side thereof be fortify with impregnable rock and the other side depend so upon the mountain as Narma do which be a city near Rome it contain very stately house every one of which house have a fountain the inhabitant be almost all weaver and there be diverse turner also which make fine cup dishes and such like vessel many of they likewise be husbandman they continue many year free from all tribute and exaction till they be at length make tributary by Barbarossa of the town of tenez this ancient town build by the african upon the side of a hill not far from the Mediterran sea be environ with fair wall and inhabit with many people the inhabitant be exceed rustical and uncivil and have always be subject to the king of Telensin king Mahumet that be grandfather unto the king which now reign leave three son behind he the elder be call Abuabdilla the second abuzeven and the three jahia Abuabdilla succeed his father who his brother be aid by the citizen go about to murder but afterward the treason be discover abuzeven be apprehend and put in prison howbeit king * * * * perhaps (@) Abuchemmeu be after that expel out of his kingdom by the people Abuzeven be not only restore to his former liberty but be also choose king and enjoy the kingdom so long till as be beforementioned he be slay by Barbarossa jahia flee unto the king of Fez who be at length proclaim king by the people of tenez reign for certain year and his young son that he leave behind he be vanquish by Barbarossa flee unto Charles who be then only king of Spain but when as the aid promise by Charles the emperor stay long and the prince of tenez be too long absent a rumour be spread abroad that he and his brother be turn christian whereupon the government of tenez fall immedial to the brother of Barbarossa their field indeed yield abundance of corn but of other commodity they have great want of the town of Mazuna this town as some report be build by the roman and stand about forty mile from the Mediterran sea it have fruitful field strong wall but most base and deform house their temple indeed be somewhat beautiful for it be in time past a most stately town but be often sack sometime by the king of Telensin and sometime by his rebel and at length fall into the hand of the arabian it be bring unto extreme misery so that at this present there be but few inhabitant remain all be either weaver or husbandman and most grievous oppress by the arabian their field abound plentiful with all kind of corn near unto this town there have be in time past many house street and village which may probable be conjecture by the letter engrave upon marble stone the name of which village be not to be find in any of our history or chronicle of gezeir otherwise call alger gezeir in the moor language signify a island which name be think to have be give unto this city because it lie near unto the isle of Maiorica and jeviza howbeit the spaniard call it alger it be found by the african of the family of Mesgana wherefore in old time it be call by the name of Mesgana it be a large town contain family to the number of four thousand and be environ with most stately and impregnable wall the building thereof be very artificial and sumptuous and every trade and occupation have here a several place inn bathstove and temple here be very beautiful but the stately temple of all stand upon the seashore next unto the sea there be a most pleasant walk upon that part of the (@) wall which the wave of the sea beat upon in the suburb be many garden replenish with all kind of fruit on the east side of the town run a certain river have many mill thereupon and out of this river they draw water fit for drink and for the service of the kitchen it have most beautiful plain adjoin upon it and especial one call which extend forty five mile in length and almost thirty mile in breadth and abound mighty with all kind of grain this town for many year be subject unto the kingdom of Telensin but hear that Bugia be also govern by a king and be near thereunto they submit themselves unto the king of Bugia for they see that the king of Telensin can not sufficient defend they against their enemy and also that the king of Bugia may do they great damage wherefore they offer unto he a yearly tribute of their own accord and yet remain almost free from all exaction but certain year after the inhabitant of this city build for themselves galley begin to play the pirate and great to molest the foresay island whereupon king Ferdinando provide a mighty armada hope thereby to become lord of the city likewise upon a certain high rock stand opposite against the town he cause a strong fort to be build and that within gunshot of the alger become tributary to the king of Spain city albeit the city wall can not be endamage thereby wherefore the citizen immediate send ambassador into Spain to crave a league for ten year upon condition that they shall pay certain yearly tribute which request be grant by king Ferdinando and so they remain for certain month free from the danger of war but at length Barbarossa hasten to the siege of Bugia and have win one fort build by the spaniard determine to encounter another hope if he can obtain that also that he shall soon conquer the whole kingdom of Bugia howbeit all matter fall not out according to his expectation for a great part of his soldier be husbandman when they perceive the time of sow corn to approach without any leave or licence they forsake their general and return home to the plough-taile and many turk also do the like so that Barbarossa fail of his purpose be constrain to break up the (@) howbeit before his departure he set on fire with his own hand twelve galley which lie in a river but three mile from Bugia and then with forty of his soldier he retire himself to the castle of Gegel be from Bugia about sixty mile distant where he remain for certain day in the mean while king Ferdinando decease the people of alger release themselves from pay any more tribute for see Barbarossa to be a most valiant warrior and a deadly enemy unto christian they send for he and choose he captain over all their force who present encounter the fort but to little effect afterwards this Barbarossa secret murder the governor of the city in a certain bath the say governor be prince of the arabian dwell on the plain of Mettegia his name be Selim Etteumi descend of the family of Telaliba and create governor of alger at the same time when Bugia be take by the spaniard this man be slay by Barbarossa after he have govern many year and then Barbarossa usurp the whole government of the city unto himself and coin money and this be the first entrance into his great and princely estate at all the foresay accident I myself be present as I travel from Fez to Tunis and be entertain by one that be send ambassador from the people of alger into Spain from whence he bring three thousand book write in the arabian tongue then I pass on to Bugia where I find Barbarossa besiege a voyage perform by John (@) the foresay fort afterward I proceed to Constantina and next to Tunis in the mean while I hear that Barbarossa be slay at tremizen and that his brother call Cairadin succeed in the government of alger then we hear also that the emperor Charles the five have send two army to surprise alger the first whereof be destroy upon the plain of alger and the second have assail the town three day together be partly slay and partly take by Barbarossa insomuch that very few escape back into Spain this be do in the year of the Hegeira nine hundred twenty two of the town of tegdemt this ancient town be build as some think by the roman and tegdemt signify in the arabian language ancient the wall of this town as a man may conjecture by the foundation thereof be ten mile in circuit there be yet remain two temple of a exceed height but they be very ruinous and in many place fall to the ground this town when it be possess by the mahometan be marvelous rich and abound with man of learning and poet it be report that idris uncle to the same idris that found Fez be once governor of this town and that the government thereof remain to his posterity almost a hundred and fifty year afterwards it be destroy in the war between the schismatical patriarch of cairaoan in the year of the Hegeira 365 but now there be a few ruin only of this town to be see of the town of medua this town stand not far from the border of Numidia be distant from the Mediterran sea almost a hundred and fourscore mile and it be situate on a most pleasant and fruitful plain and be environ with sweet river and beautiful garden the inhabitant be exceed rich exercise traffic most of all with the numidian and they be very curious both in their apparel and in the furniture of their house they be continual molest with the invasion of the arabian but because they be almost two hundred mile distant from Telensin they can have no aid send they by the king this town be once subject unto the governor of tenez afterward unto Barbarossa and last unto his brother never be I so sumptuous entertain as in this place for the inhabitant be themselves (@) so often as any learned man come among they they entertain he with great honour and cause he to decide all their controversy for the space of two month while I remain with they I gain above two hundred ducat and be so allure with the pleasantness of the place that have not my duty enforce i to depart I have remain there all the residue of my life of the town of temendfust this town also be build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea and be about twelve mile distant from alger unto this town belong a fair haven where the ship of alger be safe harbour for they have no other haven so commodious this town be at length destroy by the goth and the great part of the wall of alger be build with the stone which come from the wall of this town of the town of teddeles this town build by the african upon the Mediterran sea and be thirty mile distant from alger be environ with most ancient and strong wall the great part of the inhabitant be dyer of cloth and that by reason of the many river and stream run through the midst of the same they be of a liberal and ingenuous disposition and can play most of they upon the cittern and lute their field be fertile and abound with corn their apparel be very decent the great part of they be delight in fish and they take such abundance of fish that they free give they to every body which be the cause that there be no fishmarket in this town of the mountain contain in the kingdom of Telensin of the mountain of beni jezneten this mountain stand westward of Telensin almost fifty mile one side thereof border upon the desert of garet and the other side upon the desert of Angad in length it extend five and twenty and in breadth almost fifteen mile and it be exceed high and difficult to ascend it have diverse wood grow upon it wherein grow great store of carob which the inhabitant use for a ordinary kind of food for they have great want of barley here be diverse cottage inhabit with valiant and stout man upon the top of this mountain stand a strong castle wherein all the principal man of the mountain dwell among who there be often dissension for there be none of they all but will be sole governor of the mountain I myself have conversation with some of they who I know in the king of Fez his court for which cause I be honourable entertain by they the soldier of this mountain be almost ten thousand of mount Matgara this exceed high and cold mountain have great store of inhabitant and be almost six mile distant from Ned the inhabitant be valiant but not very rich for this mountain yield nought but barley and carob they speak all one language with the people of Ned Roma and be join in such league with they that they will often aid one another against the king of Telensin of mount Gualhasa this high mountain stand nigh unto the town of Hunain the inhabitant be savage rude and uncivil people and be at continual war with the people of Hunain so that oftentimes they have almost utter destroy the town this mountain yield great store of carob and but little corn of mount Agbal this mountain be inhabit with people of base condition and subject to the town of oran they all exercise husbandry and carry wood unto oran while the moor enjoy oran their state be somewhat better but since the christian get possession thereof they have be drive to extreme misery of mount beni gueren this mountain be three mile distant from Tremisen be well people and abound with all kind of fruit especial with fig and cherry the inhabitant be some of they collier some woodmonger and the residue husbandman and out of this only mountain as I be inform by the king of Telensin his secretary there be yearly collect for tribute the sum of twelve thousand ducat of mount Magrava this mountain extend itself forty mile in length towards the Mediterran sea be near unto the town of Mustuganin before describe the soil be fertile and the inhabitant be valiant and warlike people and of a liberal and human disposition of mount beni abusaid this mountain stand not far from tenez be inhabit with great multitude of people which lead a savage life and be notwithstanding most valiant warrior they have abundance of honey barley and goat their wax and hide they carry unto tenez and there sell the same to the merchant of Europe when as the king of tremizen his kinsman be lord of this mountain the people pay for tribute certain thousand of ducat of mount this exceed high mountain be inhabit with valiant people who be aid by the king of Fez maintain war against the kingdom of Telensin for above threescore year fruitful field they have and great store of fountain their soldier be almost twenty thousand in number whereof 2500. be horseman by their aid jahia attain to the government of tenez but after tenez begin to decay they give themselves whole to robbery and theft of the mountain belong to the state of alger never unto alger on the east side and on the west be diverse mountain well store with inhabitant free they be from all tribute and rich and exceed valiant their corn field be very fruitful and they have great abundance of cattle they be oftentimes at deadly war together so that it be dangerous travail that way unless it be in a religious man company market they have and fair upon these mountain where nought be to be sell but cattle corn and wool unless some of the neighbour city supply they with merchandise now and then here end the four book JOHN LEO his five book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein a description of the kingdom of Bugia and Tunis when as in the former part of this my history I divide Barbaria into certain part I determine to write of Bugia as of a kingdom by itself and I find indeed that not many year ago it be a kingdom for Bugia be subject to the king of Tunis and albeit for certain year the king of Telensin be lord thereof yet be it at length recover again by the king of Tunis who commit the government of the city unto one of his son both for the tranquillity of Bugia and also that no discord may happen among his son after his decease he leave behind he three son the elder whereof be call Habdulhaziz and unto he he bequeath the kingdom of Bugia as be aforesaid unto the second who name be hutman he leave the kingdom of Tunis and the three call Hammare he make governor of the region of date this Hammare begin forthwith to wage war against his brother hutman by who be at length take in the town of asfaco and deprive of both his eye he be carry captive unto Tunis where he live many year blind but his brother hutman govern the kingdom of Tunis full forty year the prince of Bugia being most love and dutiful to his brother reign for many year with great tianquilitie till at length he be by king Ferdinand of Spain and by the mean of one Pedro de Navarra cast out of his kingdom a description of the great city of Bugia this ancient city of Bugia build as some think by the roman upon the side of a high mountain near unto the Mediterran sea be environ with wall of great height and most stately in regard of their antiquity the part thereof now people contain above eight thousand family but if it be all replenish with building it be capable of more than four and twenty thousand household for it be of a great length the house temple and college of this city be most sumptuous build professor of liberal science here be great store whereof some teach matter pertain to the law and other profess natural philosophy neither monastery inn nor hospital erect after their manner be here want and their market place be very large and fair their street either descend or ascend which be very troublesome to they that have any business in the town in that part of the city next unto the top of the mountain stand a strong castle most sumptuous and beautiful wall and there be such notable letter and picture most artificial carve upon the plaister-worke and timber that they be think to have cost much more than the build of the wall itself the citizen be exceed rich and use with their warlike galley continual to molest the coast of Spain which be the occasion of the utter overthrow of their city for Pedro de Navarra be send against they with a fleet of fowerteene sail only the citizen be addict whole the city of Bugia take by Pedro de Navarra to pleasure and ease and be terrify with the rumour of war because they be never exercise therein be no soon advertise of Pedro de Navarra his approach but all of they together with their king betake themselves to flight and leave their city abound with all kind of riches and wealth to be spoil by the spaniard so that it be easy take in the year of Mahomet his Hegeira nine hundred and seventeen soon after Pedro de Navarra have sack the city build a strong fort upon the sea shore and repair a other which have lie a long time waste furnish they both with soldier and munition and six year after Barbarossa the Turk be desirous to win this city from the christian and have levy only a thousand soldier take the old fort because he be favour by the inhabitant of all the mountain adjacent wherein have place a garrison he attempt to win the other fort also but at his first encounter he lose a hundred of his principal turk and four hundred of the mountainer that come to aid he insomuch that Barbarossa be enforce to fly unto the castle of Gegel as be aforesaid of the castle of Gegel this ancient castle build by the african upon a high rock by the Mediterran sea be distant about threescore mile from Bugia family it contain to the number of five hundred and the building thereof be very base the inhabitant be of a trusty and ingenuous disposition and do most of they exercise husbandry howbeit their field be but barren and apt only for barley flax and hemp they have great store of fig and nut which they use to carry in certain bark unto Tunis they have in despite of the king of Bugia and Tunis continue always free from tribute for that impregnable mountain can be surprise by no siege nor encounter of the enemy at length they yield themselves unto Barbarossa who demand none other tribute of they but only the (@) of certain fruit and corn of the town of Mesila MEsila found by the roman not far from the numidian desert and be distant from Bugia almost a hundred mile have stately wall about it but base house within the inhabitant be partly artificer and partly husbandman go very homely apparel and be most grievous oppress with the continual exaction of the arabian and with the daily molestation of the king of Bugia myself upon a time travel this way can not find so much fodder as be sufficient for twelve horse only of the town of stefe this town also build by the roman sixty mile southward of Bugia upon a certain beautiful plain be environ with strong and stately wall it be in time pass exceed well store with inhabitant but since the mahometan be lord thereof it have so decay by the injury of the arabian who raze to the ground a great part of the wall that within the whole circuit of this great and ancient town there be but a hundred house at this present remain of the town of Necaus this town build by the roman near unto Numidia and be distant from the Mediterran sea a hundred and eighty and from the town last mention eighty mile be compass with a strong and ancient wall by this town run a certain river on both side whereof grow the best wal-nut and fig that be to be find in the whole kingdom of Tunis be usual carry to Constantina to be sell which city be thence distant a hundred and eighty mile the field of this town be exceed fruitful and the inhabitant be very rich liberal and curious in their apparel here be a hospital maintain at the common charge of the town to entertain stranger that pass by here be a college also the student whereof be allow their diet and apparel neither be this town destitute of a most stately and well-furnished temple their woman be white have black hair and a most delicate skin because they frequent the bathstove so often most of their house be but of one story high yet be they very decent and have each one a garden thereto belong replenish with damaske-rose myrtle camomile and other herb and flower and be water with most pleasant fountain in these garden likewise there be most stately arbour and bower the cool shadow whereof in summertime be most acceptable and to be brief all thing here be so delightful to the sense and so allure that any man will be loath to depart from hence of the town of Chollo the great town of Chollo found by the roman upon the Mediterran sea at the foot of a certain high mountain be environ with no wall at all for the wall be raze to the ground by the goth neither do the mahometan when they have get possession build they up again howbeit this town be notable well govern and well store with inhabitant which be all man of a liberal and tractable disposition they have continual great traffic with the merchant of Genoa and do gather abundance of wax and hide their field upon the mountain be exceed fruitful and they have always so defend themselves against the prince of Tunis and Constantina that until this present they remain free from tribute from the injury of Constantina they be easy defend both in regard of the difficult mountain lie in the midway and also in respect of the great distance for Constantina stand almost a hundred and twenty mile off neither be there any city throughout the whole kingdom of Tunis either for wealth or strong situation any way comparable unto this of the town of sucaicada this ancient city build by the roman also upon the Mediterran sea and stand about thirty five mile from Constantina be waste and almost utter destroy by the goth howbeit by reason of the haven be so famous and so frequent by the merchant of Genoa the prince of Constantina cause certain fair house to be build thereabouts for the say merchant of Genoa to repose themselves and their good therein and upon a mountain not far off he build a strong (@) for the security and defence of the say merchant from all enemy whatsoever from the say haven to Constantina the high way be pave with certain black stone such as be to be see in some place of Italy be there call roman which be a manifest argument that sucaicada be build by the roman of the city of Constantina no man can deny the roman to have be founder of this city that shall consider the great strength height and antiquity of the wall and how curious they be beset and adorn with black stone this city stand upon the south side of a exceed high mountain and be environ with steep rock under which rock and within the compass whereof run the river call sufegmare so that the say deep river with the rock on either side serve in stead of a towne-ditch to Constantina the north part be compass with a wall of great thickness and there be two extreme narrow passage only to enter into the city one on the east part and another on the west the citie-gate be very large and stately the city itself contain above eight thousand family building it have very sumptuous as namely the chief temple two college three or four monastery and other such like here every trade and occupation have a several place assign and the inhabitant be right honest and valiant people here be likewise a great company of merchant whereof some sell cloth and wool other send oil and silk into Numidia and the residue exchange linnen-cloth and other ware for slave and date neither be date so cheap in any region of all Barbary beside the king of Tunis usual commit the government of Constantina unto their elder son the hard success of the king of Tunis his three son and so he that be now king of Tunis bestow Constantina upon his elder son in like sort who wage war against the arabian be slay in the first battle then fall the government of Constantina unto his second son who intemperate life be the cause of his sudden and untimely death after he succeed the three and young son who in regard of his insolent and shameless behaviour be so hate of all the citizen that some have determine to kill he whereof his father have intelligence send for he and keep he for certain year prisoner at Tunis afterwards he commit the government of Constantina to a certain renegado that of a christian become a mahometan this renegado he trust as his own brother for he have make former trial of he who for many year govern the place with great tranquillity upon the north part of the city stand a certain strong castle build at the same time when the city itself be build which castle be more strong fortify then before by one elcaied Nabil the king lieutenant and this castle great bridle both the citizen and all the border arabian who great captain it hold as prisoner and release he not till he have leave his three son for hostage at length the say elcay grow so haughty that he coin money to the great contempt of his king and sovereign who notwithstanding he endeavour by many gift and present to appease but when man perceive elcay to degenerate from his first form of government they that before love he and have he in high regard be present of another mind and utter forsake he so that lay siege unto a certain city of Numidia call Pescara he perceive some treason to be attempt against he and thereupon return forthwith to Constantina he find the citie-gate shut against he from whence he present take his journey to the king of Tunis and be by he cast into prison and not restore to liberty till he have pay a hundred thousand ducat afterwards by the king aid he be restore to his former government but when he begin to tyrannize over some of the chief citizen he again provoke the whole city unto arm who besiege
