forthwith the castle whereunto he flee which be such a corrasive unto elcaied his mind that within few day he die for sorrow and so the people after they be reconcile to their king will fromthencefoorth never admit any foreign governor wherefore the king of Tunis be as be aforesaid again constrain to send his own son thither the field belong to this city be exceed fertile and on either side the river which run through the plain there be most commodious garden if they be well husband also without the city stand many fair and ancient building about a mile and a half from the city stand a certain triumphal arch like unto the triumphal arch at Rome which the gross common people think to have be a castle where innumerable devil remain which they say be expel by the mahometan when they come first to inhabit Constantina from the city to the river they descend by certain stair hew out of the rock and near unto the river stand a little house so artificial cut out of the main rock that the roof pillar and wall be all of one continue substance and here the woman of Constantina wash their linen near unto the city likewise there be a certain hot bath bath of hot water disperse itself among the rock in this bath be great store of snail which the fond woman of the city call devil and when any one fall into a fever or any other disease they suppose the snail to be the author thereof and the only remedy that they can apply upon a fond and senseless (@) such a occasion be this first they kill a white hen put she into a platter with her feather on and then very solemn with waxe-candle they carry she to the Bathe and there leave she and many good fellow there be which so soon as the silly woman have set down their hen at the bath will come secret thither and convey away the hen to their own kitchen somewhat far from the city eastward there be a fountain of extreme cold water and near unto it stand a certain building of marble adorn with sundry hieroglyphical picture or emblem such as I have see at Rome and at many other place of Europe but the common people imagine that it be in time past a grammar-schoole and because both the master and scholar thereof be most vicious they be transform say they into marble the inhabitant twice every year send great store of ware into Numidia and because as they travel they be in danger of the arabian thief they hire certain turkish harquebusier for great wage to guard they the merchant of Constantina travel to Tunis pay no tribute at all but only at their departure forth of Constantina for the worth of every 100 ducat in merchandise they allow two ducat and a half of the town of mela. this town build by the roman within twelve mile of Constantina and environ with most strong wall contain almost three thousand family but at this present there be but few building by reason of the war that have happen here be greatstore of artisan the most whereof be such weaver as make coverlet in the market place there be a most clear fountain the citizen be valiant though they be of rude behaviour here be abundance not only offruit whereupon some think the name of the town to be derive but also of cattle and corn unto this town the governonr of Constantina send every year a certain judge to decide the townsman controversy and to receive the yearly tribute howbeit oftentimes the say judge be slay by the people of the ancient town of bona. this town build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea almost 120. mile more to the west be in ancient time call Hippo where s. Augustine in time past bishop of hippo. the reverend father saint Augustine be once bishop it be in process of time subdue by the goth and be afterward surprise and burn to ash by hutman the three patriarch after Mahumet and many year after they build a new town within two mile of the stone that be bring from the ruin of Bona which new town they call beld elhuneb that be the city of the fruit call Ziziphus or juiuba by reason of the great abundance of that fruit the which they use to dry in the sun and to keep till winter it contain almost three hundred family and all the house and building thereof be very base save one only temple which stand next the sea the inhabitant be all of a ingenuous disposition some of they be merchant and the residue artisan here be great store of linen-cloth weave the great part whereof be carry to Numidia the inhabitant of this town have upon a time slay their governor be so bold as to threaten the king of Tunis and they have without all doubt betray the town unto the christian have not the king of Tunis take special heed thereunto in this town be certain lewd people and most beggarly apparel which notwithstanding be high reverence by the citizen here be no fountain nor yet any water at all but rainewater only which be keep in cestern on the east side of the town stand a strong castle build by the king of Tunis where the governor of the town appoint by the king have his abode unto this town adjoin a most large plain contain in length forty and in breadth five and twenty mile very commodious it be for corn and be inhabit by certain arabian call these arabian have great store of cattle and but little money and they bring good store of butter daily unto bona. unto this town the people of Tunis of the isle of Gerbi and of Genoa use yearly to resort and to buy great abundance of corn and butter every Friday they have near unto the town wall a market which be well frequent even till night not great store of coral far from hence there be a certain place in the sea abound with great store of coral and because the townsman know not how to fish for the same the king of Tunis license certain merchant of Genoa to fish for it who in regard of the continual assault of pirate because they can not speed of their purpose they obtain leave also of the king to build a castle near unto the place but that the townsman will in no case permit say that the genovese in time past take their town by such a wile and that it be afterward recover again by the king of Tunis of the town of the town of tefa found by the african upon the side of a mountain and stand almost a hundred and fifty mile southward of Bona be in time past (@) populous and full of brave building but it have be since destroy by the arabian afterwards be replant with new inhabitant and remain free from war for certain month it be the second time destroy by the arabian last of all because it be a place commodious for corn it be inhabit the three time by certain african call Haoara and that by the aid of a certain prince brother unto he which have slay Enasir the king of Tunis his son but now all that remain of this town be utter raze by the king of Tunis of the city of Tebessa this great and strong city build by the roman near unto Numidia and be distant two hundred mile southward from the Mediterran sea be compass with a high wall make of such stone as be to be see upon the Colosso at Rome neither see I to my remembrance any such wall in all Africa or Europe and yet the house and other building be very base through part of this city run a great river and in the market and diverse other place stand certain marble pillar have epigram and sentence with latin letter engrave upon they there be also other square pillar of marble cover with roof the plain adjacent albeit very dry yet be they most fruitful for corn five mile from hence grow such abundance of wall-nut-tree as you will take they to be some thick forest near unto this town stand a certain hill full of mighty cave wherein the common people say that giant inhabit of old but it be most evident that those cave be dig by the roman at the same time when they build the city for certain it be that the stone whereof the citie-walle consist be take out of those rock the inhabitant be people of a covetous inhuman and beastly disposition neither will they vouchsafe to look upon a stranger insomuch that Eldabag a famous poet of the city of malaga in Granada have in his travel this way receive some discourtesy write in disgrace of Tebessa certain satirical verse which myself likewise have think good here to set down in the dispraise thereof within this place here be nought of any worth save worthless nut which Tebessa afford soft I mistake the marble wall be worth your earnest view so be the christall-fourds but hence be banish virtue all divine the place be hell the people worse than swine this eldabag be a most learned and elegant poet in the arabian tongue and out of measure satirical and bitter in his invective but to return to our former purpose these tebessians have always rebel against the king of Tunis and have slay all the governor that he have send wherefore the king that now be travel upon a time towards Numidia send certain ambassador into the city to know how the citizen stand affect towards he unto who they instead of God save the king make answer God save our citie-walle whereat the king wax wroth sack the city forthwith behead and hang diverse of the inhabitant and make such havoc that ever since it have remain desolate this be do in the year of the Hegeira 915. of the town call Vrbs. by the name of this town it sufficient appear that the roman be the first founder thereof situate it be upon the most beautiful plain of all Africa which by reason of the abundance of fountain be so well store with corn that from thence to Tunis which stand 190. mile northward of this place and to other region adjoin great plenty of corn be transport in this town be to be see sundry monument of the roman as namely image of marble and every where upon the wall be sentence in latin letter engrave the towne-walle be most artificial and sumptuous build this town the goth be assist by the moor surprise when as it contain the chief treasure and wealth that the roman enjoy in all Africa afterwards it remain for certain year desolate be at length notwithstanding inhabit a new yet so that it deserve rather the name of a village then of a town not far from this town run a certain river upon the which be diverse water-mill and this river take his beginning from a little hill but half a mile distant from the town all the inhabitant be either weaver or husbandman and be continual molest by the king of Tunis howbeit if the fertility of the soil the pleasantness of the place and the wholesome disposition of the air be as well know to the king as they be to myself I think very that he will leave Tunis and go and dwell in this region the arabian be well acquaint with the place for from hence they yearly transport great store of corn unto their desert of the town of this town build by the roman upon a mountain almost twenty mile distant from the Mediterran sea and about eighty mile westward of Tunis stand right in the way from Tunis to Constantina but because the name of this town be no arabian name it seem that the first name have be oftentimes corrupt and change the ancient wall of this town be as yet stand and it be a most defensible place and well furnish with all kind of necessary it be inhabit with great store of weaver and husbandman and the field thereof be so large and fruitful for all kind of grain that the people of the same region can not sufficient manure they unless they be assist by certain border arabian and yet a great part of their field lie untilled howbeit they send continual great store of corn unto Tunis the king of Tunis surcharge they with continual and grievous exaction which be the cause why their estate so mighty decay of the town call hain sammit this town be in my time found by the king of Tunis be distant almost thirty mile from it be build they say of purpose that none of the field thereabouts may lie untilled but it have since be destroy by the arabian at the commandment of the king of Tunis and now there remain a tower and certain other building only whereof some have roof upon they and other none of the town of Casba this town build by the roman upon a large plain of twelve mile compass be four and twenty mile distant from Tunis the town-wall remain strong as yet but the town itself be destroy by the arabian and the field lie untilled and all by the negligence of the king of Tunis and of the inhabitant of the same region of the castle of this castle found not many year pass by the african upon the river of Magrida and be about ten mile distant from Tunis be environ with most fruitful field near unto this town grow a certain wood great abound with olive at length it be destroy by certain arabian call beni Heli which make perpetual war against the king of Tunis and live only upon theft and robbery of the town of Biserta the ancient town of Biserta otherwise call Bensart found by the african upon the Mediterran sea thirty five mile from Tunis be but of a small bigness and be inhabit with most miserable people near unto this town enter a certain creek or arm of the sea which at the first be very narrow increase by little and little into a marvelous breadth on either side there of dwell great store of fisher and husbandman and westward of the say creek lie a most large and fruitful plain call Mater which be grievous molest by the king of Tunis and by the arabian in the fish call (@) or (@) this creek be take abundance of fish and after the month of October they catch a certain fish call by the african Giarrafa which I take to be the same that be at Rome call Laccia for then by reason of the abundance of rain that fall the salt water of the bay become somewhat fresh wherewith those fish they say be much delight very deep it be and afford good fish till the end of May but then the fish begin to decrease and to be much dry in taste then before like unto the fish take in the river of Fez. of the great city of Carthage this famous and ancient city be build at the first by a certain people that come out of Syria but other say that it be found by a queen the african chronicler Rachich be of opinion that it be build by a certain people that come from barca be expel thence by the king of Egypt wherefore I can in this place affirm any certainty as touch the founder thereof for beside that the african historiographer disagree about this matter there be none that have leave any write thereof ancient than the decay of the roman empire when as all the roman that be find in Africa be expel by the goth but afterward Tripoli of Barbaria and be take by the mahometan the inhabitant of they both go unto Carthage whither the principal roman and goth have retire themselves who endeavour by all mean to withstand the mahometan and after many skirmish the roman flee to Bona and the goth leave Carthage for a pray unto the mahometan so that it remain desolate many year after till a certain mahometan patriarch call Elmahdi bring in new colony howbeit he can scarce furnish the twenty part with inhabitant there be to be see at this day certain ruin of the citie-walle till you come to a deep and large cistern and there remain as yet also a certain conduct which convey water to the city from a mountain thirty mile distant be like unto the conduct of the great palace at Rome near unto Carthage likewise be certain great and ancient building the description whereof be out of my remembrance on the west and south part of this city be diverse garden replenish with all kind of fruit which be carry from thence to Tunis in great abundance the plain adjoin to this city be exceed fruitful though not very large for upon the north part thereof lie a mountain the sea and the gulf of Tunis on the (@) and south part it join to the plain of Bensart but * * * 1526 now this city be fall into extreme decay and misery merchant shop there be not above twenty or five and twenty at the most and all the house of the town be scarce five hundred be most base and beggarly in my time here be a stately (@) and a fair college also but no student be therein the townsman though very miserable yet be they exceed proud withal and seem to pretend a great show of religion and the great part of they be either gardiner or husbandman and be grievous oppress with the king daily exaction a description of the mighty city of Tunis this city be call by the latin Tunetum and by the arabian which name they think to be corrupt because it signify nought in their language but in old time it be call Tarsis after the name of a city in Asia at the first it be a small town build by the african upon a certain lake about twelve mile distant from the Mediterran sea and upon the decay of Carthage Tunis begin to increase both in building and inhabitant for the inhabitant of Carthage be loath to remain any long in their own town fear lest some army will have be send out of Europe wherefore they repair unto Tunis and great enlarge the building thereof afterwards come thither one Hucba vtman the four mahometan patriarch who persuade the citizen that no army or garrison ought to the building of Cairaoan remain in any sea-towne wherefore he build another city call cairaoan be distant from the Mediterran sea thirty and from Tunis almost a hundred mile unto which city the army march from Tunis and in the room thereof other people be send to inhabit about a hundred and fifty year after Cairaoan be sack by the arabian the prince thereof be expel and become governor of the kingdom of Bugia howbeit he leave certain kinsman of his at Tunis who govern that city and ten year after Bugia be take by joseph the son of Tesfin who see the humanity of the foresay prince will not expel he out of his kingdom but so long as it remain to the say prince and his posterity joseph cause it to be free from all molestation afterwards Abdul Mumen king of Maroco have recover Mahdia from the christian march towards Tunis and get possession thereof also and so Tunis remain peaceable under the Tunis subject unto Abdul-Mumen and other king of Maroco dominion of the king of Maroco so long as the kingdom be govern by the say Abdul and his son joseph and their successor jacob and Mansor but after the decease of Mansor his son Mahumet Ennasir make war against the king of Spain by who be vanquish he flee to Maroco and there within few year end his life after he succeed his brother joseph who be slay by certain soldier of the king of Telensin and so upon the death of Mahumet and of his brother joseph the arabian begin to inhabit the territory of Tunis and to make often siege and assault against the city itself whereupon the governor of Tunis advertise the king of Maroco that unless present aid be send he must be coustrain to yield Tunis unto the arabian the king therefore send a certain valiant captain call Habduluahidi and bear in Seville a city of * * * * * or perhaps Andaluzia Granada with a fleet of twenty sail unto Tunis which he find half destroy by the arabian but so great be his eloquence and wisdom that he restore all thing to their former estate and receive the yearly tribute after Habduluahidi succeed his son Abu (@) who in learning and dexterity of wit excel his father this Abu build a castle upon a certain high place of the west part of Tunis which he adorn with fair building and with a most beautiful temple afterwards take his journey unto the kingdom of Tripoli and return home by the southern region he gather tribute in all those place so that after his decease he leave great treasure unto his son and after Abu succeed his son who grow so insolent that he will not be subject to the king of Maroco because he perceive his kingdom to decay at the same time also have the marin-family get possession of the kingdom of Fez and so be the family of beni Zeijen possess of the kingdom of Telensin and Granada and so while all those region be at mutual dissension the dominion of Tunis begin mighty to increase insomuch that the king of Tunis march unto Telensin and demand tribute of the inhabitant wherefore the king of Fez who as then lay siege against Maroco crave by his ambassador the king of Tunis his friendship and with great gift obtain the same then the king of Tunis return home conqueror from Telensin be receive with great triumph and be salute king of all Africa because indeed there be no prince of Africa at the same time comparable unto he wherefore he begin to ordain a royal court and to choose secretary counsellor captain and other officer appertain to a king after the very same manner that be use in the court of Maroco and from the time of this king even till our time the kingdom of Tunis have so prosper that now it be account the rich kingdom in all Africa the say king son reign after his father death enlarge the suburb of Tunis with most stately building without the gate call bed he build a street contain to the number of three hundred family and he build another street at the gate call bed Manera consist of more than a thousand family in both of these street dwell great store of artificer and in the street last mention all the christian of Tunis which be of the king guard have their abode likewise there be a three street build at the gate next unto the sea call Bahar and be but half a mile distant from the gulf of Tunis hither do the genovese venetian and all other christian merchant resort and here they repose themselves out of the tumult and concourse of the moor and this street be of so great bigness that it contain three hundred family of christian and moor but the house be very low and of small receipt the family of the city together with they of the suburb amount almost to the number of ten thousand ' this stately and populous city have a peculiar place assign for each trade and occupation here dwell great store of linnen-weavers and the linen that they weave be exceed fine and sell at a great price over all Africa the woman of this town use a strange kind of spin a strange kind of spin for (@) upon a high place or on the upper part of the house they let down their spindle at a window or through a hole of the plancher into a low room so that the weight of the spindle make the thread very equal and even and here the linendraper have many shop and be account the wealthy citizen in all Tunis here be also great store of grocer apothecary tailor and of all other trade and occupation butcher here be very many which sell mutton for the most part especial in the spring and in summer also here be abundance of all kind of artificer every of which to describe will prove tedious the apparel of their merchant priest and doctor be very decent upon their head they wear a dulipan which be cover with a great linnen-cloth the courtier likewise and the soldier wear all of they dulipan but not cover with linen rich man here be but few by reason of the exceed scarcity of all kind of grain for a man can till a piece of ground be it never so near the city in regard of the manifold invasion of the arabian corn be bring unto they from other region and city as namely from and from bona. some of the citizen of Tunis have certain field in the suburb wall round about where they sow some quantity of barley and of other corn howbeit the soil be marueluellous dry and stand in need of much water for which purpose every man have a pit whereout with a certain wheel turn about by a mule or a camel and through certain conveyance and passage make for the nonce they water all the upper part of their ground now consider I pray you what great crop of corn can be reap out of so little a field wall round about and water by such cunning and industry bread they make very excellent albeit they leave the bran still among the flower and they bake their loaf in certain mortar such as the egyptian use to beat flax in the merchant and most part of the citizen use for food a kind of homely pulse or pap call by they Besis be make of barley meal in form of a dumpling whereupon they pour oil or the broth of pome-citrons and there be a certain place in the city where nothing but barley prepare in a readiness to make the say pulse be to be sold. they use also another kind of food almost as homely as the former for seethe a quantity of meal thorough in water and afterward bray it in another vessel with a pestle they pour oil or flesh-pottage thereunto and so eat it and this meat they call Bezin but the rich sort feed themselves with more dainty meat all their mill except such as stand upon a river not far from the city be turn about either by the strength of mule or ass in this city they have no fountain river nor well of fresh water but they all use rainwater take out of cestern save that there be a fountain in the suburb from whence certain porter bring salt-water into the city to sell which they think to be more wholesome and fit for drink then rainwater other well there be that afford most excellent water which be reserve only for the king and his courtier in this city there be one most stately temple furnish with sufficient number of priest and with rich revenue other temple there be also but not endow with so ample revenue here be college likewise and monastery build after their manner all which be maintain upon the common benevolence of the city there be certain people in this city who a man will take to be distraught which go bareheaded and barefooted carry stone about with they and these be reverence by the common people for man of singular holiness moreover on the behalf of one of these mad fellow call sidi Dahi and for the residue of his fond society the king of Tunis build one of the foresay monastery and endow the same with most ample revenue all the house of this city be indifferent beautiful be build of excellent stone and adorn with much paint and carve they have very artificial pargetting or plaister-work which they beautify with orient colour for wood to carve upon be very scarce at Tunis the floor of their chamber be pave with certain shine and fair stone and most of their house be but of one story high and almost every house have two gate or entrance one towards the street and another towards the kitchen and other backe-roumes between which gate they have a fair court where they may walk and confer with their friend the bathstove here be far more commodious than those at Fez though not so large and sumptuous in the suburb be many pleasant garden which yield fruit albeit not in great abundance yet very excellent pome-citron rose and other flower here be great store especial in that place which they call bardo where the king have build a palace amid those beautiful and sweet garden on all side of the city within four or five mile there grow such plenty of olive that the oil thereof suffice not only the city but be carry also in great quantity into Egypt the wood of the olive-tree which they cut down they use to burn and to make charcoal thereof neither do I think any place to be more destitute of wood than this Povertie constrain some of their woman to lead a unchaste life they be decent apparel and go forth of the house they wear veil or mask before their face like unto the woman of Fez for with one linen-cloth they cover their forehead and join thereto another which they call but about their head they lap such fardel of linen as they seem comparable to the head of giant most part of their substance and labour they bestow upon perfume and other such vanity they have here a compound call lhasis whereof whosoever eat but one ounce fall a laugh disport and dally as if he be half drunken and be by the say confection marvellous provoke unto lust of the king of Tunis his court and of the rite and ceremony there use so soon as the king of Tunis have by inheritance attain to his kingdom all his noble doctors priest and judge bind themselves by solemn oath unto he immediate after any king death his son and heir apparent succeed in the kingdom then the chief officer of the court call the munafid because he be the king viceroy or high deputy present himself forthwith unto the new king and give up a account of all thing which he do while the old king live and then at the king appointment every of the noble receive office from the munafid according to their several place of dignity another principal officer there be call the mesuare that be the great commander and governor of the warlike force who have authority to increase or diminish the number of soldier to give they their pay to levy army and to conduct the same whither he think good the three officer in dignity be the Castellan who with his soldier take charge of the castle and look to the safeguard of the king own person and he allot punishment unto such prisoner as be bring into the say castle as if he be the king himself the four officer be the governor of the city who duty be to administer justice in the common wealth and to punish malefactor the five officer be the king secretary who have authority to write and to give answer in the king name he may open also and read any letter whatsoever except such as be send unto the Castellan and governor of the city the six be the king chief chamberlain who be to furnish the wall with hang to appoint unto every man his place and by a messenger to assemble the king counselor and this man have great familiarity with the king and have access to speak with he as often as he please the seven in dignity be the king treasurer who receive all custom tribute and yearly revenue and pay they with the king consent unto the munafid the eight officer be he that receive tribute for merchandise that be bring by land who take custom also of foreign merchant which be constrain for the value of every hundred ducat to pay two ducat and a half this customer have many spy and officer who have intelligence of any merchant arrival they bring he forthwith before their master in who absence they keep he so long in their custody till their say master be present and till the merchant have deliver all such custom as be due and then be bind with many oath he be dismiss the nine officer receive tribute only of such ware as be bring by sea and dwell in a house by the haven side the ten be the steward of the king household who be to provide bread meat and other necessary victual and to apparel all the king wife eunuch and the negro-slave that attend upon he he also take charge of the king son and of their nurse and allot business unto the christian captive these be the chief officer under the king of Tunis the residue lest I shall seem tedious to the reader I have of purpose omit to entreat of the king of Tunis have fifteen hundred most choice soldier the great part of who be renegado or backslider from the christian faith and these have liberal pay allow they they have a captain over they also who may increase or diminish their number as he please also there be a hundred and fifty soldier be Moor who have authority to remove the tent of the king army from place to place there be likewise a certain number of crossbow which attend upon the king whithersoever he ride but next of all to the king person be his guard of christian which as we signify before dwell in the suburb before the king march a guard of footman be all of they turkish archer and gunner immediate before the king go his lackey or footman one there be that ride on the one side of the king carry his partisan another on the other side bear his target and the three come (@) he carry his crossbow other there be also that attend upon the king who for brevity sake we omit here to speak of these be the principal rite and ceremony of the ancient king of Tunis be much different from they which be use by the king that now be I can here make a large discourse of the king vice that now reign at who hand I confess myself to have receive great benefit but that be not my purpose at this present this one thing I can affirm that he be marvelous cunning to procure money out of his subject purse but he himself live sometime in his palace and sometime in garden in the company of his concubine musician stageplayer and such like when he call for any musician he be bring in blindfold or hoodwink in manner of a hawk the golden coin of Tunis contain four and twenty charat apiece that be to say a ducat and one three part of the coin of Europe there be a kind of siluermoney coin also be four square in form which weigh six charat apiece and thirty or two and thirty of these piece be equal in value to one piece of their gold coin and they be call the italian call the gold-coine of Tunis doble and thus much concern the king of doble Tunis and the custom of his court of the town of neapolis this ancient town build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea almost twelve mile eastward of Tunis be inhabit by certain moor call Nabell it be in time pass very populous but now there dwell but a few peasant therein which exercise themselves only about sow and reap of (@) of the town of cammar this town be very ancient also and near unto Carthage stand eight mile northward of Tunis the inhabitant be many in number be all of they gardiner and use to bring their herb and fruit to Tunis to be sell here also grow great store of sugarcane which be bring likewise unto Tunis but because they have not the art of get sugarcane out the sugar they use only after meal to suck the sweet juice out of the say cane of the town of Marsa this ancient town stand upon the Mediterran sea near the same place where the haven of Carthage be of old remain certain year desolate but now it be inhabit by certain fisher and husbandman and here they use to white linnen-cloth not far from hence be certain castle and palace where the king of Tunis ordinary remain in summertime of the town of ariana moreover this ancient town be build by the goth almost eight mile northward of Tunis it be environ with most pleasant and fruitful garden and it have a strong wall and contain many they either fisher or collier of the town of Heraclia this little and ancient town be found by the roman upon a certain mountain and be afterward destroy by the arabian of the town of susa. this strong wall and situate upon a most beautiful plain it be in time pass well store with inhabitant and with fair building whereof some together with a goodly temple be as yet extant but now it contain very few people and but five shop in all by reason of the king continual exaction I myself be constrain to stay in this town for four day in regard of the danger of the time of the town of Monaster the ancient town of Monaster build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea and distant almost twelve mile from Susa be environ with most impregnable and stately wall and contain very fair building but the inhabitant be most miserable and beggarly people and wear shoe make of sea-rush most of they be either weaver or fisher their fare be barley bread and a kind of food mingle with oil which we call before Bezzin which be use in all the town thereabouts the soil will yield no other corn but barley the territory adjacent abound with orange pear fig pomegranate and olive save that it be continual waste by the invasion of the enemy of the town of Tobulba this town build also by the roman upon the Mediterran sea stand about twelve mile eastward of Monaster for certain year it be very populous and great abound with olive but afterward it be so waste by the arabian that now there be but few house remain which be inhabit by certain religious man these religious man maintain a fair hospital for stranger travel that way where they courteous entertain even the arabian themselves of the town of el Mahdia otherwise call Africa Mahdia found in our time by Mahdi the first patriarch of cairaoan upon the Mediterran sea and fortify with strong wall tower and gate have a most noble haven belong thereto Mahdi when he first enter into this region feign himself in a unknown habit to be (@) of the receive tribute due unto he he be take by the prince of segelmesse and put in prison howbeit the say prince of Segelmese be present move with compassion towards he restore he to his former liberty and be for his good will not long after slay by he afterward tyrannize over the people and perceive some to conspire against he he erect this town of Mahdia to the end he may there find safe refuge when Egypt and Turkey of the great city of Cairaoan the famous city of cairaoan otherwise call Caroen be found by Hucba who be send general of a army out of Arabia by hutman the three mahometan Califa from the Mediterran sea this city be distant six and thirty and from Tunis almost a hundred mile neither be it build they say for any other purpose but only that the arabian army may secure rest therein with all such spoil as they win from the barbarian and the numidian he environ it with most impregnable wall and build therein a sumptuous temple support with stately pillar the say Hucba after the death of hutman be ordain prince of Muchavia and govern the same till the time of qualid Califa the son of habdul malic who as then reign in Damascus this qualid send a certain captain call muse the son of Nosair with a huge army unto cairaoan who have stay a few day with his army not far from cairaoan march westward sack and spoil town and city till he come to the ocean sea shore and then he return towards cairaoan again from whence he send as his deputy a certain captain into Mauritania who there also conquer many region and city insomuch that muse be move with a jealous emulation command he to stay till himself come his say deputy therefore call Tarich encamp himself not far from Andaluzia whither muse within 4. month come unto he with a huge army from whence both of they with their army cross the sea arrive in Granada and so march by land against the goth against who theodoricus the king of goth oppose himself in battle be miserable vanquish then the foresay two captain with all good success proceed even to Castilia and sack the city of Toledo where among much other treasure they find many relic of the saint and the very same table whereat Christ sit with his bless apostle which be cover with pure gold and adorn with great store of precious stone be esteem to be worth half a million of ducat and this table muse carry with he as if it have be all the treasure in Spain return with his army over the sea and bend his course toward cairaoan and be in the mean space send for by the letter of qualid Califa he sail into Egypt but arrive at Alexandria it be tell he by one Hescian brother unto the say Califa that the Califa his brother be fall into a most dangerous disease wherefore he wish he not to go present unto Damascus for fear lest if the Califa die in the mean season those rich and sumptuous spoil shall be waste and disperse to no end but muse little regard this counsel proceed on to Damascus and present all his spoil to the Califa who within five day after decease after who his brother succeed Califa deprive muse of his dignity and substitute one jezul into his room who son brother and nephew succeed govern the city of cairaoan till such time as the family of qualid be deprive of that dignity and one Elagleb be appoint lieutenant who govern not the town as a Califa from that time the mahometan Califas leave Damascus remove unto bagaded as we find record in a certain chronicle after the decease of Elagleb succeed his son and the government remain unto his posterity for a hundred threescore and ten year till such time as they be deprive thereof by one Mahdi Califa but at the same time when Elagleb be governor the city of Cairaoan be so increase both with inhabitant and building that a town call Recheda be build next unto it where the prince with his noble use to remain in his time also the isle of Sicilia be win for Elagleb the isle of Sicily subdue by the governor (@) send thither a certain captain call Halcama who build upon the say island a town in stead of a fort call it according to his own name Halcama which name be use by the sicilian even till this present afterwards this new town be besiege by certain people that come to aid the sicilian whereupon one ase be send with a army and so the moor force be augment they conquer the residue of Sicilia by which mean the dominion of cairaoan begin wonderful to increase the city of Cairaoan stand upon a sandy and desert plain which bear no tree nor yet any corn at all corn be bring thither from Susa from Monaster and from Mahdia all which town be within the space of forty mile about twelve mile from cairaoan stand a certain mountain call gueslet where some of the roman building be as yet extant this mountain abound with spring of water and carob which spring run down to cairaoan where otherwise they shall have no water but such as be keep in cistern without the wall of this city rain water be to be find in certain cistern only till the beginning of june in summer time the arabian use to resort unto the plain adjoin upon this town who bring great dearth of corn and water but exceed plenty of date and flesh with they and that out of Numidia which region be almost a hundred threescore and ten mile distant in this city for certain year the study of the mahometan law mighty flourish so that here be the most famous lawyer in all Africa it be at length destroy and replant again with new inhabitant but it can never attain unto the former estate at this present it be inhabit by none but leatherdresser who send their leather unto the city of Numidia and exchange it also for cloth of Europe howbeit they be so continual oppress by the king of Tunis that now they be bring unto extreme misery of the city of cape this ancient city build by the roman upon the Mediterran sea be fortify with most high and stately wall and with a strong castle just by it run a certain river of hot and salt water it have continual be so molest by the arabian that the inhabitant abandon their city resort unto certain plain replenish with great abundance of date which by a certain art be preserve all the year long here be also dig out of the ground a kind of fruit about the bigness of a bean and in taste resemble a almond this fruit be ordinary the fruit call Habhaziz over all the kingdom of Tunis be call by the arabian habhaziz the inhabitant of the foresay plain be black people be all of they either fisher or husbandman of the town call el Hamma this most ancient town found also by the roman and be distant from cape almost fifteen mile be environ with most stately and strong wall and upon certain marble stone therein be engrave diverse monument of antiquity the street and building of this town be very base and the inhabitant miserable and addict to robbery their field be barren and unprofitable and will bring forth nought but certain unsavoury date a mile and a half to the south of this town a river (@) hot water begin a certain river of hot water to spring which be bring through the midst of the city by certain channel be so deep that it will reach up to a man navel howbeit by reason of the extreme heat of the water there be but few that will enter thereinto and yet the inhabitant use it for drink have set it a cool almost a whole day at length this river not far from the town make a certain lake which be call the lake of leper the lake of leper for it be of wonder force to heal the disease of leprosy and to cure leprous sore wherefore near unto it be diverse cottage of leper some of who be restore to their health the say water taste in a manner like brimstone so that it will nothing at all quench a man thirst whereof I myself have have often trial of the castle of machre the castle of machre be build by the african in my time upon the entrance of the gulf of cape to defend the same region from the invasion of the enemy it be almost five hundred mile distant from the isle of Gerbi all the inhabitant be either weaver shipwright or fisherman and have traffic and recourse over all the foresay isle they have all the same language that the people of the isle of Gerbi use but because they want ground and possession all of they save the weaver live only upon theft and robbery of the isle of where John Leo the author of this history be take by italian pirate and carry thence to Rome this isle be near unto the firm land of Africa and consist of a plain and sandy ground abound exceed with date vine olive and other fruit and contain about eighteen mile in compass it have also certain farm and grange which be so far distant asunder that you shall scarce find two or three in one village their ground be dry and barren which though it be never so well till will yield but a little barley and here corn and flesh be always at a (@) rate at the sea shore stand a strong castle wherein the governor of the whole island and his retinue have their abode not far from hence there be a certain village where the christian mauritanian and turkish merchant have their place of residence in which place there be a great market or fair weekly keep whither all the merchant of the island and many arabian from the main land with great store of cattle and wool do resort the inhabitant of the isle bring cloth thither to sell which they themselves make and this cloth together with great store of raisin they usual transport unto Tunis and Alexandria to be sell scarce fifty year sithence this isle be invade and conquer by christian but it be immediate recover by the king of Tunis and present after new colony be here plant the foresay castle be re-edify which the king of Tunis afterward enjoy but after the death of king hutman the islander return to their former liberty and present break the bridge from the island to the main land fear lest they shall be invade by some land-army not long after the say islander slay the king of Tunis his governor of the isle have themselves continue governor thereof till this present out of this island be gather the sum of fourscore thousand dobles every doble contain a italian ducat and one three part for yearly tribute by reason of the great concourse and resort of the merchant of Alexandria Turkey and Tunis but now because they be at continual dissension and controversy their estate be much impair in my time don Ferdinando king the army of don Ferdinando defeat of Spain send a great armada against this island under the conduct of the duke of Alva who not know the nature of the same command his soldier to land a good distance from thence but the moor so valiant defend their island that the spaniard be constrain to give back and so much the great be their distress in that they can not find water sufficient to quench their extreme thirst moreover at the spaniard arrival it be a full tide but when they will have return on board it be so great a ebb that their ship be constrain to put to sea lest they shall have be cast upon the sholde the shore be dry for almost four mile together so that the spanish soldier be put unto great toil before they can come to the water side and the moor pursue they so eager that they slay and take prisoner the great part of they and the residue escape by ship into Sicilia afterward the emperor Gerbi make tributary unto Charles the five by mean of a knight of the Rhodes Charles the five send a mighty fleet thither under the conduct of a rhodian knight of the order of saint John de Messina who so discreet behave himself in that action that the moor compound to pay five thousand dobles for yearly tribute upon condition of the emperor league and good will which yearly tribute be pay until this present of the town of zoara this town build by the african upon the Mediterran sea stand eastward from the isle of Gerbi almost fifty mile the town wall be weak and the inhabitant be poor people be occupy about nothing but make of lime and plaistr which they sell in the kingdom of Tripoli their field be most barren and the inhabitant have continual be molest by the invasion of the christian especial since the time that they win Tripoli of the town of this ancient town found by the roman and environ with most high and strong wall have twice be sack by the mahometan and of the stone and ruin thereof be Tripoli afterward build of the old city of Tripoli old Tripoli build also by the roman be after win by the goth and last by the mahometan in the time of Califa Homar the second which mahumetan have besiege the governor of Tripoli six month together compel he at length to flee unto Carthage the citizen be partly slay and partly carry captive into Egypt and Arabia as the most famous african historiographer (@) report of the new city of Tripoli in Barbary affter the destruction of old Tripoli there be build another city of that name which city be environ with most high and beautiful wall but not very strong be situate upon a sandy plain which yield great store of date the house plenty of date of this city be most stately in respect of the house of Tunis and here also every trade and occupation have a several place weaver here be many they have no well nor fountain but all their water be take out of cestern corn in this city be at a exceed rate for all the field of Tripoli be as sandy and barren as the field of Numidia the reason whereof be for that the principal and fat ground of this region be overflow with the sea the inhabitant of this region affirm that the great part of their field northward be swallow up by the Mediterran sea the like whereof be to be see in the territory of Monaster Mahdia asfaco cape the isle of Gerbi and other place more eastward where the sea for the space of a mile be so shallow that it will scarce reach unto a man navel yea some be of opinion that the city of Tripoli itself be situate in time past more to the north but by reason of the continual inundation of the sea it be build and remove by little and little southward for proof whereof there stand as yet ruin of house drown in certain place of the sea in this city be many fair temple and college build and a hospital also for the maintenance of their own poor people and for the entertainment of stranger their fare be very base and homely be only the forename besis make of barley meal for that region afford so small quantity even of barley that he be account a wealthy man that have a bushel or two of corn in store the citizen be most of they merchant for Tripoli stand near unto Numidia and Tunis neither be there any city or town of account between it and Alexandria neither be it far distant from the isle of Sicilia and Malta and unto the port of Tripoli Venetian ship yearly resort and bring thither great store of merchandise this city have always be subject unto the king of Tunis but when abulhasen the king of Fez besiege Tunis the king of Tunis be constrain with his arabian to flee into the desert howbeit when Abulhasen be conquer the king of Tunis return to his kingdom but his subject begin to oppose themselves against he and so that commonwealth be afterward grievous turmoil with civil dissension and war whereof the king of Fez have intelligence march the five year of the say civil war with a army against the city of Tunis and have vanquish the king thereof and constrain he to flee unto Constantina he so strait besiege he that the citizen of Constantina see themselves not able to withstand the king of Fez open their city gate to he and to all his army whereupon the king of Tunis be carry captive unto Fez and be afterward keep a while prisoner in the castle of in the mean season Tripoli be by a genovese fleet (@) take by a fleet of (@) of twenty sail surprise and sack and the inhabitant carry away captive whereof the king of Fez be advertise give the genovese fifty thousand ducat upon condition that he mightenjoy the town in peace but the genovese have surrender the town perceive after their departure that most part of their ducat be counterfeit afterwards the king of Tunis be restore unto his former liberty by Abuselim king of Fez return home unto his kingdom and so the government thereof remain unto he and his posterity till Abubar the son of hutman together with his young son be slay in the castle of Tripoli by a nephew of he who afterward usurp the kingdom but he be slay in a battle which he fight against habdul Mumen who present thereupon become lord of Tripoli after he succeed his son zacharias who within a few month die of the pestilence after zacharias Mucamen the son of Hesen and cousin to zacharias be choose king who beginning to tyrannize over the citizen be by they expel out of his kingdom and afterward a certain citizen be advance unto the royal throne who govern very modest but the king which be before expel send a army of soldier against Tripoli who lose the field be all of they put to flight afterwards the king that begin to reign so modest prove a very tyrant and be murder by his kinsman the people make choice of a certain nobleman lead as then a hermit life and in a manner against his will appoint he their governor and so the government of the city of Tripoli remain unto he and his posterity till such time as king Ferdinando send don Pedro de Navarra against it who Tripoli surprise by Pedro de Navarra on the sudden encounter this city carry away many captive with he the governor of Tripoli and his son in law be send prisoner unto Messina where after certain year imprisonment they be restore by the emperor Charles the five unto their former liberty and return unto Tripoli which town be afterward destroy by the christian the castle of Tripoli be environ with most strong wall begin as I understand to be replant with new inhabitant and thus much as concern the city of the kingdom of Tunis of the mountain belong to the state of Bugia the territory of Bugia be full of ragged high and woody mountain the inhabitant be a noble rich and liberal people and possess great store of goat ox and horse have always continue in liberty since the time that Bugia be surprise by the christian the people of these mountain use to have a black cross upon one of their cheek according to the ancient custom before mention their bread be make of barley and they have abundance of nut and fig upon those mountain especial which be near unto Zoaoa in some place of these mountain be certain mine of iron whereof they make a kind of coin of half a iron-mine pound weight they have also another sort of silver coin weigh four grain a piece these mountain yield abundance of wine and hemp but their linen-cloth that they weave be exceed course and these mountain of Bugia extend in length upon the coast of the Mediterran sea almost a hundred and fifty and in breadth forty mile each mountain contain inhabitant of a diverse kindred and generation from other who because they live all after one manner we will pass over in silence of mount Auraz this exceed high and populous mountain be inhabit with most barbarous people that be whole addict unto robbery and spoil from Bugia it be distant fourscore and from Constantina almost threescore mile also be separate from other mountain it extend about threescore mile in length southward it border upon the numidian desert and northward upon the region of Mesila stefe and Constantina from the very top of this mountain issue diverse stream of water which run down into the next plain increase at length into a lake the water whereof in summer time be salt the passage unto this mountain be very difficult in regard of certain cruel arabian of the mountain of Constantina all the north and west part of the territory belong to the city of Constantina be full of high mountain which beginning at the border of Bugia extend themselves to the Mediterran sea even as far as Bona that be to say almost a hundred and thirty mile their field upon the plain be replenish with olive fig and all other kind of fruit which be carry in great quantity unto the next town and city all the inhabitant for civil demeanour excel the citizen of Bugia and do exercise diverse manuary art and weave great store of linen cloth they be at continual dissension among themselves by reason that their woman will so often change husband they be exceed rich and free from all tribute and yet dare they not till their plain both for fear of the arabian and also of the governor of the next city every week upon sundry day here be a market great frequent with merchant of Constantina and of other place and whatsoever merchant have no friend nor acquaintance dwell upon the mountain be in great hazard to be notable cozen upon these mountain they have neither judge priest nor yet any learned man so that when any of the inhabitant will write a letter unto his friend he must trudge up and down sometime twelve and sometime fifteen mile to seek a scribe footman for the war they have almost forty thousand and about four thousand horseman the inhabitant be man of such valour that if they agree among themselves they will soon be able to conquer all Africa of the mountain of bona. the city of Bona have on the north part the Mediterran sea on the south and west part certain mountain adjoin almost unto the mountain of Constantina and on the east side it have most fruitful field and large plain whereupon in time past be diverse town and castle build by the roman the ruin whereof be now only remain and the name quite forget all these region by reason of the arabian cruelty be so desolate that they be inhabit but in very few place and there they be constrain to keep out the arabian by force of arm the mountain of Bona extend in length from east to west almost fourscore mile and in breadth about thirty mile here be great store of fountain from whence certain river issue run through the plain into the Mediterran sea of the mountain stand near unto (@) the city of Tunis stand upon a plain have no mountain nigh unto it but only on the west side towards the Meditterran sea where it have a mountain like unto that which environ Carthage near unto Tunis stand another high and cold mountain call zagoan inhabitant here be none at all but a few that tend the bee-hive and gather some quantity of barley upon the top of this mountain the roman build certain fort the ruin whereof be yet to be see have (@) engrave upon they in latin letter from this mountain unto Carthage water be convey by certain passage under the ground of the mountain of beni Tefren and these high and cold mountain be distant from the desert from Gerbi and from almost thirty mile and yield very small store of barley the inhabitant be valiant and renounce the law of Mahumet do follow the doctrine of the patriarch of cairaoan in most point neither be there any other nation among the arabian that observe the same doctrine in Tunis and other city these people earn their live by most base occupation neither dare they open profess their religion of mount garian this high and cold mountain contain in length forty and in breadth fifteen mile and be separate from other mountain by a sandy desert be distant from Tripoli almost fifty mile it yield great plenty of barley and of date which unless they be spend while they be new will soon prove rot here be likewise abundance of olive wherefore from this mountain unto Alexandria and other city there be much oil convey there be not better saffron to be find in any part of the most (@) saffron world beside which in regard of the goodness be sell very dear for yearly tribute there be gather out of this mountain threescore thousand ducat and as much saffron as fifteen mule can carry they be continual oppress with the exaction of the arabian and of the king of Tunis they have certain base village upon this mountain of mount beni guarid this mountain be almost a hundred mile distant from Tripoli be inhabit with most valiant and stout people which live at their own liberty and be at continual war with the people of the next mountain and of the numidian desert of the castle call Casr acm this castle build upon the Mediterran sea by a captain which come with a army into Africa stand not far from Tripoli and be at the last lay waste by the arabian of the castle of (@) the castle of erect about the same time when the mahometan come into Africa be in time pass well furnish
