destroy by the arabian here end the five book JOHN LEO his six book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein of the village call gar. have hitherto entreat of the mountain it now remain that we say somewhat as touch (@) village hamlet and territory and afterward we will describe in order the city of Numidia and first the village of Gar situate upon the Mediterran sea and abound with date offer itself the field thereto belong be dry and barren and yet bring they forth some quantity of barley for the sustenance of the inhabitant of garell gare. it be a certain little territory or grange contain cave of a marvelous depth whence they say the stone be take wherewith old Tripoli be build because it be not far distant from that city of the village of Sarman this large village stand not far from old Tripoli abound with date but no corn will grow there of the village call ben jarbuh this village be situate near unto the Mediterran sea yield great plenty of date but no corn at all and be inhabit by certain religious person of the village of Zanzor this village also stand near unto the Mediterran sea within twelve mile of Tripoli be inhabit by sundry artificer and abound with great store of date pomegranate and peach the inhabitant have be very miserable ever since Tripoli be take by the christian and yet they traffic with the citizen of Tripoli and carry date thither to sell. of the village of Hamrozo it stand six mile from Tripoli and the garden there of bring forth great plenty of date and of all other kind of fruit of the plain of Taiora this plain stand two mile eastward of Tripoli contain many grange exceed replenish with date and other fruit the surprise of Tripoli be very profitable for this place for then many principal citizen flee hither for refuge the inhabitant be ignorant and rude people and altogether addict to theft and robbery build their cottage with the bough of palmtree their food be barley bread and Bezin before describe all round about be subject unto the king of Tunis and the arabian save those only that inhabit upon this plain of the province of Mesellata this province stand upon the Mediterran sea about five and thirty mile from Tripoli and be fraught with rich village castle and inhabitant abound also with great plenty of olive and date the inhabitant be free from all foreign authority have a captain among themselves which govern their commonwealth and fight their battle against the arabian and the soldier of this province be about 5000. of the province of Mesrata this province be situate also upon the Mediterran sea about a hundred mile from Tripoli have many village both upon the plain and mountain the inhabitant be rich and pay no tribute at all and exercise traffic with the venetian resort to this province with their galley carry the venetian ware to Numidia and there exchange the same for slave musk and civet which be bring thither out of Ethiopia of the desert of barca this desert beginning at the utmost frontier of Mesrata and extend eastward as far as the confine of Alexandria contain in length a thousand and three hundred and in breadth about 200. mile it be a rough and unpleasant place be almost utter destitute of water and corn before the arabian invade Africa this region be void of inhabitant but now certain arabian lead here a miserable and hungry life be a great way distant from all place of habitation neither have they any corn grow at all but corn and other necessary be bring unto they by sea from Sicilia which that every of they may purchase they be constrain to lay their son to gage and then go rob and rifle traveller to redeem they again never do you hear of more cruel and bloody the arabian of barca most cruel and bloody thief thief for after they have rob merchant of all their good and apparel they pour warm milk down their throat hang they up by the heel upon some tree and force they to cast their gorge wherein the lewd varlet search diligent for gold suspect that the merchant swallow up all their crown before they enter that dangerous desert of the city of tesset in Numidia in the first book of this present discourse we say that Numidia be account by the african cosmographer the base part of all Africa and there we allege certain reason for the same purpose we signify also in the second book write of the province of Hea that certain city of Numidia stand near unto mount Atlas howbeit * * * error Sus Guzula Helchemma and cape be within the kingdom of Tunis albeit some will have they situate in Numidia but myself follow the opinion of Ptolemey suppose Tunis to be a part of Barbary be therefore about to describe all the city and town of Numidia I will first begin with tesset which ancient town build by the numidian near unto the libyan desert and environ with wall of sunne-dried brick deserve scarce the name of a town and yet contain four hundred family it be compass round about with sandy plain save that near unto the town grow some store of date of mill-seed and of barley which the miserable townsman use for food they be constrain also to pay large tribute unto the (@) inhabit the next desert they exercise traffic in the land of negro and in Guzula insomuch that they spend most of their time in foreign region they be of a black colour and destitute of all learning the woman indeed teach their young child the first rudiment of learning but before they can attain to any perfection they be put to labour and to the ploughtail the say woman be somewhat white than other woman some of they get their live by spin and card of wool and the residue spend their time in idleness such as be account rich in this region possess but very few cattle they till their ground with a horse and a camel which kind of plough be observe throughout all Numidia of the village of (@) this village situate upon the numidian desert near unto Libya be inhabit by most miserable and gross people here grow nothing but date and the inhabitant be at such enmity with their neighbour that it be dangerous for they to go abroad howbeit they give themselves the beast call (@) to hunt and take certain wild beast call elamth and ostrich neither do they eat any other flesh all their goat they reserve for milk and these people also be black of colour of the castle of Ifran four castle there be call by this name build by the numidian three mile each from other upon a certain river which in the heat of summer be destitute of water near unto these castle be certain field great abound with date the inhabitant be very rich for they have traffic with the portugal at the port of Gart who ware the port of Gart (@) they (@) to Gualata and Tombuto these castle contain great store of inhabitant which make certain brazen vessel to be sell in the land of negro for they have coppermine in sundry place thereabouts every coppermine castle have a weekly market but corn and flesh be at a extreme rate there they go decent apparel and have a fair temple to resort unto and a judge also that decide none but civil controversy for criminal matter they use to punish with banishment only of the castle of Accha three castle of this name build upon the numidian desert not far from Lybia be in time pass well store with inhabitant but at length by civil war they be utter dispeople afterwards all matter be pacify there be by the mean of a certain religious man who govern the same people certain new colony plant neither have the poor inhabitant any thing to do but only to gather date of the province of dara this province begin at mount Atlas extend itself southward by the desert of Lybia almost two hundred and fifty mile and the breadth thereof be very narrow all the inhabitant dwell upon a certain river which be call by the name of the province this river sometime so overflow that a man will think it to be a sea but in summer it so diminish that any one may pass over it on foot if so be it overflow about the begin of April it bring great plenty unto the whole region if not there follow great scarcity of corn upon the bank of this river there be sundry village and hamlet and diverse castle also which be environ with wall make of sunne-dried brick and mortar all their beam and plancher consist of date-tree be notwithstanding unfit for the purpose for the wood of date-tree be not solid but flexible and spongy on either side of the say river for the space of five or six mile the field abound exceed with date which with good keep will last many year and as here be diverse kind of date so they be sell at sundry price for a bushel of some be worth a ducat but other wherewith they feed their horse and camel be scarce of a quarter so much value of the strange property of the palm or date-tree date-tree some be male and some be female the male bring forth flower only and the female fruit but the flower of the female will not open unless the bough and flower of the male be join unto they and if they be not join the date will prove stark naught and contain great stone the inhabitant of dara live upon barley and other gross meat neither may they eat any bread but only upon festival day their castle be inhabit by goldsmith and other artificer and so be all the region lie in the way from Tombuto to Fez in this province also there be three or four proper town frequent by merchant and stranger and contain many shop and temple but the principal town call beni Sabih and inhabit with most valiant and liberal people be divide into two part either part have a several captain or governor which governor be oftentimes at great dissension and especial when they moisten their arable ground by reason that they be so scant of water a merchant they will most courteous entertain a whole year together and then friendly dismiss he they will require nought at his hand but will accept such liberality as he think good to bestow upon they the say governor so often as they fall a skirmish hire the next arabian to aid they allow they daily half a ducat for their pay and sometime more and give they their allowance every day in time of peace they trim their harquebuss handgun and other weapon neither see I ever to my remembrance more cunning harquebuzier then at this place in this province grow great store of indigo be a herb like unto wild woad and this indigo herb they exchange with the merchant of Fez and Tremisen for other ware corn be very scarce among they and be bring thither from Fez and other region neither have they any great store of goat or horse unto who in stead of provender they give date and a kind of herb also which grow in the kingdom of Naples and be call by the neapolitan Farfa they feed their goat with the nut or stone of their date beat to powder whereby they grow exceed fat and yield great quantity of milk their own food be the flesh of camel and goat be unsanorie and displeasant in taste likewise they kill and eat ostrich the flesh whereof the flesh of the ostrich taste not much unlike to the flesh of a dunghill-cocke save that it be more tough and of a strong smell especial the ostrich leg which consist of slimy flesh their woman be fair fat and courteous and they keep diverse slave which be bring out of the land of Negro of the province of segelmesse this province call segelmesse according to the name of the principal city therein contain begin not far from the town of Gherseluin and stretch southward by the river of Ziz a hundred and twenty mile even to the confine of the libyan desert the say province be inhabit by certain barbarous people of the family of Zeneta Zanhagia and Haoara and be in time past subject unto a certain prince which bare rule over the same province only afterwards it fall into the possession of king joseph of the luntune-famy and then into the hand of one Muahidin and not long after it be enjoy by the king of Fez his son but since that time the prince of this region be slay in a rebellion and the city of segelmesse be destroy and till this day remain desolate afterwards the inhabitant build certain castle whereof some be at liberty and other be subject to the arabian of the province of Cheneg this region extend itself by the river of Ziz unto mount Atlas contain many castle and bring forth great abundance of date which date be but of small value their field be barren and of little circuit save only between the river Ziz and the foot of mount Atlas where some store of barley use to grow the inhabitant be some of they subject to the arabian other to the city of Gherseluin and the residue live at their own liberty and unto these the high way lead from segelmesse to Fez be subject and they exact great tribute of the merchant travel the same way near unto the say high way stand three castle the first whereof be situate upon a exceed high rock seem to touch the cloud under this castle there be a certain house where a guard of soldier continual stand who for the load of every camel that pass by demand one four part of a ducat the second castle be fifteen mile distant from the first stand not upon a hill but on a plain and be far more stately and rich then the former the three castle call tammaracrost be situate upon the common high way about twenty mile southward of the second there be certain village also and other castle of mean account corn be marvelous scarce among they but they have goat great plenty which in winter they keep in certain large cave as in place of great safety whereinto they enter by a most narrow passage likewise the entrance into this region for the space of forty mile be so narrow that two or three arm man only may withstand mighty force of the region of Matgara this region begin southward from the region last describe contain many castle build upon the river of Ziz the principal whereof be call Helel wherein remain the governor of the whole region be a arabian by birth the soldier of this arabian governor dwell in tent upon the plain and he have other soldier attend upon his own person also who will suffer no man to pass but under safe conduct without deprive he of all his good here be likewise diverse other village and castle which not be worthy the name I have of purpose omit of the territory of retel retel border upon the region last describe extend also fifty mile southward along the river of Ziz even to the confine of segelmesse it contain many castle and yield plenty of date the inhabitant be subject unto the arabian be extreme covetous and so faint heart that a hundred of they dare scarce oppose themselves against ten arabian they till the arabian ground also as if they be their slave the east part of retel border upon a certain desolate mountain and the west part upon a desert and sandy plain whereunto the arabian return home from the wilderness do resort of the territory of segelmesse this territory extend itself along the river of Ziz from north to south almost twenty mile contain about three hundred and fifty castle beside village and hamlet three of which castle be more principal than the rest the first call tenegent and consist of a thousand and more family stand near unto the city of segelmesse and be inhabit with great store of artificer the second call Tebuhasan stand about eight mile to the south of tenegent be furnish also with great number of inhabitant and so frequent with merchant that there be not in that respect the like place to be find in all the whole region beside the three call (@) be resort unto by sundry merchant both jew and moor these three castle have three several governor who be at great dissension among themselves they will oftentimes destroy one another channel whereby their field be water which can without great cost be repair again they will stow the palmtree also to the very stock and unto they a company of lewd arabian associate themselves they coin both silver and gold-money but their gold be not very special their silver coin weigh four grain (@) eighty of which piece be esteem to be worth one piece of their gold-coine the jew and arabian pay excessive tribute here some of their principal man be exceed rich and use great traffic unto the land of negro whither they transport ware of Barbary exchange the same for gold and slave the great part of they live upon date except it be in certain place where infinite number of scorpion some corn grow here be infinite number of scorpion but no fly at all in summertime this region be extreme hot and then be the river so destitute of water that the people be constrain to draw salt water out of certain pit the say territory contain in circuit about eighty mile all which after the destruction of segelmesse the inhabitant with small cost wall round about to the end they may not be molest by continual inroad of horseman while they live all at unity and concord they retain their liberty but since they fall to mutual debate their wall be raze and each faction invite the arabian to help they under who by little and little they be bring in subjection of the town or city of segelmesse some be of opinion that this town be build by a certain roman captain who have conduct his troop forth of Mauritania conquer all Numidia and march westward build a town and call it (@) because it stand upon the border of messa and be as it be the seal of all his victory and afterward by a corrupt word it begin to be call segelmesse the common people together with one of our african cosmographer call Bicri suppose that this town be build by Alexander the great for the relief of his sick and wound soldier which opinion seem not probable to i for I can never read that Alexander the great come into any part of these region this town be situate upon a plain near unto the river of Ziz and be environ with most stately and high wall even as in many place it be to be see at this present when the mahometan come first into Africa the inhabitant of this town be subject unto the family of Zeneta which family be at length dispossess of that (@) by king joseph the son of tesfin of the family of Luntuna the town itself be very gallant build and the inhabitant be rich and have great traffic unto the land of Negro here stand stately temple and college also and great store of conduct the water whereof be draw out of the river by wheel the air in this place be most temperate and wholesome save that in winter it abound with overmuch moisture which breed some disease but now since the town be destroy the inhabitant begin to plant themselves in the next castle and village as we have before signify I myself abide in this region almost seven month at the foresay castle of Meniun of the castle of (@) this castle be build by the arabian in a certain desert place twelve mile southward of the town last describe and here they keep their ware free from the danger of their enemy near unto this castle there be neither garden nor field nor any other commodity but only certain black stone and sand of the castle of Humeledegi this castle be build also by the arabian upon a desert eighteen mile from segelmesse like as be the former near unto it lie a certain dry plain so replenish with sundry fruit that in behold it a far off a man will think the ground be strew with pome-citron of the castle of Vmmelhefen it be a forlorn and base castle found by the arabian also five and twenty mile from segelmesse upon a desert direct in the way from segelmesse to dara it be environ with black wall and continual guard by the arabian all merchant that passeby pay one four part of a ducat for every camel load myself travel this way upon a time in the company of fourteen jew and be demand how many there be of we we say thirteen but after I begin particular to reckon I find the fowerteenth and the fifteen man among we who the arabian will have keep prisoner have we not affirm they to be mahumetan howbeit not credit our word they examine they in the law of Mahumet which when they perceive they indeed to understand they permit they to depart of the village of Tebelbelt this village stand in the numidian desert two hundred mile from Atlas and a hundred southward of segelmesse be situate near unto three castle well store with inhabitant and abound with date water and flesh be very scarce among they they use to hunt and take ostrich and to eat the flesh of they and albeit they have a trade unto the land of negro yet be they most miserable and beggarly people and subject to the arabian of the province of Todga this little province stand upon a river of the same name have great plenty of date peach grape and figs. it contain four castle and ten village the inhabitant be either husbandman or lether-dresser and it stand westward of segelmesse about forty mile of the region of Farcala it stand also upon a river and abound with date and other fruit but corn be great want here here be in this region three castle and five village it stand southward of mount Atlas a hundred and of segelmesse almost threescore mile the poor inhabitant be subject to the arabian of the region of Teserin this beautiful region situate upon a river be distant from Farcala thirty and from mount Atlas about threescore mile date it yield in abundance and contain village to the number of fifteen and six castle together with the ruin of two town the name whereof I can by no mean inquire and the word Teserin in the african language signify a town of the region call beni Gumi this region adjoin upon the river of Ghir abound great with date the inhabitant be poor and miserable and buy horse at Fez which they sell afterward unto merchant that travel to the land of Negro it contain eight castle and fifteen village and stand southeast of segelmesse about a hundred and fifty mile of the castle of Mazalig and Abuhinan they be situate in the numidian desert upon the river of Ghir almost fifty mile from segelmesse inhabit they be by certain beggarly arabian neither do the soil adjacent yield any corn at all and but very few date of the town of Chasair this town stand upon the desert of Numidia twenty mile from Atlas have mine of lead and antimony near unto it whereby the inhabitant mine of lead and antimony get their live for this place yield none other commodity of the region of beni this little region situate at the foot of mount Atlas and abound with all kind of fruit save date will bear no corn at all it contain three castle and a certain iron-mine which serve all the province a iron-mine of segelmesse with iron village here be but few which be subject partly to the prince of Dubdu and partly to the arabian and all the inhabitant employ themselves about work in the foresay iron-mine of the region of (@) this region stand seventy mile southward of segelmesse have three castle and sundry village situate upon the river of Ghir date it yield great plenty and but very little corn the inhabitant exercise traffic in the land of negro and be all subject and pay tribute to the arabian of the castle of Fighig the three castle of Fighig stand upon a certain desert marvellous abound with date the woman of this place weave a kind of cloth in form of a carpet which be so fine that a man will take it to be silk and this cloth they sell at a excessive rate at Fez Telensin and other place of Barbary the inhabitant be man of a excellent wit do part of they use traffic to the land of negro and the residue become student at Fez and so soon as they have attain to the degree of a doctor they return to Numidia where they be make either priest or senator and prove most of they man of great wealth and reputation from segelmesse the say castle be distant almost a hundred and fifty mile eastward of the region of Tesebit the region of Tesebit be situate upon the numidian desert two hundred and fifty mile eastward of segelmesse and a hundred mile from mount Atlas have four castle within the precinct thereof and many village also which stand upon the confine of Lybia near unto the high way that lead from Fez and Telensin to the kingdom of Agadez and to the land of Negro the inhabitant be not very rich for all their wealth consist in date and some small quantity of corn the man of this place be black but the woman be somewhat fair and yet they be of a swart and brown hue of the region of Tegorarin this great and large region of the numidian desert stand about a hundred and twenty mile eastward of Tesebit contain fifty castle and above a hundred village and yield great plenty of date the inhabitant be rich and have ordinary traffic to the land of Negro their field be very apt for corn and yet by reason of their extreme drought they stand in need of continual water and dung they allow unto stranger house to dwell in require no money for rend but only their dung which they keep most chary yea they take it in ill part if any stranger ease himself without the door flesh be very scarce among they for their soil be so dry that it will scarce nourish any cattle at all they keep a few goat indeed for their milk sake but the flesh that they eat be of camel which the arabian bring unto their market to sell they mingle their meat with salt tallow which be bring into this region from Fez and tremizen there be in time past many rich jew in this region who by the mean of a certain mahometan preacher be at length expel and a great part of they slay by the seditious people and that in the very same year when the jew be expel out of Spain and Sicily the inhabitant of this region have one only governor of their own nation be notwithstanding often subject to civil contention and yet they do not molest other nation howbeit they pay certain tribute unto the next arabian of the region of Meszab this region be situate upon the numidian desert 300. mile eastward from Tegorarin and 300. mile also from the Mediterran sea contain six castle and many village the inhabitant be rich and use traffic to the land of Negro likewise the negro-merchant together with they of Bugia and Ghir make resort unto this region subject they be and pay tribute unto the arabian of the town of techort the ancient town of techort be build by the numidian upon a certain hill by the foot whereof run a river upon which river stand a drawbridge the wall of this town be make of free stone and lime but that part which be next unto the mountain (@) instead of a wall a impregnable rock opposite against it this town be distant (@) hundred mile southward from the Mediterran sea and (@) 300. mile from (@) family it contain to the number of five and twenty hundred all the house be build of sunne-dried brick except their temple which be somewhat more stately here dwell great store both of gentleman and artificer and because they have great abundance of date and be destitute of corn the merchant of Constantina exchange corn with they for their date all stranger they favour exceed and friendly dismiss they without pay of aught they have rather match their daughter unto stranger then to their own citizen and for a dowry they give some certain portion of land as it be accustom in some place of Europe so great and surpass be their liberality that they will heap many gift upon stranger albeit they be sure never to see they again at the first they be subject to the king of Maroco afterward to the king of Telensin and now to the king of Tunis unto who they pay fifty thousand ducat for yearly tribute upon condition that the king himself come personal to receive it the king of Tunis that now be demand a second tribute of they many castle and village and some territory there be also which be all subject unto the prince of this town who collect a hundred and thirty thousand ducat of yearly revenue and have always a mighty garrison of soldier attend upon he unto who he allow very large pay the governor at this present call habdulla be a valiant and liberal young prince and most courteous unto stranger whereof I myself converse with he for certain day have good experience of the city of Guargala this ancient city found by the numidian and environ with strong wall upon the numidian desert be build very sumptuous and abound exceed with date it have some castle and a great number of village belong thereunto the inhabitant be rich because they be near unto the kingdom of Agadez here be diverse merchant of Tunis and Constantina which transport ware of Barbary unto the land of Negro and because flesh and corn be very scarce among they they live upon the flesh of ostrich and camel they be all of a black colour and have black slave and be people of a courteous and liberal disposition and most friendly and bountiful unto stranger a governor they have who they reverence as if he be a king which governor have about two thousand horseman always attend upon he and collect almost fifteen thousand ducat for yearly revenue of the province of Zeb. ZEb a province situate also upon the numidian desert begin westward from Mesila northward from the mountain of Bugia eastward from the region of date over against Tunis and southward it border upon a certain desert over which they travail from Guargala to techort this region be extreme hot sandy and destitute both of water and corn which want be partly supply by their abundance of date it contain to the number of five town and many village all which we purpose in order to describe of the town of Pescara this ancient town build by the roman while they be lord of Mauritania and afterward destroy by the mahometan at their first entrance into Africa be now re-edify store with new inhabitant and environ with fair and stately wall and albeit the townsman be not rich yet be they lover of civility their soil yield nought but date they have be govern by diverse prince for they be a while subject unto the king of Tunis and that to the death of king hutman after who succeed a mahometan priest neither can the king of Tunis ever since that time recover the dominion of Pescara here be great abundance of deadly scorpion scorpion and it be present death to be sting by they wherefore all the townsman in a manner depart into the country in summer time where they remain till the month of November of the city of Borgi another town there be also call Borgi which stand about fowerteene mile eastward of Pescara here be a great many of artificer but more husbandman and because water be very scarce in this region and yet their field stand in need of continual water every man may convey water into his field by a certain sluice for the space of a hour or two according to the breadth or length of his ground and after one have do water his ground his next neighbour begin which oftentimes breed great contention and bloodshed of the town of Nefta NEfta be the name of the town itself and also of the territory adjacent which territory contain three castle the great whereof seem by the manner of building to have be found by the roman inhabitant here be great store be very rustical and uncivil people in time past they be exceed rich for they dwell near unto Lybia in the very way to the land of negro howbeit by reason of their perpetual hostility with the king of Tunis the king of Tunis that now be destroy their town and themselves he partly slay and partly put to flight likewise he so deface the wall and other building that now a man will esteem it to be but a base village not far from hence run a certain river of hot water which serve they both to drink and to water their field withal of the town of Teolacha it be build by the numidian and compass with slender wall and have a river of hot water also run thereby the field adjacent yield plenty of date but great scarcity of corn the miserable inhabitant be oppress with continual exaction both by the arabian and also by the king of Tunis yet be they extreme covetous and proud and disdainful unto stranger of the town of deusen DEusen a very ancient town found by the roman in the same place where the kingdom of Bugia join to Numidia be destroy by the mahometan at their first entrance into Africa because of a certain roman captain which endure the saracen siege for a whole year together the town be at length take this captain and all the man of the town be put to the sword but the woman and child be carry away captive howbeit after the town be sack the wall thereof remain entire by reason it be build of most hard stone and that a wonder thickness though in some place it seem to be ruin which I think may be cause by a earthquake not far from this town be diverse monument of antiquity like unto sepulchre wherein be find sundry piece of silver coin adorn with certain letter and hieroglyphical figure the interpretation whereof I can never find out of the province of Biledulgerio from the territory of Pescara this province extend itself unto the isle of Gerbi and one part thereof in which Cafsa and Teusar be situate be almost three hundred mile distant from the Mediterran sea it be a extreme hot and dry place bring forth no corn at all but great plenty of date which because they be special good be transport unto the kingdom of Tunis here be diverse town and city which we will describe in their due place of the town of Teusar this ancient town build by the roman upon the numidian desert near unto a certain river spring forth of the southern mountain be environ with most stately and impregnable wall and have a ample territory thereunto belong but it be since so destroy by the mahometan that now instead of the wont sumptuous palace thereof it contain nought but base cottage the inhabitant be exceed rich both in ware and money for they have many fair every year whereunto resort great number of merchant from Numidia and Barbary the foresay river divide the town into two part one whereof be inhabit by the principal gentleman and burgo-master be call Fatnasa and in the other call merde dwell certain arabian which have remain there ever since the town be destroy by the mahometan they be at continual civil war among themselves and will perform but little obedience to the king of Tunis for which cause he deal always most rigorous with he of the town of Caphsa the ancient town of Caphsa build also by the roman have for certain year a governor of their own but afterward be sack by one Hucba a captain of Hutmen Califa the wall thereof be raze to the ground but the castle as yet remain and be of great force for the wall thereof be five and twenty cubit high and five cubit thick be make of excellent stone like unto the stone of vespasian amphitheatre at Rome afterwards the towne-walle be re-edify and be destroy again by Mansor who have slay the governor of the town and all the inhabitant appoint a new governor over the same place now this town be very populous all the house thereof except the temple and a few other building be very deform and base and the street be pave with black stone like unto the street of Naples and Florence the poor inhabitant be continual oppress with the exaction of the king of Tunis in the midst of the town be certain square large and deep fountain wall round about the water whereof be hot and unfit to be drink unless it be set a hour or two a cool the air of this place be very unwholesome insomuch that the great part of the inhabitant be continual sick of fever people they be of a rude and illiberal disposition and unkind unto stranger wherefore they be have in great contempt by all other african not far from this town be field abound with date olive and pome-citron and the date and olive there be the best in all the whole province here be likewise most excellent oil the inhabitant make themselves shoe of buck leather of the castle of Nefzaoa three castle there be of this name be well store with inhabitant but very homely build and oppress with the king of Tunis his continual exaction and they be distant from the Mediterran sea about fifty mile of the region of Teorregu this little territory belong to the kingdom of Tripoli and border upon the desert of barca contain three castle of the same name which abound great with date but have no corn at all the inhabitant be far distant from other town and city lead a most miserable life of the territory of jasliten it lie upon the Mediterran sea and contain many village abound with date the inhabitant because they dwell so near the sea have great traffic with the people of Sicily and Egypt of the region of gademe this large region have many castle and village therein stand southward of the Mediterran sea almost three hundred mile the inhabitant be rich in date and all other kind of merchandise and traffic into the land of negro pay tribute unto the arabian albeit for a certain time they be subject unto the king of Tunis and the prince of Tripoli corn and flesh be marvelous scarce here of the region of fezzen this ample region contain great store of castle and village and be inhabit with rich people and border upon the kingdom of Agadez the libyan desert and the land of Egypt be distant from cairo almost threescore day journey neither be there any village in all that desert beside Augela which stand in the bound of Libya this region of fezzen have a peculiar governor within itself who bestow the revenue of the whole region according to his own discretion and pay some tribute unto the next arabian of corn and flesh here be great scarcity so that they be constrain to eat camel flesh only a description of the desert of Libya and first of Zanhaga have hitherto describe all the region of Numidia now proceed unto the descriprion of Libya which be divide into five part as we signify in the begin of this our discourse we will therefore begin at the dry and forlorn desert of Zanhaga which border westward upon the ocean sea and extend eastward to the salt-pit of Tegaza northward it abut upon Sus Haccha and dara region of Numidia and southward it stretch to the land of negro adjoin itself unto the kingdom of Gualata and Tombuto water be here to be find scarce in a hundred mile travel be salt and unsavoury and draw out of deep well especial in the way from segelmesse to Tombuto here be great store of wild beast and creep thing whereof we will make mention in place convenient in this region there be a barren desert call azaoad wherein neither water nor any habitation be to be find in the space of a hundred mile beginning from the well of azaoad to the well of araoan which be distant from Tombuto about 150. mile here both for lack of water and extremity of heat great number of man and beast daily perish of the desert inhabit by the people call Zuenziga this desert begin westward from Tegaza extend eastward to the desert of hair which be inhabit by the people call Targa northward it border upon the desert of segelmesse tebelbelt and Benigorai and southward upon the desert of Ghir which join unto the kingdom of Guber it be a most barren and comfortless place and yet merchant travel that way from Telensin to Tombuto howbeit many be find lie dead upon the same way in regard of extreme thirst within this desert there be include another desert call where for the space of nine day journey not one drop of water be to be find unless perhaps some rain fall wherefore the merchant use to carry their water upon camel back of the desert inhabit by the people call Targa this desert begin westward upon the confine of hair and extend eastward to the desert of Ighidi northward it border upon the desert of Tuath Tegorarin and Mezab and be enclose southward with a certain wilderness near unto the kingdom of Agadez it be a place much more comfortable and pleasant than the two desert last describe and have great plenty of water also near unto Hair the air be marvelous wholesome and the soil abound with all kind of herb not far from Agadez there be great store of manna find great store of manna which the inhabitant gather in certain little vessel carry it while it be new unto the market of Agadez and this manna be mingle with water they esteem very dainty and precious drink they put it also into their pottage and be so take it have a marvelous force of refrigerate or cool which be the cause that here be so few disease albeit the air of Tombuto and Agadez be most unwholesome and corrupt this desert stretch from north to south almost 300. mile of the desert inhabit by the people of Lemta the four desert beginning at the territory of Ighidi and extend to another which be inhabit by the people call Berdoa border northward upon the desert of techort Guarghala and Gademis and southward upon the kingdom of canon in the land of Negro it be exceed dry and very dangerous for merchant travel to Constantina for the inhabitant challenge unto themselves the signiory of Guargala wherefore make continual war against the prince of Guargala they oftentimes spoil the merchant of all their good and as many of the people of Guargala as they can catch they kill without all pity and compassion of the desert inhabit by the people call Berdoa the five desert begin westward from the desert last mention and stretch eastward to the desert of Augela adjoin northward upon the desert of fezzen and barca and trend southward to the desert (@) Borno this place be extreme dry also neither have any but the Gademites which be in league with the people of Berdoa safe passage through it for the merchant of fezzen so often as they fall into their enemy hand be deprive of all their good the residue of the libyan desert that be to say from Augela to the river of Nilus be inhabit by certain arabian and african common call and this be the extreme easterly part of the desert of Libya of the region of nun. this region border upon the ocean sea contain many village and hamlet and be inhabit with most beggarly people it stand between Numidia and Libya but somewhat near unto Libya here grow neither barley nor any other corn some date here be but very unsavoury the inhabitant be continual molest by the arabian invasion and some of they traffic in the kingdom of Gualata of the region of Tegaza in this region be great store of salt dig be white than any marble (@) mine this salt be take out of certain cave or pit at the entrance whereof stand their cottage that work in the salt-mine and these workman be all stranger who sell the salt which they dig unto certain merchant that carry the same upon camel to the kingdom of Tombuto where there will otherwise be extreme scarcity of salt neither have the say digger of salt any victual but such as the merchant bring unto they for they be distant from all inhabit place almost twenty day journey insomuch that oftentimes they perish for lack of food when as the merchant come not in due time unto they moreover the southeast wind do so often blind they that they can live here without great peril I myself continue three day among they all which time I be constrain to drink salt-water draw out of certain well not far from the salt-pit of the region of (@) AVgela be a region of the libyan desert and distant four hundred and fifty mile from Nilus contain three castle and certain village date here be great plenty but extreme scarcity of corn unless it be bring hither by merchant out of Egypt through this region lie the way by the libyan desert from Mauritania to Egypt of the town of serte serte a ancient town build according to the opinion of some by the egyptian of other by the roman and as some other suppose by the african be at length destroy by the mahometan albeit Ibnu Rachich affirm the roman to have sack it but now there be nought remain but only a few ruin of the wall of the region of Berdeoa BErdeoa a region situate in the midst of the libyan desert and stand almost five hundred mile from Nilus contain three castle and five or six village abound with most excellent date and the say three castle be discover eighteen year ago by one hamar in manner follow the carovan of merchant wander out of the direct way have a certain blind man in their company which be acquaint with all those region this blind guide ride foremost upon his camel command a whole conduct by a blind guide who lead they by send only as at (@) present the Carovans of Maroco be conduct over the libyan desert to Tombuto some sand to be give he at every mile end by the smell whereof he declare the situation of the place but when they be come within forty mile of this region the blind man smell of the sand affirm that they (@) not far from some place inhabit which some believe not for they know that they be distant from Egypt four hundred and eighty mile so that they take themselves to be near unto Augela howbeit within three day they find the say three castle the inhabitant whereof wonder at the approach of stranger and be great astonish present shut all their gate and will give the merchant no water to quench their extreme thirst but the merchant by main force enter and have get water sufficient betake themselves again to their journey of the region of (@) ALguechet also be a region of the lybian desert be from Egypt a hundred and twenty mile distant here be three castle and many village abound with date the inhabitant be black vile and covetous people and yet exceed rich for they dwell in the mid way between Egypt and Gaoga they have a governor of their own notwithstanding they pay tribute unto the next arabian here end the six book JOHN LEO his seven book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein wherein he intreat of the land of negro and of the confine of Egypt our ancient chronicler of Africa to wit and Meshudi know nothing in the land of negro but only the region of Guechet and canon for in their time all other place of the land of negro be undiscovered but in the year of the Hegeira 380 by the mean of a certain mahometan which come into Barbary the residue of the say land be find out be as then inhabit by great number of people which live a brutish and savage life without any king governor common wealth or knowledge of husbandry clad they be in skin of beast neither have they any peculiar wife in the day time they keep their cattle and when night come they resort ten or twelve both man and woman into one cottage together use hairy skin in stead of bed and each man choose his leman which he have most fancy unto war they wage against no other nation ne yet be desirous to travel out of their own country some of they perform great adoration unto the sun rise other namely the people of Gualata worship the fire and some other to wit the inhabitant of Gaoga approach after the egyptian manner near unto the christian faith these negro be the negro subject unto joseph king of Maroco first subject unto king joseph the founder of Maroco and afterward unto the five nation of Libya of who they learn the mahometan law and diverse needful handycraft a while after when the merchant of Barbary begin to resort unto they with merchandise they learn the barbarian language also but the foresay five people or nation of Libya divide this land so among themselves that every three part of each nation possess one region howbeit the king of Tombuto that now reign call Abuacre abuacre Izchia Izchia be a negro by birth this abuacre after the decease of the former king who be a libyan bear slay all his son and so usurp the kingdom and have by war for the space of fifteen year conquer many large dominion he then conclude a league with all nation and go on pilgrimage to Mecca in which journey he so consume his treasure that he be constrain to borrow great sum of money of other prince moreover the fifteen kingdom of the land of negro know to we be all situate upon the river of Niger and upon other river which fall thereinto and all the land of Negro stand between two vast desert for on the one side lie the main desert between Numidia and it which extend itself unto this very land and the south side thereof adjoin upon another desert which stretch from thence to the main ocean in which desert be infinite nation unknown to we both by reason of the huge distance of place and also in regard of the diversity of language and religion they have no traffic at all with our people but we have hear oftentimes of their traffic with the inhabitant of the ocean sea shore a description of the kingdom of Gualata this region in regard of other be very small for it contain only three great village with certain grange and field of date from nun it be distant southward about three hundred from Tombuto northward five hundred and from the ocean sea about two hundred mile in this region the people of Libya while they be lord of the land of negro ordain their chief princely seat and then great store of barbarie-merchant frequent Gualata but afterward in the reign of the mighty and rich prince Heli the say merchant leave Gualata begin to resort unto Tombuto and Gago which be the occasion that the region of Gualata grow extreme beggarly the language of this region be call Sungai and the inhabitant be black people and most friendly unto stranger in my time this region be conquer by the king of Tombuto and the prince thereof flee into the desert whereof the king of Tombuto have intelligence and fear least the prince will return with all the people of the desert grant he peace conditional that he shall pay a great yearly tribute unto he and so the say prince have remain tributary to the king of Tombuto until this present the people agree in manner and fashion with the inhabitant of the next desert here grow some quantity of mil-seed and great store this round and white pulse be call Maiz in the west indies of a round and white kind of pulse the like whereof I never see in Europe but flesh be extreme scarce among they both the man and the woman do so cover their head that all their countenance be almost hide here be no form of a common wealth nor yet any governor or judge but the people lead a most miserable life a description of the kingdom of Ghinea this kingdom call by the merchant of our nation Gheneoa by the natural inhabitant thereof Genni and by the portugal and other people of Europe Ghinea stand in the midst between Gualata on the north Tombuto on the east and the kingdom of on the south in length it contain almost five hundred mile and extend two hundred the natural commodity of Ghinea and fifty mile along the river of Niger and border upon the ocean sea in the same place where Niger fall into the say sea this place exceed abound with barley rice cattle fish and cotton and their cotton they sell unto the merchant of Barbary for cloth of Europe for brazen vessel for armour and other such commodity their coin be of gold without any stamp or inscription at all they have certain iron-money also which they use about matter of small value some piece whereof weigh a pound some half a pound and some one quarter of a pound in all this kingdome-there be no fruit to be find but only date which be bring hither either out of Gualata or Numidia here be neither town nor castle but a certain great village only wherein the prince of Ghinea together with his priest doctor merchant and all the principal man of the region inhabit the wall of their house be build of chalk and the roof be cover with straw the inhabitant be clad in black or blue cotton wherewith they cover their head also but the priest and doctor of their law go apparel in white cotton this region during the three month of julie August and September be yearly environ with the overflow of Niger in manner of a island all which time the merchant of Tombuto convey their merchandise hither in certain canoas or narrow boat make of one tree which they row all the day long but at night they bind they to the shore and lodge themselves upon the land this kingdom be subject in time pass unto a certain people of Libya and become afterward tributary unto king Soni Heli after the prince of Ghinea keep prisoner by Izchia who succeed Soni Heli Izchia who keep the prince of this region prisoner at Gago where together with a certain nobleman he miserable die of the kingdom of melli. this region extend itself almost three hundred mile along the side of a river which fall into Niger border northward upon the region last describe southward upon certain desert and dry mountain westward upon huge wood and forest stretch to the ocean sea shore and eastward upon the territory of Gago in this kingdom there be a large and ample village contain to the number of six thousand or more family and call whereof the whole kingdom be so name and here the king have his place of residence the region itself yield great abundance of corn flesh and cotton here be many artificer and merchant in all place and yet the king honourable entertain all stranger the inhabitant be rich and have plenty of ware here be great store of temple priest and professor which professor read their lecture only in the temple because they have no college at all the people of this region excel all other negro in wit civility and industry and be the first that embrace the law of Mahumet at the same time when the uncle of joseph the king of Maroco be their prince and the government the prince of M^lli subdue by Izchia remain for a while unto his posterity at length Izchia subdue the prince of this region and make he his tributary and so oppress he with grievous exaction that he be scarce able to maintain his family of the kingdom of Tombuto this name be in our time as some think impose upon this kingdom Tombuto be conquer by the king of Maroco 1589. from whenc^ he have for yearly tribute mighty sum of gold from the name of a certain town so call which they say king Mensae Suleiman found in the year of the Hegeira 610. and it be situate within twelve mile of a certain branch of Niger all the house whereof be now change into cottage build of chalk and cover with thatch howbeit there be a most stately temple to be see the wall whereof be make of stone and lime and a princely palace also build by a most excellent workman of Granada here be many shop of artificer and merchant and especial of such as weave linen and cotton cloth and hither do the barbarie-merchant bring cloth of Europe all the woman of this region except maidservant go with their face cover and sell all necessary victual the inhabitant and especial stranger there reside be exceed the king of Tombuto his daughter marry unto two rich merchant rich insomuch that the king that * * * 1526. now be marry both his daughter unto two rich merchant here be many well contain most sweet water and so often as the river Niger overflow they convey the water thereof by certain sluice into the town corn cattle milk and butter great scarcity of salt in Tombuto which commodity may be supply by our english merchant to their unspeakable gain this region yield in great abundance but salt be very scarce here for it be bring hither by land from Tegaza which be five hundred mile distant when I myself be here I see one camel load of salt sell for 80. ducat the rich king of Tombuto have many plate and sceptre of gold some whereof weigh 1300. pound and he keep a magnificent and well furnish court when he travel any whither he ride upon a camel which be lead by some of his nobleman and so he do likewise when he reverence use before the king of Tombuto go to warfar and all his soldier ride upon horse whosoever will speak unto this king must first fall down before his foot and then take up earth must sprinkle it upon his own head and shoulder which custom be ordinary observe by they that never salute the king before or come as ambassador from other prince he have always three thousand horseman poison arrow and a great number of footman that shoot poison arrow attend upon he they have often skirmish with those that refuse to pay tribute and so many as they take they sell unto the merchant of Tombuto here be very few horse breed and the merchant and courtier keep certain little nag which they use to travel upon but their best horse be bring out of Barbary and the king so soon as he hear that any merchant be come to town with horse he command a certain number to be bring before he and choose the best horse for himself he pay a most liberal price for he he so deadly hate all jew that he will not admit any into his city and whatsoever Barbary merchant he understand to have any deal with the jew he present cause their good to be confiscate here be great store of doctor judge priest and other learned man that be bountiful maintain at the king cost and charge and hither be bring diverse manuscript or write book out of Barbary which be sell for more money than any other merchandise the coin of Tombuto be of gold without any stamp or superscription but in shell use for coin like as in the kingdom of congo matter of small value they use certain shell bring hither out of the kingdom of Persia four hundred of which shell be worth a ducat and six piece of their golden coin with two three part weigh a ounce the inhabitant be people of a gentle and cheerful disposition and spend a great part of the night in sing and dance through all the street of the city they keep great store of man and woman slave and their town be much in danger of fire at my second be there half the town almost be burn in five hour space without the suburb there be no garden nor orchard at all of the town of this large town build without wall in manner of a village stand about twelve mile from Tombuto upon the river Niger and here such merchant as travel unto the kingdom of Ghinea and (@) themselves neither be the people or building of this town any (@) inferior to the people and building of Tombuto and hither the negro resort in great number by water in this town the king of Tombuto appoint a judge to decide all controverfy for it be tedious to go (@) so oft as need shall require I myself be acquaint with Abu Bacr surname Pargama the king brother who be black in colour but most beautiful in mind and condition here breed many disease which exceed diminish the people and that by reason of the fond and loathsome mixture of their meat for they mingle fish milk butter and flesh altogether and this be the ordinary food also in Tombuto of the town and kingdom of Gago the great town of Gago be unwall also be distant southward of Tombuto almost four hundred mile and incline somewhat to the southeast the house thereof be but mean except those wherein the king and his courtier remain here be exceed rich merchant and hither continual resort great store of negro which buy cloth here bring out of Barbary and Europe this town abound with corn and flesh but be much destitute of wine tree and fruit howbeit here be plenty of melon citron and rice here be many well also contain most sweet and wholesome water here be likewise a certain place where slave be to be sell especial upon such day as the merchant use to assemble and a young slave of fifteen year age be sell for six ducat and so be child sell also the king of this region have a certain private palace wherein he maintain a great number of concubine and slave which be keep by eunuch and for the guard of his own person he keep a sufficient troop of horseman and footman between the first gate of the palace and the inner part thereof there be a place wall round about wherein the king himself decide all his subject controversy and albeit the king be in this function most diligent and perform all thing thereto appertain yet have he about he his counsellor and other officer as namely his secretary treasurer factor and auditor it be a wonder to see what plenty of merchandise be daily bring hither and how costly and sumptuous all thing be horse buy in Europe for ten ducat be here sell again for forty and sometime for fifty ducat a piece there be not any cloth of Europe so course which will not here be sell for rich sale for cloth four ducat a ell and if it be any thing fine they will give fifteen ducat for a ell and a ell of the scarlet of Venice or of turkie-cloath be here worth thirty ducat a sword be here value at three or four crown and so likewise be spur bridle with other like commodity and spice also be sell at a high rate but of all other commodity salt be most extreme dear the residue of this kingdom contain nought but village and hamlet inhabit by husbandman and shepherd who in winter cover their body with beast skin but in summer they go all naked save their privy member and sometime they wear upon their foot certain shoe make of camel leather they be ignorant and rude people and you shall scarce find one learned man in the space of a hundred mile they be continual burden with grievous exaction so that they have scarce any thing remain to live upon of the kingdom of Guber it stand eastward of the kingdom of Gago almost three hundred mile between which two kingdom lie a vast desert be much destitute of water for it be about forty mile distant from Niger the kingdom of Guber be environ withhigh mountain and contain many village inhabit by shepherd and other herdsmen abundance of cattle here be both great and small but of a low stature than the cattle in other place here be also great store of artificer and linen weaver and here be such shoe make as the ancient roman be wont to wear the great part whereof be carry to Tombuto and Gago likewise here be abundance of rice and of certain other grain and pulse the like whereof I never see in Italy but I think it grow in some place of Spain at the inundation their manner of sow (@) at the (@) of Niger of Niger all the field of this region be overflow and then the inhabitant cast their seed into the water only in this region there be a certain great village contain almost six thousand family be inhabit with all kind of merchant and here be in time past the court of a certain king who in my time be slay by Izchia the king of Tombuto the (@) of Guber slay by Izchia and his son be geld and account among the number of the king eunuch afterwards he send governor hither who mighty oppress and impoverish the people that be before rich and most part of the inhabitant be carry captive and keep for slave by the say Izchia of the city and kingdom of Agadez the city of Agadez stand near unto Lybia be not long since wall round about by a certain king the inhabitant be all white than other negro and their house be stately build after the fashion of Barbary the great part of the citizen be foreign merchant and the residue be either artificer or stipendary to the king every merchant have a great many of servant and slave who attend upon they as they travel from canon to Borno for in that journey they be exceed molest by certain thief call Zingani insomuch that they dare not travel the Zingani same way unless they be well appoint in my time they use crossbow for their defence when the say merchant be arrive at any town they present employ all their slave about some business to the end they may not live in idleness ten or twelve they keep to attend upon themselves and their ware the king of this city have always a notable guard about he and continue for the most part at a certain palace in the midst of the city he have great regard unto his subject that inhabit in the desert and field for they will sometime expel their king and choose another so that he which please the inhabitant of the desert best be sure to be king of Agadez the residue of this kingdom lie southward be inhabit by shepherd and herdsman who dwell in certain cottage make of bough which cottage they carry about upon ox from place to place they erect their cottage always in the same field where they determine to feed their cattle like as the arabian also do such as bring merchandise out of Agadez tributary to the king of Tombuto other place pay large custom to the king and the king of Tombuto receive for yearly tribute out of this kingdom almost a hundred and fifty thousand ducat of the province of cano. the great province of canon stand eastward of the river Niger almost five hundred mile the great part of the inhabitant dwell in village be some of they herdsman and other husbandman here grow abundance of corn of rice and of cotton also here be many desert and wild woody mountain contain many spring of water in these wood grow plenty of wild citron and lemon which differ not much in taste from the best of all in the midst of this province stand a town call by the same name the wall and house whereof be build for the most part of a kind of chalk the inhabitant be rich merchant and most civil people their king be in time pass of great puissance and have mighty troop of horseman at his command but he have since be constrain the king of zegzeg of Casena and of canon subdue by Izchia the king of Tombuto to pay tribute unto the king of zegzeg and Casena afterward Ischia the king of Tombuto feign friendship unto the two foresay king treacherous slay they both and then he wage war against the king of canon who after a long siege he take and compel he to marry one of his daughter restore he again to his kingdom (@) that he shall pay unto he the three part of all his tribute and the say king of Tombuto have some of his courtier perpetual reside at canon for the receipt thereof of the kingdom of Casena CAsena border eastward upon the kingdom last describe be full of mountain and dry field which yield notwithstanding great store of barley and mill-seed the inhabitant be all extreme black have great nose and blabber lip they dwell in most forlorn and base cottage neither shall you find any of their village contain above three hundred family and beside their base estate they be mighty oppress with famine a king they have in time past who the foresay Ischia Izchia slay since who death they have all be tributary unto Ischia of the kingdom of Zegzeg the southeast part thereof border upon canon and it be distant from Casena almost a hundred and fifty mile the inhabitant be rich and have great traffic unto other nation some part of this kingdom be plain and the residue mountainous but the mountain be extreme cold and the plain intolerable hot and because they can hardly endure the sharpness of winter they kindle great fire in the midst of their house lay the coal thereof under their high bedstead and (@) betake themselves to sleep their field abound with water be exceed fruitful and their house be build like the house of the kingdom of Casena they have a king of their own in time past who be slay by Ischia as be aforesaid Izchia they have ever since be subject unto the say Ischia of the region of Zanfara the region of Zanfara border eastward upon zegzeg be inhabit by most base and rustical people their field abound with rice mill the king of Zanfara slay by Izchia and the people make tributary and cotton the inhabitant be tall in stature and extreme black their visage be broad and their disposition most savage and brutish their king also be slay by Ischia and themselves make tributary of the town and kingdom of Guangara this kingdom adjoin southeasterly upon Zanfara be very populous and have a king reign over it which maintain a garrison of seven thousand archer and five hundred horseman and receive yearly great tribute in all this kingdom there be none but base village one only except which exceed the rest both in largeness and fair building the inhabitant be very rich and have continual traffic with the nation adjoin southward thereof lie a region great abound with gold but now they can have no traffic with foreign nation for they Gold be molest on both side with most cruel enemy for westward they be oppress by Ischia and eastward by the king of Borno when I myself Izchia be in Borno king Abraham have levy a huge army determine to expel the prince of Guangara out of his kingdom have he not be hinder by Homar the prince of Gaoga which begin to assail the kingdom of Borno wherefore the king of Borno be draw home into his own country be enforce to give over the conquest of Guangara so often as the merchant of Guangara travel unto the foresay region abound with gold because the way be so rough and difficult that their camel can go upon they they carry their ware upon slave back who be lade with great burden do usual travel ten or twelve mile a day yea some I see that make two of those journey in one day a wonder it be to see what heavy burden these poor slave be charge withal for beside the merchandise they carry victual also for their master and for the soldier that go to guard they of the kingdom of Borno the large province of Borno border westward upon the province of Guangara and from thence extend eastward five hundred mile be distant from the fountain of Niger almost a hundred and fifty mile the south part thereof adjoin unto the desert of set and the north part unto that desert which lie towards barca the situation of this kingdom be very uneeven some part thereof be mountainous and the residue plain upon the plain be sundry village inhabit by rich merchant and abound with corn the king of this region and all his follower dwell in a certain large village the mountain be inhabit by herdesman and shepherd do bring forth mill and other grain altogether unknown to we the inhabitant in summer go all naked save their privy member which they cover with a piece of leather but all winter they be clad in skin and have bed of skin also they embrace no religion at all be neither christian mahometan nor jew nor of any other profession but live after a brutish manner and have wife and child in common and as I understand of a certain merchant that abide a long time among they they have no proper name at all but every one be nickname according to his length his fatness or some other quality they have a most puissant prince be lineal descend from the libyan people call Bardoa horseman he have in a continual readiness to the number of three thousand and a huge number of footman for all his subject be so serviceable and obedient unto he that whensoever he command they they will arm themselves and follow he whither he please to conduct they they pay unto he none other tribute but the tithe of all their corn neither have this king any revenue to maintain his estate but only such spoil as he get from his next enime by often invasion and assault he be at perpetual enmity with a certain people inhabit the desert of seu. beyond the desert of who in time past march with a huge army of footman over the say desert waste a great part of the kingdom of Borno whereupon the king of Borno send for the merchant of Barbary and will they to bring he great store of horse for in this country they use to exchange horse for slave and to give fifteen and sometime twenty fifteen or twenty (@) exchange for one horse slave for one horse and by this mean there be abundance of horse bring howbeit the merchant be constrain to stay for their slave till the king return home conqueror with a great number of captive and satisfy his creditor for their horse and oftentimes it fall out that the merchant must stay three month together before the king return from the war but they be all that while maintain at the king charge sometime he bring not home slave enough to satisfy the merchant and otherwhiles they be constrain to await there a whole year together for the king make invasion but every year once and that at one set and appoint time of the year yea I myself meet with sundry merchant here who despair of the king payment because they have trust he a whole year determine never to come thither with horse again and yet the king seem to be marvelous rich for his spur his bridle platter dish pot and other vessel wherein his meat and drink be bring to the table be all of pure gold yea and the chain of his dog and hound be of gold also howbeit this king be extreme covetous for he have much rather pay his debt in slave then in gold in this kingdom be great multitude of negro and of other people the name of who because I tarry here but one month I can not well note of the kingdom of Gaoga GAoga border westward upon the kingdom of Borno and extend eastward to the confine of Nubia adjoin southward unto a certain desert situate upon a crooked and wind part of Nilus and be enclose northward with the frontier of Egypt it stretch from east to west in length five hundred mile and as much in breadth they have neither humanity nor learning among they but be most rustical and savage people and especial those that inhabit the mountain who go all naked save their privity their house be make of bough and raft and be much subject to burn and they have great abundance of cattle whereunto they give diligent attendance for many year they remain in liberty of which a negro-slave who have slay his lord grow to great might and authority liberty they be deprive by a certain negro slave of the same region this slave lie upon a certain night with his master that be a wealthy merchant and consider that he be not far from his native country slay his say master possess his good and return home where have buy a certain number of horse he begin to invade the people next adjoin and obtain for the most part the victory for he conduct a troop of most valiant and warlike horseman against his enemy that be but slender appoint and by this mean he take great number of captive who he exchange for horse that be bring out of Egypt insomuch that at length the number of his soldier increase he be account of by all man as sovereign k. of Gaoga after he succeed his son be no whit inferior in valour and high courage unto his father who reign for the space of forty year next he succeed his brother Moses and after Moses his nephew Homara who bear rule at this present this Homara have great enlarge his dominion and have enter league with the sultan of cairo by who he be often present with magnificent gift which he most bountiful requite also diverse merchant of Egypt and diverse inhabitant of cairo present most precious and rare thing unto he and high commend his surpass liberality this prince great honour all learned man and especial such as be of the lineage of Mahumet I myself be in his court a certain noble man of Damiata bring he very rich and royal gift as namely a gallant horse a turkish sword and a kingly robe with certain other particular that cost about a hundred and fifty ducat at cairo in recompense whereof the king give he five slave five camel five hundred ducat of that region and a hundred elephant tooth of wonder bigness of the kingdom of
