they can pass by water from this kingdom into the river of Nilus not naevigable between Nubia and Egypt Egypt for the river of Nilus be in some place no deep than a man may wade over on foot the principal town of this kingdom call Dangala be exceed populous and contain to the number of ten thousand family the wall of their house consist of a kind of chalk and the roof be cover with straw the townsman be exceed rich and civil people and have great traffic with the merchant of cairo and of Egypt in other part of this kingdom you shall find none but village and hamlet situate upon the river of Nilus all the inhabitant whereof be husbandman the kingdom of Nubia be most rich in corn and sugar which notwithstanding the rich commodity of Nubia they know not how to use also in the city of Dangala there be great plenty of civet and sandall-wood this region abound with ivory likewise because here be so many elephant take here be also a most most strong poison strong and deadly poison one grain whereof be divide among ten person will kill they all within less than a quarter of a hour but if one man take a grain he die there of out of hand a ounce of this poison be sell for a hundred ducat neither may it be sell to any but to foreign merchant and whosoever buy it be bind by a oath not to use it in the kingdom of Nubia all such as buy of this poison be constrain to pay as much unto the king as to the merchant but if any man sell poison without the prince knowledge he be present put to death the king of Nubia maintain continual war partly against the people of goran who be descend of the people call Zingani inhabit the desert Zingani and speak a kind of language that no other nation understand and partly against certain other people also dwell upon the desert which lie eastward of Nilus and (@) towards the red sea be not far from the border of Suachen their language as I take it be mix for it have great affinity with the chaldean tongue with the language of Suachen and with the language of Ethiopia the high where Prete Gianni be say to Prete (@) bear rule the people themselves be call Bugiha and be most base and Bugiha miserable and live only upon milk camels-flesh and the flesh of such beast as be take in those desert sometime they receive tribute of the governor of Suachen and sometime of the governor of Dangala they have once a rich town situate upon the red sea call zibid whereunto belong a commodious haven be opposite unto the haven of which be forty mile distant from Mecca but a hundred year since it be destroy by the sultan because the inhabitant receive certain ware which shall have be carry to Mecca and at the same time the famous port of Zibid be destroy from whence notwithstanding be gather a great yearly tribute the inhabitant be chase from thence flee unto Dangala and Suachin and at length be overcome in battle by the governor of Suachin there be in one day slay of they above four thousand and a thousand be carry captive unto Suachin who be massacre by the woman and child of the city and thus much friendly reader as concern the land of negro the fifteen kingdom whereof agree much in rite and custom be subject unto four prince only let we now proceed unto the description of Egypt here end the seven book JOHN LEO his eight book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing contain therein of Egypt the most noble and famous province of Egypt border westward upon the desert of barca Numidia and Libya eastward upon the desert lie between Egypt itself and the red sea and northward upon the Mediterran sea be enclose southward with the land of the foresay people call Bugiha and with the river of Nilus it stretch in length from the (@) sea to the land of the people call Bugiha about four hundred and (@) 450. mile long fifty mile but in breadth it be very narrow so that it contain nought but a small distance between both the bank of Nilus and the barren mountain border upon the foresay desert be inhabit only in that place where Nilus be separate from the say mountain albeit towards the Mediterran sea it extend itself somewhat broad for Nilus about fower-score mile from the great city of cairo be divide into two branch one whereof (@) in his channel westward return at length into the main stream from whence he take his original and have pass about threescore mile beyond cairo it divide itself into two other branch whereof the one run to Damiata and the other to Rosetto and (@) of that which trend to Damiata issue another branch which discharge itself into a lake pass through a certain gullet or strait into the Mediterran sea upon the bank whereof stand the most ancient city of tenesse and this division of Nilus into so many stream and branch cause Egypt as I have beforesaid to be so narrow all this province be plain and be most fruitful for all kind of grain and pulse there be most pleasant and green meadow and great store of goose and other fowl the country people be of a swart and brown colour but the citizen be white garment they wear which be correced reading down to their waste and broad beneath and the sleeve likewise be straight they cover their head with a round and high habit call by the italian a dulipan their shoe be make according to the ancient fashion in summer they wear garment of particoloured cotton but in winter they use a certain garment line with cotton which they call Chebre but the chief citizen and merchant be apparel in cloth of Europe the inhabitant be of a honest cheerful and liberal disposition for their victual they use a kind of new and extreme salt cheese and sour milk also artificial congeal which fare albeit they account very dainty yet can stranger digest it and into every dish almost they put sour milk a division of Egypt since the mahometan be lord of Egypt it have be divide into three part for the region from cairo to Rosetto be call the shore of Errif and from cairo to the land of Bugiha it be call sahid that be to say the firm land but the region adjoin upon that branch of Nilus which run towards Damiata and tenesse they call by the name of Bechria or Maremma all Egypt be exceed fertile but the province of Sahid excel the two other part for abundance of corn cattle fowl and flax and maremma abound with cotton and sugar howbeit the inhabitant of marremma and Errif be far more civil than the people of Sahid because those two province lie near unto the sea and be more frequent by european barbarian and assyrian merchant but the people of Sahid have no conversation with stranger except it be with a few ethiopian of the ancient pedigree and original of the egyptian the egyptian as Moses write fetch their original from gen. 10. 6. * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * Mesraim be record to be the brother of Chus and the son of cham. Chibith Mesraim the son of Chus the son of cham the son of Noah and the hebrew call both the country and the inhabitant of Egypt by the name of Mesraim the arabian call Egypt itself mesre but the inhabitant Chibith and Chibith they say be the man that first take upon he the government of this region and begin first to build house thereon also the inhabitant call themselves by the same name neither be there leave any true egyptian beside a few christian which be at this present remain the residue embrace the mahometan religion have mingle themselves among the arabian and the moor this kingdom be govern many year by the egyptian themselves as namely by the king that be call Pharaoh who by their monument and admirable building seem to have be mighty prince and also by the king call Ptolomaei afterwards be subdue unto the roman empire this kingdom since the come of Christ be convert unto the christian religion under the say roman government since the decay of which empire it fall into the possession of the emperor of Constantinople who be very careful to maintain this kingdom be at length deprive thereof by the mahometan under the conduct of the son of Hasi be appoint captain general over the arabian army of Homar the second Califa or mahometan patriarch of that name who permit all man to have their own religion require nought but tribute at their hand the say captain build upon the bank of Nilus a certain town call by the arabian fustato which word signify in their language a tabernacle for when he first undertake this expedition he march through wild and desert place void of inhabitant so that his army be constrain to lie in tent the common people call this town mesre Hatichi that be to say the ancient city which notwithstanding in comparison of cairo may not unfit be call the new city and as concern the situation of this town many excellent man both christian jew and mahometan have in these our time be deceive for they think mesre to be situate in the same place where king Pharaoh in the time of Moses and king Pharaoh in the time of joseph have their abode because they suppose the town of Pharaoh to have stand in that part of Africa where Nilus stretch out one of his arm westward towards Africa and where the pyramid be as yet to be see which the holy scripture also seem to avouch in the book of genesis where it be say that the jew in Moses time be employ about the build the town of Pharaoh of the town of Aphthun which be found by Pharaoh namely in that place where Nilus trend towards Africa be about fifty mile southward of cairo and near unto the most westerly arm or branch of Nilus they allege also another probability that the town of Pharaoh be build in the same place because that at the very head or confluence of the branch of Nilus there stand a build of marvelous antiquity call the sepulchre of joseph wherein the dead body of joseph lie till it be the (@) of joseph by the jew transport unto the sepulchre of their father to be brief neither cairo nor any place near unto it can by any likelihood challenge that they be at any time inhabit by the ancient pharaos but here it be to be note that the nobility of the ancient egyptian dwell in time pass in the region of Sahid beyond cairo in the city of of Manfichmin and in other such famous city howbeit after Egypt be conquer by the roman the egyptian nobility plant themselves in the region of Errif upon the sea shore thereof namely about the city of Alexandria Rosetto and other famous town retain as yet the latin name also when the roman empire be translate into Greece the say nobility still inhabit upon the seashore the emperor lieutenant reside at Alexandria but after the mahometan get the dominion of Egypt the foresay nobility retire themselves into the inland hope thereby to reap a double commodity namely first in that they may be a mean to pacify the kingdom on both side of they and second that they may be free from the invasion of the christian whereof they shall have be in danger have they remain any long upon the sea coast of the quality and temperature of the air in Egypt the air of this country be hot and unwholesome and it rain here very seldom or never and rain be the cause of many disease in Egypt for in rainy weather some of the egyptian be subject unto dangerous rheum and fever and other unto a strange kind of swell in their privy member which swell the physician impute unto salt-cheese and beef which be the common diet of the egyptian in summer time this country be most extreme hot for a remedy of which heat they build in every town certain high tower have one door aloft and another beneath right over against the house through the top whereof the wind pass downard do somewhat cool and refresh the air otherwise in regard of the intolerable heat of the sun it be impossible for any man to live there sometime the pestilence be so extreme pestilence hot among they especial at cairo that almost every day there die twelve thousand person thereof but with the french pox I think that no the french malady most rife in Egypt other country under heaven be so molest nor that contain so many people infect therewith about the begin of April they reap their corn and have reap it they present thrash the same neither shall you see one ear of their corn stand till the twenty of May the inundation the increase of Nilus or overflow of Nilus begin about the midst of june increase afterward for the space of forty day and for the space of other forty day also decrease during which time all the city and town of Egypt be like unto land which none can come unto but by boat and barge at this time also Nilus be very fit to be sail upon with vessel of burden some whereof be so big that they will contain six thousand bushel of corn and a hundred head-cattell and in these vessel they sail only down the stream for against the stream it be impossible for they to pass empty the egyptian according to the increase of Nilus do foresee the plenty or dearth of the year follow as we will more at large declare when we come to speak of the island of Nilus over against the old city where the inundation of Nilus be measure neither be it our purpose in this place particular to describe all the city of Egypt because our african writer be of diverse opinion thereabouts for some will have Egypt to be a part of Africa but other be of a contrary mind diverse there be that affirm that part of Egypt adjoin upon the desert of Barbary Numidia and Libya to belong unto Africa some other ascribe unto Africa all those place that border upon the principal and main channel of Nilus but as for other place as namely Manf semenud damanhore Berelles tenesse and Damiata they think they not to be situate in Africa which opinion I myself also upon many and great reason take to be true wherefore my purpose be to describe none other city but such as stand near the main and principal channel of Nilus of the city of Bosiri the ancient city of Bosiri build by the egyptian upon the Mediterran sea and stand twenty mile westward from Alexandria be in time past environ with most strong wall and adorn with most beautiful and stately building at this present it be compass with many possession or ground bear date whereof no man take charge nor reap any commodity for when Alexandria be win by the christian the inhabitant abandon this city and flee towards the lake call Buchaira of the great city of Alexandria in Egypt the great city of Alexandria in Egypt found by Alexander the great not without the advice of most famous and skilful architect upon a beautiful point of land stretch into the Mediterran sea and be distant 40. mile westward of Nilus be in time past till it grow subject unto the mahometan most sumptuous and strong build as diverse and sundry author bear record afterwards this city decay many year together be deprive of the ancient renown and honour and remain in manner desolate because no merchant of Greece nor of any other part of Europe exercise any long traffic therein howbeit a certain crafty mahometan patriarch make the rude people (@) that by the prophecy of Mahumet most ample indulgence be grant unto all such as will inhabit the city or guard it for certain day and will bestow some alm for a public benefit by which wily stratagem the city be in short time (@) with foreign people which from all place resort thereunto by who be build many house near unto the citie-walle and many college of student and diverse monastery for the relief of pilgrim the city itself be four square and have four gate to enter in at one stand on the east side towards Nilus another on the south side towards the lake of Buchaira the three westward towards the desert of barca and the four towards the Mediterran sea and the haven whereat stand the searcher and customer which ransack stranger even to their very shirt for they demand custom not only for ware and merchandise but also some allowance in the hundred for all kind of money near unto the citie-walle there be two other gate also be divide asunder by a fair walk and a most impregnable castle which stand upon the strand or wharf of the port common call Marsa Bargi that be to say the port of the castle in which port ride the principal and best ship namely such as come from Venice Genoa Ragusa with other ship of Europe for hither resort the english the low dutch the Biscayne the ancient traffic of the (@) unto Alexandria portugal and man of all other nation in Europe for traffic sake howbeit this port be most usual frequent by the (@) of Appulia Sicilia and of Greece which be turkish ship all which resort into this harbour to save themselves from pirate and from tempestuous weather another port there be also call Marsa Essil Sela that be to say the port of the chain wherein the ship of Barbary namely those of Tunis and of the isle of Gerbi harbour themselves the christian be constrain to pay about the 10. part for all ware that they bring in and carry out but the mahometan pay but the 20. part and whatsoever ware be carry by land to cairo pay no custom at all and at this present that part of the city which be next unto cairo be the most famous and best furnish with merchandise bring by merchant from all place of the world the other part of this city be destitute both of civility and inhabitant for except one long street and that part of the city next the haven which be full of merchant shop and inhabit by christian the residue be void and desolate which desolation happen at that time Alexandria surprise and sack by the king of Cyprus when Lewis the four king of France be restore to liberty by the sultan the king of Cyprus with a fleet partly of venetian and partly of frenchman sudden assail Alexandria and with great slaughter surprise and (@) the same but the sultan come with a huge army to rescue Alexandria so discourage the cyprian that they burn down the house (@) and (@) themselves to flight whereupon the sultan repair the (@) and build a castle near unto the haven the city grow by (@) and little into that estate wherein it stand at this present in the city of Alexandria there be a certain high mount fashion like unto the place call testaccio at Rome whereon although it have no natural situation be find diverse earthen vessel of great antiquity upon the top of the say mount stand a turret where a certain officer be appoint to watch for such ship as direct their course towards the city who for every ship that he give notice of unto the customer receive a certain fee but if he chance to fall asleep or to be out of the way at the arrival of any ship whereof he certify not the customer he pay double for his negligence into the sultan exchequer under each house of this city there be a great vault the water of Nilus bring by a sluice into Alexandria cistern build upon mighty pillar and arch whereinto the water of Nilus at every inundation be convey under the wall of the city by a certain wonder and most artificial sluice stand without the city itself but these cistern grow sometime corrupt and foul be often in summer the occasion of many disease and infirmity this city stand in the midst of a sandy desert and be destitute of garden and vine neither be the soil round about it apt to bear corn so that their corn be bring they from place forty mile distant howbeit near the foresay sluice whereby the water of Nilus be convey into the city be certain little garden the fruit whereof be grow to ripeness be so unwholesome that they breed fever and other noisome disease among the citizen six mile westward of Alexandria among certain ancient building stand a pillar of a wonder height and thickness which the arabian call hemadussaoar that be to say the pillar of tree of this pillar there be a fable report that Ptolemey one of the king of Alexandria build it upon a extreme point of land stretch from the haven whereby to the end he may defend the city from the invasion of foreign enemy and make it invincible he place a certain steele-glasse upon the top thereof by the hide virtue of which glass as many ship as pass by while the glass be uncover shall immediate be set on fire but the say glass be break by the mahometan the secret virtue thereof vanish and the great pillar whereon it stand be remove out of the place but this be a most ridiculous narration and fit for babe to give credit unto at this present there be among the ancient inhabitant of Alexandria many christian call jacobite be all certain christian call jacobite of they artisan and merchant these jacobite have a church of their own to resort unto wherein the body of s. mark the evangelist lie in time past inter which have since be privy steal by the venetian and carry unto Venice and the say jacobite pay tribute unto the governor of cairo neither be it to be pass over in silence that in the midst of the ruinous monument of Alexandria there remain as yet a certain little house build in form of a chapel and contain a sepulchre much honour by the mahometan wherein they affirm out of the authority of their Koran that the body of the high prophet and king as they term he Alexander the great lie bury and thither resort yearly great multitude of pilgrim from foreign nation to adore and reverence the say sepulchre and oftentimes to bestow large alm thereupon other thing worthy the note I purposely pass over lest I shall seem too tedious unto the reader of the city of Bochin this ancient and small city situate in time pass upon the Mediterran sea shore eight mile eastward of Alexandria lie at this time utter desolate nought remain thereof but certain ruin of the wall it be now plant with date-tree wherewith the poor inhabitant dwell in base and solitary cottage sustain themselves near unto this city stand a tower upon a certain dangerous rock against which many ship of Syria be drive in the night do suffer shipwreck because they can in the dark find the right course to the port of Alexandria round about this city there be no field but sandy desert even to the river of Nilus of the city of Rasid call by the italian Rosetto the city of Rosetto be build by a slave of a certain mahometan patriarch and governor of Egypt upon the eastern bank of Nilus three mile from the Mediterran sea not far from the place where Nilus discharge his stream into the say sea it contain most beautiful house and palace build upon the shore of Nilus and a fair marketplace environ on all side with shop of merchant and artisan with a stately and sumptuous temple also have some gate towards the marketplace and other towards Nilus and certain commodious stair to descend into the same river near unto the temple there be a certain harbour for the safety of ship and bark of burden that carry ware unto cairo for the city be unwall resemble a village rather than a city about this city stand diverse cottage wherein they use to thrash rice with certain wooden instrument and to make ready each month three thousand bushel thereof a little far from this city there be a place like unto a village wherein great store of hackney-mule and ass be keep for traveller to ride upon unto Alexandria neither need the traveller to guide the say hackney but to let they run their ordinary course for they will go direct to the same house or inn where they ought to be leave and their pace be so good that they will from sunrising to sunset carry a man forty mile they travel always so near the seashore that sometime the wave thereof beat upon the hackney foot near unto this city be many field of date and ground which yield abundance of rice the inhabitant be of a cheerful disposition and courteous to stranger especial to such as love to spend their time in jollity and disport here be a stately bathstove also have fountain both of cold and hot water belong thereunto the John Leo be at Rasid the same time (@) Selim the great Turk pass that way like whereof for stately and commodious building be not to be find in all Egypt beside I myself be in this city when Selim the great Turk return this way from Alexandria who with his private and familiar friend behold the say bathstove seem to take great delight and contentment therein of the city call Anthius this city be build upon the eastern bank of Nilus by the roman as many latin inscription engrave in marble and remain till this present do bear sufficient record it be a beautiful and well-governed city and be furnish with man of all kind of trade and occupation the field adjacent abound with great plenty of rice corn and date the inhabitant be of a cheerful and gentle disposition and gain much by rice which they transport unto cairo of the city of Barnabal this city be found at the same time when the christian religion begin to take place in Egypt upon the eastern bank of Nilus in a most pleasant and fruitful place here be such abundance of rice that in the city there be more than four hundred house for the thrash and trim thereof but they that impose this task upon the inhabitant be man of foreign country and especial of Barbary which be so lascivious and riotous give that almost all the harlot of Egypt resort hither unto they who shave off their hair to the very bone without any cizzer or razor of the city of Thebes by who this ancient city of Thebes stand upon the western bank of Nilus shall be build our african chronicler be of sundry opinion some affirm it to be build by the egyptian some by the roman and other by the grecian because there be as yet to be see most ancient monument partly in latin partly in greek and partly in egyptian character howbeit at this present it contain but three hundred family in all be most of they very stately and sumptuous build it abound with corn rice and sugar and with certain fruit of a most excellent the fruit call mose taste call muse. it be also furnish with great store of merchant and artificer but the most part of the inhabitant be husbandman and if a man walk the street in the daytime he shall see none but trim and beautiful woman the territory adjacent abound with date-tree which grow so thick that a man can see the city till he approach nigh unto the wall here grow likewise store of grape fig and peach which be carry in great plenty unto cairo without the city there be many ancient monument as namely pillar inscription and wall of a great thickness build of excellent stone and such a number of ruinous place that this city seem in time past to have be very large of the city of Fuoa this city be distant about 45. mile southward from Rosetto be build by the egyptian on the side of Nilus next unto Asia the street there of be narrow be otherwise a well govern and populous city and abound with all necessary commodity here be likewise very fair shop of merchant and artificer albeit the inhabitant be much addict unto their ease and pleasure the woman of this town live in so great liberty that they may go whither they will all the daytime return home at night without any controlment of their husband the field adjacent abound great with date and near unto they there be a certain plain which be very apt for sugar and corn howbeit the sugar sugar cane there bring not forth perfect sugar but in steed thereof a certain kind of honey like soap which they use throughout all Egypt because there be but little other honey in the whole country of gezirat Eddeheb that be to say the golden isle over against the foresay city the river of Nilus make a isle which be situate on a high place bring forth all kind of fruitful tree except olive upon this island be many palace and beautiful building which can be see through the thick and shady wood the soil of this island be apt for sugar and rice be manure by most of the inhabitant but the residue be employ about carry of their merchandise unto cairo of the city of Mechella this city build by the mahometan in my time upon the eastern shore of Nilus and environ with a low wall contain great store of inhabitant the most part of who be either weaver or husbandman be void of all courtesy and civility they bring up great store of goose which they sell at cairo and their field bring forth plenty of corn and flax of the city of Derotte when Egypt be subject to the roman empire this town be build also upon the eastern bank of Nilus which as it be very populous so be it adorn with stately building and large street have merchant shop on either side of they they have a most beautiful temple and the citizen be exceed rich for their ground yield such abundance great abundance of sugar of sugar that they pay yearly unto the sultan a hundred thousand piece of gold call in their language Saraffi for their liberty of make and refine thereof in this city stand a certain great house like (@) a castle wherein be their press and caldron for the boil and prepare of their sugar neither do I ever in all my life see so many workman employ about that business who daily wage as I understand by a certain public officer amount to two hundred saraffi of the city call Mechellat Chais the mahometan have conquer Egypt build this city upon a high hill stand by the western bank of Nilus the field of this city be high ground be apt for to plant vine upon because the water of Nilus can overflow they this town afford new grape unto cairo almost for half the year long but the inhabitant be (@) people be most of they waterman and bargeman a description of the huge and admirable city of cairo CAiro be common repute to be one of the great and most famous city in all the whole world but leave the common report and opinion thereof I will exact describe the form and estate wherein it * * * 1526. now stand and that I may begin with the etymology or derivation of the name cairo be a arabian word corrupt pronounce by the people of Europe for the true arabian word be el Chahira which signify a enforce or imperious mistress this city build in ancient time by one gehoar Chetib a dalmatian slave as I have before signify in the begin of my discourse contain within the wall not above eight thousand family be inhabit by nobleman gentleman and merchant that sell ware bring from all other place the famous temple of cairo common call gemih hashare that be to say the glorious temple be build also by the foresay slave who we affirm to be the founder of the city and who surname be hashare that be to say famous be give he by the mahometan patriarch that be his prince this city stand upon a most beautiful plain near unto a certain mountain call Mucatun about two mile distant from Nilus and be environ with stately wall and fortify with iron gate the principal of which gate be call babe nansre that be the gate of victory which stand eastward towards the desert of the red sea and the gate call beb Zuaila be next unto the old city and to Nilus and also Bebel futuh that be to say the gate of triumph stand towards the lake and the field and albeit cairo abound every where with all kind of merchant and artificer yet that be the principal street of the whole city which stretch from the gate of nansre to the gate of Zuaila for in it be build most stately and admirable palace and college and most sumptuous temple among which be the temple of Gemith Elhechim the three schismatical Califa of cairo other temple there be of a marvelous bigness which to describe in particular I think it superfluous here be many bathstove also very artificial build next of all be the street call beinel casrain contain to the number of threescore cook or victualler shop furnish with vessel of tin there be (@) other shop also wherein be to be sell delicate water or drink make of delicate drink make of all kind of fruit all kind of fruit be for nobleman to drink of and these water they keep most chary in fine vessel partly of glass and partly of tin next unto these be shop where diverse confection of honey and sugar unlike unto the confection of Europe be to be sell then follow the fruiterer shop who bring outlandish fruit out of Syria to wit quince pomegranate and other fruit which grow not in Egypt next unto they be the shop of such as sell egg cheese and pancake fry with oil and next of all there be a street of the principal artificer shop beyond which street stand a college build by the sultan call Ghauri who be slay in a battle against (@) Selim the great Turk and next unto the college be diverse rank of draper shop in the first rank there be most excellent outlandish linen cloth to be sell as namely fine cloth of cotton bring from Balabach and cloth call Mosall bring from Ninou of a marvelous breadth and fineness whereof nobleman and other of account have shirt make they and scarf to wear upon their dulipan beside these there be certain mercer shop where the rich stuff of Italy namely silk damask velvet cloth of gold and such like be to be buy unto which stuff I never see any comparable to my remembrance in Italy where they use to be make next unto the mercer be the woollen draper which bring cloth out of Europe as namely from Florence Venice Flanders and other place next of all there be chamblet to be sell and from thence the way lie to the gate of Zuaila at which gate dwell great store of artificer near unto the say way stand the famous burse call Canel Halili wherein the persian merchant dwell it be build very stately in manner of a king palace and be of three story high beneath it be certain convenient room whither merchant for the exchange of rich and costly ware do resort for here do the principal and most wealthy merchant abide who ware be spice precious stone cloth of India and such like next unto the burse stand a street of shop where all kind of perfume namely civet musk amber and such like be to be sell which commodity be here in so great plenty that if you ask for twenty pound of musk they will present show you a hundred next follow the street of the paper-merchant where you may buy most excellent and smooth paper here also be to be sell jewel and precious stone of great value which the broker carry from one shop to another then come you to the goldsmith street be inhabit for the most part by jew who deal for riches of great importance and next unto the goldsmith be certain street of upholster or broker who sell the apparel and rich furniture of nobleman and other citizen at the second hand which be not cloak coat nappery or such like but thing of exceed price and value among which I myself once see a beautiful pavilion embroider with needlework and beset with pearl that weigh forty pound which pearl be take out of it be sell for ten thousand saraffi in this city also there be a most stately hospital build a stately (@) by the first sultan of the mamaluck race the yearly revenue whereof amount unto two hundred thousand saraffi hither may any impotent or disease person resort and be well provide of physician and of all thing necessary for those that be sick who if they chance to die here all their good be due unto the hospital of the suburb call beb Zuaila this great suburb belong unto cairo and contain about twelve thousand family begin at the gate of Zuaila and extend westward almost a mile and a half southward it border upon the palace of the sultan and stretch northward for the space of a mile unto the suburb call beb Elloch here dwell as many noble man and gentleman almost as within the city itself and the citizen have shop both here and in the city as likewise many inhabitant of this suburb maintain family in the city also among all the building of this suburb the principal be that stately college build by sultan Hesen be of such a wonder height and great strength that oftentimes the college have presume to rebel against the sultan and therein to fortify themselves against the whole city and to discharge ordinance against the sultan castle which be but half a crossbow shoot distant of the suburb call Gemeh Tailon this huge suburb confine eastward upon the foresay suburb of Beb Zuaila extend westward to certain ruinous place near unto the old city before the foundation of cairo this suburb be erect by one Tailon who be subject unto the Califa of Bagdet and governor of Egypt and be a most famous and prudent man this Tailon leave the old city inhabit this suburb and adorn the same with a most admirable palace and sumptuous temple here dwell also great store of merchant and artificer especial such as be moor of Barbary of the suburb call beb Elloch this large suburb be distant from the wall of cairo about the space of a mile and contain almost three thousand family be inhabit by merchant and artisan of diverse sort as well as the former upon a certain large place of this suburb stand a great palace and a stately college build by a certain mammaluck call (@) be counsellor unto the sultan of those time and the place itself be call after his name jazbachia hither after mahometan sermon and devotion the common people of cairo together with the bawd and harlot do usual resort and many stage player also and such as teach camel ass and dog to dance which dance be a thing very delightful to behold and especial that of the ass who have frisk and dance a while his master come unto he and tell he with a loud voice that the sultan be about to build some great palace must use all the ass of cairo to carry mortar stone and other necessary provision then the ass fall present these ass be somewhat like to bank his curtal that play his prize all England over to the ground and lie with his heel upward make his belly to swell and close his eye as if he be stark dead in the mean while his master lament the misfortune of the ass unto the stander by earnest crave their friendly assistance and liberality to buy he a new ass and have gather of each one as much money as he can get you be much deceive my master quoth he that think my ass to be dead for the hungry jade know his master necessity have wrought this sleight to the end he may get some money to buy he provender then turn about to the ass he command he with all speed to arise but the ass lie stark still though he command and beat he never so much whereupon turn again to the people be it know quoth he unto you all that the sultan have publish a edict or proclamation that to morrow next all the people shall go forth of the city to behold a triumph and that all the honourable and beautiful lady and gentlewoman shall ride upon the most comely ass and shall give they oat to eat and the crystal water of Nilus to drink which word be scarce end the ass sudden start from the ground prance and leap for joy then his master prosecute still his narration but say he the warden of our street have borrow this goodly ass of i for his deform and old wife to ride upon at these word the ass as though he be endue with human reason couch his ear and limp with one of his leg as if it be quite out of joint then say his master what sir jade be you so in love with fair woman the ass nod his head seem to say yea come on therefore sirrah quoth his master and let we see among all these pretty damosel which please your fancy best whereupon the ass go about the company and espy some woman more comely and beautiful than the rest walk direct unto she and touch she with his head and then the beholder laugh and cry out amain lo the ass paramour the paramour of the ass whereupon the fellow that show all this sport leap upon the back of his ass ride to some other place there be also another kind of charmer or juggler which keep certain little bird in soothsay bird cage make after the fashion of cupboard which bird will reach unto any man with their beak certain skroule contain either his good or evil success in time to come and whosoever desire to know his fortune must give the bird a halfpenny which she take in her bill carry into a little box and then come forth again bring the say skroule in her beak I myself have once a skroule of ill fortune give i which although I little regard yet have I more unfortunate success than be contain therein also there be master of defence play at all kind of weapon and other that sing song of the battle fight between the arabian and egyptian when as the arabian conquer Egypt with diverse other that sing such toy and ballad unto the people of the suburb call Eulach this large and ancient suburb of cairo stand two mile distant from the wall of the city upon the bank of Nilus contain four thousand family upon the way lie be full of stately temple palace and college but the fair building thereof stand along the river of Nilus for from thence there be a most beautiful prospect upon the river and thither do the vessel and bark of Nilus resort unto the common stathe of cairo be situate in this suburb at which place you shall see at some time and especial in the time of harvest above 1000 bark and here the officer appoint to receive custom for ware bring from Alexandria and Damiata have their abode albeit but little tribute be demand for the say ware because it be pay before at the port of their arrival but balme-tree grow in the midst of a large fountain and have a short stock or body bear leaf like unto vineleave but that they be not so long and this tree they say will utter wither and decay if the water of the fountain shall chance to be diminish the garden be environ with a strong wall where into no man may enter without the special favour and licence of the governor in the midst of Nilus over against the old city stand the isle call Michias that be to say the isle of measure in which isle according to the inundation of Nilus they have a kind of device invent by the ancient egyptian whereby they most certain foresee the plenty or scarcity of the year follow throughout all the land of Egypt this island be well inhabit and contain about 1500. family upon the extreme point or end where of stand a most beautiful palace build in my remembrance by a sultan and a large temple also which be very pleasant in regard of the cool stream of Nilus the manner of measure the increase of Nilus upon another side of the island stand a house alone by itself in the midst whereof there be a foursquare cistern or channel of eighteen cubit deep whereinto the water of Nilus be convey by a certain sluice under this pillar be call by Pliny Niloscopium the ground and in the midst of the cistern there be erect a certain pillar which be mark and divide into so many cubit as the cistern itself contain in depth and upon the seventeen of june when Nilus begin to overflow the water thereof convey by the say sluice into the channel increase daily sometime two and sometime three finger and sometime half a in height unto this place there daily resort certain officer appoint by the senate who view and observe the increase of Nilus declare unto certain child how much it have increase which child wear yellow scarf upon their head do publish the say increase of Nilus in every street of the city and the suburb and receive gift every day of the merchant artificer and woman so long as Nilus increase the foresay device or experiment of the increase of Nilus be this that follow if the water reach only to the fifteen cubit of the foresay pillar they hope for a fruitful year follow but if it stay between the twelve cubit and the fifteen than the increase of the year will prove but mean if it rest between the ten and twelve cubit then be it a sign that corn will be sell ten ducat the bushel but if it arise to the eighteen there be like to follow great scarcity in regard of too much moisture and if the eighteen be surmount all Egypt be in danger to be swallow up by the inundation of Nilus the officer therefore declare unto the child the height of the river and the child publish the same in all street of the city charge the people to fear God and tell they how high Nilus be increase and the people be astonish at the wonder increase of Nilus whole exercise themselves in prayer and give of alm and thus Nilus continue forty day increase and forty day decrease all which time corn be sell very dear because while the innundation last every man may sell at his own pleasure but when the eightith day be once past the clerk of the market appoint the price of all victual and especial of corn according as he know by the foresay experiment that the high and low ground of Egypt have receive either too little or too much or convenient moisture all which custom and ceremony be due perform there follow so great a solemnity and such a thunder noise of drum and trumpet throughout all cairo that a man will suppose the whole city to be turn upside down and then every family have a barge adorn with rich cover and carpet and with torchlight and furnish with most dainty meat and confection wherewith they solace themselves the sultan also with all his noble and courtier resort unto that sluice or conduct which be call the great conduct and be compass round about with a wall who take a axe in his hand break the say wall and so do his noble and courtier likewise insomuch that the same part of the wall be cast down which stop the passage of the water the river of Nilus be so swift and forcible carry through that conduct and through all other conduct and sluice in the city and the suburb that cairo at that time seem to be another Venice and then may you row over all place of the land of Egypt seven day and seven night together the foresay festival solemnity continue in cairo during which space the merchant and artificer of the city may according to the custom of the ancient egyptian consume and spend in torch perfume confection music and such like jollity all their gain that they have get the whole year past without the city of cairo near unto the suburb of Beb Zuaila stand the castle of the sultan upon the side of the mountain call Mochattan this castle be environ with high and impregnable wall and contain such stately and beautiful palace that they can hardly be describe pave they be with excellent marble and on the roof they be gild and curious paint their window be adorn with diverse colour like to the window in some place of Europe and their gate be artificial carve and beautify with gold and azure some of these palace be for the sultan and his family other for the family of his wife and the residue for his concubine his eunuch and his guard likewise the sultan have one palace to keep public feast in and another wherein to give audience unto foreign ambassador and to exalt himself with great pomp and ceremony and another also for the governor and official of his court but all these be at this present abolish by Selim the great Turk of the custom rite and fashion of the citizen of cairo the inhabitant of cairo be people of a merry jocund and cheerful disposition such as will promise much but perform little they exercise merchandise and mechanical art and yet travel they not out of their own native soil many student there be of the law but very few of other liberal art and science and albeit their college be continual full of student yet few of they attain unto perfection the citizen in winter be clad in garment of cloth line with cotton in summer they wear fine shirt over which shirt some put on linen garment curious wrought with silk and other wear garment of chamblet and upon their head they carry great turban cover with cloth of India the woman go the attire of the woman of cairo costly attire adorn their forehead and neck with frontlet and chain of pearl and on their head they wear a sharp and slender bonnet of a span high be very precious and rich gown they wear of woollen cloth with correced reading sleeve be curious embroider with needlework over which they cast certain veil of most excellent fine cloth of India they cover their head and face with a kind of black scarf through which behold other they can be see themselves upon their foot they wear fine shoe and pantofle somewhat after the turkish fashion these woman be so ambitious and proud that all of they disdain either to spin or to play the cook wherefore their husband be constrain to buy victual ready dress at the cook shop for very few except such as have a great family use to prepare and dress their victual in their own house also the liberty of the woman of cairo they vouchsafe great liberty unto their wife for the good man be go to the tavern or victualling-house his wife trick up herself in costly apparel and be perfume with sweet and precious odour walk about the city to solace herself and parley with her kinsfolk and friend they use to ride upon ass more than horse which be break to such a gentle pace that they go easy than any amble horse these ass they cover with most costly furniture and let they out unto woman to ride upon together with a boy to lead the ass and certain footman to run by in this city like as in diverse other great store of people carry about sundry kind of victual to be sold. many there be also that sell water which they carry up and down in certain leather bag upon the back of camel for the city as I say before be two mile distant from Nilus other carry about a more fine and handsome vessel with a cock or spout of brass upon it have a cup of myrrh or crystal in their hand and these sell water for man to drink and for every draught they take a farthing other sell young chicken bird hatch after a strange manner in Egypt and other fowl by measure which they hatch after a wonder and strange manner they put great number of egg into certain oven build upon sundry loft which oven be moderate will within seven day convert all the say egg into chicken their measure be bottomless which be put into the basket of the buyer and fill full of chicken they lift it up and so let the chicken fall into the basket likewise such as buy those chicken have keep they a few day carry they about to sell again the cook shop stand open very late but the shop of other artificer be shut up before ten of the clock who then walk abroad for their solace and recreation from one suburb to another the citizen in their common talk use ribald and filthy speech and that I may pass over the rest in silence it fall out often time that the wife will complain of her husband unto the judge that he do not his duty nor content she sufficient in the night season whereupon as it be permit by the mahometan law the woman be divorce and marry unto other husband among the artisan whosoever be the first inventor of any new and ingenious device be the reward of new and ingenious device clad in a garment of cloth of gold and carry with a noise of musician after he as it be in triumph from shop to shop have some money give he at every place I myself once see one carry about with solemn music and with great pomp and triumph because he have bind a flea in a chain which lie before he on a piece of paper for all man to behold and if any of they chance to fall out in the street they present go to buffet and then a great number of people come flock about they to see the conflict who will not depart thence till they have reconcile they their most usual food be buffle flesh and great store of pulse when they go to dinner or supper if their family be little they lay a short and round tablecloth but if their household be great they spread a large cloth such as be use in the hall of prince among the sundry sect of religion in this city there be one sect of the moor call Chenesia and this sect live upon horseflesh so that their butcher when they can hear of any halt or lame jade buy he forthwith and set he up a fat and have kill he the say sect of Chenefia come and buy up his flesh hand-smoothe this sect be rife also among the turk the mamaluk and the people of Asia and albeit the turk may free use the food beforementioned yet do they not enure themselves thereunto in Egypt and four sever all sect of the mahometan religion permit in the city of cairo in the city of cairo there be permit four several sect differ each from other both in canon and civil law all which sect have their original from the religion of Mahumet for there be in time past four man of singular learning who by subtlety and sharpness of wit find out a way to make particular deduction out of mahumets general precept so that each of they will interpret the opinion of Mahumet according to their own fancy and will every man apply they to his own proper sense and therefore they must needs disagree much between themselves howbeit grow famous among the common people in regard of their diverse canon and precept they be the first author and founder of the say four sect any one of which whatsoever mahometan profess can renounce the same at his pleasure and embrace another sect unless he be a man of deep learning and know the reason and allegation of both part also there be in the city of cairo four principal judge who give sentence only upon matter of great importance under which four be substitute other inferior judge in evestreete of the city which decide petty contention and brabble and if the party which be at controversy chance to be of diverse sect the plaintiff may summon and convent the defendant before the judge of his street howbeit the defendant may if he will appeal from he unto the high judge of all be place over the four principal judge aforesaid and be governor of the sect call essafichia and this high judge have authority to dispense withal or to disannul the decree of the four principal and of all the other inferior judge according as he shall see cause whosoever attempt aught against the canon and precept of his own religion be severe punish by the judge of the same religion moreover albeit the priest of the foresay sect differ very much both in their form of liturgy or prayer and also in many other respect yet do they not for that diversity of ceremony hate one another neither yet do the common people of sundry sect fall to mutiny and debate but man indeed of singular learning and much read confer oftentimes together and as in private each man affirm his own sect to be the best so likewise do they confirm their opinion by subtle argument neither may any man under pain of grievous punishment reproach any of the say four ancient doctor and in very deed they all of they follow one and the same religion to wit that which be prescribe in the canon of the principal doctor of the mahometan which canon go for currant over all Africa and most part of Asia except in the dominion of the great sophi of Persia who because he reject the say canon be account by other mahometan a heretic and a schismatic but how such variety of opinion proceed from the four doctor aforesaid it be tedious and troublesome to rehearse he that be desirous to know more of this matter let he read my commentary which I have write concern the law and religion of Mahumet according to the doctrine of Malich who be a man of profound learning and be bear at Medina Talnabi where the body of Mahumet lie bury which doctrine of Malich be embrace throughout all Syria Egypt and Arabia wherewith if any man be delight let he peruse my foresay commentary and they will satisfy he to the full upon malefactor they inflict most grievous and horrible punishment especial upon such as have commit any heinous crime in the court thief they condemn to the halter a murder commit treacherous they punish in manner follow the executioner assistant take the malefactor one by the head and another by the foot and then come the chief executioner with a two-hand sword and cut his body in twain the one part whereof adjoin to the head be put into a fire full of unslaked lime and it be a a horrible kind of execution most strange and dreadful thing to consider how the same dismember and half body will remain alive in the fire for the space of a quarter of a hour speak and make answer unto the stander by but rebel or seditious person they flay alive stuff their skin with bran till they resemble man shape which be do they carry the say stuff skin upon camel back through every street of the city and there publish the crime of the party (@) than which punishment I never see a more dreadful by reason that the condemn party live so long in torment but if the tormenter once touch his navel with the knife he present yield the navel be cut be present death up the ghost which he may not do until he be command by the magistrate stand by if any be (@) for debt not have wherewithal to satisfy the same the governor of the prison pay their creditor and send they poor (@) bind in chain and accompany with certain keeper daily to beg alm from street to street all which alm redound to the governor and he allow the say prisoner very bare maintenance to live upon moreover there go cry up and down this woman (@) city certain age woman who though that which they say in the street can be understand be notwithstanding enjoin by their office to circumcise woman according to the prescript of Mahumet which ceremony be observe in Egypt and Syria of the manner of create the sultan and of the order degree and office in his court the dignity and power of the sultan be in time past exceed great but Selim the great Turk in the year of Christ if I be not deceive 1517. utter abolish the say dignity and change all the custom and law of the sultan and because it have be my hap John Leo be thrice in Egypt thrice to travel into Egypt since the say wonder alteration befall I suppose it will not be much beside my purpose if I set down in this place such particular as I know to be most certain true concern the court of the sultan unto this high dignity be wont to be choose some one of the (@) the most noble mamaluk these mamaluk be all christian at the first and steal in their childhood by the tartar out of the province of circassia which border upon the Euxin sea and be sell at Caffa a town of taurica chersonesus be bring from thence by certain merchant unto the city of cairo and be there buy by the sultan who constrain they forthwith to abjure and renounce their baptism cause they to be instruct in the arabian and turkish language and to be train up in military discipline to the end they may ascend from one degree of honour to another till at last they be advance unto the high dignity of the sultan but this custom whereby it be enact that the sultan shall be choose out of the number of such as be mamaluk and slave by their condition begin about 250. year since whenas the family of the valiant saladin who name be so terrible unto christian be support but by a few of the kindred fall to utter decay and ruin at the same time when the last king of jerusalem be determine to sack the city of cairo which also in regard of the sloth and cowardice of the mahometan Califa then reign over it intend to make itself tributary unto the same king the judge and lawyer of the city with the consent of the Califa send for a certain prince of Asia call Azedudin of the nation of the people whereof live in tent like the arabian which Azedudin together with his son saladin come with a army of fifty thousand horseman and albeit saladin be inferior in age unto his father yet in regard of his redoubt valour and singular knowledge in military affair they create he general of the field and give he free liberty to bestow all the tribute and revenue of Egypt as himself shall think expedient and so march at length against the christian he get the victory of they without any bloodshed and drive they out of jerusalem and out of all Syria then saladin return back with triumph unto cairo have a intent to usurp the government thereof where upon have slay the Califa his guard who bear principal sway over the egyptian he procure the death also of the Califa himself be thus bereave of his guard with a poison cup and then forthwith submit himself unto the patronage of the Califa of Bagdet who be the true and lawful mahometan prelate of cairo thus the jurisdiction of the Califas of cairo who have continue lord of that city by perpetual succession for the space of two hundred and thirty year surcease and return again unto the Califa of Bagdet who be the true and lawful governor thereof and so the schismatical Califas and patriarch be suppress there grow a contention between saladin and the sultan of Bagdet and saladin make himself a sovereign of cairo because the say sultan of Bagdet be in time past prince of the province of Mazandran and euarizin situate upon the river of Ganges and be bear in a certain country of Asia lay claim notwithstanding unto the dominion of cairo and intend to wage war against Saladine he be restrain by the tartar of Corasan who make invasion and inroad upon he saladin on the other side fear least the christian in revenge of the foresay injury will make a expedition into Syria and consider that his force be partly slay in the former war and partly consume by pestilence except a few which remain for the defence and safeguard of his kingdom begin to employ himself (@) buy of slave that come the original of the mamaluk from circassia who the king of Armenia by those day take and send unto cairo to be sell which slave he cause to abjure the christian faith and to be train up in feat of war and in the turkish language as be the proper language of saladin himself and so the say slave within a while increase so exceed both in valour and number that they become not only valiant soldier and skilful commander but also governor of the whole kingdom after the decease of saladin the dominion remain unto his family 150. year and all his successor observe the custom of buy slave of circassia but the family of saladin grow at length to decay the slave by a general consent elect one a valiant Mamaluk of their own company to be their sovereign lord and sultan which custom they afterward so inviolable keep that not the sultan own son nor any other mamaluk can attain unto that high dignity unless first he have be a Christian and have abjure his faith and have learn also exact to speak the circassian and turkish language insomuch that many sultan scent their son in their childhood into circassia that by learn the language and fashion of the country they may prove in process of time fit to bear sovereign authority but by the dissension of the mameluke they be always defeat of their purpose and thus much brief concern the government of the mameluke and of their prince call even till this present by a word of their own mother (@) by the name of sultan let we now speak of the honourable degree and dignity inferior to the soldanship of the principal peer next under the sultan call eddaguadare this man be in dignity second unto the sultan and be as it be his viceroy or lieutenant have authority to place or displace any magistrate or officer and maintain a family almost as great as the family of the sultan himself of the sultan officer call Amir Cabir this man have the three place of honour be lord general over the sultan military force who be by office bind to leafy army against the foreign enemy especial against the next arabian and to furnish the castle and city with (@) garrison and also have authority to dispend the sultan treasure upon such necessary affair as he think good of Nai Bessan the four in dignity after the sultan call Nai Bessan be the sultan his lieutenant in Syria and gather up all the tribute of Assiria bestow they at his own discretion and yet the sultan himself be to place garrison in the castle and fort of those province this Nai Bessan be bind yearly to pay certain thousand of saraffi unto the sultan of the Ostadar the five magistrate call the Ostadar be the great master or steward of the palace who duty be to provide apparel for the sultan with victual and other necessary for his whole family and unto this dignity the sultan use to advance some one of his most ancient honourable and virtuous noble under who tuition himself have in time past be train up of the Amiri anchor the six call the Amiri anchor be master of the horse and camel and distribute they unto each man in court according to his degree of the amiralf the seven office be perform by certain principal mameluke be like unto the colonel of Europe every of who be captain of a thousand inferior mamaluk and their office be to conduct the sultan force against the enemy and to take charge of his armour of the Amirmia the eight degree of honour be allot unto certain centurion over the mameluke who be continual to attend upon the sultan either when he ride any whither or when he exercise himself in arm of the Chazendare the nine person be the treasurer who make a account unto the sultan of all the tribute and custom of his kingdom disburse money for the daily and necessary expense of the sultan household and lay up the rest in the sultan castle of the Amirsileh the ten call the Amirsileh have the armour of the sultan commit to his charge which be contain in a great armoury be to be scour furbush and renew at his direction for which purpose he have sundry mamaluk place under he of the Testecana the eleven call the Testecana be master of the sultan wardrobe and take charge of all such robe and apparel as be deliver unto he by the Ostadar or high steward of the household which robe he distribute according to the appointment of the sultan for whosoever the sultan promote unto any dignity he he apparel also all the say garment be of cloth of gold of velvet or of silk and whither soever the Testecana go he be attend upon by a great number of mameluke certain other officer there be also as namely the serbedare who duty be to provide delicate drink for the sultan and to have always in a readiness most excellent compound water temper both with sugar and with spice moreover there be other officer call * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * there be such a officer in the court of England call the master of the revel Farrasin that be diverse chamberlain who furnish the place also call Sebabathia to wit the footman of the sultan and certain other call Taburchania which be the sultan halberdier who attend upon his person when he ride forth or fate in public audience Adavia be those that take charge of the sultan carriage whithersoever he travel out of which number there be a master-hangman or executioner choose and so often as any malefactor be to be punish all his letter from cairo into Syria and travel on foot threescore mile a day because that between Egypt and Syria there be neither mountainous nor miry way but a continual sandy plain howbeit such as carry letter of serious and weighty matter ride upon camel of the sultan military force of soldiers or martial man the sultan have four degree the first call Caschia be certain horseman and be most valiant and expert warrior out of which number the sultan choose governor over his city and castle some of these be allow their stipend in ready money out of the sultan treasury and other out of the tribute of town and castle the second call Eseifia be a company of footman bear no arm but sword only who likewise have their pay allow they out of the sultan treasury the three call Charanisa be voluntary or such as serve have no other pay but only their victual allow they but when any Mamaluke decease that be well provide for some one of they supply his room the four and last of all call Galeb be the young and newcome mamaluk be as yet ignorant of the turkish and egyptian language and such as have show no experiment of their valour of certain other great officer and magistrate in the sultan commonwealth of the magistrate call the nadheasse he be as it be the sultan chief receiver for all the tribute and custom of the whole kingdom come through his hand and be pay from he unto the treasurer also he be customer of cairo by which office he gain infinite sum of money neither can any man attain unto this office unless he first pay unto the sultan a hundred thousand saraffi which he recover again within six month follow of the Chetebeessere this man be the sultan secretary and write letter and make answer on the sultan behalf do beside his secretariship take notice and account of all the land-tribute in Egypt and receive the particular sum from the collector thereof of the Muachih this be a secretary also but inferior to the former and yet more trusty unto the sultan his office be to review the letter and brief pen by the former and to examine whether they be agreeable unto the sultan mind and also in the name of the sultan to subscribe unto they but the other have so many cunning and expert scribe about he that the Muachih seldom cancel any of his write of the Mutesib this man office be to set a price upon corn and all other victual which price partly according to the increase of Nilus and partly also according to the resort of ship and other vessel out of the province of Errif and Sahid he either diminish or enhance and upon the offender impose such penalty as the sultan think good to appoint be at cairo I understand that the say Mutesib get daily by his office about a thousand saraffi have his minister and substitute not only in cairo but in all other city and place of Egypt of the Amir Cheggi the office of the Amir Cheggi be of no less charge than dignity be impose by the sultan upon one of his most sufficient and wealthy mamaluk unto who be commit the conduct of the carovan which go every year from cairo to (@) which duty he can not perform without great expense of his own purse for be guard with a company of mameluke he must travel with majestical pomp and costly diet expect no recompense for his exceed charge either at the hand of the sultan or of the passenger which he conduct other office and dignity there be which I think needless to rehearse of the city of geza the city of geza be situate upon the bank of Nilus over against the old city before mention and be separate therefrom by the foresay island of Nilus be a very and civil place and be adorn with many sumptuous palace build by the mamaluk whither they use to retire themselves out of the throng and multitude of cairo here be likewise great store of artificer and merchant especial such as buy cattle bring from the mountain of barca the drover of which cattle be arabian do sell their ware in this city unto the merchant and butcher of cairo to the end they may avoid the trouble of pass over the river the temple and other principal building of this city stand upon the shore of Nilus on all side of the city there be garden and ground of date such as come hither in the morning (@) cairo to buy (@) sell use not to return home again till the evening this way they travel the (@) the city of (@) over a sandy desert unto the pyramid and sepulchre of the ancient egyptian king in which place they affirm the stately city of Memphis to have stand in time past and albeit the way thither be very troublesome in regard of the manifold lake and pit make by the inundation of Nilus yet by the direction of a trusty and expert guide it may easy be travail of the town of Muhallaca this little town build upon the bank of Nilus by the ancient egyptian and stand three mile from the old city have a most beautiful temple situate upon the shore of Nilus and diverse other stately building therein it abound with date and with certain fruit call egyptian (@) egyptian fig and the inhabitant use the very same rite and custom that be observe by the citizen of cairo of the city of chanca the great city of chanca situate about six mile from cairo at the very entrance of the desert lie in the way to mount Sinai be replenish with most stately house temple and college all the field between cairo and this city abound with great plenty of date but from chanca to mount Sinai which be a hundred and forty mile there be no place of habitation at all the inhabitant be but of mean wealth for when any carovan be to pass into Syria hither resort a company of people from cairo to provide thing necessary for their journey because the village adjoin yield (@) but date through this city lie two main road (@) the one lead to (@) and the other to Arabia this city have (@) other water but such as remain in certain channel after the inundation of Nilus which channel be break the water run forth into the plain and there make a number of small lake from whence it be convey back by certain sluice into the cestern of the city of the city of Muhaisira this little city build upon the river of Nilus mile eastward of cairo abound great with the grain or seed call sesame and contain store of the grain call sesame sundry mill to grind oil out of the same seed the inhabitant be most of they husbandman except a few that exercise trade of merchandise of the town of Benisuaif this town be situate on the west side of Nilus be distant from cairo 120. mile the plain adjacent abound exceed with flax and hemp which be so excellent that it be carry from most excellent hemp thence as far as Tunis in Barbary and this town furnish all Egypt with flax whereof they make very fine and strong cloth the field of the same be continual wear and diminish and especial at this present by the inundation of Nilus for now their date-grounde be half consume the inhabitant for the most part be employ about their flax and beyond crocodile this town there be find crocodile that will eat man flesh as we will declare in our history of live creature of the city of munia upon the same side of Nilus stand the fair city of munia which be build in the time of the mahometan by one Chasib a lieutenant and courtier of the Califa of Bagdet upon a high place here be most excellent grape and abundance of all kind of fruit which albeit they be carry to cairo yet can they not come thither fresh and new by reason that this city be distant from cairo a hundred and fower-score mile it be adorn with most stately temple and other building and here be to be see at this present sundry ruin of the ancient egyptian building the inhabitant be rich for they travail for their gain as far as Gaoga a kingdom of the land of Negro of the city of this ancient city be found by one of the pharaos upon a little branch of Nilus and on a high ground at the same time when the israelite depart out of Egypt who the say Pharaoh great oppress with make of brick and with other servile occupation in this city the place where joseph be bury they say that joseph the son of jacob be bury and that his bone be dig up by Moses and the israelite when they depart fruit here grow great plenty and especial olive which be good to eat but unprofitable to make oil of it be a well govern and populous city and contain many artificer especial weaver of the city of Manf loth. this great and ancient city be build by the egyptian destroy by the roman and re-edify by the mahometan but not in so stately manner as it be first build at this present there be find certain huge and high pillar and porch whereon be verse engrave in the egyptian tongue near unto Nilus stand the ruin of a stately building which seem to have be a temple in time past among which ruin the citizen find sometime coin of silver sometime of gold and sometime of lead have on the one side high graphick note and on the other side the picture of ancient king the field adjacent be very fruitful be extreme scorch by the heat of the sun and much haunt with crocodile which be the occasion as some think why the roman abandon this city the inhabitant be man of indifferent wealth for they exercise traffic in the land of Negro of the city of Azioth this ancient city found by the egyptian upon the bank of Nilus two hundred and fifty mile from cairo be most admirable in regard of the hugeness and of the variety of old building and of epitaph engrave in egyptian letter although at this present the great part thereof lie desolate when the mahometan be first lord of this city it be inhabit by honourable personage and continue as yet famous in regard of the nobility and great wealth of the citizen there be in this city almost a hundred family of christian and three or four church still remain and without the city stand a monastery contain more than a hundred monk who eat neither flesh nor fish but only herb bread and olive and yet have they dainty cates without any fat among they this monastery be very rich and give three day entertainment to all stranger that resort thither for the welcome of who they bring up great store of dove of chicken and of such like commodity of the city of Ichmin IChmin be the most silver coin and sundry fragment of smaragd or emerald emerald of the city of Cana. the ancient city of Cana build by the egyptian upon the bank of Antonio Galuano make large mention of this city Nilus over against Barbanda and environ with wall of sunne-dried brick be inhabit with people of base condition apply themselves unto husbandry by which mean the city abound with corn hither be the merchandise bring against the stream of Nilus which be send from cairo to Mecca for the distance from hence over the wilderness unto the red sea be at least 120. mile all which way there be no water at all to befounde and at the haven of chossir upon the shore of the red sea be the haven of Chossir diverse cottage whereinto the say merchandise be unlade and over against chossir on the side of Asia lie jambuh another haven of the red sea whereat traveller go on pilgrimage to see the tomb of Mahumet at Medina must make their rendezvous or general meeting morecuer Chana furnish Medina and Mecca with corn in which place they suffer great and continual scarcity of the city of Asna ASna in time past be call Siene which name be afterward change by the arabian in who language the word Siene signify a filthy or unclean thing wherefore they call it Asna that be to say fair and beautiful because it stand in a pleasant situation upon the western bank of Nilus which city though it be bring almost to desolation by the roman yet be it so repair again in the mahometan time that the inhabitant grow exceed rich both in corn cattle and money for they transport their commodity partly up the stream of Nilus and partly over the desert into the kingdom of Nubia round about this city there be to be see diverse huge building and admirable sepulcher together with sundry epitaph engrave both in egyptian and latin letter of the city of Assuan the great ancient and populous city of Assuan be build by the egyptian upon the river of Nilus about fower-score mile eastward from Asna the soil adjacent be most apt and fruitful for corn and the citizen be exceed addict unto the trade of merchandise because they dwell so near unto the kingdom of Nubia upon the confine whereof stand their city beyond which city Nilus disperse himself over the plain through many small lake become innavigable also the say city stand near unto that desert over which they travel unto the port of Suachen upon the red sea and it adjoin likewise upon the frontier of Suachen Ethiopia and here in summer time the inhabitant be extreme scorch with the heat of the sun be of a swart or brown colour and be mingle with the people of Nubia and Ethiopia here be to be see also many building of the ancient egyptian and most high tower which they call in the language of that country Barba beyond this place there be neither city nor habitation of any account beside a few village of black people who speech be compound of the arabian egyptian and ethiopian language these be subject unto the people call * * * * * * * * * * * * Bugiha be those which in (@) time be call Troglodytae Bugiha live in the field after the arabian manner be free from the sultan jurisdiction for there his dominion be limit and thus much concern the principal city stand along the main channel of Nilus some whereof I see other I enter into and pass by the residue but I have most certain intelligence of they all either by the inhabitant themselves or by the mariner which carry i by water from cairo to Assuan with who return back unto Chana I travel thence over the desert unto the red sea over which sea I cross unto jambuth and two haven-towne of Arabia of which two town because they belong unto Asia I will not here discourse lest I shall seem to transgress the limit of Africa but if it shall please god to the great travel of John leo. vouchsafe i long life I purpose to describe all the region of Asia which I have travel to wit Arabia Arabia Arabia Petrea the asian part of Egypt Armenia and some part of Tartary all which
