country I see and pass through in the time of my youth likewise I will set down my last voyage from Fez to Constantinople from Constantinople to Egypt and from thence into Italy in which journey I see diverse and sundry island all which my travel I mean by god assistance be return forth of Europe into my own country particular to describe decipher first the region of Europe and Asia which I have see and thereunto annex this my discourse of Africa to the end that I may promote the endeavour of such as be desirous to know the state of foreign country JOHN LEO his nine book of the history of Africa and of the memorable thing therein contain wherein he entreat of the principal river and of the strange live creature plant and mineral of the same country of the river of to insist the river of * * * * or (@) to insist that we may begin in Barbary from the western part of Africa spring forth of the mountain of Atlas which be next unto the city of Hanimmei to wit about the east part of the territory of Maroco and continue his course northward over the plain receive many other river thereinto and at Azafi a town of Duccala discharge his stream into the main ocean into this mighty river of to insist fall two other great river call Siffelmel and Niffis the one whereof spring out of Hanteta a mountain of Maroco and the other issue forth of mount Atlas near unto Maroco and wind itself along the plain of that region disemboqu at last into the say mighty river and albeit the river tensi be for the most part of a exceed depth yet may it in diverse place be wade over where the water reach unto the stirrup of a horseman but a footman must strip himself naked to pass over the same near unto Maroco there be a bridge of fifteen arch build by king Mansor upon this river which bridge be account one of the most curious building in all Africa three of the say arch be demolish by Abu the last king and patriarch of Maroco to the end he may hinder the passage of jacob the first Fezsan king of the marin family but this attempt of his be to none effect as it sufficient appear by the success thereof of the two river call teseuhin the two river call by this one name spring each of they three mile asunder out of mount gugideme and run through the plain of Hascora exonerate themselves into the river call Lebich these two river as I have say have one only name be either of they according to the african language call teseut in the singular number and in the plural teseuhin which signify list or border of quadelhabid that be to say the river of servant qvadelhabid take his original among the high and chill mountain of Atlas and runniug through certain narrow and uneeven valley hold on his course by the confine of Hascora and Tedle and then stretch northward over a certain plain fall at length into the river of Ommirabih in May when the snow melt this river increase to some bigness of the river of Ommirabih the mighty river of Ommirabih issue also forth of the lofty mountain of Atlas where the province of tedle border upon the kingdom of Fez pass through certain plain call adachsun and be afterward straighten among the narrow valley it run under a stately bridge build by ibulhasen the four king of the marin family from thence trend southward it water the plain situate between the region of Duccala and Temesne and last disburden itself under the wall of Azamor into the main ocean about the end of may they take great store of fish in this river call by the italian Lasche wherewith all be sufficient store they salt the say fish and send many ship full of they into Portugal of the river of buregrag BVregrag arise out of one of the mountain of Atlas and continue his course by sundry valley wood and hill proceed on over a certain plain and near unto the town of Sala and Rabat be the utmost frontier of the fezsan kingdom it fall into the ocean sea neither have the two foresay town any other port or harbour but within the mouth of the say river only which be so difficult to enter that unless the pilot be thorough acquaint with the place he be in great hazard of run his ship upon the shall which shall serve instead of bulwark to defend either town from the fleet of the christian of the river of Baht this river issue forth of mount Atlas stretch northward by the wood and mountain and run among certain little hill disperse itself upon the plain of the province of azgar and from thence it fall into certain fen lake and moist valley where they take great store of eel and of the foresay fish call Lasche the inhabitant live upon cattle and fish and by reason of the plenty of milk fish and butter which they eat they be much subject unto the disease call in italian this river may continual be wade over except it be much increase by abundance of rain and melt snow of the river of subu the river of (@) begin upon mount Selilgo stand in Cheuz a province of the fezsan kingdom and it spring out of a great fountain in the midst of a vast and solitary wood and run by diverse mountain and hill from whence extend upon the plain it approach within six mile of Fez divide in sunder the region of Habat and Azgar and at length about Mahmora a place not far from Sala exonerate itself into the ocean sea into this river fall diverse other two of which namely Guarga and Aodor spring out of the mountane of Gumera and the residue from the mountain of the territory of Teza and although subu be a large river yet may it in sundry place be wade over except in winter and the spring when as it can be cross but in certain dangerous and small boat the same river also which run through the city of Fez call in the language of that country the river of pearl enter into the foresay river of subu this river of subu abound exceed with fish and especial with the foresay fish call Lasche which be there of no reckon the mouth thereof near unto the ocean sea be very deep and broad be navigable for ship of great burden as the portugal and spaniard have find by often experience and be not the inhabitant so slothful it may usual and commodious be sail upon yea if the corn which be carry by the merchant of Fez over land through the region of azgar be convey by water up this river it may be sell at Fez for half the price of the river of Luccus issue forth of the mountain of Gumera and stretch westward over the plain of Habat and Azgar pass by the city of Caesar Elcabir and near unto Harais a city of azgar upon the border of Habat discharge itself into the main-ocean in the mouth of this river lie the haven of the foresay city be very difficult to enter of the river of Mulullo MVlullo arise out of mount Atlas between the city of Teza and Dubdu run through the desert and barren plain of terrest and Tafrata and at length exonerate itself into the river Muluia of the river of Mulwa the famous river of * * * * or Muluia Mulwa take his original from that part of Atlas which be situate in the region of Cheuz about five and twenty mile from the city of Gherseluin and pass over dishabit and drieplaine as also amid the desert of Angad and of garet and by the foot of mount beni jeznaten fall not far from the town of Chasasa into the Mediterran sea this river a man may wade over always in summer in the mouth whereof be catch most excellent fish of the river of za. this river spring out of mount Atlas run through a certain plain of the desert of Angad whereas the kingdom of Fez and of Telensin confine one upon a other which though it be exceed deep yet never do I see the water thereof thick or muddy it abound with fish but the inhabitant be destitute of fit instrument can not take they neither indeed be the water convenient to fish upon because they be so clear of the river of tefne the small river of tefne issue forth of the mountain border upon Numidia and continue a northerly course over the desert of Angad fall into the Mediterran sea about fifteen mile from Telensin and it affourd nought but a few small fish of the river mina this river flow out of certain mountain near unto tegdent pass through the field of the city of Batha and thence run northerly into the Mediterran sea of the river this great river fall from the mountain of and descend through barren plain to the confine of the kingdom of Telensin and tenez separate Mezagran from Mustuganin and then enter into the Mediterran sea in the mouth of which river be catch very excellent fish of diverse kind of the river Sefsaia this small river beginning from mount Atlas pass over the plain of Mettegia near unto alger and not far from the ancient town of temendefust discharge itself into the Mediterran sea of that which be call the great river this river arise out of the mountain adjoin upon the region of zeb from whence run along it disemboqu into the Mediterran sea about three mile from Bugia it overflow not but in rainy and snowy weather neither use the people of Bugia to fish therein have the sea so near they of the river call sufgmare it spring out of the mountain border upon mount and pass on through the barren field unto the territory of the city Constantina and glide along by the border thereof it receive a small river and so hold a northerly course it fall into the Mediterran sea about the same place where it separate the field of Chollo from the field of the castle call jegel of the river jadog this small river issue forth of the mountain near Constantina and stretch by the same mountain towards the east disburden itself into the sea not far from the city of bona. of the river call guadilbarbar it proceed out of certain mountain adjoin upon the field of the city call and glide by the hill and mountain it run in such a crooked channel that such as travel from Bona to Tunis must cross over it without either boat or bridge above twenty time and so at length it fall into the sea not far from the forsake port of tabraca and about fifteen mile from the city of bege of the river of Megerada the mighty river of Megerada spring forth of the mountain near unto the city Tebessa upon the border of the province of zeb continue a northerly course until at a place call gharel Meleh forty mile distant from Tunis it exonerate itself into the Mediterran sea in rainy weather it so increase that traveller because there be neither boat nor bridge be constrain to stay two or three day by the river side till it be decrease especial within six mile of Tunis and hereby you may see how the african of these time degenerate both in wit and courage from the ancient african who make the people of Rome to tremble so often at their valour of the river of it proceed from a certain southern desert and pass through sandy plain fall into the sea by a town of that very name the water thereof be salt and so hot that whosoever list to drink of it must set a river of hot and salt water it a cool for the space of a hour thus much concern the principal river of Barbary let we now proceed on to describe the numidian river of the river of Numidia and first of the river call sus. the great river of Sus flow out of the mountain of Atlas that separate the two province of Hea and Sus in sunder run southward among the say mountain stretch into the field of the foresay region and from thence trend westward unto a place call * * * * or Guartguessen Gurtuessen where it discharge itself into the main ocean in winter time it mighty overflow but in summer it be very shallow of the river of Darha this river take his original from mount Atlas about the confine of Hascora pass southward to the province call Darha from whence proceed through the desert it be disperse among certain field and pasture where because of the abundance of grass the arabian feed their camel in summer it be so dry up that a man shall not wet his shoe in go over it but it so increase in winter that it can be pass over in boat and by extreme heat of the sun the water thereof prove bitter of the river of ziz. this river spring out of the mountain of Atlas inhabit by the people call Zanaga and run along by many other mountain and by the city of Gherseluin hold on his course through the field of cheneg Metgara and reteb and enter the territory of the city segelmesse from whence it proceed by the desert castle of Sugaihila and beyond the say castle fall into a lake amid the sandy desert where no inhabitant be to be find whither notwithstanding the arabian hunter usual resort for that they find great store of game there of the river of Ghir the river of Ghir issue also forth of mount Atlas stretch southward by certain desert and then pass through the region of benigumi transform itself likewise into a lake in the very midst of the desert whereas in the begin of this my discourse entreat of the division of Africa I describe the river call by Ptolemey Niger it will here be superfluous to make any repetition thereof wherefore let we now proceed unto the description of Nilus of the mighty river of Nilus the course of this river be in very deed most admirable and the creature therein contain be exceed strange as namely sea-horse sea-oxen crocodile and other such monstrous and cruel beast as we will afterward declare which be not so hurtful either in the ancient time of the egyptian or of the roman as they be at this present but they become more dangerous ever since the mahometan be lord of Egypt Meshudi in his treatise of the memorable thing of his time report that when hume the son of Thaulon be lieutenant of Egypt under Gihsare Mutavichil the Califa of Bagdet namely in the year of the Hegeira 270. there be a certain leaden image about the bigness of a crocodile find among the ruin of a old egyptian temple which in regard of the hieroglyphic character and constellation engrave thereon serve instead of a enchantment against all crocodile but so soon as the say lieutenant cause it to be break in piece the crocodile begin then to invade man and to do much mischief howbeit what the reason shall be why the crocodile between cairo and the Mediterran sea be harmless and those above cairo towards the main land shall devour and kill so many person it go beyond my skill to determine but to return unto the description of Nilus it increase as we have say for the space of forty day begin from the seventeen of june and it continue just so long time in decrease for whereas in the high Ethiopia it rain most abundant about the begin of May the course and inundation of the water be hinder all the month of May and some part of june before it can attain unto the plain country of Egypt concern the original fountain of this river there sundry opinion concern (@) be manifold opinion and all of they uncertain some there be which affirm the same to spring out of the mountain call by themselves the mountain of the moon and other say that it begin upon certain plain situate beneath the foot of the say mountain and issue out of sundry fountain be a great way distant one from another howbeit the former of these two avouch that Nilus with great violence fall down from the say mountain into certain deep cave under the ground and come forth again at the foresay fountain both of which opinion be false for never do any man as yet see where Nilus take his original the ethiopian merchant which resort for traffic unto the city of Dancala affirm that Nilus towards the south be enlarge into such a mighty lake that no man can perceive which way the course thereof trend and that afterward be divide into manifold branch run in several channel and stretch themselves east and west it hinder the passage of traveiler so that they can compass those intricate wind and turn likewise diverse ethiopian inhabit upon the plain in manner of the arabian say that many of they travel five hundred mile southward to seek their camel which be stray away in the heat of their lust find Nilus to be in all place alike that be to say disperse into manifold arm and lake and that they discover sundry desert and barren mountain where the foresay Meshudi affirm emerald to be find which seem more probable than that which the same author affirm concern savage man which wander up and down like wild goat and feed upon the grass of the desert in manner of beast but if I record all the fable which our writer report concern Nilus I shall seem over tedious unto the reader of the strange beast and other live creature of Africa my purpose be not in this discourse to make a complete history of all the live creature in Africa but only of such as be either not to be find in Europe or such as differ in any respect from those that be find and here I intend to describe in order certain beast fish and fowl omit many thing report by Pliny who be doubtless a man of rare and singular learning notwithstanding by the default and negligence of certain author which write before he he err a little in some small matter concern Africa howbeit a little blemish ought not quite to disgrace all the beauty of a fair and amiable body of the elephant this witty beast keep in the wood and be find in great number in the forest of the land of Negro they use to go many in one company and if they chance to meet with any man they either shun he or give place unto he but if the elephant intend to hurt any man he cast he on the ground with his long snout or trunk and never cease trample upon he till he be dead and although it be a mighty and fierce beast yet be there great store of they catch by the ethiopian hunter in manner follow these hunter be acquaint with the wood and the manner of take elephant in (@) thicket where they keep use to make among the tree a round hedge of strong bough and rafte leave a space open on the one side thereof and likewise a door stand upon the plain ground which may be lift up with rope wherewith they can easy stop the say open place or passage the elephant therefore come to take his rest under the shady bough enter the hedge or enclosure where the hunter by draw the say rope and fasten the door have imprison he descend down from the tree and kill he with their arrow to the end they may get his tooth and make sale of they but if the elephant chance to break through the hedge he murder as many man as he can find in Ethiopia the high and India they have other device to take the elephant which lest I shall seem over-tedious I pass over in silence of the beast call Giraffa this beast be so savage and wild that it be a very rare matter to see any of they for they hide themselves among the desert and wood where no other beast use to come and so soon as one of they espy a man it fly forthwith though not very swift it be head like a camel ear like a ox and foot like a * * * * * * * * * * here be a word want in the original neither be any take by hunter but while they be very young of the camel camel be gentle and domestical beast and be find in Africa in great number especial in the desert of Libya Numidia and Barbaria and these the arabian esteem to be their principal possession and riches so that speak of the wealth of any of their prince or governor he have say they so many thousand camel and not so many thousand ducat moreover the arabian that possess camel live like lord and potentate in great liberty because they can remain with their camel in barren desert whither no king nor prince can bring army to subdue they these kind of beast be to be see in * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * in all part of the world which the author at that (@) know all part of the world to wit in Asia Africa and Europe and they be use in Asia by the tartar the curdian the dalemians and the turcoman in Europe the turk use they to carry burden upon as likewise do all the arabian in Africa and the inhabitant of the lybian desert yea king in their army use camel also to convey their victual and carriage howbeit the african camel far excel they of Asia for travail forty or fifty day together without any provender at all they be unlade in the evening and the african (@) be the best turn loose into the next field where they feed upon grass bramble and the bough of tree which hardness the camel of Asia can endure but when they set forth any journey they must be well pamper and full of flesh experience have teach that our camel have travail lade fifty day together without any provender have so waste first the flesh of their bunch second of their belly and last of their hip that they have scarce be able to carry the weight of 100 pound but the merchant of Asia give their camel provender half of they be lade with ware and the other half with provender and so their whole carovan of camel go forth and return home lade by which mean they keep they in good plight and reap double gain by their labour contrariwise the african merchant travail with merchandise into Ethiopia because they return empty and bring back with they thing of no great weight so soon as they arrive with their lean and gall camel in Ethiopia they sell they half for nought unto the inhabitant of the desert and they that return into Barbary or Numidia need very few camel namely for themselves to ride upon for to carry their victual their money and other light commodity of camel there be three kind whereof the first be call Hugiun be gross and of a tall stature and most fit to carry three kind of camel burden but ere four year end they grow unprofitable after which time every camel but of mean stature will carry a thousand pound of italian weight when any of the say camel be to be lade be beat upon his knee and neck with a wand he kneel down and when he feel his load sufficient he rise up again and the african use to geld their camel which they keep for the burden put but one male camel among ten female the second kind of camel call and have a double bunch be fit both to carry burden and to ride upon and these be breed only in Asia the three kind call Raguahill be camel of a slender and low stature which albeit they be unfit to carry burden yet camel of a wonder swiftness otherwise call dromedary do they so excel the two other kind in swiftness that in the space of one day they will travel a hundred mile and will so continue over the desert for eight or ten day together with very little provender and these do the principal arabian of Numidia and the moor of Libya usual ride upon when the king of Tombuto be desirous to send any message of importance unto the numidian merchant with great celerity his post or messenger ride upon one of these camel will run from Tombuto to Darha or segelmesse be nine hundred mile distant in the space of eight day at the far but such as travel must be expert in the way through the desert neither will they demand less than five hundred ducat for every journey the say camel about the begin of the spring incline to their lust and venery do not only hurt one another but also will deadly wound such person as have do they any injury in time past not forget light and easy stripe and whosoever they lie hold on with their tooth they lift he up on high and cast he down again trample upon he with their foot and in this mad mood they continue forty day together neither be they so patient of hunger as of thirst for they will abstain from drink without any inconvenience for fifteen day together the camel great abstinence from drink and if their guide water they once in three day they do they great hurt for they be not usual water but once in five or nine day or at a urgent necessity once in fifteen day moreover the say camel be of a gentle disposition and be endue as it be with a kind of human reason for when as between Ethiopia and Barbary they have a day journey to travel more than their wont their master can drive they on be so tire with whip but be fain to sing certain song unto they wherewith be exceed delight they perform their journey with such swiftness that their say master be scarce able to follow they at my be in cairo I see a camel dance which art of dance how he how the camel of (@) learn to dance learn of his master I will here in few word report they take a young camel and put he for half a hour together into a place like a bathstove prepare for the same purpose the floor whereof be with fire then play they without upon a drum whereat the camel not so much in regard of the noise as of the hot pavement which offend his foot lift up one leg after another in manner of a dance and have be accustom unto this exercise for the space of a year or ten month they then present he unto the public view of the people when as hear the noise of a drum and remember the time when he tread upon the hot floor he present fall a dance and leap and so use be turn into a kind of nature he perpetual observe the same custom I can here report other matter concern the same beast which for brevity sake I omit of the horse of Barbary this name be give unto the Barbary horse throughout Italy and all Europe because they come forth of Barbary and be a kind of horse that be breed in those region but they which so think be deceive for the horse of Barbary differ not in any respect from other horse but horse of the same swiftness and agility be in the arabian tongue call throughout all Egypt Syria Asia Arabia Felix and by the name of arabian horse and the historiographer affirm that this kind of wild horse range up and down the arabian desert and be break and manage by the arabian ever since the time of Ishmael have so exceed multiply and increase that they have replenish the most part of Africa which opinion savour of truth for even at this present there be great store of wild horse find both in the african and arabian desert and I myself see in the numidian desert a wild colt of a white colour and (@) a curl main the most certain trial of these horse be when they can overtake the beast call lant or the ostrich in a race which if they be able to perform they be esteem worth a thousand ducat or a hundred camel howbeit very few of these horse be bring up in Barbary but the arabian that inhabit the desert and the people of Libya bring up great number of they use they not for travel or warfare but only for hunt neither do they give they any other meat but the milk of morse feed with camel milk camel and that twice every day and night to the end they may keep they nimble lively and of spare flesh and in the time of grass they suffer they to feed in pasture but then they ride not upon they but those that the prince of Barbary bring up be not of such swiftness but be feed with provender be more beautiful and comely to the eye and these they use upon a urgent necessity when they will escape the danger of their enemy of the wild horse the wild horse be one of those beast that come seldom in sight the arabian of the desert take the wild horse and eat he say that the young the horse be the sweet be his flesh but he will hardly be take either with horse or dog in the water where this beast keep they lay certain snare cover they over with sand wherein his foot be catch he be entangle and slay of the beast call lant or this beast in shape resemble a ox save that he have small leg and comely horn his hair be white and his hoof be as black as (@) and he be so exceed swift that no beast can overtake he but only the Barbary horse as be beforesaid he be easily catch in summer then in winter because that in regard of the extreme fret heat of the sand his hoof be then strain and set awry by which mean his swiftness be abate like as the (@) of stags and roe-deer of the hide of this beast target make of a skin be make shield and target of great defence which will not be pierce but only with the forcible shot of a bullet but they be sell at a extreme price of the wild ox it resemble the tame ox save that it be less in stature be of a gray or ashe-colour and of great swiftness it haunt either the desert or the confine of the desert and the flesh thereof they say be very savoury of the wild ass this beast also be find either in the desert or upon the border thereof be of a ash-colour in swiftness they be surpass only by the Barbary horse and when they see a man they bray out a loud kick and wince with their heel and stand stone-still till one approach so near they that he may touch they with his hand and then they betake themselves to flight by the arabian of the desert they be catch with snare and other engine they go in company either when they feed or water themselves their flesh be hot and unsavoury and have a wild taste but be set a cool two day after it be sodden it become very savoury and pleasant of the ox upon the mountain of Africa all the ox upon the mountain of Africa be tame cattle be of so mean a stature that in comparison of other ox they seem to be but heifer of two year old but the mountainer use they to the plough say that they be strong and will endure much labour of the beast call adimmain it be a tame beast be shape like a ram and of the stature of a ass and have long and dangle ear the libyan use these beast instead of kine and make of their milk great store of cheese and butter they have some wool though it be but short I myself upon a time be merry dispose ride a quarter of a mile upon the back of one of these beast very many of they there be in the desert of Libya and but few in other place and it be a rare matter to see one of they in the numidian field of the african ram there be no difference between these ram of Africa and other save only in their tail which be of a great thickness be by so much the grosser by how much they be more fat so that some of their tail weigh ten and other twenty pound a piece and they become fat of their own natural inclination but in Egypt there be diverse that feed they fat with bran and barley until their tail grow so big that they can remove themselves from place to place insomuch that those which take charge of they be fain to bind little cart under their tail to the end they may have strength to walk I myself see at a city in Egypt call Asiot and stand upon Nilus about a hundred and fifty mile from cairo one of the say ram tail that weigh fower-score pound and other affirm that they have see one of those tail of a hundred and fifty pound weight all the fat therefore of this beast consist in his tail neither be there any of they to be find but only in Tunis and in Egypt of the Lyon the (@) be a most fierce and cruel beast be hurtful unto all other beast and excel they both in strength courage and cruelty neither be he only a devourer of beast but of man also in some place one lion will bold encounter two hundred horseman they range without all fear among the flock and drove of cattle and whatsoever beast they can lay hold on they carry it into the next wood unto their whelp yea some lion there be as I have before say that will vanquish and kill five or six horseman in one company howbeit such lion as live upon the cold mountain be not so outrageous and cruel but the hot the place be where they keep the more ravenous and bold be they as namely upon the frontier of Temesna and of the kingdom of Fez in the desert of Angad near Telensin and between the city of Bona and Tunis all which be account the most famous and fierce lion in all Africa in the spring while they be give to lust and venery they have most fierce and bloody conflict one with a other eight or twelve lion follow after one lioness I have hear many both man and woman report that if a woman chance to meet with a lion and show he her privy part he will with cry and roar cast his eye upon the ground and so depart believe it they that list but this I be well assure of that whatsoever a lion get in his paw though it be a camel he will carry it away I myself be twice in great hazard to have be devour of lion but by the goodness of God I escape they of the leopard these beast live in the wood of Barbary will not for all their great strength and cruelty hurt any man unless it be very seldom when as they meet with a man in a narrow passage and can shun he or when they be check and provoke unto fury for than they will fly upon a man lay hold upon his visage with their talent and pluck off so much flesh as they can catch insomuch that sometime they will crush his brain in piece they invade not any flock or drove of tame cattle but be at deadly feud with dog who they will kill and devour the mountainer of the region of hunt they on horseback stop all passage where they may escape the leopard range up and down and find every place so beset with horseman that he can get away wind and turn himself on all side and so become a fit mark for the hunter to discharge their dart and arrow upon but if the leopard chance to escape that man that let he pass be bind by a usual custom to invite the residue of the hunter unto a banquet of the beast call dabuh this beast call by the arabian dabuh and by the african jesef in bigness and shape resemble a wolf save that his leg and foot be like to the leg and foot of a man it be not hurtful unto any other beast but will rake the carkeise of man out of their grave and will devour they be otherwise a abject and silly creature the hunter be acquaint with his den come before it sing and play upon a drum by which melody be allure forth his leg be entrap in a strong rope and so he be draw out and slay of the (@) cat. these cat be natural wild and be find in the wood of Ethiopia the merchant take their young whelp or kitte feed they the manner of gather civet with milk bran and flesh and keep they in cage or grate but their odoriferous excrement which be nought else but their sweat they gather twice or thrice every day in manner follow first they drive they up and down the grate with a wand till they sweat and then they take the say sweat from under their flank their shoulder their neck and their tail which excrement of sweat be common call civet of the ape of ape there be diverse and sundry kind those which have tail be call in the african tongue monne and those which have none they be find in the wood of Mauritania and upon the mountain of Bugia and Constantina they represent the shape of man not only in their foot and hand but also in their visage and be natural endue with wonder wit and subtlety they live upon grass and corn and go in great company to feed in the corn field and one of their company which stand centinel or keep watch and ward upon the border when he espy the husbandman come he cry out and give as it be a alarm to his fellow who every one of they flee immediate into the next wood and betake themselves to the tree the she ape carry their whelp upon their shoulder and will leap with they in that sort from one tree to another such of they as be teach will do wonder feat but they be angry and curse notwithstanding they will soon be appease of the coney of Africa there be great store of wild coney in Mauritania and upon the mountain of Gumera which albeit they be account wild yet in my opinion they seem tame for their flesh differ neither in taste nor colour from the flesh of tame coney of the strange fish of Africa and first of the fish call (@) the fish call Ambara be of a monstrous shape and bigness be never see but when it be cast up dead upon the seashore and some of these fish there be which contain twenty five cubit in length the head of this fish be as hard as a stone the inhabitant of the ocean sea coast affirm that this fish cast forth amber but whether the say amber amber be the or the excrement thereof they can well determine howsoever it be the fish may in regard of the hugeness be call a whale of the sea-horse this creature be common find in the river of Niger and Nilus in shape it resemble a horse and in stature a ass but it be altogether destitute of hair it live both in the water and upon the land and swim to the shore in the night season bark and boat lade with ware and sail down the river of Niger be great endanger by this sea-horse for oftentimes he overwhelm and sink they of the sea-oxe the sea-oxe be cover with a exceed hard skin be shape in all respect like unto the land-oxe save that in bigness it exceed not a calf of six month old it be find in both the river of Niger and of Nilus and be take by fisher be keep a long time alive out of the water I myself see one at cairo lead up and down by the neck in a chain which they say be take at the city of Asna stand upon the bank of Nilus about four hundred mile from cairo of the tortoise this might benumbred among the land-creature because it live for the most part in the desert in the libyan desert be find (@) many as big as a ton and Bicri the cosmographer in his book of the region and journey of Africa report that a certain man be weary of travel ascend to his think upon a high stone lie in the desert to the end he may free himself from the danger of serpent and venomous beast who have sleep sound thereupon all night find himself in the morning remove three mile from the place where he first lie down and thereby understand that it be not a stone but a tortoise whereon he repose himself which lie still all the day long creep for food in the night-season but so slow that her pace can hardly be perceive I myself have see some of these tortoise as big as a barrel but never any so huge as the last before mention the flesh of a tortoise not above seven a medicine for the leprosy year old be eat seven day together be say to be a perfect medicine against the leprosy of the crocodile this cruel and noisome beast common frequent the river of Niger and Nilus and contain in length twelve cubit and above the tail thereof be as long as the whole body beside albeit there be the craft of the crocodile in take both man and beast but few of so huge a bigness it go upon four foot like a lizard neither be it above a and a half high the tail of this beast be full of knot and the skin thereof be so exceed hard that no crossbow will enter it some prey upon fish only but other upon beast and man which lurk about the bank of the river do crafty lay wait for man and beast that come the same way about who sudden wind their tail they draw they into the water and there devour they howbeit some of they be not so cruel by nature for if they be no inhabitant can live near unto the river of Nilus and Niger in eat they move the upper jaw only their neither jaw be join unto their breastbone not many year since pass up the river of Nilus towards the city of Cana stand in the upper part of Egypt four hundred mile from cairo on a certain night while we be in the midst of our journey the moon be overshadow with cloud the mariner and passenger all fast a sleep and the bark under sail I myself study by candlelight in my cabin be call upon by a devout old man in the bark who bestow the same night in watch and prayer and say unto i call I pray you some of your company who may help i to draw up this piece of wood float upon the water which will serve to morrow for the dress of our dinner myself sir quoth I will come and help you rather than wake any of our company in the dead of the night nay quoth the old man I will try whether I be able to draw it up alone or no. and so when the bark be near unto the wood as he suppose hold a rope in his hand to cast into the water he be sudden entangle with a crocodile long tail and be in a moment draw under the water whereupon I make a shout all the people in the bark arise and strike sail we stay for the space of a hour diverse in the mean time leap into the water to seek the man but altogether in vain and therefore all of they affirm that he be catch by a crocodile as we sail far we see great number of crocodile upon the bank of island in the midst of Nilus lie beak they in the sun with their jaw wide open whereinto certain little bird about the bigness of a thrush enter come fly forth again present after the occasion whereof be tell i to be this the crocodile little bird fly into the crocodile mouth to pick worm from between their tooth by reason of their continual devour of beast and fish have certain piece of flesh stick fast between their (@) tooth which flesh be (@) breed a kind of (@) wherewith they be cruel torment wherefore the say bird fly about and see the worm enter into the crocodile jaw to satisfy their hunger therewith but the crocodile perceive himself free from the worm of his tooth offer to shut his mouth and to devour the little bird that do he so good a turn but be hinder from his ungrateful attempt by a prick which grow upon the bird head he be constrain to open his jaw and to let she depart the she crocodile lay egg upon the shore cover they with sand and so soon as the young crocodile be hatch they crawl into the river those crocodile that forsake the river and haunt the desert become venomous but such as continue in Nilus be destitute of poison in Egypt there be many that eat the flesh of the crocodile and affirm it to be of a excellent taste his lord or grease be sell very dear at cairo the manner of take the crocodile and be say to be very medicinable for old and canker wound they take the crocodile in manner follow the fisher bind a strong and large rope unto some tree or post stand for the nonce upon the bank of Nilus fasten unto the end thereof a iron hook of a long and about the thickness of a man finger and upon the hook they hang a ram or a goat by the bleat noise whereof the crocodile be allure come forth of the water and swallow up both the bait and the hook wherewithal feel himself inward wound he struggle mighty and beat the ground the fisher in the mean time pull and slack the rope till the crocodile fall down vanquish and dead then they thrusthim in with certain dart and javelin under the shoulder and flank where his skin be most tender and so make a quick dispatch of he his back be so hard and thick that a harquebuse or caliver will scarce pierce it of these beast I see above three hundred head place upon the wall of Cana with their jaw wide open be of so monstrous and incredible a bigness that they be sufficient to have swallow up a whole cow at once and their tooth be great and sharp the egyptian fisher use to cut off the head of crocodile and to set they upon the wall of their city and so do hunter use the head of wild beast of the dragon in the cave of Atlas be find many huge and monstrous dragon which be heavy and of a slow motion because the midst of their body be gross but their neck and tail be slender they be most venomous creature insomuch that whosoever be bite or touch by they his flesh present wax soft and weak neither can he by any mean escape death of the Hydra this serpent be short in proportion of body and have a slender tail and neck live in the libyan desert the poison thereof be most deadly so that if a man be bite by this beast he have none other remedy but to cut off the wound part before the poison disperse itself into the other member of the creature call dub. this creature live also in the desert resemble in shape a Lizzard save that it be somewhat big and contain in length a and in breadth four finger it drink no water at all and if a man pour any water into the mouth thereof it present die it lay egg in manner of a tortoise and be destitute of poison the arabian take it in the desert and I myself cut the throat of one which I take but it bleed a very little be flay and roast it taste somewhat like a frog in swiftness it be comparable to a Lizzard and be hunt if it chance to thrust the head into a hole it can by no force be draw out except the hole be dig wide by the hunter have be slay three day together and then be put to the fire it stir itself as if it be new dead of the guaral this beast be like unto the former save that it be somewhat big and have poison both in the head and tail which two part be cut off the arabian will eat it notwithstanding it be of a deform shape and ugly colour in which respect I loathe always to eat the flesh thereof of the chameleon the chameleon be of the shape and bigness of a lizzard be a deform crooked and lean creature have a long and slender tail like a mouse and be of a slow pace it be nourish by the element of air and the sunbeam at the rise whereof it gape and turn itself up and down it change the colour according to the variety of place where it come be sometime black and sometime green as I myself have see it it be at great enmity with venomous serpent for when it how the chameleon kill the serpent see any lie sleep under a tree it present climb up the same tree and look down upon the serpent head it void out of the mouth as it be a long thread of spittle with a round drop like a pearl hang at the end which drop fall wrong the chameleon change his place till it may light direct upon the serpent head by the virtue wherofhe present die our african writer have report many thing concern the property and secret quality of this beast which at this present I do not well remember of the ostrich somewhat we will here say concern the strange bird and fowl of Africa and first of the ostrich which in shape resemble a goose but that the neck and leg be somewhat long so that some of they exceed the length of two cubit the body of this bird be large and the wing thereof be full of great feather both white and black which wing and feather be unfit to fly withal do help the ostrich with the motion of her train to run a swift pace this fowl live in dry desert and lay to the number of ten or twelve egg in the sand which be about the bigness of great bullet weigh fifteen pound a piece but the ostrich be of so weak a memory that she present forget the place where her egg be lay and afterward the same or some other ostrichehenne find the say egg by chance hatch and fosterech they as if they be certain her own the chicken be no soon creep out of the shell but they prowl up and down the desert for their food and before their feather be grow they be so swift that a man shall hardly overtake they the ostrich be a silly and deaf creature feed upon any thing which it find be it as hard and undigestable as iron the flesh especial of their leg be of a slimy and strong taste and yet the numidian use it for food for they take young ostrich and set they up a fat the ostrich wander up and down the desert in orderly troop so that a far off a man will take they to be so many horseman which illusion have often dismay whole carovans be in Numidia I myself (@) of the ostrich flesh which seem to have not (@) a unsavoury taste of the eagle of eagle there be diverse kind according to their natural property the proportion of their body or the diversity of their colour and the great kind of eagle be call in the arabian tongue Nesir the african teach their eagle to pray upon fox and wolf which in their encounter (@) upon the head of the say beast with their bill and upon the back with their talent to avoid the danger of bite but if the beast turn his belly upward the eagle will not forsake he till she have either a strange narration peck out his eye or slay he many of our african writer affirm that the male eagle oftentimes engender with a (@) woof beget a dragon have the beak and wing of a bird a serpent tail the foot of a wolf and a skin speckle and party colour like the skin of a serpent neither can it open the eyelid and it live in cave this monster albeit myself have not see yet the common report over all Africa affirm that there be such a one of the foul call Nesir this be the great foul in all Africa and exceed a crane in bigness though the bill neck and leg be somewhat short in fly this bird mount up so high into the air that it can be (@) but at the sight of a dead carcase it will immediate descend this bird live a long time and I myself have see many of they unfeathered by reason of extreme old age wherefore have cast all their feather they return unto their nest as if they be new hatch and be there nourish by the young bird of the same kind the italian call it by the name of a vulture but I think it to be of another kind they nestle upon high rock and upon the top of wild and desert mountain especial upon mount Atlas and they be take by such as be acquaint with those place of the bird call Bezi or the hawk this bird call in latin be very common in Africa but the best african hawk be white be take upon certain mountain of the numidian desert and with these hawk they pursue the crane of these hawk there be diverse kind some be use to fly at partridge and quail and other at the hare of the bat. these ugly nightbird be rife all the world over but in certain cave of Atlas there be many of they find as big and big than dove especial in their wing which albeit myself never see yet have I hear of they by diverse person of the parrot or poppiniay these parrot be common find in the wood of Ethiopia but the better sort of they and such as will imitate man voice more perfect be the green one parrot there be as big as a dove of diverse colour some red some black and some ash-coloured which albeit they can so fit express man speech yet have they most sweet and shrill voice of the locust of locust there be sometime see such monstrous swarm in Africa that in fly they intercept the sunbeam like a thick cloud they devour tree leaf fruit and all green thing grow out of the earth at their departure they leave egg behind they whereof other young locust breed which in the place where they be leave will eat and consume all thing even to the very bark of tree procure thereby extreme dearth of corn especial in Mauritania howbeit the inhabitant of Arabia and of Libya esteem the come of these locust as a fortunate bode for seethe or dry they in the sun they bruise they to powder and so eat they and now let thus much suffice to have speak of the african beast fowl fish serpent etc. which be either not to be find in Europe or such as differ from creature of the same kind there wherefore have once brief entreat in the chapter follow of certain mineral tree and fruit of Africa I purpose then to conclude this my present discourse whereas my author John Leo intreat but brief of these locust which God uf as a most sharp scourge between time to discple all the nation of Africa I think it not unmeet to add two other relation or testimony of the same argument the one be reverend in regard of the author antiquity and the other credible and to be accept for that the reporter himself be a most diligent and faithful eyewitness of the same the first testimony take out of the 11. chap. of the five book of Paulus orosius of a huge and pernicious company of locust in Africa which after they have waste the country be drown in the sea and cast up dead on the shore breed a most wonder pestilence both of man and beast in the consulship of Marcus Plautius hypsaeus and Marcus Fuluius Flaccus Africa scarce breathe from bloody war a horrible and extraordinary destruction ensue for whereas now throughout all Africa infinite multitude of locust be gather together and have not only quite devour the corn on the ground and consume the herb with part of their root and the leaf and tender bough of the tree but have gnaw also the bitter bark and dry wood be with a violent and sudden wind hoist aloft in mighty swarm and carry a long time in the air they be at length drown in the african sea who loathsome and putrify carcase be by the wave of the sea cast up in huge heap far and wide along the shore breed a incredible stink and infectious smell whereupon follow so general a pestilence of all live creature that the corrupt dead body of fowl cattle and wild beast dissolve by the contagion of the air augment the fury of the plague but how great and extraordinary a death of man there be I can but tremble to report for in Numidia where micipsa be then king die fourscore thousand person and upon the sea-coast next adjoiningto Carthage and Utica above two hundred thousand be say to have perish yea in the city of Utica itself be by this mean sweep from the face of the earth thirty thousand brave soldier which be appoint to be the garrison for all Africa and the destruction be so sudden and violent as they report that out of one gate of Utica in one and the same day be carry above fifteen hundred dead corpse of those lusty young gallant so that by the grace and favour of almighty God through who mercy and in confidence of who I do speak these thing I may bold affirm that albeit sometime in our day the locust in diverse part and usual do some damage which be tolerable yet never befall there in the time of the christian so insupportable a mischief as that this scourge of locust which be alive be by no mean (@) shall after their death prove far more pernicious and which also live the fruit of the earth will have be quite devour it have be much better they have never die to the plague and destruction of all earthly creature hitherto Paulus orosius the second testimony take out of the 32. and 33. chapter of the ethiopian history of Francis Aluarez which for the satisfaction of every reader I have put down with all particularity and circumstance of the great multitude of locust and the infinite damage that they procure in the dominion of Prete janni chap. 32. in this quarter and throughout all the dominion of Prete janni there be a horrible and great plague to wit a innumerable company of locust which eat and consume the corn and tree of fruit and so great be the number of these creature as it be not credible for with the multitude of they the earth be cover and the air so endeavour as one may hardly discern the sun and further I affirm that it be a thing most strange to he who (@) not see it and if the damage they perform be general through all the province and kingdom of Prete janni his people will die with famine neither can man possible there inhabit but one year they destroy one province and the next year another (@) as if for example they waste the kingdom of Portugal or Castille this (@) a other year they be in the quarter of Lenteio a other in estremadura a other in Beira or between the river Dorus and minius a other on the mountain a other in old Castilia Arragon or Andaluzia and otherwhiles in two or three of these province at once and wheresoever they come the earth be more waste and destroy by they then if it have be all over consume with a fire these locust be as big as the great grasshopper have yellow wing their come into the country be know a day before not for that we can see they but we know it by the sun who be yellow of colour this be a sign that they draw near to the country as also the earth look yellow by reason of the light which reflect from their wing whereupon the people in a manner become present half dead say we be undo for the Ambati that be to say the locust be come and I can not forbear to set down that which I see three sundry time and first in Barua where we have now be for the space of three year and here we often hear it say that such a country and such a realm be destroy by the locust and be in this province we see the sun and the upper part of the earth look all yellow the people be in a manner half dead for sorrow but the day follow it be a incredible thing to see the number of these creature that come which to our judgement cover four and twenty mile of land as afterward we be inform when this scourge and plague be come the priest of that place come and seek i out request i to give they some remedy for the drive of they away and I answer that I can tell they nothing but only that they shall devout pray unto God that he will drive they out of the country and so I go to the ambassador and tell he that it will be very good to go on procession beseech God that he will deliver the country who peradventure in his great mercy may hear we this like the ambassador very well and the day follow we gather together the people of the land with all the priest and take the consecrate stone and the cross according to their custom all we Portugal sing the litany and appoint those of the land that they shall lift up their voice aloud as we do say in their language Zio Christos which be as much to say as lord God have mercy upon we and with this manner of invocation we go over a piece of ground where there be field of wheat for the space of a mile even to a little hill and here I a strange (@) cause many of these locust to be take pronounce over they a certain conjuration which I have about i in writing have make it that night request admonish and excommunicate they enjoin they within the space of three hour to depart towards the sea or the land of the moor or the desert mountain and to let the christian alone and they not perform this I summon and charge the bird of heaven the beast of the earth and all sort of tempest to scatter destroy and eat up their body and to this effect I take a quantity of locust make this admonition to they present in the behalf likewise of they absent and so give they liberty I suffer they to depart it please God to hear we sinner for in our return home they come so thick upon our back as it seem that they will have break our head or shoulder so hard they strike against we as if we have be beat with stone and cudgel and in this sort they go towards the sea the man woman and child remain at home be get upon the top or terrace of their house give God thanks that the locust be go away some afore and other follow in the mean while towards the sea there arise a great cloud with thunder which meet they full in the tooth and continue for the space of three hour with much rain and tempest that fill all the river and when the rain cease it be a fearful thing to behold the dead locust which be more than two * * * * or fathom yard in height upon the bank of the river and in some river there be mighty heap of they so that the morning follow there be not one of they find alive upon the earth the people of the place adjoin hear this come in great number to inquire how this matter be effect many of the inhabitant say these portugal be holy man and by the power of their god they have kill and drive away the locust other say especial the priest and friar of those place near about that we be witch and by power of enchantment have drive away the say creature and that for this cause we fear neither lion nor any other wild beast three day after this effect there come unto we a xuum that be a captain of a place call Coiberia with man priest and friar to request we that we will for the love of God help they say that they be in a manner destroy by the locust and that place be a day journey off towards the sea they come to we about evening and at the same instant I and four other portugal depart away with they we go all night and come thither a hour within day where we find that all those of the country with many of the other place adjoin be assemble together for they be also molest by the locust and assoon as we be come we go our procession round about the land which be seat upon a high hill from whence we may discern many country and place all yellow by reason of the multitude of locust such invocatious and ceremony be end as we perform in the other place we go to dinner and the man that be borderer request we to go with they promise we great reward it please god that as soon as we have dine we see all the earth so clear that there be not so much as one locust to be see the people see this and not be satisfy with the favour and grace receive they request we to go and bless their possession for they be yet afraid lest the locust will return and so we depart of the damage we see do in another province by the locust in two sundry place chap. 33. a other time also we see the locust be in a town call Abuguna Prete janni send we to this town which be in the kingdom of Angote and distant from Barua where we continue thirty day journey to the end that there we may be furnish with victual be come (@) I go with the ambassador Zagazabo who come into Portugal and five genovese towards a certain town and a mountain call aguoan and we travail five day through place all desert and destroy which place be sow with Maiz have stalk as great as those prop which we use about our vine and we may see they all break and tread underfoot as if there have be a tempest and this have the locust do their wheat barley and Taffo be so eat as it seem they never have be either till or sow the tree be without leaf and their bark all gnaw and eat and there be not so much as a spire of grass for they have devour every thing and if we have not be advise and foresee the same for when we depart we lade our mule with victual we and our beast have die together for hunger the country be cover all over with winglesse locust and they say that those be the seed of they which have devour all and that when they have get wing they will go seek out the rest the number of these be so great as I be loath to report because I shall not perhaps be credit but this I may well affirm that I see man woman and child sit as it be amaze among these locust and I say unto they why sit you thus half dead and do not kill these creature and so revenge yourselves of the wrong that their father and mother have do you or at least that those which you kill may be able to do you no more harm they answer that they have not the hart to withstand the scourge of God which he have send upon they for their sin and all the people of this place depart hence so that we find the way full of man and woman on foot with their child in their arm and upon their head go into other country where they may find victual and it be great pity to behold they we be in the say province of Abuguna in a place call aquate there come such swarm of locust as be innumerable which one day begin to fall upon the ground about nine of the clock in the morning and cease not while night where they light there they stay and then the next day in the morning go away so that at three of the clock in the afternoon there be not one of they to be see and in this short time they leave the tree utter destitute of leaf on the same day and hour there come a other squadron and these leave neither tree nor bough ungnawen and eat and thus do they for five day one after a other they say that those be young one which go to seek their father and they do the like as those we see without wing the space that these locust take up be nine mile for which circuit there remain neither bark nor leaf upon the tree and the country look not as though it have be burn but as though it have snow thereupon and this be by reason of the whiteness of the tree which be peel bare by the locust and the earth be all sweep clean it be God will that the harvest be already in we can not understand which way they afterward go because they come from the sea ward out of the kingdom of (@) which belong to the moor who be continual in war as also we can by no mean know the end of their journey or course thus much out of Francis (@) of the mineral and first of miner all salt the great part of Africa have none other salt but such as be dig out of quarry and mine after the manner of marble or free stone be of a white red and grey colour Barbary abound with salt and Numidia be indifferent furnish therewith but the land of negro and especial the inner part of Ethiopia be so destitute thereof that a pound of salt be there sell for half a ducat and the people of the say region use not to (@) salt upon their table but hold a crumb of salt in hand they lick the same at every morsel of meat which they put in their mouth in certain lake of Barbary all the summer time there be fair and white salt congeal or kern as namely in diverse place near unto the city of Fez. of the mineral call antimony this mineral grow in many place of Africa in the lead-mine be separate from the lead by the help of brimstone great plenty of this mineral be dig out of the bottom of mount Atlas especial where Numidia border upon the kingdom of Fez. Brimstone likewise be dig in great abundance out of other place of Africa of (@) be the juice or gum of a certain herb grow like the head of a wild thistle between the branch whereof grow certain fruit as big in compass as a green cucumber after which shape or likeness it bear certain (@) grain or (@) and some of the say fruit be a ell long and some be long they grow not out of the branch of the herb but spring out of the firm ground and out of one flag you shall see sometime 20. and sometime 30. of they issue forth the people of the same region when the say fruit be once ripe do prick they with their knife and out of the hole proceed a liquor or juice much like unto milk which by little and little grow thick and slimy and so be grow thick they take it off with their knife put it in bladder and dry it and the plant or herb itself be full of sharp prickle of pitch of pitch there be two kind the one be natural and take out of certain stone which be in fountain the water whereof retain the (@) smell and (@) of the same and the other be artificial and proceed out of the juniper or pinetree and this artificial pitch I see make upon mount Atlas in manner follow they make a deep and round furnace with a hole in the bottom through which hole the pitch may fall down into a hollow place within the ground be make in form of a little vessel and put into the say furnace the bough of the foresay tree break into small piece they close up the mouth of the furnace and make a fire under it by the heat whereof the pitch distil forth of the wood through the bottom of the furnace into the foresay hollow place and so it be take up and put in bladder or bag of the fruit call Maus or Musa this fruit grow upon a small tree which bear large and broad leaf of a long have a most excellent and delicate taste and spring forth about the bigness of a small cucumber the mahometan doctor affirm that this be the fruit which God forbid our first parent to eat in paradise which when they have eat they cover their nakedness with leaf of the same fruit as be of all other leave most meet for that purpose they grow in great abundance at Sela a town of the kingdom of Fez but in far great plenty in the land of Egypt and especial at Damiara of cassia the tree bear cassia be of great thickness have leaf like unto the mulberie-tree they bear a broad and white blossom and be so lade with fruit that they be constrain to gather great store before they be ripe lest the tree shall break with overmuch weight and this kind of tree grow only in Egypt of the fruit call Terfez TErfez be to be call rather by the name of a root then of a fruit and be like unto a mushroom or toadstool but that it be somewhat big it be enclose with a white rind and grow in hot and sandy place where it lie it may (@) be perceive by the swell and open of the ground some of they be as big as a walnut and other as a (@) the physician which call it Camha affirm it to be a refrigerative or cool fruit it grow in great plenty upon the numidian desert and the arabian take as great delight in eat of the same as in eat of sugar this fruit be stew upon the coal and afterward make clean and sodden in fat broth they esteem for great dainty also the arabian seethe it in water and milk and so eat it it grow likewise plentiful in the sand near unto the town of Sela. of the date or palm-tree because we have (@) speak in our description of segelmesse in Numidia we will here in this place say nothing at all of the egyptian fig call by the egyptian themselves giumeiz the tree of this fig resemble other figtree both in outward form and in leaf but it be of a exceed height neither do the fruit grow among the leaf or upon the end of the twig but out of the very body of the tree where no leaf at all grow these fig taste like unto other but they have a thick skin and be of a tawny colour of the tree call it be a high and a thorny tree have such leaf as the juniper have and bear a gum like unto mastic wherewith the african apothecary use to mingle and adulterate their mastic because it have the same colour and yield some smell also there be find likewise such tree in (@) numidian and lybian desert and in the land of negro but the tree of Numidia be cut in the midst consist of white wood like unto the tree beforenamed and the lybian tree of a brown or tawny wood but the tree of the land of negro be extreme black within and that black pith or hart of this tree whereof musical instrument be make be call by the italian sangu that wood which be of the brown or tawny colour be use by the african physician for the cure of the french pox whereupon it be common call by the name of pock-wood of the root call Tauzarghente this root grow in the western part of Africa upon the ocean sea shore yield a fragrant and odoriferous smell and the merchant of Mauritania carry the same into the land of negro where the people use it for a most excellent perfume and yet they neither burn it nor put any-fire at all thereto for be keep only in a house it yield a natural send of itself in Mauritania they sell a bunch of these root for half a ducat which be carry to the land of Negro be sell again for eighty or one hundred ducat and sometime for more of the root call Addad the herb thereof be bitter and the root itself be so venomous that one drop of the water distil thereout will kill a man within the space of a hour which be common know even to the woman of Africa of the root call Surnag this root grow also upon the western part of mount Atlas be say to be very comfortable and preservative unto the privy part of man and be drink in a electuary to stir up venereal lust etc. neither must I here omit that which the inhabitant of mount Atlas do common report that many of those damosel which keep cattle upon the say mountain have lose their virginity by none other occasion but by make water upon the say root unto who I will in merriment answer that I belceve all which experience have teach concern the secret virtue of the same root yea they affirm moreover that some of their maiden be so infect with this root that they be not only deflower of their virginity but have also their whole body puff up and swell these be the thing memorable and worthy of knowledge see and observe by i John Leo throughout all Africa which country I have in * * * * * * * * * * * * * * that be in Barbary Numidia Libya the land of negro and Egypt all place travel quite over wherein whatsoever I see worthy the observation I present commit to writing and those thing which I see not I procure to be at large declare unto i by most credible and substantial person which be themselves eie-witness of the same and so have get a fit opportunity I think good to reduce these my travel and study into this one volume write at Rome in the year of Christ 1526. and upon the ten of March. here end the description of Africa write by John Leo bear in Granada and bring up in Barbary a brief relation concern the dominion revenue force and manner of government of sundry the great prince either inhabit within the bound of Africa or at least possess some part thereof translate for the most part out of italian AFricke have ever be the least know and haunt part in the world chief by reason of the situation thereof under the torrid zone which the ancient think to be unhabitable who opinion although in very deed it be not true because we know that between the two tropic there be most fruitful country as namely Abassia and the kingdom of angola and congo with all India new Spain and Brasile yet neither be it altogether false for no part of the world have great desert nor vast wilderness than this of Africa these desert which extend themselves from the atlantic ocean even unto the border of Egypt for more than a thousand mile and run out sometime two hundred and otherwhiles 300. mile in breadth divide Africa into two part whereof the southerly part be never thorough know to the people of Europe as also Atlas which divide Numidia from Africa the less be some impediment to the same and towards the east it seem that nature also mean to conceal the same by those desert that lie betwixt the red sea and the land of Egypt in the first time after the flood we find mention very often make of the kingdom of Egypt and ethopia and as for Ethiopia the notice we have thereof be but obscure and confuse but Egypt by reason of the commodious situation thereof between the Mediterran and the red sea have always be renown and famous yea king Sesostris that egyptian monarch enlarge his empire from the atlantic ocean even to the euxine sea afterward the king of Numidia and Mauritania and the carthaginian flourish in those province which be bound by the Meditterran sea in our time wherein all Africa have be and be daily environ there be sufficient knowledge have of the marine part thereof but for the inland province there be not so much know as may be rather through want of writer then for default of discovery and trade now therefore leave those part of Africa which be possess by the Turk and the king of Spain to a brief narration in the last place we have reduce all the residue of our relation to three prince that be to Prete janni the Monomotapa and the Xeriffo who be king of Maroco and Fez for the rest refer you to John Leo and the discourse prefix before he the Xeriffo reign between Atlas and the atlantic ocean Prete janni about the centre of Africa and the Monomotapa have his empire towards the sinus Barbaricus or the barbarian gulf the empire of Prete janni the empire of Prete janni answer not certain in effect although it be very large unto the fame and opinion which the common sort and most writer have of it for lately of any other Hor Malugucci in a certain discourse of he touch the greatness of state at this day will needs have his dominion to be great than any other prince but the king of Spain I confess indeed that in time past his state have most ample and large confine as may be judge by the multitude of kingdom with which he adorn and set forth his style for he entitle himself king of Goiame a kingdom seat beyond Nilus and of Vangue and damut situate beyond Zaire and yet it be at this day evident know that his empire scarce reach unto Nilus yea and John Barros write that the abassin have little notice of that river by reason of the mountain lie between they and it the hart or centre of his state be the lake Barcena for on the east it extend from Suaquen as far as the entrance of the red sea for the space of a hundred and two and twenty league howbeit betwixt the red sea and it there thwart a long rank of mountain inhabit by the moor who also command the sea-coast on the west it have another ridge of mountain along the channel of Nilus inhabit by the gentile who pay tribute unto the Prete on the north it consine with a imaginary line draw from Suaquen to the further part of the isle of Meroe which be a hundred and five and twenty league long from hence it make as it be a bow but not very crooked towards the south even to the kingdom of adel from the mountain whereof spring that river which Ptolemey call and place to the south of Melinde for the space of two hundred and thirty league all which distance be border upon by the gentile from whence it turn and end eastward at the kingdom of adel who head city be Arar in the northerly latitude of nine degree so that this whole empire little more or less amount to six hundred threescore and twelve league in circuit the country which be distinguish with ample plain pleasant hill and high mountain most of they manurable and well inhabit bring forth barley and mill for it abound not great with other sort of grain and likewise Taffo da guza another good and durable seed but there be mill and Zaburro which we call the grain of India or guinea wheat great plenty with all sort of our pulse and some also unknown to we some of they wear clothes of cotton but the great part be clad in sheep skin and those which be more honourable in the skin of lion tiger and ounce they have all kind of our domestical creature as hen goose and such like as also abundance of kine and wild swine heart goat hare but no coney beside panther lion ounce and elephant to conclude there can be a country more apt than this for the generation and increase of all plant and creature true it be that it have little help or furtherance by the industry of the inhabitant because they be of a slothful dull nature and capacity they have flax and yet can make no cloth sugar cane and know not the art of get the sugar thereout iron and have no use thereof but take all smith to be negromancer they have river and water and know not how to better their possession by they they conceive not great of hunt or fish whereupon the field be full of bird and wild beast and the river and lake of fish another reason of their slackness and negligence be the evil entreaty of the commonalty by those of the mighty sort for the poor see every thing take from they that they have sow no more then very necessity urge they unto their speech also be without any rule or prescription and to write a letter require a great assembly of man and many day to deliberate thereon the noble citizen and peasant live distinct and apart and any of these may purchase nobility by some famous or worthy act the first bear inherit all thing there be not in all the country a castle or fortify place for they think as the spartan do that a country shall be maintain and defend by force of arm and not with rampire of earth or stone they dwell for the most part disperse in town and village their trade of merchandise be perform by exchange one thing for a other supply the overplus of their prize with wheat or salt pepper incense myrrh and salt they sell for the weight in gold in their bargain they use gold also but by weight silver be not ordinary among they their great city be the prince court which be never firm and resident in one place but remove here and there and remain in the open field under tent this court comprehend ten or more mile in compass his government PRete janni his government be very absolute for he hold his subject in most base servitude and no less the noble and great than those of mean quality and condition entreat they rather like slave than subject and the better to do this he maintain himself among they in the reputation of a sacred and divine person all man bow at the name of the prince and touch the earth with their hand they reverence the tent wherein he lie and that when he be absent also the pretes in time past be wont to be see of the people but only once in three year space and afterwards they show themselves thrice in a year that be on Christmas and Easter day as also on holy rood day in September who now reign albeit he be grow more familiar than his predecessor yet when any commission come from he the party to who it be direct hear the word thereof naked from the girdle upward neither put he on his apparel but when the king permit he the people think they bind it with a oath yet do they seldom speak truth but when they swear by the king life who give and take away what great signiory soever it please he neither may he from who it be take so much as show himself aggrieve therewith except the give of holy order and the administration of the sacrament he dispose as well of the religious as of the lie sort and of their good on the way he ride environ with high and long red curtain which compass he on every side he wear usual upon his head a crown half gold half silver and a cross of silver in his hand his face be cover with a piece of blue taffeta which he lift up or let down more or less according as he favour they that he treat withal and sometime he only show the end of his foot which he put forth from under the say curtain they that carry and return ambassage come not to his curtain but with long time diverse ceremony and sundry observation none have slave but himself to who every year his subject come to do homage this prince as the abassin report descend from a son of Solomon and the queen of Saba call Meilech they
